When I ask them about their career prospects, most answer that, in the medium term, they see themselves on the boards of global companies. Years ago, both my fellow students and I gave the same answer. The way I see it, my role is to give students a base-rate crash course: “With a degree from this school, your chance of landing a spot on the board of a Fortune 500 company is less than 0.1 percent. No matter how smart and ambitious you are, the most likely scenario is that you will end up in middle management.” With this, I earn shocked looks and tell myself that I have made a small contribution toward mitigating their future midlife crises.

有时，我荣幸地在精英商学院的学生面前演讲，这份荣誉或许有些可疑。当我问起他们的职业前景时，大多数人回答说，从中期来看，他们认为自己会进入跨国公司的董事会。几年前，我和我的同学都给出了同样的答案。在我看来，我的职责是给学生们上一堂基础速成课：“凭借这所学校的学位，你进入财富500强公司董事会的几率不到0.1%。无论你多么聪明、多么雄心勃勃，最有可能的情况是你最终会进入中层管理。” 听到这句话，我收获了他们震惊的表情，并告诉自己，我为缓解他们未来的中年危机做出了一点贡献。

29

Why the “Balancing Force of the Universe” Is Baloney

为什么“宇宙平衡力”是无稽之谈

Gambler’s Fallacy

赌徒谬误

I n the summer of 1913, something incredible happened in Monte Carlo. Crowds gathered around a roulette table and could not believe their eyes. The ball had landed on black twenty times in a row. Many players took advantage of the opportunity and immediately put their money on red. But the ball continued to come to rest on black. Even more people flocked to the table to bet on red. It had to change eventually! But it was black yet again—and again and again. It was not until the twenty-seventh spin that the ball eventually landed on red. By that time, the players had bet millions on the table. In a few spins of the wheel, they were bankrupt.

1913年夏天，蒙特卡洛发生了一件不可思议的事。人们聚集在轮盘赌桌旁，简直不敢相信自己的眼睛。球连续20次落在黑色上。许多玩家抓住机会，立即把钱押在红色上。但球仍然停留在黑色上。更多的人涌向赌桌，押注红色。最终，情况必须改变！但黑色再次出现——一次又一次。直到第27次旋转，球才最终落在红色上。那时，玩家们已经在赌桌上押注了数百万。转了几圈后，他们就破产了。

The average IQ of pupils in a big city is 100. To investigate this, you take a random sample of fifty students. The first child tested has an IQ of 150. What will the average IQ of your fifty students be? Most people guess 100. Somehow, they think that the super-smart student will be balanced out—perhaps by a dismal student with an IQ of 50 or by two below-average students with IQs of 75. But with such a small sample, that is very unlikely. We must expect that the remaining forty-nine students will represent the average of the population, so they will each have an average IQ of 100. Forty-nine times 100 plus one IQ of 150 gives us an average of 101 in the sample.

大城市学生的平均智商是 100。为了调查这一点，你随机抽取了 50 名学生作为样本。第一个接受测试的孩子的智商是 150。这 50 名学生的平均智商是多少？大多数人猜测是 100。不知何故，他们认为超级聪明的学生会被一个智商为 50 的平庸学生或两个智商为 75 的低于平均水平的学生所抵消。但由于样本量如此之小，这种情况不太可能发生。我们必须预期剩下的 49 名学生将代表人口的平均水平，因此他们每个人的平均智商都是 100。49 乘以 100 再加上一个智商为 150 的学生，得出样本平均值为 101。

The Monte Carlo example and the IQ experiment show that people believe in the “balancing force of the universe.” This is the gambler’s fallacy . However, with independent events, there is no harmonizing force at work: A ball cannot remember how many times it has landed on black. Despite this, one of my friends enters the weekly Mega Millions numbers into a spreadsheet, and then plays those that have appeared the least. All this work is for naught. He is another victim of the gambler’s fallacy .

蒙特卡罗的例子和智商实验表明，人们相信“宇宙的平衡力量”。这就是赌徒谬误。然而，对于独立事件，并不存在任何协调力量：球无法记住自己有多少次落在黑色上。尽管如此，我的一个朋友还是把每周的超级百万彩票号码输入电子表格，然后投注出现次数最少的号码。所有这些努力都白费了。他又是一个赌徒谬误的受害者。

The following joke illustrates this phenomenon: A mathematician is afraid of flying due to the small risk of a terrorist attack. So, on every flight he takes a bomb with him in his hand luggage. “The probability of having a bomb on the plane is very low,” he reasons, “and the probability of having two bombs on the same plane is virtually zero!”

下面这个笑话说明了这一现象：一位数学家害怕乘坐飞机，因为恐怖袭击的风险很小。所以，他每次飞行都会在手提行李中放一枚炸弹。“飞机上有一枚炸弹的概率非常低，”他解释道，“而同一架飞机上同时有两枚炸弹的概率几乎为零！”

A coin is flipped three times and lands on heads on each occasion. Suppose someone forces you to spend thousands of dollars of your own money betting on the next toss. Would you bet on heads or tails? If you think like most people, you will choose tails, although heads is just as likely. The gambler’s fallacy leads us to believe that something must change.

一枚硬币抛三次，每次都是正面。假设有人强迫你花费数千美元自掏腰包，赌下一轮结果。你会押正面还是反面？如果你像大多数人一样思考，你会选择反面，尽管正面的可能性也一样大。赌徒谬误让我们相信，有些事情必须改变。

A coin is tossed fifty times, and each time it lands on heads. Again, with someone forcing you to bet, do you pick heads or tails? Now that you’ve seen an example or two, you’re wise to the game: You know that it could go either way. But we’ve just come across another pitfall: the classic déformation professionnelle (professional oversight; see chapter 92 ) of mathematicians: Common sense would tell you that heads is the wiser choice, since the coin is obviously loaded.

一枚硬币抛了五十次，每次都是正面。同样，如果有人强迫你下注，你会选正面还是反面？既然你已经看过一两个例子，你对这个游戏应该很了解了：你知道结果可能有两种。但我们刚刚又遇到了另一个陷阱：数学家们的经典“职业疏忽”（déformation professionalnelle，参见第92章）：常识会告诉你，正面是更明智的选择，因为硬币显然是投了钱的。

In chapter 19 , we looked at regression to mean . An example: If you are experiencing record cold where you live, it is likely that the temperature will return to normal values over the next few days. If the weather functioned like a casino, there would be a 50 percent chance that the temperature would rise and a 50 percent chance that it would drop. But the weather is not like a casino. Complex feedback mechanisms in the atmosphere ensure that extremes balance themselves out. In other cases, however, extremes intensify. For example, the rich tend to get richer. A stock that shoots up creates its own demand to a certain extent, simply because it stands out so much—a sort of reverse compensation effect.

在第十九章中，我们探讨了均值回归。举个例子：如果你居住的地方正经历着创纪录的寒冷，那么未来几天气温很可能会恢复到正常值。如果天气像赌场一样运作，那么气温上升的可能性是50%，下降的可能性也是50%。但天气并非如此。大气中复杂的反馈机制确保极端事件能够相互抵消。然而，在其他情况下，极端事件会加剧。例如，富人往往会变得更富。一只股价飙升的股票在一定程度上创造了自身的需求，仅仅是因为它非常引人注目——这是一种反向补偿效应。

So, take a closer look at the independent and interdependent events around you. Purely independent events really only exist at the casino, in the lottery, and in theory. In real life, in the financial markets and in business, with the weather and your health, events are often interrelated. What has already happened has an influence on what will happen. As comforting an idea as it is, there is simply no balancing force out there for independent events. “What goes around, comes around” simply does not exist.

所以，仔细观察一下你周围那些独立和相互依存的事件。纯粹的独立事件实际上只存在于赌场、彩票和理论中。在现实生活中，在金融市场和商业领域，无论是天气还是健康状况，事件往往都是相互关联的。已经发生的事情会影响将要发生的事情。尽管这个想法令人欣慰，但独立事件之间根本就没有平衡的力量。“善有善报，恶有恶报”根本不存在。

30

Why the Wheel of Fortune Makes Our Heads Spin

为什么命运之轮让我们头晕目眩

The Anchor

锚

W hen was Abraham Lincoln born? If you don’t know the year off the top of your head, and your smartphone battery has just died, how do you answer this? Perhaps you know that he was president during the Civil War in the 1860s and that he was the first U.S. president to be assassinated. Looking at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, you don’t see a young, energetic man but something more akin to a worn-out sixty-year-old veteran. The memorial must depict him at the height of his political power, say, at the age of sixty. Let’s assume that he was assassinated in the mid-1860s, making 1805 our estimate for the year he was born. (The correct answer is 1809.) So how did we work it out? We found an anchor to help us—the year 1865—and worked from there to an educated guess.

亚伯拉罕·林肯出生于何时？如果你一时想不起来年份，而你的智能手机又刚好没电，你该如何回答这个问题呢？或许你知道他在19世纪60年代南北战争期间担任总统，并且是第一位遇刺身亡的美国总统。但站在华盛顿的林肯纪念堂，你看到的并非一位年轻气盛的男子，而更像是一位疲惫不堪的六十岁老兵。纪念堂的画像应该描绘的是他政治权力的巅峰时期，比如说六十岁。假设他在19世纪60年代中期遇刺身亡，那么我们估算他的出生年份应该是1805年。（正确答案是1809年。）那么我们是如何推算出来的呢？我们找到了一个基准——1865年——然后以此为基础进行推测。

Whenever we have to guess something—the length of the Mississippi River, population density in Russia, the number of nuclear power plants in France—we use anchors . We start with something we are sure of and venture into unfamiliar territory from there. How else could we do it? Just pick a number off the top of our heads? That would be irrational.

每当我们需要猜测一些事情时——比如密西西比河的长度、俄罗斯的人口密度、法国的核电站数量——我们都会使用锚点。我们从确定的事物开始，然后从那里开始探索未知的领域。否则我们还能怎么做呢？随便找个数字？那太不合理了。

Unfortunately, we also use anchors when we don’t need to. For example, one day in a lecture, a professor placed a bottle of wine on the table. He asked his students to write down the last two digits of their Social Security numbers and then decide if they would be willing to spend that amount on the wine. In the auction that followed, students with higher numbers bid nearly twice as much as students with lower numbers. The Social Security digits worked as an anchor —albeit in a hidden and misleading way.

不幸的是，我们也会在不必要的时候使用锚点。例如，有一天在一次讲座上，一位教授在桌上放了一瓶酒。他让学生们写下他们的社保号码的后两位数字，然后决定是否愿意花同样的金额买下这瓶酒。在随后的拍卖中，社保号码较高的学生出价几乎是社保号码较低的学生的两倍。社保号码起到了锚点的作用——尽管是以一种隐蔽且具有误导性的方式。

The psychologist Amos Tversky conducted an experiment involving a wheel of fortune. He had participants spin it, and afterward they were asked how many member states the United Nations has. Their guesses confirmed the anchor effect: The highest estimates came from people who had spun high numbers on the wheel.

心理学家阿莫斯·特沃斯基（Amos Tversky）进行了一项关于命运之轮的实验。他让参与者旋转命运之轮，然后询问他们联合国有多少个成员国。他们的猜测证实了锚定效应：最高的估值来自那些在轮盘上旋转数字较大的人。

Researchers Russo and Shoemaker asked students in what year Attila the Hun suffered his crushing defeat in Europe. Just like the example with Social Security numbers, the participants were anchored—this time with the last few digits of their telephone number. The result? People with higher numbers chose later years and vice versa. (If you were wondering, Attila’s demise came about in 453.)

研究人员鲁索（Russo）和舒梅克（Shoemaker）询问学生们匈奴王阿提拉（Attila the Hun）在哪一年在欧洲遭遇惨败。就像之前用社保号码的例子一样，参与者被锚定——这次是用他们电话号码的后几位数字。结果如何？数字较大的人选择了较晚的年份，反之亦然。（如果你想知道，阿提拉的灭亡发生在453年。）

Another experiment: Students and professional real estate agents were given a tour of a house and asked to estimate its value. Beforehand, they were informed about a (randomly generated) listed sales price. As might be expected, the anchor influenced the students: The higher this price, the higher they valued the property. And the professionals? Did they value the house objectively? No, they were similarly influenced by the random anchor amount. The more uncertain the value of something—such as real estate, company stock, or art—the more susceptible even experts are to anchors .

另一项实验：学生和专业房地产经纪人参观了一栋房子，并被要求估算其价值。事先，他们被告知一个（随机生成的）挂牌售价。不出所料，锚定效应影响了学生：价格越高，他们对房产的估价就越高。那么专业人士呢？他们客观地估价了吗？没有，他们同样受到了随机锚定金额的影响。某些东西的价值越不确定——例如房地产、公司股票或艺术品——即使是专家也更容易受到锚定效应的影响。

Anchors abound, and we all clutch at them. The “recommended retail price” printed on many products is nothing more than an anchor . Sales professionals know they must establish a price at an early stage—long before they have an offer. Also, it has been proven that if teachers know students’ past grades, it influences how they will mark new work. The most recent grades act as a starting point.

锚点无处不在，我们每个人都紧紧抓住它们不放。许多产品上印的“建议零售价”只不过是一个锚点。销售人员知道，他们必须尽早确定价格——远在收到报价之前。此外，经验表明，如果老师了解学生过去的成绩，这将影响他们如何批改新作业。最近的成绩可以作为参考。

In my early years, I had a quick stint at a consulting firm. My boss was a pro when it came to using anchors . In his first conversation with any client, he made sure to fix an opening price, which, by the way, almost criminally exceeded our internal costs: “I’ll tell you this now so you’re not surprised when you receive the quote, Mr. So-and-So: We’ve just completed a similar project for one of your competitors and it was in the range of five million dollars.” The anchor was dropped: The price negotiations started at exactly five million.

我早年曾在一家咨询公司短暂工作过。我的老板非常擅长使用锚定价格。他与任何客户的第一次谈话，都会确保确定一个开价，顺便说一句，这个价格几乎超出了我们的内部成本：“某某先生，我现在就告诉你，这样你收到报价时就不会感到惊讶了：我们刚刚为你们的一家竞争对手完成了一个类似的项目，价格在500万美元左右。” 锚定价格就此落下：价格谈判从500万美元开始。

31

How to Relieve People of Their Millions

如何帮助人们摆脱数百万美元的债务

Induction

就职

A farmer feeds a goose. At first, the shy animal is hesitant, wondering: “What’s going on here? Why is he feeding me?” This continues for a few more weeks until, eventually, the goose’s skepticism gives way. After a few months, the goose is sure: “The farmer has my best interests at heart.” Each additional day’s feeding confirms this. Fully convinced of the man’s benevolence, the goose is amazed when he takes it out of its enclosure on Christmas Day—and slaughters it. The Christmas goose fell victim to inductive thinking , the inclination to draw universal certainties from individual observations. Philosopher David Hume used this allegory back in the eighteenth century to warn of its pitfalls. However, it’s not just geese that are susceptible to it.

一位农夫正在喂鹅。起初，这只害羞的动物犹豫不决，疑惑不解：“这是怎么回事？他为什么要喂我？”这种情况持续了几个星期，最终，鹅的疑虑消失了。几个月后，它确信：“农夫是真心为我好。” 每天的喂食都印证了这一点。这只鹅完全相信农夫的仁慈，当农夫在圣诞节那天把它从笼子里放出来并宰杀它时，它大吃一惊。这只圣诞鹅成了归纳思维的受害者，这种思维倾向于从个体观察中得出普遍的确定性。哲学家大卫·休谟早在18世纪就用这个寓言来警告人们这种思维的陷阱。然而，并非只有鹅容易受其影响。

An investor buys shares in stock X. The share price rockets, and at first he is wary. “Probably a bubble,” he suspects. As the stock continues to rise, even after months, his apprehension turns into excitement: “This stock may never come down,” especially since every day this is the case. After half a year, he invests his life savings in it, turning a blind eye to the huge cluster risk this poses. Later, the man will pay for his foolish investment. He has fallen hook, line, and sinker for induction .

一位投资者买入了X股票。股价飙升，起初他心存疑虑。“可能是泡沫，”他怀疑道。但随着股价持续上涨，即使几个月过去了，他的担忧也变成了兴奋：“这只股票可能永远不会跌了”，尤其是在每天都如此的情况下。半年后，他把毕生积蓄都投入其中，对这带来的巨大集群风险视而不见。最终，他会为自己的愚蠢投资付出代价。他完全被诱导性投资所蒙蔽。

Inductive thinking doesn’t have to be a road to ruin, though. In fact, you can make a fortune with it by sending a few e-mails. Here’s how: Put together two stock market forecasts—one predicting that prices will rise next month and one warning of a drop. Send the first mail to fifty thousand people and the second mail to a different set of fifty thousand. Suppose that after one month, the indices have fallen. Now you can send another e-mail, but this time only to the fifty thousand people who received a correct prediction. These fifty thousand you divide into two groups: The first half learns that prices will increase next month, and the second half discovers they will fall. Continue doing this. After ten months, around a hundred people will remain, all of whom you have advised impeccably. From their perspective, you are a genius. You have proven that you are truly in possession of prophetic powers. Some of these people will trust you with their money. Take it and start a new life in Brazil.

不过，归纳思维并不一定会带来毁灭。事实上，你只需发送几封电子邮件就能发财。方法如下：将两份股市预测放在一起——一份预测下个月股价会上涨，另一份警告股价会下跌。将第一封邮件发送给五万人，第二封邮件再发送给另一组五万人。假设一个月后，股市指数下跌。现在你可以再发送一封邮件，但这次只发送给那些收到正确预测的五万人。你将这五万人分成两组：前一半人预测下个月股价会上涨，后一半人预测股价会下跌。继续这样做。十个月后，大约会有一百人留下来，你对他们的建议都无可挑剔。在他们看来，你是个天才。你已经证明了你确实拥有预言能力。其中一些人会把钱托付给你。拿着这笔钱，去巴西开始新的生活吧。

However, it’s not just naive strangers who get deceived in this way; we constantly trick ourselves, too. For example, people who are rarely ill consider themselves immortal. CEOs who announce increased profits in consecutive quarters deem themselves infallible—their employees and shareholders do, too. I once had a friend who was a base jumper. He jumped off cliffs, antennae, and buildings, pulling the rip cord only at the last minute. One day, I brought up how risky his chosen sport is. He replied quite matter-of-factly: “I’ve over a thousand jumps under my belt, and nothing has ever happened to me.” Two months later, he was dead. It happened when he jumped from a particularly dangerous cliff in South Africa. This single event was enough to eradicate a theory confirmed a thousand times over.

然而，受骗的不仅仅是天真的陌生人，我们也经常自欺欺人。比如，很少生病的人自认为长生不老。那些连续几个季度宣布利润增长的CEO自认为万无一失——他们的员工和股东也这么认为。我曾经有个朋友，他是个定点跳伞运动员。他从悬崖、天线和建筑物上跳下，只在最后一刻拉开拉绳。有一天，我提起他选择的运动有多危险。他非常平静地回答说：“我跳伞经验超过一千次，从未出过什么事。”两个月后，他死了。死因是他从南非一处特别危险的悬崖上跳下。仅凭这一事件，就足以推翻一个已经被证实了一千次的理论。

Inductive thinking can have devastating results. Yet we cannot do without it. We trust that, when we board a plane, aerodynamic laws will still be valid. We imagine that we will not be randomly beaten up on the street. We expect that our hearts will still be beating tomorrow. These are confidences without which we could not live, but we must remember that certainties are always provisional. As Benjamin Franklin said, “Nothing is certain but death and taxes.”

归纳思维可能会带来毁灭性的后果。然而，我们离不开它。我们相信，当我们登上飞机时，空气动力学定律仍然有效。我们想象自己不会在街上被随意殴打。我们期望明天我们的心脏仍然会跳动。没有这些信心，我们就无法生存，但我们必须记住，确定性总是暂时的。正如本杰明·富兰克林所说：“除了死亡和税收，没有什么是确定的。”

Induction seduces us and leads us to conclusions such as: “Mankind has always survived, so we will be able to tackle any future challenges, too.” Sounds good in theory, but what we fail to realize is that such a statement can only come from a species that has lasted until now. To assume that our existence to date is an indication of our future survival is a serious flaw in reasoning. Probably the most serious of all.

归纳推理会引诱我们得出这样的结论：“人类一直以来都生存了下来，所以我们也一定能够应对未来的任何挑战。” 理论上听起来不错，但我们没有意识到，只有延续至今的物种才能说出这样的话。认为我们迄今为止的存在预示着我们未来的生存，这本身就是一个严重的推理缺陷，或许是所有缺陷中最严重的。

32

Why Evil Is More Striking Than Good

为什么邪恶比善良更引人注目

Loss Aversion

损失厌恶

O n a scale of 1 to 10, how good do you feel today? Now consider what would bring you up to a perfect 10. That vacation in the Caribbean you’ve always dreamed of? A step up the career ladder, maybe? Next question: What would make you drop down by the same number of points? Paralysis, Alzheimer’s, cancer, depression, war, hunger, torture, financial ruin, damage to your reputation, losing your best friend, your children getting kidnapped, blindness, death? The long list of possibilities makes us realize just how many obstacles to happiness exist; in short, there are more bad things than good—and they are far more consequential.

如果以1到10分来打分，你今天感觉如何？现在想想什么能让你达到满分10分。是你一直梦想的加勒比海度假？还是事业上的更上一层楼？下一个问题：什么会让你的得分下降10分？瘫痪、阿尔茨海默病、癌症、抑郁症、战争、饥饿、酷刑、经济崩溃、名誉受损、失去挚友、孩子被绑架、失明、死亡？这长长的清单让我们意识到，通往幸福的障碍重重；简而言之，坏事比好事多，而且后果更为严重。

In our evolutionary past, this was even more the case. One stupid mistake and you were dead. Everything could lead to your rapid departure from the game of life—carelessness on the hunt, an inflamed tendon, exclusion from the group, and so on. People who were reckless or gung ho died before they could pass their genes on to the next generation. Those who remained, the cautious, survived. We are their descendants.

在我们进化的过去，情况更是如此。一个愚蠢的错误就足以让你丧命。任何事情都可能导致你迅速退出生命游戏——狩猎时的疏忽、肌腱发炎、被群体排斥等等。那些鲁莽或狂热的人在将基因传给下一代之前就死了。那些留下来的人，那些谨慎的人，活了下来。我们就是他们的后代。

So, no wonder we fear loss more than we value gain. Losing $100 costs you a greater amount of happiness than the delight you would feel if I gave you $100. In fact, it has been proven that, emotionally, a loss “weighs” about twice that of a similar gain. Social scientists call this loss aversion .

所以，难怪我们对失去的恐惧远大于对得到的珍惜。失去100美元，你失去的幸福感，远大于我给你100美元时你感受到的快乐。事实上，已经证明，在情感上，损失的“重量”大约是同等收益的两倍。社会科学家称之为损失厌恶。

For this reason, if you want to convince someone about something, don’t focus on the advantages; instead highlight how it helps them dodge the disadvantages. Here is an example from a campaign promoting breast self-examination (BSE): Two different leaflets were handed out to women. Pamphlet A urged: “Research shows that women who do BSE have an increased chance of finding a tumor in the early, more treatable state of the disease.” Pamphlet B said: Research shows that women who do not do BSE have a decreased chance of finding a tumor in the early, more treatable state of the disease.” The study revealed that pamphlet B (written in a “loss frame”) generated significantly more awareness and BSE behavior than pamphlet A (written in a “gain frame”).

因此，如果你想说服某人接受某件事，不要只关注其优点，而要强调它如何帮助他们避免缺点。以下是一个来自乳房自我检查 (BSE) 宣传活动的例子：向女性分发了两份不同的传单。传单 A 敦促道：“研究表明，进行 BSE 的女性在疾病早期、更易治疗的阶段发现肿瘤的几率更高。”传单 B 说：研究表明，不进行 BSE 的女性在疾病早期、更易治疗的阶段发现肿瘤的几率较低。”研究表明，传单 B（以“损失框架”编写）比传单 A（以“收益框架”编写）产生了更多的认知和 BSE 行为。

The fear of losing something motivates people more than the prospect of gaining something of equal value. Suppose your business is home insulation. The most effective way of encouraging customers to purchase your product is to tell them how much money they are losing without insulation—as opposed to how much money they would save with it, even though the amount is exactly the same.

相比获得同等价值物品的前景，失去的恐惧更能激励人们。假设你的企业是家庭隔热材料。鼓励顾客购买你的产品最有效的方法就是告诉他们，如果没有隔热材料，他们会损失多少钱，而不是有了隔热材料，他们会省多少钱，即使两者金额完全相同。

This type of aversion is also found on the stock market, where investors tend to simply ignore losses on paper. After all, an unrealized loss isn’t as painful as a realized one. So they sit on the stock, even if the chance of recovery is small and the probability of further decline is large. I once met a man, a multimillionaire, who was terribly upset because he had lost a $100 bill. What a waste of emotion! I pointed out that the value of his portfolio fluctuated by at least $100 every second.

这种厌恶情绪在股市中也存在，投资者往往对账面损失视而不见。毕竟，未实现的损失不如已实现的损失那么痛苦。所以，即使反弹的可能性很小，进一步下跌的可能性很大，他们也会继续持有股票。我曾经遇到过一位千万富翁，他因为丢了一张100美元的钞票而非常沮丧。真是浪费感情！我指出，他的投资组合价值每秒至少波动100美元。

Management gurus push employees in large companies to be bolder and more entrepreneurial. The reality is: Employees tend to be risk averse. From their perspective, this aversion makes perfect sense: Why risk something that brings them, at best, a nice bonus, and at worst, a pink slip? The downside is larger than the upside. In almost all companies and situations, safeguarding your career trumps any potential reward. So, if you’ve been scratching your head about the lack of risk taking among your employees, you now know why. (However, if employees do take big risks, it is often when they can hide behind group decisions. Learn more in chapter 33 on social loafing. )

管理大师们鼓励大公司的员工更加大胆创新。但现实情况是：员工往往厌恶风险。从他们的角度来看，这种厌恶完全合情合理：既然能给他们带来丰厚奖金，甚至可能被解雇，何必冒险呢？这样做弊大于利。在几乎所有公司和情况下，维护自己的职业生涯都比任何潜在的回报更重要。所以，如果你一直在为员工缺乏风险承担能力而苦恼，现在你明白为什么了。（然而，如果员工确实愿意承担巨大风险，通常是因为他们可以躲在集体决策的背后。更多信息，请参阅第33章关于社会惰化的内容。）

We can’t fight it: Evil is more powerful and more plentiful than good. We are more sensitive to negative than to positive things. On the street, scary faces stand out more than smiling ones. We remember bad behavior longer than good—except, of course, when it comes to ourselves.

我们无力抗拒：邪恶的力量远大于善良，数量也远多于善良。我们对负面事物比正面事物更敏感。在街上，可怕的面孔比微笑的面孔更引人注目。我们对不良行为的记忆比良好行为更持久——当然，除非事关我们自身。

33

Why Teams Are Lazy

为什么团队很懒惰

Social Loafing

社会惰化

M aximilian Ringelmann, a French engineer, studied the performance of horses in 1913. He concluded that the power of two animals pulling a coach did not equal twice the power of a single horse. Surprised by this result, he extended his research to humans. He had several men pull a rope and measured the force applied by each individual. On average, if two people were pulling together, each invested just 93 percent of his individual strength, when three pulled together, it was 85 percent, and with eight people, just 49 percent.

1913年，法国工程师马克西米利安·林格尔曼（Maximilian Ringelmann）研究了马匹的性能。他得出结论，两匹马拉车的力量远不及一匹马的两倍。这一结果令他感到惊讶，于是他将研究扩展到人类身上。他让几个人拉一根绳子，并测量每个人施加的力。平均而言，如果两个人一起拉，每个人只用出其自身力量的93%；如果三个人一起拉，则为85%；如果是八个人一起拉，则仅为49%。

Science calls this the social loafing effect. It occurs when individual performance is not directly visible; it blends into the group effort. It occurs among rowers, but not in relay races, because here, individual contributions are evident. Social loafing is rational behavior: Why invest all of your energy when half will do—especially when this little shortcut goes unnoticed? Quite simply, social loafing is a form of cheating of which we are all guilty even if it takes place unconsciously, just as it does with the horses.

科学称之为社会惰化效应。当个人表现无法直接看到时，就会发生这种情况；它会融入到团队的努力中。这种情况发生在赛艇运动员身上，但在接力赛中不会发生，因为在接力赛中，个人的贡献显而易见。社会惰化是一种理性行为：既然一半的精力就能做到，为什么要投入全部精力呢——尤其是在这条小小的捷径被忽视的时候？简而言之，社会惰化是一种作弊行为，即使它是无意识的，我们所有人都会犯这种错误，就像马匹一样。

When people work together, individual performances decrease. This isn’t surprising. What is noteworthy, however, is that our input doesn’t grind to a complete halt. So what stops us from putting our feet up and letting the others do the hard work? The consequences. Zero performance would be noticed, and it brings with it weighty punishments, such as exclusion from the group or vilification. Evolution has led us to develop many fine-tuned senses, including how much idleness we can get away with and how to recognize it in others.

当人们一起工作时，个人绩效会下降。这并不奇怪。然而，值得注意的是，我们的投入并没有完全停止。那么，是什么阻止我们放松，让其他人来做艰苦的工作呢？后果就是：零绩效会受到关注，并带来严厉的惩罚，例如被排除在群体之外或受到诽谤。进化使我们发展出了许多精细的感知能力，包括我们可以逃避多少懒惰，以及如何识别他人的懒惰。

Social loafing does not occur solely in physical performance. We slack off mentally, too. For example, in meetings, the larger the team, the weaker our individual participation. However, once a certain number of participants are involved, our performance plateaus. Whether the group consists of twenty or one hundred people is not important—maximum inertia has been achieved.

社会惰化不仅仅发生在身体表现上。我们也会懈怠于精神状态。例如，在会议中，团队规模越大，我们的个人参与度就越低。然而，一旦参与者人数达到一定水平，我们的表现就会停滞不前。团队规模无论二十人还是一百人都无关紧要——惯性已经达到了极限。

One question remains: Who came up with the much-vaunted idea that teams achieve more than individual workers? Maybe the Japanese. Thirty years ago, they flooded global markets with their products. Business economists looked more closely at the industrial miracle and saw that Japanese factories were organized into teams. This model was copied—with mixed success. What worked very well in Japan could not be replicated with the Americans and Europeans—perhaps because social loafing rarely happens there. In the West, teams function better if and only if they are small and consist of diverse, specialized people. This makes sense, because within such groups, individual performances can be traced back to each specialist.

一个问题依然存在：是谁提出了“团队比个人成就更大”这一备受推崇的理念？也许是日本人。30年前，他们的产品席卷了全球市场。商业经济学家更深入地研究了这一工业奇迹，发现日本工厂的组织形式是团队。这种模式被效仿，但成败参半。在日本行之有效的方法无法在美国和欧洲复制——或许是因为那里很少发生社会惰化。在西方，团队只有规模较小、由多元化、专业化的人员组成才能更好地发挥作用。这很有道理，因为在这样的团队中，个人绩效可以追溯到每位专家。

Social loafing has interesting implications. In groups, we tend to hold back not only in terms of participation but also in terms of accountability. Nobody wants to take the rap for the misdeeds or poor decisions of the whole group. A glaring example is the prosecution of the Nazis at the Nuremberg trials or, less controversially, any board or management team. We hide behind team decisions. The technical term for this is “diffusion of responsibility.” For the same reason, teams tend to take bigger risks than their members would take on their own. The individual group members reason that they are not the only ones who will be blamed if things go wrong. This effect is called “risky shift” and is especially hazardous among company and pension-fund strategists, where billions are at stake, or in the Defense Department, where groups decide on the use of nuclear weapons.

社会惰化有着有趣的含义。在群体中，我们不仅倾向于参与，也倾向于承担责任。没有人愿意为整个群体的过失或糟糕决策承担责任。一个明显的例子是纽伦堡审判中对纳粹的起诉，或者一个争议较少的例子是任何董事会或管理团队。我们躲在团队决策的背后。这种现象的专业术语是“责任分散”。出于同样的原因，团队往往会比其成员独自承担更大的风险。个体成员认为，如果事情出错，他们不是唯一要受到指责的人。这种效应被称为“风险转移”，在涉及数十亿美元利益的公司和养老基金战略师，或在由群体决定使用核武器的国防部，这种风险尤其严重。

In conclusion: People behave differently in groups than when alone (otherwise there would be no groups). The disadvantages of groups can be mitigated by making individual performances as visible as possible. Long live meritocracy! Long live the performance society!

总结：人们在群体中的行为与独处时不同（否则就不会有群体了）。群体的劣势可以通过尽可能地展现个人表现来弥补。精英管理万岁！绩效社会万岁！

34

Stumped by a Sheet of Paper

被一张纸难住了

Exponential Growth

指数增长

A piece of paper is folded in two, then in half again, and again and again. How thick will it be after fifty folds? Write down your guess before you continue reading.

一张纸对折，再对折，如此反复。对折五十次后，它的厚度是多少？继续阅读之前，写下你的猜测。

Second task. Choose between these options: (a) Over the next thirty days, I will give you $1,000 a day. (b) Over the next thirty days, I will give you a cent on the first day, two cents on the second day, four cents on the third day, eight cents on the fourth day, and so on. Don’t think too long about it: A or B?

第二个任务。请从以下选项中选择：(a) 在接下来的30天里，我每天给你1000美元。(b) 在接下来的30天里，我第一天给你1美分，第二天给你2美分，第三天给你4美分，第四天给你8美分，以此类推。别想太多：A还是B？

Are you ready? Well, if we assume that a sheet of copy paper is approximately 0.004 inches thick, then its thickness after fifty folds is a little over sixty million miles. This equals the distance between the earth and the sun, as you can check easily with a calculator. With the second question, it is worthwhile choosing option B, even though A sounds more tempting. Selecting A earns you $30,000 in thirty days; choosing B gives you more than $5 million.

你准备好了吗？假设一张复印纸的厚度约为0.004英寸（约1.9厘米），那么折叠50次后的厚度略大于6000万英里（约1.9亿公里）。这相当于地球和太阳之间的距离，用计算器就能轻松算出来。对于第二个问题，选择B是值得的，尽管A听起来更诱人。选择A可以在30天内让你赚到3万美元；选择B可以让你赚到超过500万美元。

Linear growth we understand intuitively. However, we have no sense of exponential (or percentage) growth. Why is this? Because we didn’t need it before. Our ancestors’ experiences were mostly of the linear variety. Whoever spent twice the time collecting berries earned double the amount. Whoever hunted two mammoths instead of one could eat for twice as long. In the Stone Age, people rarely came across exponential growth. Today, things are different.

我们直观地理解线性增长。然而，我们却没有指数（或百分比）增长的概念。为什么呢？因为我们以前不需要它。我们祖先的经历大多是线性增长。谁花两倍时间采集浆果，谁就能赚到双倍的钱。谁猎杀了两头猛犸象而不是一头，就能吃上两倍的食物。在石器时代，人们很少遇到指数增长。如今，情况不同了。

“Each year, the number of traffic accidents rises by 7 percent,” warns a politician. Let’s be honest: We don’t intuitively understand what this means. So, let’s use a trick and calculate the “doubling time.” Start with the magic number of 70 and divide it by the growth rate in percent. In this instance: 70 divided by 7 = 10 years. So what the politician is saying is: “The number of traffic accidents doubles every ten years.” Pretty alarming. (You may ask: “Why the number 70?” This has to do with a mathematical concept called logarithm. You can look it up in the notes section.)

“每年，交通事故数量都会增加7%。”一位政客警告道。坦白说，我们无法直观地理解这意味着什么。所以，我们来用个小技巧，计算一下“翻倍时间”。先用神奇的数字70除以增长率的百分比。在这个例子中，70除以7=10年。所以这位政客的意思是：“交通事故数量每十年翻一番。”这相当惊人。（你可能会问：“为什么是70？”这与一个叫做对数的数学概念有关。你可以在注释部分查找。）

Another example: “Inflation is at 5 percent.” Whoever hears this thinks: “That’s not so bad, what’s 5 percent anyway?” Let’s quickly calculate the doubling time: 70 divided by 5 = 14 years. In fourteen years, a dollar will be worth only half what it is today—a catastrophe for anyone who has a savings account.

再举个例子：“通货膨胀率是5%。” 听到这句话的人都会想：“这还不算太糟，5%又算什么？” 让我们快速计算一下翻倍时间：70除以5=14年。14年后，一美元的价值将只有今天的一半——这对任何有储蓄账户的人来说都是一场灾难。

Suppose you are a journalist and learn that the number of registered dogs in your city is rising by 10 percent a year. Which headline do you put on your article? Certainly not: “Dog Registrations Increasing by 10 Percent.” No one will care. Instead, announce: “Deluge of Dogs: Twice as Many Mutts in Seven Years’ Time!”

假设你是一名记者，得知你所在城市登记的犬只数量每年增长10%。你会在文章中用什么标题？当然不是：“犬只登记数量增长10%”。没人会在意。相反，你应该这样报道：“犬只泛滥：七年内杂种狗数量翻倍！”

Nothing that grows exponentially grows forever. Most politicians, economists, and journalists forget that. Such growth will eventually reach a limit. Guaranteed. For example, the intestinal bacterium Escherichia coli divides every twenty minutes. In just a few days, it could cover the whole planet, but since it consumes more oxygen and sugar than is available, its growth has a cutoff point.

任何指数级增长的东西都不会永远增长。大多数政客、经济学家和记者都忘记了这一点。这种增长最终会达到一个极限。这是肯定的。例如，肠道细菌大肠杆菌每二十分钟分裂一次。只需几天时间，它就能覆盖整个地球，但由于它消耗的氧气和糖分超过了地球的可用量，它的生长有一个临界点。

The ancient Persians were well aware that people struggled with percentage growth. Here is a local tale: There was once a wise courtier who presented the king with a chessboard. Moved by the gift, the king said to him: “Tell me how I can thank you.” “Your highness, I want nothing more than for you to cover the chess board with rice, putting one grain of rice on the first square, and then on every subsequent square, twice the previous number of grains.” The king was astonished: “It is an honor to you, dear courtier, that you present such a modest request.” But how much rice is that? The king guessed about a sack. Only when his servants began the task—placing a grain on the first square, two grains of rice on the second square, four grains of rice on the third, and so on—did he realize that he would need more rice than was growing on earth.

古波斯人深知，人们在百分比增长面前举步维艰。这里有一个当地传说：从前，一位睿智的朝臣献给国王一副棋盘。国王深受感动，对朝臣说：“告诉我该如何感谢你。”“陛下，我只希望您能把棋盘铺满米粒，在第一个方格上放一粒米，之后的每个方格上都放两倍于先前数量的米粒。”国王大吃一惊：“陛下，您能提出如此谦卑的要求，实属荣幸。”可是，这需要多少米呢？国王猜测大约一袋米。直到他的仆人开始执行任务——在第一个方格上放一粒米，在第二个方格上放两粒米，在第三个方格上放四粒米，以此类推——他才意识到，他需要的米粒比地球上种植的还要多。

When it comes to growth rates, do not trust your intuition. You don’t have any. Accept it. What really helps is a calculator or, with low growth rates, the magic number of 70.

说到增长率，不要相信你的直觉。你没有直觉。接受它。真正有用的是计算器，或者在低增长率的情况下，神奇的数字70。

35

Curb Your Enthusiasm

抑制你的热情

Winner’s Curse

胜利者的诅咒

T exas in the 1950s. A piece of land is being auctioned. Ten oil companies are vying for it. Each has made an estimate of how much the site is worth. The lowest assessment is $10 million, and the highest is $100 million. The higher the price climbs during the auction, the more firms exit the bidding. Finally, one company submits the highest bid and wins. Champagne corks pop.

20世纪50年代的德克萨斯州。一块土地正在拍卖。十家石油公司竞相竞拍。每家公司都对该地块的估价进行了估算。最低估价为1000万美元，最高估价为1亿美元。拍卖过程中，价格越高，退出竞标的公司就越多。最终，一家公司出价最高，最终胜出。香槟开瓶。

The winner’s curse suggests that the winner of an auction often turns out to be the loser. Industry analysts have noted that companies that regularly emerged as winning bidders from these oil field auctions systematically paid too much and years later went under. This is understandable. If the estimates vary between $10 million and $100 million, the actual value most likely lies somewhere in the middle. The highest bid at an auction is often much too high—unless these bidders have critical information others are not privy to. This was not the case in Texas. The oil managers actually celebrated a Pyrrhic victory.

赢家的诅咒意味着拍卖的赢家往往最终沦为输家。行业分析师指出，那些经常在油田拍卖中胜出的公司，系统性地支付了过高的出价，多年后却破产了。这可以理解。如果估价在1000万美元到1亿美元之间，实际价值很可能介于两者之间。拍卖中的最高出价通常过高——除非这些竞标者掌握着其他人无法知晓的关键信息。德克萨斯州的情况并非如此。石油经理们实际上庆祝了一场得不偿失的胜利。

Today, this phenomenon affects us all. From eBay to Groupon to Google AdWords, prices are consistently set by auction. Bidding wars for cell-phone frequencies drive telecom companies to the brink of bankruptcy. Airports rent out their commercial spaces to the highest bidder. And if Walmart plans to introduce a new detergent and asks for tenders from five suppliers, that’s nothing more than an auction—with the risk of the winner’s curse .

如今，这种现象影响着我们所有人。从eBay到Groupon，再到谷歌AdWords，价格始终通过拍卖来制定。手机频率的竞价战将电信公司逼到了破产的边缘。机场将商业空间出租给出价最高的人。如果沃尔玛计划推出一款新的洗涤剂，并向五家供应商招标，那也不过是一场拍卖——而且面临着“赢家诅咒”的风险。

The auctioning of everyday life has now reached tradesmen, too, thanks to the Internet. When my walls needed a new lick of paint, instead of tracking down the handiest painter, I advertised the job online. Thirty painters from more than three hundred miles away competed for the job. The best offer was so low that, out of compassion, I could not accept it—to spare the poor painter the winner’s curse .

得益于互联网，日常生活的拍卖如今也延伸到了商人的手中。当我家的墙壁需要重新粉刷时，我没有去找最灵巧的油漆工，而是在网上发布招聘广告。来自三百多英里外的三十位油漆工竞相竞标。最好的报价太低了，出于同情，我无法接受——以免这位可怜的油漆工遭受“赢家诅咒”。

Initial public offerings (IPOs) are also examples of auctions. And when companies buy other companies—the infamous mergers and acquisitions—the winner’s curse is present more often than not. Astoundingly, more than half of all acquisitions destroy value, according to a McKinsey study.

首次公开募股 (IPO) 也属于拍卖。而当公司收购其他公司时——也就是臭名昭著的并购——赢家的诅咒往往也会出现。令人震惊的是，根据麦肯锡的一项研究，超过一半的收购都会损害公司的价值。

So why do we fall victim to the winner’s curse ? First, the real value of many things is uncertain. Additionally, the more interested parties, the greater the likelihood of an overly enthusiastic bid. Second, we want to outdo competitors. A friend owns a micro-antenna factory and told me about the cutthroat bidding war that Apple instigated during the development of the iPhone. Everyone wants to be the official supplier to Apple, even though whoever gets the contract is likely to lose money.

那么，我们为什么会沦为“赢家魔咒”的受害者呢？首先，很多东西的真正价值都难以确定。此外，感兴趣的企业越多，出现过度热情竞标的可能性就越大。其次，我们渴望超越竞争对手。一位拥有微天线工厂的朋友告诉我，苹果在iPhone研发过程中挑起的残酷竞价战。每个人都想成为苹果的官方供应商，即使最终拿到合同的一方很可能亏损。

So how much would you pay for $100? Imagine that you and an opponent are invited to take part in such an auction. The rules: Whoever makes the highest offer gets the $100 bill, and—most important—when this happens, both bidders have to pay their final offer. How high will you go? From your perspective, it makes sense to pay $20, $30, or $40. Your opponent does the same. Even $99 seems like a reasonable offer for a $100 bill. Now, your competitor offers $100. If this remains the highest bid, he will come away breaking even (paying $100 for $100), whereas you will simply have to cough up $99. So you continue to bid. At $110, you have a guaranteed loss of $10, but your opponent would have to shell out $109 (his last bid). So he will continue playing. When do you stop? When will your competitor give up? Try it out with friends.

那么，你愿意出多少钱买100美元呢？想象一下，你和你的对手被邀请参加这样的拍卖。规则是：出价最高的人赢得100美元的钞票，而且——最重要的是——当这种情况发生时，两位竞标者都必须支付他们的最终出价。你会出价多少？从你的角度来看，出价20美元、30美元或40美元是合理的。你的对手也会这么做。对于一张100美元的钞票来说，即使99美元似乎也是一个合理的出价。现在，你的竞争对手出价100美元。如果这个出价仍然是最高，他将不亏不赚（用100美元买100美元），而你只需支付99美元。所以你继续出价。在110美元时，你肯定会损失10美元，但你的对手必须支付109美元（他的最终出价）。所以他会继续玩。你什么时候停止？你的竞争对手什么时候会放弃？和朋友们一起试试吧。

In conclusion: Accept this piece of wisdom about auctions from Warren Buffett: “Don’t go.” If you happen to work in an industry where they are inevitable, set a maximum price and deduct 20 percent from this to offset the winner’s curse . Write this number on a piece of paper and don’t go a cent over it.

总结：记住沃伦·巴菲特关于拍卖的这句至理名言：“别去。” 如果你恰好身处一个拍卖不可避免的行业，那就设定一个最高价格，并从中扣除20%，以抵消“赢家诅咒”。把这个数字写在纸上，一分钱都别超过。

36

Never Ask a Writer If the Novel Is Autobiographical

永远不要问作家这本小说是否是自传

Fundamental Attribution Error

基本归因错误

O pening the newspaper, you learn that another CEO has been forced to step down because of bad results. In the sports section, you read that your team’s winning season was thanks to player X or coach Y. In history books, you learn that the success of the French army in the early 1800s is a testament to Napoleon’s superb leadership and strategy. “Every story has a face,” it seems. Indeed, this is an ironclad rule in every newsroom. Always on the lookout for the “people angle,” journalists (and their readers) take this principle one step further, and thus fall prey to the fundamental attribution error . This describes the tendency to overestimate individuals’ influence and underestimate external, situational factors.

打开报纸，你得知另一位CEO因业绩不佳而被迫下台。在体育版块，你读到自己球队本赛季的胜利归功于某位球员或某位教练。在历史书中，你了解到19世纪初法国军队的胜利证明了拿破仑卓越的领导力和战略眼光。“每个故事都有其独特的面孔”，这似乎是每个新闻编辑室的铁律。事实上，这已成为每个新闻编辑室的铁律。记者（及其读者）总是关注“人物视角”，他们更进一步地运用了这一原则，从而陷入了基本归因错误。这种错误指的是高估个人影响力、低估外部情境因素的倾向。

In 1967, researchers at Duke University set up the following experiment: Participants read an argument either lauding or loathing Fidel Castro. They were informed that the author of the text had been allocated the viewpoint regardless of his true political views; he was just making a coherent argument. Nevertheless, most of the audience believed what he said reflected his true opinion. They falsely attributed the content of the speech to his character and ignored the external factors—in this case, the professors who had crafted the text.

1967年，杜克大学的研究人员进行了如下实验：参与者阅读一篇赞扬或憎恶菲德尔·卡斯特罗的论证。他们被告知，文本作者被赋予了这一观点，无论其真实的政治观点如何；他只是在提出一个连贯的论点。然而，大多数听众仍然认为他所说的反映了他的真实观点。他们错误地将演讲内容归咎于他的性格，而忽略了外部因素——在本例中，是那些精心编撰文本的教授们。

The fundamental attribution error is particularly useful for whittling negative events into neat little packages. For example, the “blame” for wars we lazily push onto individuals: The Yugoslav assassin in Sarajevo has World War I on his conscience, and Hitler singlehandedly caused World War II. Many swallow these simplifications, even though wars are unforeseeable events whose innumerable dynamics we may never fully understand. Which sounds a little like financial markets and climate issues, don’t you agree?

基本归因错误尤其适用于将负面事件精简成小块。例如，我们懒惰地将战争的“责任”推到个人身上：萨拉热窝的南斯拉夫刺客良心上背负着第一次世界大战的罪责，希特勒一手引发了第二次世界大战。许多人接受了这些简化的说法，尽管战争是不可预见的事件，其无数的动态我们可能永远无法完全理解。这听起来有点像金融市场和气候问题，你不觉得吗？

We see this same pattern when companies announce good or bad results. All eyes shift to the CEO’s office, even if we know the truth: Economic success depends far more on the overall economic climate and the industry’s attractiveness than on brilliant leadership. It is interesting how frequently firms in ailing industries replace their CEOs—and how seldom that happens in booming sectors. Are ailing industries less careful in their recruitment processes? Such decisions are no more rational than what happens between football coaches and their clubs.

无论公司公布业绩好坏，我们都会看到同样的模式。所有人的目光都转向CEO的办公室，即使我们知道真相：经济成功更多地取决于整体经济环境和行业吸引力，而非卓越的领导力。耐人寻味的是，在境况不佳的行业中，公司更换CEO的频率之高——而在蓬勃发展的行业中，这种情况却很少发生。难道境况不佳的行业在招聘过程中就不那么谨慎了吗？这样的决定并不比足球教练和俱乐部之间发生的事情更理性。

I often go to musical concerts. In my hometown of Lucerne, in the center of Switzerland, I am spoiled with one-off classical recitals. During the intermission, however, I notice that the conversations almost always revolve around the conductors and/or soloists. With the exception of world premieres, composition is rarely discussed. Why not? The real miracle of music is, after all, the composition, the creation of sounds, moods, and rhythms where previously only a blank sheet lay. The difference among scores is a thousand times more impressive than the difference among performances of the same score. But we do not think like this. The score is—in contrast to the conductors and soloists—faceless.

我经常去听音乐会。在我的家乡瑞士中部卢塞恩，我经常被各种古典独奏会宠坏。然而，在中场休息时，我注意到大家的谈话几乎总是围绕着指挥家和/或独奏家。除了世界首演，作曲很少被讨论。这又有何不可？毕竟，音乐的真正奇迹在于作曲，在于声音、情绪和节奏的创造，而这些创造在以前只是一张白纸。不同乐谱之间的差异，比同一乐谱不同演奏之间的差异要深刻一千倍。但我们不这么认为。与指挥家和独奏家相比，乐谱是没有面孔的。

In my career as a fiction writer, I experience the fundamental attribution error in this way: After a reading (which in itself is a debatable undertaking), the first question always, really always, is: “What part of your novel is autobiographical?” I often feel like thundering: “It’s not about me, damn it! It’s about the book, the text, the language, the credibility of the story!” But unfortunately my upbringing allows such outbursts only rarely.

在我的小说写作生涯中，我经历过这样的基本归因错误：读完一本书（这本身就是一件值得商榷的事情）后，第一个问题永远是：“你的小说哪一部分是自传？”我常常想怒吼：“该死，这不是关于我！而是关于这本书、文本、语言以及故事的可信度！”但不幸的是，我的成长经历很少允许我爆发这样的情绪。

We shouldn’t judge those guilty of the fundamental attribution error too harshly. Our preoccupation with other people stems from our evolutionary past: Belonging to a group was necessary for survival. Reproduction, defense, and hunting large animals—all these were impossible tasks for individuals to achieve alone. Banishment meant certain death, and those who opted for the solitary life—of which there were surely a few—fared no better and disappeared from the gene pool. In short, our lives depended on and revolved around others, which explains why we are so obsessed with our fellow humans today. The result of this infatuation is that we spend about 90 percent of our time thinking about other people and dedicate just 10 percent to assessing other factors and contexts.

我们不应该过于严厉地评判那些犯了基本归因错误的人。我们对他人的关注源于我们进化的过去：归属于一个群体是生存的必要条件。繁衍、防御和猎捕大型动物——所有这些任务对于个体来说都是不可能完成的。被放逐意味着必死无疑，而那些选择独居生活的个体——其中肯定有少数——的命运也好不到哪里去，最终从基因库中消失了。简而言之，我们的生活依赖于他人，并围绕着他人运转，这也解释了为什么我们如今如此痴迷于我们的同胞。这种痴迷的结果是，我们大约90%的时间都在思考他人，而只有10%的时间用于评估其他因素和环境。

In conclusion: As much as we are fascinated with the spectacle of life, the people onstage are not perfect, self-governed individuals. Instead, they tumble from situation to situation. If you want to understand the current play—really understand it—then forget about the performers. Pay close attention to the dance of influences to which the actors are subjected.

总结：尽管我们着迷于人生的奇观，但舞台上的人物并非完美、自律的个体。相反，他们会在不同情境中跌宕起伏。如果你想理解当前的戏剧——真正理解它——那么就忘掉表演者。密切关注演员们所承受的影响之舞。

37

Why You Shouldn’t Believe in the Stork

为什么你不应该相信鹳

False Causality

虚假因果关系

F or the inhabitants of the Hebrides, a chain of islands north of Scotland, head lice were a part of life. If the lice left their host, he became sick and feverish. Therefore, to dispel the fever, sick people had lice put in their hair intentionally. There was a method to their madness: As soon as the lice had settled in again, the patient improved.

对于苏格兰北部赫布里底群岛的居民来说，头虱是生活的一部分。如果虱子离开宿主，宿主就会生病发烧。因此，为了退烧，病人会故意把虱子放在头发里。他们的这种疯狂做法是有方法的：一旦虱子再次扎进头发里，病人的病情就会好转。

In one city, a study revealed that in each blaze, the more firefighters called out to fight it, the greater the fire damage. The mayor imposed an immediate hiring freeze and cut the firefighting budget.

某市一项研究显示，每次火灾中，出动的消防员越多，火灾损失就越大。市长立即下令冻结消防员招聘，并削减消防预算。

Both stories come from German physics professors Hans-Peter Beck-Bornholdt and Hans-Hermann Dubben. In their book (unfortunately there is no English version), they illustrate the muddling of cause and effect. If the lice leave the invalid, it is because he has a fever and they simply get hot feet. When the fever breaks, they return. And the bigger the blaze, the more firefighters were called out—not, of course, vice versa.

这两个故事都出自德国物理学教授汉斯-彼得·贝克-博恩霍尔特（Hans-Peter Beck-Bornholdt）和汉斯-赫尔曼·杜本（Hans-Hermann Dubben）。在他们的书中（可惜没有英文版），他们阐释了因果关系的混乱。如果虱子离开病人，那是因为他发烧了，虱子只是让病人的脚发热而已。退烧后，虱子又回来了。火势越大，叫来的消防员就越多——当然，反之并非如此。

We may smirk at these stories, but false causality leads us astray practically every day. Consider the headline: “Employee Motivation Leads to Higher Corporate Profits.” Does it? Maybe people are simply more motivated because the company is doing well. Another headline touts that the more women on a corporate board, the more profitable the firm is. But is that really how it works? Or do highly profitable firms simply tend to recruit more women to their boards? Business book authors and consultants often operate with similar false—or at least fuzzy—causalities.

我们或许会对这些故事嗤之以鼻，但虚假的因果关系几乎每天都在误导我们。想想这个标题：“员工激励带来更高的公司利润”。真的如此吗？也许人们只是因为公司业绩良好才更有动力。另一个标题宣称，公司董事会中的女性越多，公司的盈利就越高。但事实真的如此吗？还是说，高盈利的公司只是倾向于招募更多女性加入董事会？商业书籍作者和顾问经常使用类似的虚假——或至少是模糊的——因果关系。

In the ’90s, there was no one holier than the then-head of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan. His obscure remarks gave monetary policy the aura of a secret science that kept the country on the secure path of prosperity. Politicians, journalists, and business leaders idolized Greenspan. Today we know that these commentators fell victim to false causality . America’s symbiosis with China, the globe’s low-cost producer and eager buyer of U.S. debt, played a much more important role. In other words, Greenspan was simply lucky that the economy did so well during his tenure.

90年代，没有人比时任美联储主席艾伦·格林斯潘更神圣。他那些晦涩难懂的言论赋予货币政策神秘的科学光环，使美国走上了繁荣的康庄大道。政客、记者和商界领袖都崇拜格林斯潘。如今我们知道，这些评论员沦为虚假因果关系的受害者。美国与中国——全球低成本生产国和美国国债的积极买家——的共生关系发挥了更为重要的作用。换句话说，格林斯潘只是幸运地看到美国经济在他任期内表现如此出色。

A further example: Scientists found that long periods in the hospital affected patients adversely. This was music to health insurers’ ears, who, of course, are keen to make stays as brief as possible. But, clearly, patients who are discharged immediately are healthier than those who must stay on for treatment. This hardly makes long stays detrimental.

再举一个例子：科学家发现，长期住院会对患者产生不利影响。这对医疗保险公司来说无疑是好消息，他们当然希望尽可能缩短住院时间。但显然，立即出院的患者比必须住院治疗的患者更健康。这并不能说明长期住院有害。

Or, take this headline: “Fact: Women Who Use Shampoo XYZ Every Day Have Stronger Hair.” Though the context can be substantiated scientifically, this statement says very little—least of all, that the shampoo makes your hair stronger. It might simply be the other way round: Women with strong hair tend to use shampoo XYZ—and perhaps that’s because it says “especially for thick hair” on the bottle.

或者，看看这个标题：“事实：每天使用XYZ洗发水的女性头发更坚韧。” 虽然上下文有科学依据，但这句话几乎没有说明什么——至少没有说明洗发水能让你的头发更坚韧。事实可能恰恰相反：头发坚韧的女性往往会使用XYZ洗发水——或许是因为瓶子上写着“尤其适合浓密的头发”。

Recently I read that students get better grades at school if their homes contain a lot of books. This study was surely a shot in the arm for booksellers, but it is another fine example of false causality . The simple truth is that educated parents tend to value their children’s education more than uneducated ones do. Plus, educated parents often have more books at home. In short, a dust-covered copy of War and Peace alone isn’t going to influence anyone’s grades; what counts is parents’ education levels, as well as their genes.

最近我读到一篇文章，说如果家里有很多书，学生在学校的成绩会更好。这项研究无疑给书商们打了一针强心剂，但也再次证明了因果关系的谬误。一个简单的事实是，受过教育的父母往往比没有受过教育的父母更重视孩子的教育。而且，受过教育的父母家里通常藏书更多。简而言之，一本积满灰尘的《战争与和平》不会影响任何人的成绩；真正重要的是父母的教育水平，以及他们的基因。

The best example of false causality was the supposed relationship between the birth rate and the numbers of stork pairs in Germany. Both were in decline, and if you plot them on a graph, the two lines of development from 1965 to 1987 appeared almost identical. Does this mean the stork actually does bring babies? Obviously not, since this was a purely coincidental correlation.

虚假因果关系的最佳例子，就是德国出生率与鹳鸟数量之间所谓的关联。两者都在下降，如果把它们画成图表，你会发现1965年至1987年的两条发展曲线几乎完全相同。这是否意味着鹳鸟真的会带来婴儿？显然不是，因为这纯粹是巧合的关联。

In conclusion: Correlation is not causality. Take a closer look at linked events: Sometimes what is presented as the cause turns out to be the effect, and vice versa. And sometimes there is no link at all—just like with the storks and babies.

结论：相关性并非因果关系。仔细观察关联事件：有时，被呈现为原因的事物最终会变成结果，反之亦然。有时，两者之间根本没有任何联系——就像鹳鸟和婴儿的案例一样。

38

Why Attractive People Climb the Career Ladder More Quickly

为什么有魅力的人晋升更快

Halo Effect

光环效应

C isco, the Silicon Valley firm, was once a darling of the new economy. Business journalists gushed about its success in every discipline: its wonderful customer service, perfect strategy, skillful acquisitions, unique corporate culture, and charismatic CEO. In March 2000, it was the most valuable company in the world.

硅谷公司思科曾是新经济的宠儿。商业记者们对其在各个领域的成功赞不绝口：卓越的客户服务、完美的战略、娴熟的收购、独特的企业文化，以及魅力非凡的首席执行官。2000年3月，思科成为全球市值最高的公司。

When Cisco’s stock plummeted 80 percent the following year, the journalists changed their tune. Suddenly the company’s competitive advantages were reframed as destructive shortcomings: poor customer service, a woolly strategy, clumsy acquisitions, a lame corporate culture, and an insipid CEO. All this—and yet neither the strategy nor the CEO had changed. What had changed, in the wake of the dot-com crash, was demand for Cisco’s product—and that was through no fault of the firm.

次年思科股价暴跌80%，记者们改变了态度。突然间，该公司的竞争优势被重新定义为破坏性的缺陷：糟糕的客户服务、模糊的战略、笨拙的收购、糟糕的企业文化以及乏味的首席执行官。所有这些——然而，战略和首席执行官都没有改变。互联网泡沫破灭后，真正改变的是思科产品的需求——而这并非该公司的错。

The halo effect occurs when a single aspect dazzles us and affects how we see the full picture. In the case of Cisco, its halo shone particularly bright. Journalists were astounded by its stock prices and assumed the entire business was just as brilliant—without closer investigation.

光环效应是指某个方面让我们眼花缭乱，并影响我们对整体的看法。以思科为例，它的光环格外耀眼。记者们对其股价感到震惊，并认为整个公司也同样辉煌——而没有进行更深入的调查。

The halo effect always works the same way: We take a simple-to-obtain or remarkable fact or detail, such as a company’s financial situation, and extrapolate conclusions from there that are harder to nail down, such as the merit of its management or the feasibility of its strategy. We often ascribe success and superiority where little is due, such as when we favor products from a manufacturer simply because of its good reputation. Another example of the halo effect : We believe that CEOs who are successful in one industry will thrive in any sector—and furthermore that they are heroes in their private lives, too.

光环效应总是以同样的方式运作：我们会根据一些简单易得或引人注目的事实或细节，例如一家公司的财务状况，推断出一些难以确定的结论，例如其管理的优劣或战略的可行性。我们常常将一些看似不该发生的事情归因于成功和优越性，例如，我们仅仅因为某个制造商的良好声誉就青睐其产品。光环效应的另一个例子是：我们相信，在一个行业取得成功的CEO在任何行业都能蓬勃发展——而且，他们在私人生活中也是英雄。

The psychologist Edward Lee Thorndike discovered the halo effect nearly one hundred years ago. His conclusion was that a single quality (e.g., beauty, social status, age) produces a positive or negative impression that outshines everything else, and the overall effect is disproportionate. Beauty is the best-studied example. Dozens of studies have shown that we automatically regard good-looking people as more pleasant, honest, and intelligent. Attractive people also have it easier in their professional lives—and that has nothing to do with the myth of (women) “sleeping their way to the top.” The effect can even be detected in schools, where teachers unconsciously give good-looking students better grades.

心理学家爱德华·李·桑代克（Edward Lee Thorndike）在近一百年前发现了光环效应。他的结论是，单一特质（例如美貌、社会地位、年龄）会给人留下正面或负面的印象，使其黯然失色，最终导致整体效应不成比例。美貌是研究最深入的例子。数十项研究表明，我们会自动认为长得好看的人更友善、更诚实、更聪明。有魅力的人在职业生涯中也会更加顺利——这与女性“靠睡觉爬上顶峰”的迷思毫无关系。这种效应甚至在学校里也能感受到，老师们会不自觉地给长得好看的学生更高的分数。

Advertising has found an ally in the halo effect : Just look at the number of celebrities smiling at us from TV ads, billboards, and magazines. What makes a professional tennis player like Roger Federer a coffee machine expert is still open for debate, but this hasn’t detracted from the success of the campaign. We are so used to seeing celebrities promoting arbitrary products that we never stop to consider why their support should be of any importance to us. But this is exactly the sneaky part of the halo effect : It works on a subconscious level. All that needs to register is the attractive face, dream lifestyle—and that product.

广告业在光环效应中找到了盟友：看看电视广告、广告牌和杂志上那些朝我们微笑的名人就知道了。罗杰·费德勒这样的职业网球运动员究竟是如何成为咖啡机专家的，这仍有争议，但这丝毫没有影响广告宣传的成功。我们已经习惯了看到名人代言各种产品，以至于从未停下来思考为什么他们的支持对我们如此重要。但这恰恰是光环效应的隐秘之处：它作用于潜意识层面。人们只需要记住迷人的面容、理想的生活方式——以及产品本身。

Sticking with negative effects, the halo effect can lead to great injustice and even stereotyping when nationality, gender, or race becomes the all-encompassing feature. One need be neither racist nor sexist to fall victim to this. The halo effect clouds our view, just as it does journalists, educators, and consumers.

继续讨论负面影响，当国籍、性别或种族成为包罗万象的特征时，光环效应会导致极大的不公，甚至形成刻板印象。即使不是种族主义者或性别歧视者，也会成为这种效应的受害者。光环效应会蒙蔽我们的视野，就像它遮蔽记者、教育工作者和消费者一样。

Occasionally, this effect has pleasant consequences—at least in the short term. Have you ever been head over heels in love? If so, you know how flawless a person can appear. Your Mr. or Ms. Perfect seems to be the whole package: attractive, intelligent, likable, and warm. Even when your friends might point out obvious failings, you see nothing but endearing quirks.

这种效应偶尔会带来令人愉悦的后果——至少在短期内如此。你曾经坠入爱河吗？如果有的话，你就知道一个人可以有多么完美无瑕。你心中的完美先生或女士似乎拥有所有的一切：魅力四射、聪明睿智、讨人喜欢、热情友好。即使你的朋友可能会指出他们明显的缺点，你看到的也只是他们讨人喜欢的怪癖。

The halo effect obstructs our view of true characteristics. To counteract this, go beyond face value. Factor out the most striking features. World-class orchestras achieve this by making candidates play behind a screen, so that sex, race, age, and appearance play no part in their decision. To business journalists I warmly recommend judging a company by something other than its easily obtainable quarterly figures (the stock market already delivers that). Dig deeper. Invest the time to do serious research. What emerges is not always pretty, but almost always educational.

光环效应会遮蔽我们对真实特征的认知。为了抵消这种影响，我们必须超越表面价值，剔除那些最引人注目的特征。世界一流的管弦乐团正是通过让候选人在屏幕后演奏来实现这一点的，这样性别、种族、年龄和外貌就不会对他们的决定产生影响。对于商业记者，我强烈建议评判一家公司时，除了容易获得的季度数据（股市已经提供了这些数据）之外，还要考虑其他因素。深入挖掘，投入时间进行认真的研究。最终的结果并不总是令人满意，但几乎总是具有教育意义的。

39

Congratulations! You’ve Won Russian Roulette

恭喜！你赢了俄罗斯轮盘赌

Alternative Paths

替代路径

Y ou arrange to meet with a Russian oligarch in a forest just outside your city. He arrives shortly after you, carrying a suitcase and a gun. Placing the suitcase on the hood of his car, he opens it so you can see it is filled to the brim with stacks of money—$10 million in total. “Want to play Russian roulette?” he asks. “Pull the trigger once, and all this is yours.” The revolver contains a single bullet; the other five chambers are empty. You consider your options. Ten million dollars would change your life. You would never have to work again. You could finally move from collecting stamps to collecting sports cars!

你约好在城外森林里与一位俄罗斯寡头见面。他比你晚到不久，提着一个手提箱和一把枪。他把手提箱放在车盖上，打开后，你看到里面装满了成堆的钞票——总计1000万美元。“想玩俄罗斯轮盘赌吗？”他问。“扣动一次扳机，这一切都是你的。”左轮手枪里只有一颗子弹，其他五个弹膛是空的。你考虑着你的选择。1000万美元可以改变你的人生。你再也不用工作了。你终于可以从集邮转向收藏跑车了！

You accept the challenge. You put the revolver to your temple and squeeze the trigger. You hear a faint click and feel adrenaline flood your body. Nothing happens. The chamber was empty! You have survived. You take the money, move to the most beautiful city you know, and upset the locals by building a luxurious villa there.

你接受了挑战。你把左轮手枪抵着太阳穴，扣动了扳机。你听到一声微弱的咔哒声，感觉肾上腺素瞬间涌遍全身。什么也没发生。枪膛里空无一物！你活了下来。你拿着钱，搬到了你所知道的最美丽的城市，并在那里建造了一座豪华别墅，惹怒了当地人。

One of these neighbors, whose home now stands in the shadow of yours, is a prominent lawyer. He works twelve hours a day, three hundred days a year. His rates are impressive, but not unusual: $500 per hour. Each year he can put aside half a million dollars net after taxes and living expenses. From time to time, you wave to him from your driveway, laughing on the inside: He will have to work for twenty years to catch up with you.

有一位邻居，他的家现在就在你家的阴影下，他是一位杰出的律师。他每天工作十二小时，一年工作三百天。他的收费标准令人印象深刻，但并不罕见：每小时500美元。每年扣除税款和生活开支后，他能净赚五十万美元。你时不时地会在车道上向他挥手致意，心里暗自窃喜：他得工作二十年才能赶上你。

Suppose that, after twenty years, your hardworking neighbor has saved up $10 million. A journalist comes along one day and puts together a piece on the more affluent residents in the area—complete with photos of the magnificent buildings and the beautiful second wives that you and your neighbor have accrued. He comments on the interior design and the exquisite landscaping. However, the crucial difference between the two of you remains hidden from view: the risk that lurks behind each of the $10 million. For this he would need to recognize the alternative paths.

假设你辛勤工作的邻居，二十年后攒下了1000万美元。有一天，一位记者过来，整理了一篇关于当地富裕居民的文章，并附上了你和邻居的豪宅照片，以及他们娶的漂亮二房。他称赞了房子的室内设计和精致的景观。然而，你们两人之间至关重要的区别却隐藏在人们的视线之外：1000万美元背后潜藏着风险。为此，他需要识别其他途径。

But not only journalists are underachievers at this skill. We all are.

但并非只有记者在这项技能上表现不佳。我们所有人都是如此。

Alternative paths are all the outcomes that could have happened but did not. With the game of Russian roulette, four alternative paths would have led to the same result (winning the $10 million) and the fifth alternative to your death. A huge difference. In the case of the lawyer, the possible paths lie much more closely together. In a village, he would have earned perhaps just $200 per hour. In the heart of New York working for one of the major investment banks, maybe it would have been $600 per hour. But, unlike you, he risked no alternative path that would have cost him his fortune—or his life.

备选路径指的是所有可能发生但最终未发生的结果。在俄罗斯轮盘赌中，四条备选路径都可能导致同样的结果（赢得1000万美元），而第五条路径则会导致死亡。这其中的区别巨大。而对于那位律师来说，可能的路径分布则更加紧密。在村子里，他每小时可能只能挣200美元。而在纽约市中心一家大型投资银行工作，他的时薪或许能达到600美元。但与你不同的是，他没有选择任何可能让他失去财富——甚至生命的备选路径。

Alternative paths are invisible, so we contemplate them very rarely. Those who speculate on junk bonds, options, and credit default swaps, thus making millions, should never forget that they flirt with many alternative paths that lead straight to ruin. To a rational mind, $10 million that comes about through a huge risk is worth less than the same sum earned by years of drudgery. (An accountant might disagree, though.)

替代路径是看不见的，所以我们很少去思考它们。那些投机垃圾债券、期权和信用违约掉期并因此赚取数百万美元的人，永远不要忘记，他们正与许多最终导致毁灭的替代路径擦肩而过。对于理性的人来说，通过巨大风险获得的1000万美元，其价值远不及多年辛苦工作赚到的1000万美元。（不过，会计师可能会不同意。）

Recently, I was at a dinner with an American friend who suggested tossing a coin to decide who should pay the bill. He lost. The situation was uncomfortable for me, since he was my guest in Switzerland. “Next time I’ll pay, whether here or in New York,” I promised. He thought for a moment and said, “Considering the alternative paths , you’ve actually already paid for half of this dinner.”

最近，我和一位美国朋友共进晚餐，他提议掷硬币决定谁付账。结果他输了。这让我很不舒服，因为他是我在瑞士的客人。“下次我来付账，不管是在这里还是在纽约，”我保证道。他想了一会儿，说：“考虑到其他可能的情况，你其实已经付了这顿饭一半的钱了。”

In conclusion: Risk is not directly visible. Therefore, always consider what the alternatives paths are. Success that comes about through risky dealings is, to a rational mind, of less worth than success achieved the “boring” way (for example, with laborious work as a lawyer, a dentist, a ski instructor, a pilot, a hairdresser, or a consultant). Yes, looking at alternative paths from the outside is a difficult task, looking at them from the inside an almost impossible task. Your brain will do everything to convince you that your success is warranted—no matter how risky your dealings are—and will obscure any thought of paths other than the one you are on.

结论：风险并非直接可见。因此，务必思考其他路径。理性的头脑认为，通过冒险获得的成功，其价值远低于通过“枯燥乏味”的方式获得的成功（例如，通过辛勤工作，成为律师、牙医、滑雪教练、飞行员、理发师或咨询师）。没错，从外部审视其他路径并非易事，而从内部审视则几乎不可能。你的大脑会竭尽全力让你相信，无论你的交易多么冒险，你的成功都是值得的，并且会屏蔽掉任何你正在走的路径之外的路径的想法。

40

False Prophets

假先知

Forecast Illusion

预测错觉

F acebook to be number one entertainment platform in three years.”

Facebook 将在三年内成为第一大娱乐平台。”

“Regime shift in North Korea in two years.”

“朝鲜两年内将发生政权更迭。”

“Sour grapes for France as Argentinian wines expected to dominate.”

“法国的葡萄品种不好，因为阿根廷葡萄酒有望占据主导地位。”

“Euro collapse likely.”

“欧元可能崩溃。”

“Low-cost space flights by 2025.”

“到2025年实现低成本太空飞行。”

“No more crude oil in fifteen years.”

“十五年后不再有原油。”

Every day, experts bombard us with predictions, but how reliable are they? Until a few years ago, no one bothered to check. Then along came Philip Tetlock. Over a period of ten years, he evaluated 28,361 predictions from 284 self-appointed professionals. The result: In terms of accuracy, the experts fared only marginally better than a random forecast generator. Ironically, the media darlings were among the poorest performers; and of those, the worst were the prophets of doom and disintegration. Examples of their far-fetched forecasts included the collapse of Canada, Nigeria, China, India, Indonesia, South Africa, Belgium, and the EU. None of these countries has imploded.

专家们每天都会用各种预测轰炸我们，但这些预测究竟有多可靠？直到几年前，人们才开始去核实。后来，菲利普·泰特洛克出现了。他用十年时间评估了284位自封的专家的28361个预测。结果显示，专家们的预测准确率仅略高于随机生成的预测。讽刺的是，媒体宠儿的预测结果却最差；而其中，最差的预测者则是那些预言世界末日和解体的预言家。他们做出的不靠谱的预测包括加拿大、尼日利亚、中国、印度、印度尼西亚、南非、比利时和欧盟的解体。然而，这些国家最终都没有崩溃。

“There are two kinds of forecasters: those who don’t know, and those who don’t know they don’t know,” wrote Harvard economist John Kenneth Galbraith. With this he made himself a figure of hatred in his own guild. Fund manager Peter Lynch summed it up even more cuttingly: “There are 60,000 economists in the U.S., many of them employed full-time trying to forecast recessions and interest rates, and if they could do it successfully twice in a row, they’d all be millionaires by now. . . . As far as I know, most of them are still gainfully employed, which ought to tell us something.” That was ten years ago. Today, the United States could employ three times as many economists—with little or no effect on the quality of their forecasts.

“预测者有两种：一种是不知道的，一种是不知道自己不知道的，”哈佛大学经济学家约翰·肯尼斯·加尔布雷斯写道。他因此在同行中成了众矢之的。基金经理彼得·林奇对此的总结更为尖锐：“美国有6万名经济学家，其中许多人全职工作，试图预测经济衰退和利率，如果他们能连续两次成功，现在他们早就都是百万富翁了……据我所知，他们中的大多数人仍然有收入，这应该能说明一些问题。”这还是十年前的事了。如今，美国可以雇佣三倍于此的经济学家——而他们的预测质量却几乎没有任何影响。

The problem is that experts enjoy free rein with few negative consequences. If they strike it lucky, they enjoy publicity, consultancy offers, and publication deals. If they are completely off the mark, they face no penalties—neither in terms of financial compensation nor in loss of reputation. This win-win scenario virtually incentivizes them to churn out as many prophecies as they can muster. Indeed, the more forecasts they generate, the more will be coincidentally correct. Ideally, they should have to pay into some sort of “forecast fund”—say, $1,000 per prediction. If the forecast is correct, the expert gets his money back with interest. If he is wrong, the money goes to charity.

问题在于，专家们享有自由发挥的权利，几乎不会产生任何负面影响。如果他们预测得当，就能获得宣传、咨询服务以及出版合同。如果他们完全偏离目标，也不会受到任何处罚——既不会获得经济赔偿，也不会遭受名誉损失。这种双赢的局面实际上激励着他们尽可能多地做出预测。事实上，他们做出的预测越多，巧合正确的预测就越多。理想情况下，他们应该设立某种“预测基金”，比如每个预测1000美元。如果预测正确，专家可以连本带利地收回本金。如果预测错误，这笔钱就捐给慈善机构。

So what is predictable and what is not? Some things are fairly simple. For example, I have a rough idea of how many pounds I will weigh in a year’s time. However, the more complex a system, and the longer the time frame, the more blurred the view of the future will be. Global warming, oil prices, or exchange rates are almost impossible to foresee. Inventions are not at all predictable because if we knew what technology we would invent in the future, we would already have invented it.

那么，什么是可预测的，什么是不可预测的呢？有些事情相当简单。例如，我大概知道一年后我的体重会是多少磅。然而，系统越复杂，时间跨度越长，对未来的预测就越模糊。全球变暖、油价或汇率几乎无法预测。发明完全无法预测，因为如果我们知道未来会发明什么技术，我们早就发明出来了。

So, be critical when you encounter predictions. Whenever I hear one, I make sure to smile, no matter how bleak it is. Then I ask myself two questions. First, what incentive does the expert have? If he is an employee, could he lose his job if he is always wrong? Or is he a self-appointed guru who earns a living through books and lectures? The latter type of forecaster relies on the media’s attention so, predictably, his prophecies tend to be sensational. Second, how good is his success rate? How many predictions has he made over the past five years? Out of these, how many have been right and how many have not? This information is vital, yet often goes unreported. I implore the media: Please don’t publish any more forecasts without giving the pundit’s track record.

所以，遇到预测时，务必保持批判性思维。每当我听到预测，无论多么悲观，我都会报以微笑。然后我会问自己两个问题。首先，专家的动机是什么？如果他是一名员工，总是预测错误，他会丢掉工作吗？还是他自封为大师，靠出书和讲课谋生？后一种预测者依赖媒体的关注，因此不出所料，他的预言往往耸人听闻。其次，他的成功率有多高？过去五年他做了多少次预测？其中，有多少次正确，有多少次失败？这些信息至关重要，但却常常被忽略。我恳请媒体：请不要再发布任何未提供专家过往记录的预测。

Finally, since it is so fitting, a quote from former British prime minister Tony Blair: “I don’t make predictions. I never have, and I never will.”

最后，既然如此贴切，不妨引用英国前首相托尼·布莱尔的一句话：“我不做预测。我从来没有，也永远不会。”

41

The Deception of Specific Cases

具体案例的欺骗

Conjunction Fallacy

合取谬误

C hris is thirty-five. He studied social philosophy and has had an interest in developing countries since he was a teenager. After graduation, he worked for two years with the Red Cross in West Africa and then for three years in its Geneva headquarters, where he rose to head of the African aid department. He then completed an MBA, writing his thesis on corporate social responsibility. What is more likely? (a) Chris works for a major bank or (b) Chris works for a major bank, where he runs its Third World foundation. A or B?

克里斯今年35岁。他学习的是社会哲学，自青少年时期就对发展中国家产生了浓厚的兴趣。毕业后，他在西非红十字会工作了两年，之后又在日内瓦总部工作了三年，最终晋升为非洲援助部门负责人。之后，他获得了MBA学位，并撰写了关于企业社会责任的论文。哪种可能性更大？(a) 克里斯在一家大型银行工作；或 (b) 克里斯在一家大型银行工作，并管理着该银行的第三世界基金会。A还是B？

Most people will opt for B. Unfortunately, it’s the wrong answer. Option B does not only say that Chris works for a major bank but also that an additional condition has been met. Employees who work specifically within a bank’s Third World foundation comprise a tiny subset of bankers. Therefore, option A is much more likely. The conjunction fallacy is at play when such a subset seems larger than the entire set—which by definition cannot be the case. Amos Tversky and Nobel laureate Daniel Kahneman have studied this extensively.

大多数人会选择B。不幸的是，这是错误的答案。选项B不仅表明克里斯在一家大型银行工作，还表明一个附加条件已得到满足。专门在银行第三世界基金会工作的员工只占银行家的一小部分。因此，选项A的可能性更大。合取谬误是指这样一个子集看起来比整个集合更大——而根据定义，这是不可能的。阿莫斯·特沃斯基和诺贝尔奖得主丹尼尔·卡尼曼对此进行了深入研究。

We are easy prey for the conjunction fallacy because we have an innate attraction to “harmonious” or “plausible” stories. The more convincingly, impressively, or vividly that Chris the aid worker is portrayed, the greater the risk of false reasoning. If I had put it a different way, you would have recognized the extra details as overly specific, for example: “Chris is thirty-five. What is more likely? (a) Chris works for a bank or (b) Chris works for a bank in New York, where his office is on the twenty-fourth floor, overlooking Central Park.”

我们很容易陷入合取谬误，因为我们天生就被“和谐”或“似是而非”的故事所吸引。对救援人员克里斯的描述越令人信服、越令人印象深刻、越生动，错误推理的风险就越大。如果我换一种说法，你就会意识到这些额外的细节过于具体，例如：“克里斯35岁。哪个更有可能？(a) 克里斯在一家银行工作，或 (b) 克里斯在纽约的一家银行工作，他的办公室在24层，可以俯瞰中央公园。”

Here’s another example: What is more likely? (a) “Seattle airport is closed. Flights are canceled,” or (b) “Seattle airport is closed due to bad weather. Flights are canceled.” A or B? This time, you have it: A is more likely since B implies that an additional condition has been met, namely, bad weather. It could be that a bomb threat, accident, or strike closed the airport; however, when faced with a “plausible” story, we don’t stop to consider such things. Now that you are aware of this, try it out with friends. You will see that most pick B.

再举个例子：哪个更有可能？（a）“西雅图机场关闭。航班取消”，或（b）“西雅图机场因恶劣天气关闭。航班取消”。A还是B？这次，你明白了：A更有可能，因为B意味着满足了一个附加条件，即恶劣天气。也可能是炸弹威胁、事故或袭击导致机场关闭；然而，当面对一个“似是而非”的故事时，我们不会停下来考虑这些事情。既然你已经意识到了这一点，那就和朋友们一起试试吧。你会发现大多数人都会选B。

Even experts are not immune to the conjunction fallacy . In 1982, at an international conference for future research, experts—all of them academics—were divided into two groups. To group A, Daniel Kahneman presented the following forecast for 1983: “Oil consumption will decrease by 30 percent.” Group B heard: “A dramatic rise in oil prices will lead to a 30 percent reduction in oil consumption.” Both groups had to indicate how likely they considered the scenarios. The result was clear: Group B felt much more strongly about its forecast than group A did.

即使是专家也难免会犯合取谬误。1982年，在一次未来研究国际会议上，专家们——全是学者——被分成两组。丹尼尔·卡尼曼向A组提出了对1983年的预测：“石油消费量将下降30%。” B组听到的预测是：“油价大幅上涨将导致石油消费量下降30%。” 两组都必须表明他们考虑这些情景的可能性。结果显而易见：B组对其预测的信心远高于A组。

Kahneman believes that two types of thinking exist: The first kind is intuitive, automatic, and direct. The second is conscious, rational, slow, laborious, and logical. Unfortunately, intuitive thinking draws conclusions long before the conscious mind does. For example, I experienced this after the 9/11 attacks on the World Trade Center. I wanted to take out travel insurance and came across a firm that offered special “terrorism cover.” Although other policies protected against all possible incidents (including terrorism), I automatically fell for the offer. The high point of the whole farce was that I was willing to pay even more for this enticing yet redundant add-on.

卡尼曼认为，思维有两种类型：第一种是直觉的、自动的、直接的。第二种是有意识的、理性的、缓慢的、费力的、逻辑的。不幸的是，直觉思维比意识思维更早得出结论。例如，我在9/11世贸中心袭击事件后就经历过这种情况。我想买旅行保险，偶然发现一家公司提供特殊的“恐怖主义保险”。虽然其他保单涵盖所有可能发生的事件（包括恐怖主义），但我还是毫不犹豫地接受了这个优惠。整个闹剧的高潮在于，我愿意为这个诱人却多余的附加险支付更高的价格。

In conclusion: Forget about left brains and right brains: The difference between intuitive and conscious thinking is much more significant. With important decisions, remember that, at the intuitive level, we have a soft spot for plausible stories. Therefore, be on the lookout for convenient details and happy endings. Remember: If an additional condition has to be met, no matter how plausible it sounds, it will become less, not more, likely.

总结：忘掉左右脑的区别吧：直觉思维和意识思维之间的区别要显著得多。在做重要决定时，请记住，在直觉层面，我们更容易接受看似合理的故事。因此，要留意那些方便的细节和圆满的结局。记住：如果必须满足一个附加条件，无论它听起来多么合理，它发生的可能性都会降低，而不是增加。

42

It’s Not What You Say, but How You Say It

重要的不是你说什么，而是你怎么说

Framing

框架

C onsider these two statements:

考虑以下两个陈述：

“Hey, the trash can is full!”

“嘿，垃圾桶满了！”

“It would be really great if you could empty the trash, honey.”

“亲爱的，如果你能清空垃圾就太好了。”

C’est le ton qui fait la musique : it’s not what you say but how you say it. If a message is communicated in different ways, it will also be received in different ways. In psychologists’ jargon, this technique is called framing .

这就是音乐的意义：重要的不是你说什么，而是你怎么说。如果一个信息以不同的方式传达，它也会以不同的方式被接收。用心理学家的术语来说，这种技巧叫做“框架”。

We react differently to identical situations, depending on how they are presented. Kahneman and Tversky conducted a survey in the 1980s in which they put forward two options for an epidemic-control strategy. The lives of six hundred people were at stake, they told participants. “Option A saves two hundred lives. Option B offers a 33 percent chance that all six hundred people will survive, and a 66 percent chance that no one will survive.” Although options A and B were comparable (with two hundred survivors expected), the majority of respondents chose A—remembering the adage: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush. It became really interesting when the same options were reframed . “Option A kills four hundred people. Option B offers a 33 percent chance that no one will die, and with a 66 percent chance that all six hundred will die.” This time, only a fraction of respondents chose A and the majority picked B. The researchers observed a complete U-turn from almost all involved. Depending on the phrasing—survive or die—the respondents made completely different decisions.

我们对相同情境的反应因呈现方式不同而不同。卡尼曼和特沃斯基在20世纪80年代进行了一项调查，提出了两种疫情控制策略方案。他们告诉参与者，六百人的生命危在旦夕。“方案A拯救两百人的生命。方案B有33%的几率六百人全部幸存，66%的几率无人幸存。”尽管方案A和B的存活率相当（预计都有两百人幸存），但大多数受访者选择了A——这让人想起那句谚语：双鸟在林不如一鸟在手。当同样的方案被重新表述时，情况变得非常有趣。“方案A杀死四百人。方案B有33%的几率无人幸存，600人全部死亡，66%的几率无人幸存。”这一次，只有一小部分受访者选择了A，而大多数人选择了B。研究人员发现，几乎所有参与者的回答都发生了180度大转弯。根据方案A和B的表述——生存还是死亡——受访者做出了截然不同的决定。

Another example: Researchers presented a group of people with two kinds of meat, “99 percent fat free” and “1 percent fat,” and asked them to choose which was healthier. Can you guess which they picked? Bingo: Respondents ranked the first type of meat as healthier, even though both were identical. Next came the choice between “98 percent fat free” and “1 percent fat.” Again, most respondents chose the first option—despite its higher fat content.

再举一个例子：研究人员向一组受试者展示了两种肉类：“99% 无脂肪”和“1% 脂肪”，并要求他们选择哪种更健康。你能猜出他们选了哪一种吗？猜对了：受访者认为第一种肉类更健康，尽管两种肉类完全相同。接下来，他们又要在“98% 无脂肪”和“1% 脂肪”之间做出选择。同样，大多数受访者选择了第一种——尽管它的脂肪含量更高。

“Glossing” is a popular type of framing . Under its rules, a tumbling share price becomes a “correction.” An overpaid acquisition price is branded “goodwill.” In every management course, a problem magically transforms into an “opportunity” or a “challenge.” A person who is fired is “reassessing his career.” A fallen soldier—regardless of how much bad luck or stupidity led to his death—turns into a “war hero.” Genocide translates to “ethnic cleansing.” A successful emergency landing, for example on the Hudson River, is celebrated as a “triumph of aviation.” (Shouldn’t a textbook landing on a runway count as an even bigger triumph of aviation?)

“粉饰”是一种流行的框架化手法。在这种框架下，股价暴跌变成了“回调”。过高的收购价被冠以“商誉”的标签。在每一门管理课程中，问题都会神奇地转化为“机遇”或“挑战”。被解雇的人正在“重新评估自己的职业生涯”。阵亡的士兵——无论他的死因是多大的厄运或愚蠢——都会被奉为“战争英雄”。种族灭绝被解读为“种族清洗”。例如，在哈德逊河上成功的紧急迫降，会被庆祝为“航空业的胜利”。（难道一次教科书式的在跑道上的着陆，难道不应该算作航空业更大的胜利吗？）

Have you ever looked more closely at the prospectus for financial products—for example, ETFs (exchange-traded funds)? Generally the brochure illustrates the product’s performance in recent years, going back just far enough for the nicest possible upward curve to emerge. This is also framing . Another example is a simple piece of bread. Depending on how it is framed , as either the “symbolic” or the “true” body of Christ, it can split a religion, as happened in the sixteenth century with the Reformation.

你有没有仔细看过金融产品的招股说明书，比如ETF（交易所交易基金）？通常，产品说明书会展示产品近年来的表现，回溯的时间恰好足以展现出最漂亮的上升曲线。这也是一种框架效应。另一个例子是一块普通的面包。根据它被如何描述，是基督的“象征性”还是“真正的”身体，它可能会分裂一个宗教，就像16世纪宗教改革时期那样。

Framing is used to good effect in commerce, too. Consider used cars. You are led to focus on just a few factors, whether the message is delivered through a salesman, a sign touting certain features, or even your own criteria. For example, if the car has the low mileage and good tires, you home in on this and overlook the state of the engine, the brakes, or the interior. Thus, the mileage and tires become the main selling points and frame our decision to buy. Such oversight is only natural, though, since it is difficult to take in all possible pros and cons. Interestingly, had other frames been used to tout the car, we might have decided very differently.

框架效应在商业中也能发挥良好的作用。以二手车为例。你会被引导只关注几个因素，无论信息是通过销售人员传递的，还是通过宣传某些功能的广告牌，甚至是你自己的标准。例如，如果这辆车的里程数低且轮胎状况良好，你就会关注这一点，而忽略发动机、刹车或内饰的状况。因此，里程数和轮胎就成了主要卖点，并构成了我们购买决策的框架。然而，这种疏忽也很自然，因为很难考虑到所有可能的利弊。有趣的是，如果使用其他框架来推销这辆车，我们的决定可能会大不相同。

Authors are conscious framers, too. A crime novel would be rather dull if, from page one, the murder were shown as it happened—stab by stab, as it were. Even though we eventually discover the motives and murder weapons, the novelist’s framing injects thrills and suspense into the story.

作者也是有意识的框架构建者。如果一部犯罪小说从第一页就直接呈现凶杀案的发生过程——就像一刀一刀地捅下去，那它肯定很枯燥。即使我们最终发现了作案动机和凶器，小说家的框架设计也为故事注入了刺激和悬念。

In conclusion: Realize that whatever you communicate contains some element of framing , and that every fact—even if you hear it from a trusted friend or read it in a reputable newspaper—is subject to this effect, too. Even this chapter.

结论：要意识到你所传达的任何信息都包含某种框架因素，并且每个事实——即使是从值得信赖的朋友那里听到的，或在信誉良好的报纸上读到的——也都可能受到这种框架的影响。即使是这一章。

43

Why Watching and Waiting Is Torture

为什么观望和等待是一种折磨

Action Bias

行动偏见

I n a penalty situation in soccer, the ball takes less than 0.3 seconds from the player who kicks the ball to the goal. There is not enough time for the goalkeeper to watch the ball’s trajectory. He must make a decision before the ball is kicked. Soccer players who take penalty kicks shoot one third of the time at the middle of the goal, one third of the time at the left, and one third of the time at the right. Surely goalkeepers have spotted this, but what do they do? They dive either to the left or to the right. Rarely do they stay standing in the middle—even though roughly a third of all balls land there. Why on earth would they jeopardize saving these penalties? The simple answer: appearance. It looks more impressive and feels less embarrassing to dive to the wrong side than to freeze on the spot and watch the ball sail past. This is the action bias : Look active, even if it achieves nothing.

在足球点球时刻，从球员将球踢进球门到拿到球的时间不到 0.3 秒。守门员没有足够的时间观察球的轨迹。他必须在球被踢出之前做出决定。主罚点球的足球运动员三分之一的时间射向球门中间，三分之一的时间射向左侧，三分之一的时间射向右侧。守门员肯定已经发现了这一点，但是他们会怎么做呢？他们要么向左扑救，要么向右扑救。他们很少会站在中间——尽管大约三分之一的球都落在那里。他们究竟为什么要冒险扑救这些点球呢？答案很简单：外表。向错误的一侧扑救比站在原地不动看着球飞过去看起来更令人印象深刻，也更不尴尬。这就是行动偏见：看起来很活跃，即使这样做毫无意义。

This study comes from the Israeli researcher Michael Bar-Eli, who evaluated hundreds of penalty shoot-outs. But not just goalkeepers fall victim to the action bias . Suppose a group of youths exit a nightclub and begin to argue, shouting at each other and gesturing wildly. The situation is close to escalating into an all-out brawl. The police officers in the area—some young, some more senior—hold back, monitor the scene from a distance, and intervene only when the first casualties appear. If no experienced officers are involved, this situation often ends differently: Young, overzealous officers succumb to the action bias and dive in immediately. A study revealed that later intervention, thanks to the calming presence of senior officers, results in fewer casualties.

这项研究来自以色列研究员迈克尔·巴埃利，他评估了数百场点球大战。但并非只有守门员会受到“行动偏见”的影响。假设一群年轻人从夜总会出来后开始争吵，互相叫喊，并做出疯狂的手势。情况几乎升级为一场全面的斗殴。该地区的警官——有的很年轻，有的资历较深——保持距离，在远处监视现场，直到出现第一批伤亡人员才进行干预。如果没有经验丰富的警官参与，这种情况的结果往往会有所不同：年轻、过于热心的警官会屈服于“行动偏见”，立即投入行动。一项研究表明，由于高级警官的镇定，较晚的干预可以减少伤亡人数。

The action bias is accentuated when a situation is new or unclear. When starting out, many investors act like the young, gung ho police officers outside the nightclub: They can’t yet judge the stock market so they compensate with a sort of hyperactivity. Of course this is a waste of time. As Charlie Munger sums up his approach to investing: “We’ve got . . . discipline in avoiding just doing any damn thing just because you can’t stand inactivity.”

当情况陌生或不明朗时，行动偏差会更加明显。许多投资者在创业之初，就像夜总会外那些年轻、热情高涨的警察：他们还无法判断股市行情，所以会用一种过度活跃来弥补。当然，这是在浪费时间。正如查理·芒格总结他的投资方法：“我们……有一套自律原则，避免仅仅因为无法忍受无所事事就贸然行动。”

The action bias exists even in the most educated circles. If a patient’s illness cannot yet be diagnosed with certainty, and doctors must choose between intervening (i.e., prescribing something) or waiting and seeing, they are prone to take action.
