Such decisions have nothing to do with profiteering, but rather with the human tendency to want to do anything but sit and wait in the face of uncertainty.

即使在受教育程度最高的圈子里，行动偏见也同样存在。如果患者的病情尚无法确诊，医生必须在干预（例如开药）和观望之间做出选择，他们很容易采取行动。这样的决定与牟取暴利无关，而是源于人类在面对不确定性时，除了坐等之外，更愿意采取任何行动的倾向。

So what accounts for this tendency? In our old hunter-gatherer environment (which suited us quite well), action trumped reflection. Lightning-fast reactions were essential to survival; deliberation could be fatal. When our ancestors saw a silhouette appear at the edge of the forest—something that looked a lot like a saber-toothed tiger—they did not take a pew to muse over what it might be. They hit the road—and fast. We are the descendants of these quick responders. Back then, it was better to run away once too often. However, our world today is different; it rewards reflection, even though our instincts may suggest otherwise.

那么，是什么导致了这种倾向呢？在我们古老的狩猎采集环境中（这种环境非常适合我们），行动胜过思考。闪电般的快速反应对生存至关重要；深思熟虑可能会致命。当我们的祖先看到森林边缘出现一个轮廓——看起来很像剑齿虎——他们不会坐下来沉思那是什么。他们会立即上路——而且速度很快。我们就是这些快速反应者的后代。在那个年代，逃跑一次总是好的。然而，今天的世界不同了；它奖励反思，即使我们的本能可能暗示并非如此。

Although we now value contemplation more highly, outright inaction remains a cardinal sin. You get no honor, no medal, no statue with your name on it if you make exactly the right decision by waiting —for the good of the company, the state, even humanity. On the other hand, if you demonstrate decisiveness and quick judgment, and the situation improves (though perhaps coincidentally), it’s quite possible your boss, or even the mayor, will shake your hand. Society at large still prefers rash action to a sensible wait-and-see strategy.

尽管我们现在更加重视深思熟虑，但彻底的无所作为仍然是不可饶恕的罪过。如果你为了公司、国家甚至人类的利益而做出完全正确的决定，等待却得不到荣誉、奖章，甚至刻上你的名字的雕像。另一方面，如果你表现出果断和快速的判断，并且情况有所改善（尽管可能是巧合），你的老板，甚至市长，很可能会与你握手言和。整个社会仍然更喜欢鲁莽行事，而不是采取明智的观望策略。

In conclusion: In new or shaky circumstances, we feel compelled to do something, anything. Afterward we feel better, even if we have made things worse by acting too quickly or too often. So, though it might not merit a parade in your honor, if a situation is unclear, hold back until you can assess your options. “All of humanity’s problems stem from man’s inability to sit quietly in a room alone,” wrote Blaise Pascal. At home, in his study.

总结：在新的或动荡的环境中，我们感到不得不做点什么，任何事都行。事后我们会感觉好一些，即使我们行动过快或过频反而让情况变得更糟。所以，虽然这或许不值得你为此欢呼雀跃，但如果情况尚不明朗，请先等等，直到你能够评估自己的选择。布莱兹·帕斯卡写道：“人类的所有问题都源于人无法独自静静地待在房间里。” 就在他家的书房里。

44

Why You Are Either the Solution—or the Problem

为什么你要么是解决方案，要么就是问题

Omission Bias

遗漏偏差

Y ou are on a glacier with two climbers. The first slips and falls into a crevasse. He might survive if you call for help, but you don’t, and he perishes. The second climber you actively push into the ravine, and he dies shortly afterward. Which weighs more heavily on your conscience?

你和两位登山者在冰川上。第一位登山者失足掉进了冰裂缝。如果你呼救，他或许还能活下来，但你没有，他死了。你主动把第二位登山者推入峡谷，他不久后也死了。哪一位登山者让你良心不安？

Considering the options rationally, it’s obvious that both are equally reprehensible, resulting as they do in death for your companions. And yet something makes us rate the first option, the passive option, as less horrible. This feeling is called the omission bias . It crops up where both action and inaction lead to cruel consequences. In such cases, we tend to prefer inaction; its results seem more anodyne.

理性地考虑这两种选择，显然两者都同样应受谴责，因为它们都会导致同伴死亡。然而，某种原因让我们觉得第一种选择，也就是被动的选择，不那么可怕。这种感觉被称为遗漏偏差。当行动和不作为都会导致残酷后果时，就会出现这种情况。在这种情况下，我们倾向于选择不作为；它的结果似乎更温和。

Suppose you are the head of the Federal Drug Administration. You must decide whether or not to approve a drug for the terminally ill. The pills can have fatal side effects: They kill 20 percent of patients on the spot, but save the lives of the other 80 percent within a short period of time. What do you decide?

假设你是联邦药品管理局局长。你必须决定是否批准一种用于治疗绝症的药物。这种药物可能产生致命的副作用：它们会当场杀死20%的病人，但会在短时间内挽救其余80%的病人的生命。你会如何决定？

Most would withhold approval. To them, waving through a drug that takes out every fifth person is a worse act than failing to administer the cure to the other 80 percent of patients. It is an absurd decision, and a perfect example of the omission bias . Suppose that you are aware of the bias and decide to approve the drug in the name of reason and decency. Bravo. But what happens when the first patient dies? A media storm ensues, and soon you find yourself out of a job. As a civil servant or politician, you would do well to take the ubiquitous omission bias seriously—and even foster it.

大多数人会拒绝批准。对他们来说，批准一种夺走五分之一病人生命的药物，比未能治愈其余80%的病人更糟糕。这是一个荒谬的决定，也是遗漏偏差的完美例证。假设你意识到了这种偏差，并决定以理性和体面的名义批准这种药物。太棒了。但是，如果第一个病人死了怎么办？媒体风暴接踵而至，很快你就失业了。作为一名公务员或政客，你最好认真对待普遍存在的遗漏偏差——甚至加以鼓励。

Case law shows how engrained such “moral distortion” is in our society. Active euthanasia, even if it is the explicit wish of the dying, is punishable by law, whereas deliberate refusal of lifesaving measures is legal (for example, following so-called DNR orders—do not resuscitate).

案例法表明，这种“道德扭曲”在我们社会中根深蒂固。主动安乐死，即使是临终者明确表示的意愿，也会受到法律的惩罚，而故意拒绝采取救生措施却合法（例如，遵守所谓的“DNR”命令——不要进行心肺复苏）。

Such thinking also explains why parents feel it is perfectly acceptable not to vaccinate their children, even though it discernibly reduces the risk of catching the disease. Of course, there is also a very small risk of getting sick from the vaccine. Overall, however, vaccination makes sense. Vaccination protects not only the children, but society, too. A person who is immune to the disease will never infect others. Objectively, if non-vaccinated children ever contracted one of these sicknesses, we could accuse the parents of actively harming them. But this is exactly the point: Deliberate inaction somehow seems less grave than a comparable action—say, if the parents intentionally infected them.

这种想法也解释了为什么父母觉得不给孩子接种疫苗完全可以接受，即使接种疫苗确实能显著降低患病风险。当然，接种疫苗也存在极小的致病风险。但总的来说，接种疫苗是合理的。接种疫苗不仅保护孩子，也保护社会。对某种疾病具有免疫力的人永远不会感染他人。客观地说，如果未接种疫苗的孩子感染了其中一种疾病，我们可以指责父母故意伤害他们。但关键在于：故意不作为似乎比采取类似行动（比如，如果父母故意感染孩子）更不严重。

The omission bias lies behind the following delusions: We wait until people shoot themselves in the foot rather than taking aim ourselves. Investors and business journalists are more lenient on companies that develop no new products than they are on those that produce bad ones, even though both roads lead to ruin. Sitting passively on a bunch of miserable shares feels better than actively buying bad ones. Building no emission filter into a coal plant feels superior to removing one for cost reasons. Failing to insulate your house is more acceptable than burning the spared fuel for your own amusement. Neglecting to declare income tax is less immoral than faking tax documents, even though the state loses out either way.

遗漏偏差背后隐藏着以下错觉：我们宁愿等到别人搬起石头砸自己的脚，也不愿自己动手。投资者和商业记者对那些不开发新产品的公司比对那些生产劣质产品的公司更宽容，尽管两条路都会导致毁灭。被动地持有一堆低迷的股票比主动购买劣质股票感觉更好。在燃煤电厂不安装排放过滤器比出于成本原因拆除一个感觉更好。不给房子做隔热处理比把多余的燃料烧了自娱自乐更容易被接受。逃避申报所得税比伪造税务文件更不道德，尽管无论哪种方式国家都会蒙受损失。

In the previous chapter, we met the action bias . Is it the opposite of the omission bias ? Not quite. The action bias causes us to offset a lack of clarity with futile hyperactivity and comes into play when a situation is fuzzy, muddy, or contradictory. The omission bias , on the other hand, usually abounds where the situation is intelligible: A future misfortune might be averted with direct action, but this insight doesn’t motivate us as much as it should.

在上一章中，我们讨论了行动偏差。它是遗漏偏差的对立面吗？并非如此。行动偏差会让我们用徒劳的过度行动来抵消不清晰的认知，这种偏差在情况模糊、混乱或自相矛盾时就会发挥作用。而遗漏偏差通常出现在情况易于理解的地方：未来的不幸或许可以通过直接行动来避免，但这种洞察力并不能充分激励我们。

The omission bias is very difficult to detect—after all, action is more noticeable than inaction. In the 1960s student movements coined a punchy slogan to condemn it: “If you’re not part of the solution, you’re part of the problem.”

遗漏偏差很难察觉——毕竟，行动比不行动更引人注目。20世纪60年代，学生运动创造了一句有力的口号来谴责这种偏差：“如果你不是解决方案的一部分，你就是问题的一部分。”

45

Don’t Blame Me

不要怪我

Self-Serving Bias

自我服务偏差

D o you ever read annual reports, paying particular attention to the CEO’s comments? No? That’s a pity, because there you’ll find countless examples of this next error, which we all fall for at one time or another. For example, if the company has enjoyed an excellent year, the CEO catalogs his indispensable contributions: his brilliant decisions, tireless efforts, and cultivation of a dynamic corporate culture. However, if the company has had a miserable year, we read about all sorts of other dynamics: the unfortunate exchange rate, governmental interference, the malicious trade practices of the Chinese, various hidden tariffs, subdued consumer confidence, and so on. In short: We attribute success to ourselves and failures to external factors. This is the self-serving bias .

你读过年报吗？会不会特别留意CEO的评论？没有？那很遗憾，因为年报里有无数类似这种错误的例子，我们每个人都会犯。比如，如果公司度过了一个辉煌的一年，CEO会列举自己不可或缺的贡献：他明智的决策、不懈的努力以及对充满活力的企业文化的培育。然而，如果公司度过了一个糟糕的一年，我们就会读到各种各样的其他因素：糟糕的汇率、政府干预、中国的恶意贸易行为、各种隐性关税、消费者信心低迷等等。简而言之：我们把成功归因于自己，把失败归咎于外部因素。这就是自利偏差。

Even if you have never heard the expression, you definitely know the self-serving bias from high school. If you got an A, you were solely responsible; the top grade reflected your intelligence, hard work, and skill. And if you flunked? The test was clearly unfair.

即使你从未听过这种说法，你肯定在高中就了解自利偏差。如果你得了A，那责任完全在你身上；最高分体现了你的智慧、努力和技能。如果你不及格呢？考试显然不公平。

But grades don’t matter to you anymore: Perhaps the stock market has taken their place. There, if you make a profit, you applaud yourself. If your portfolio performs miserably, the blame lies exclusively with “the market” (whatever you imply by this)—or maybe that useless investment adviser. I, too, have periods where I’m a power user of the self-serving bias : If my new novel rockets up the best-seller list, I clap myself on the shoulder. Surely this is my best book yet! But if it disappears in the flood of new releases, it is because the readers simply don’t recognize good literature when they see it. And if critics slay it, it is clearly a case of jealousy.

但成绩对你来说已经不再重要：或许股市已经取代了它们。在那里，如果你赚了钱，你会为自己鼓掌。如果你的投资组合表现糟糕，那责任就完全在“市场”（无论你具体指的是什么）——或者也许是那个没用的投资顾问。我也有一段时间会过度利用自利偏见：如果我的新小说一炮打响登上畅销书排行榜，我会拍拍自己的肩膀。这肯定是我迄今为止最好的书！但如果它消失在一波新书洪流中，那是因为读者根本无法识别出优秀的文学作品。而如果评论家们把它评得一塌糊涂，那显然是出于嫉妒。

To investigate this bias, researchers put together a personality test and afterward allocated the participants’ good or bad scores at random. Those who got scored highly found the test thorough and fair; low scorers rated it completely useless. So why do we attribute success to our own skill and ascribe failure to other factors? There are many theories. The simplest explanation is probably this: It feels good. Plus, it doesn’t cause any major harm. If it did, evolution would have eliminated it over the past hundred thousand years. But beware: In a modern world with many hidden risks, the self-serving bias can quickly lead to catastrophe. Richard Fuld, the self-titled “master of the universe,” might well endorse this. He was the almighty CEO of the investment bank Lehman Brothers, until it went bankrupt in 2008. It would not surprise me if he still called himself “master of the universe,” blaming government inaction for the bank’s collapse.

为了调查这种偏见，研究人员设计了一个性格测试，然后随机分配参与者的好坏分数。得分高的人认为测试全面公正；得分低的人则认为测试完全没用。那么，为什么我们会把成功归功于自己的技能，而把失败归咎于其他因素呢？有很多理论。最简单的解释可能是：自利偏见让人感觉良好。而且，它不会造成任何重大伤害。如果造成伤害，进化在过去的几十万年里早就把它消灭了。但要注意：在当今这个隐藏着诸多风险的世界，自利偏见可能迅速酿成灾难。自诩为“宇宙主宰”的理查德·富尔德很可能赞同这种说法。他曾是投资银行雷曼兄弟的全能首席执行官，直到2008年该公司破产。如果他仍然自称“宇宙主宰”，并将银行倒闭归咎于政府的不作为，我一点也不会感到惊讶。

In SAT tests, students can score between 200 and 800 points. When asked their results a year later, they tend to boost their scores by around 50 points. Interestingly, they are neither lying nor exaggerating; they are simply “enhancing” the result a little—until they start to believe the new score themselves.

在SAT考试中，学生的得分在200到800分之间。一年后被问及成绩时，他们往往会把分数提高50分左右。有趣的是，他们既没有撒谎，也没有夸大其词；他们只是稍微“夸大”了结果——直到他们自己也开始相信新的分数。

In the building where I live, five students share an apartment. I meet them now and again in the elevator, and I decided to ask them separately how often they take out the trash. One said he did it every second time. Another: every third time. Roommate number 3, cursing because his garbage bag had split, reckoned he did it pretty much every time, say 90 percent. Although their answers should have added up to 100 percent, these boys achieved an impressive 320 percent! The five systematically overestimated their roles—and so, are no different from any of us. In married couples, the same thing happens: It’s been shown that both men and women overestimate their contribution to the health of the marriage. Each assumes their input is more than 50 percent.

在我住的这栋楼里，五个学生合租一套公寓。我偶尔在电梯里碰到他们，于是决定分别问他们多久倒一次垃圾。一个说他每隔两次才倒一次。另一个说：每隔三次才倒一次。室友三号因为垃圾袋裂了而破了脸，他咒骂着，估计他几乎每次都倒，大概占了90%。虽然他们的答案加起来应该是100%，但这五个男孩却达到了惊人的320%！这五个人系统性地高估了自己的角色——所以，他们和我们没什么不同。在已婚夫妇中，同样的情况也会发生：研究表明，男人和女人都会高估自己对婚姻健康的贡献。每个人都认为自己的贡献超过了50%。

So, how can we dodge the self-serving bias ? Do you have friends who tell you the truth—no holds barred? If so, consider yourself lucky. If not, do you have at least one enemy? Good. Invite him or her over for coffee and ask for an honest opinion about your strengths and weaknesses. You will be forever grateful you did.

那么，我们该如何避免自利偏差呢？你有没有朋友会毫无保留地告诉你真相？如果有，那你真是幸运。如果没有，你至少有一个敌人吗？很好。邀请他或她来喝杯咖啡，问问他/她对你的优点和缺点的真实看法。你会永远感激你这么做的。

46

Be Careful What You Wish For

小心你的愿望

Hedonic Treadmill

享乐跑步机

S uppose one day the phone rings: An excited voice tells you that you have just scooped the lottery jackpot—$10 million! How would you feel? And how long would you feel like that? Another scenario: The phone rings, and you learn that your best friend has passed away. Again, how would you feel, and for how long?

假设有一天，电话铃响了：一个激动的声音告诉你，你刚刚中了彩票大奖——1000万美元！你会是什么感觉？这种感觉会持续多久？再假设一下：电话铃响了，你得知你最好的朋友去世了。同样，你会是什么感觉？这种感觉会持续多久？

In chapter 40 (“False Prophets: Forecast Illusion”), we examined the miserable accuracy of predictions, for example in the fields of politics, economics, and social events. We concluded that self-appointed experts are of no more use than a random forecast generator. So, moving on to a new area: How well can we predict our feelings? Are we experts on ourselves? Would winning the lottery make us the happiest people alive for years to come? Harvard psychologist Dan Gilbert says no. He has studied lottery winners and discovered that the happiness effect fizzles out after a few months. So, a little while after you receive the big check, you will be as content or as discontent as you were before. He calls this “affective forecasting”: our inability to correctly predict our own emotions.

在第40章（“假先知：预测错觉”）中，我们考察了预测的惨淡准确性，例如在政治、经济和社会事件等领域。我们得出结论，自封的专家不过是一个随机的预测生成器。那么，让我们转向一个新的领域：我们能多准确地预测自己的感受？我们是自己的专家吗？中彩票会让我们在未来几年成为世界上最幸福的人吗？哈佛大学心理学家丹·吉尔伯特给出了否定的答案。他研究了彩票中奖者，发现幸福效应会在几个月后逐渐消失。所以，在你收到那张巨额支票后不久，你的满足感或不满感会和以前一样。他称之为“情感预测”：我们无法正确预测自己的情绪。

A friend, a banking executive, whose enormous income was beginning to burn a hole in his pocket, decided to build himself a new home away from the city. His dream materialized into a villa with ten rooms, a swimming pool, and an enviable view of the lake and mountains. For the first few weeks, he beamed with delight. But soon the cheerfulness disappeared, and six months later he was unhappier than ever. What happened? As we now know, the happiness effect evaporates after a few months. The villa was no longer his dream. “I come home from work, open the door and . . . nothing. I feel as indifferent about the villa as I did about my one-room student apartment.” To make things worse, the poor guy now faced a one-hour commute twice a day. This may sound tolerable, but studies show that commuting by car represents a major source of discontent and stress, and people hardly ever get used to it. In other words, whoever has no innate affinity for commuting will suffer every day—twice a day. Anyhow, the moral of the story is that the dream villa had an overall negative effect on my friend’s happiness.

一位朋友是银行高管，巨额收入开始让他的口袋空空如也，于是决定在城外建造一栋新家。他的梦想变成了现实，一栋拥有十个房间、一个游泳池以及令人艳羡的湖光山色的别墅。最初的几周，他欣喜若狂。但很快，这种快乐就消失了，六个月后，他比以往任何时候都更加不快乐。发生了什么？正如我们现在所知，幸福效应在几个月后就消失了。别墅不再是他的梦想了。“我下班回家，打开门……什么也没有。我对别墅的感受，就像我对我的一居室学生公寓一样漠不关心。”更糟糕的是，这个可怜的家伙现在每天要面对两次，每次一小时的通勤。这听起来或许可以忍受，但研究表明，开车通勤是人们不满和压力的主要来源，而且人们很难习惯。换句话说，任何天生不爱通勤的人，每天都会很痛苦——一天两次。无论如何，这个故事的寓意是，梦想中的别墅对我朋友的幸福产生了总体负面影响。

Many others fare no better: People who change or progress in their careers are, in terms of happiness, right back where they started after around three months. The same goes for people who buy the latest Porsche. Science calls this effect the hedonic treadmill : We work hard, advance, and are able to afford more and nicer things, and yet this doesn’t make us any happier.

很多人的境遇也好不到哪里去：那些在职业生涯中有所改变或进步的人，在幸福感方面，大约三个月后就回到了最初的水平。购买最新款保时捷的人也是如此。科学界将这种效应称为“享乐跑步机”：我们努力工作，不断进步，能够买得起更多更好的东西，但这并没有让我们更快乐。

So how do negative events affect us—perhaps a spinal cord injury or the loss of a friend? Here, we also overestimate the duration and intensity of future emotions. For example, when a relationship ends, it feels like life will never be the same. The afflicted are completely convinced that they will never again experience joy, but after three or so months, they are back on the dating scene.

那么，负面事件——比如脊髓损伤或失去朋友——会如何影响我们呢？我们也会高估未来情绪的持续时间和强度。例如，当一段感情结束时，感觉生活再也不会像以前一样了。受此影响的人完全相信自己再也不会感受到快乐，但大约三个月后，他们又重新开始约会了。

Wouldn’t it be nice if we knew exactly how happy a new car, career, or relationship would make us? Well, this is doable in part. Use these scientifically rubber-stamped pointers to make better, brighter decisions: (a) Avoid negative things that you cannot grow accustomed to, such as commuting, noise, or chronic stress. (b) Expect only short-term happiness from material things, such as cars, houses, lottery winnings, bonuses, and prizes. (c) Aim for as much free time and autonomy as possible since long-lasting positive effects generally come from what you actively do. Follow your passions even if you must forfeit a portion of your income for them. Invest in friendships. For most people, professional status achieves long-lasting happiness, as long as they don’t change peer groups at the same time. In other words, if you ascend to a CEO role and fraternize only with other executives, the effect fizzles out.

如果我们能够确切地知道一辆新车、一份新工作或一段新恋情能带给我们多大的幸福感，那岂不是很好？这在某种程度上是可以做到的。运用这些科学的、行之有效的建议，做出更好、更明智的决定：(a) 避免那些你无法习惯的负面事物，例如通勤、噪音或慢性压力。(b) 只期望从物质中获得短期幸福，例如汽车、房子、彩票奖金、奖金和奖品。(c) 争取尽可能多的空闲时间和自主权，因为持久的积极影响通常来自于你积极主动做的事情。追随你的激情，即使你必须为此放弃一部分收入。投资友谊。对大多数人来说，职业地位能够带来持久的幸福，只要他们不同时更换同龄人群体。换句话说，如果你升职成为首席执行官，却只与其他高管交往，那么这种幸福感就会逐渐消失。

47

Do Not Marvel at Your Existence

不要对你的存在感到惊奇

Self-Selection Bias

自我选择偏差

T raveling from Philadelphia up to New York, I got stuck in a traffic jam. “Why is it always me?” I groaned. Glancing to the opposite side of the road, I saw carefree southbound drivers racing past with enviable speed. As I spent the next hour crawling forward at a snail’s pace, and started to grow restless from braking and accelerating, I asked myself whether I really was especially unlucky. Do I always pick the worst lines at the bank, post office, and grocery store? Or do I just think I do?

从费城开车去纽约，我被堵在了路上。“为什么总是我？”我呻吟着。我瞥了一眼马路对面，看到南行的司机们无忧无虑地以令人羡慕的速度飞驰而过。接下来的一个小时里，我像蜗牛一样缓慢地爬行，刹车和加速让我开始焦躁不安，我问自己是不是真的特别倒霉。难道我在银行、邮局和杂货店总是排着最差的队吗？还是我只是自以为是？

Suppose that, on this highway, a traffic jam develops 10 percent of the time. The probability that I will get stuck in a jam on a particular day is not greater than the probability that one will occur. However, the likelihood that I will get stuck at a certain point in my journey is greater than 10 percent. The reason: Because I can only crawl forward when in a traffic jam, I spend a disproportionate amount of time in this state. In addition, if the traffic is zooming along, the prospect never crosses my mind. But the moment it arises and I am stuck, I notice it.

假设这条高速公路上发生交通堵塞的概率为10%。我在某一天被困在交通堵塞中的概率并不大于交通堵塞发生的概率。然而，我在旅途中的某个时刻被困住的概率却大于10%。原因是：由于我只能在交通堵塞时缓慢前进，因此我会在这种状态下度过不成比例的时间。此外，如果车流飞驰，我永远不会想到这种情况。但一旦交通堵塞出现，我被困住了，我就会注意到。

The same applies to the lines at bank counters or traffic lights: Let’s say the route between point A and point B has ten traffic lights. On average, one out of the ten will always be red, and the others green. However, you may spend more than 10 percent of your total travel time waiting at a red light. If this doesn’t seem right, imagine that you are traveling at near the speed of light. In this case, you would spend 99.99 percent (not 10 percent) of your total journey time waiting and cursing in front of red traffic lights.

这同样适用于银行柜台或交通信号灯前的排队：假设A点和B点之间的路线有10个交通信号灯。平均而言，其中10个信号灯中总会有一个是红色的，其余的是绿色的。然而，你可能会花费超过10%的总行程时间在红灯前等待。如果这看起来不对，想象一下你以接近光速的速度行驶。在这种情况下，你将花费99.99%（而不是10%）的总行程时间在红灯前等待和咒骂。

Whenever we complain about bad luck, we must be wary of the so-called self-selection bias . My male friends often gripe about there being too few women in their companies, and my female friends groan that theirs have too few men. This has nothing to do with bad luck: The grumblers form part of the sample. The probability is high that a man will work in a mostly male industry. Ditto for women. On a grander scale: If you live in a country with a large proportion of men or women (such as China or Russia, respectively), you are likely to form part of the bigger group and accordingly feel hard done by. In elections, it is most probable that you will choose the largest party. In voting, it is most likely that your vote corresponds with the winning majority.

每当我们抱怨运气不好时，都必须警惕所谓的自我选择偏差。我的男性朋友经常抱怨他们公司里女性太少，而我的女性朋友则抱怨她们公司里男性太少。这与运气不好无关：抱怨者本身就是样本的一部分。男性在男性占主导地位的行业工作的可能性很高。女性也是如此。从更宏观的角度来看：如果你生活在一个男性或女性比例很大的国家（例如中国和俄罗斯），你很可能会成为更大群体中的一员，因此会感到不公平。在选举中，你很可能会选择最大的政党。在投票中，你的选票很可能与获胜的多数票相符。

The self-selection bias is pervasive. Marketers sometimes stumble into the trap in this way: To analyze how much customers value their newsletter, they send out a questionnaire. Unfortunately, this reaches only one group: current subscribers who are clearly satisfied, have time to respond, and have not canceled their subscriptions. The others make up no part of the sample. Result: The poll is worthless.

自我选择偏差无处不在。营销人员有时会这样陷入陷阱：为了分析客户对其新闻通讯的重视程度，他们会发出一份问卷。不幸的是，这只能覆盖一个群体：那些明显满意、有时间回复且没有取消订阅的现有订阅者。其他群体根本不构成样本。结果：这项调查毫无价值。

Not too long ago, a rather maudlin friend remarked that it bordered on the miraculous that he—yes, he!—ever existed. A classic victim of the self-selection bias . Only someone who is alive can make such an observation. Nonentities generally don’t consider their nonexistence for too long. And yet precisely the same delusion forms the basis of at least a dozen philosophers’ books, as they marvel year in, year out at the development of language. I’m quite sympathetic to their amazement, but it is simply not justified. If language did not exist, philosophers could not revere it at all—in fact, there would be no philosophers. The miracle of language is tangible only in the environment in which it exists.

不久前，一位颇为伤感的朋友评论说，他——是的，他！——曾经存在过，简直是个奇迹。典型的自我选择偏差受害者。只有活着的人才能做出这样的观察。无足轻重的人通常不会长时间地认为自己不存在。然而，同样的错觉构成了至少十几位哲学家著作的基础，他们年复一年地惊叹于语言的发展。我很理解他们的惊讶，但这根本说不通。如果语言不存在，哲学家们根本就不会对它感到崇敬——事实上，也不会有哲学家。语言的奇迹只有在它存在的环境中才能感受到。

Particularly amusing is this recent telephone survey: A company wanted to find out, on average, how many phones (landline and cell) each household owned. When the results were tallied, the firm was amazed that not a single household claimed to have no phone. What a masterpiece.

最近一项电话调查尤其有趣：一家公司想了解平均每户家庭拥有多少部电话（包括座机和手机）。结果统计出来后，公司惊讶地发现，竟然没有一户家庭声称自己没有电话。真是个杰作。

48

Why Experience Can Damage Your Judgment

为什么经验会损害你的判断力

Association Bias

联想偏差

K evin has presented his division’s results to the company’s board on three occasions. Each time, things have gone perfectly. And, each time, he has worn his green polka-dot boxer shorts. It’s official, he thinks: These are my lucky underpants.

凯文已经三次向公司董事会汇报了自己部门的业绩。每次都进展顺利。而且，每次他都穿着那条绿色波点平角短裤。他心想，这下可正式了：这可是我的幸运内裤。

The girl in the jewelry store was so stunning that Kevin couldn’t help buying the $10,000 engagement ring she showed him. Ten thousand bucks was way over his budget (especially for a second marriage), but for some reason he associated the ring with her and imagined his future wife would be just as dazzling.

珠宝店里的姑娘美得令人窒息，凯文忍不住买下了她给他看的那枚价值一万美元的订婚戒指。一万美元远远超出了他的预算（尤其是对于二婚而言），但不知为何，他把这枚戒指和姑娘联系在一起，幻想着未来的妻子也会同样光彩夺目。

Each year, Kevin goes to the doctor for a checkup. Generally, he is told that, for a man of forty-four, he is still in pretty good shape. Only twice has he left the practice with worrying news. Once the problem was his appendix, which was promptly removed. The other time it was a swollen prostate, which, upon further inspection, turned out to be a simple inflammation rather than cancer. Of course, on both occasions, Kevin was beside himself with worry when leaving the clinic—and coincidentally, both days were extremely hot. Since then, he has always felt uncomfortable on very warm days. If the temperature starts to heat up around one of his checkups, he cancels right away.

凯文每年都会去看医生做一次体检。医生通常告诉他，对于一个44岁的男人来说，他的身体状况还算不错。只有两次他离开诊所时，听到的消息让他感到担忧。一次是阑尾炎，医生立即切除了它。另一次是前列腺肿大，经过进一步检查，发现只是普通的炎症，而不是癌症。当然，这两次凯文离开诊所时都忧心忡忡——巧合的是，这两次都是酷热难耐。从那以后，他总是在非常炎热的日子里感到不舒服。如果体检前后气温开始升高，他就会立即取消。

Our brain is a connection machine. This is quite practical: If we eat an unknown fruit and feel sick afterward, we avoid it in future, labeling the plant poisonous or at least unpalatable. This is how knowledge comes to be. However, this method also creates false knowledge. Russian scientist Ivan Pavlov was the first to conduct research into this phenomenon. His original goal was to measure salivation in dogs. He used a bell to call the dogs to eat, but soon the ringing sound was enough to make the dogs salivate. The animals’ brains linked two functionally unrelated things—the ringing of a bell and the production of saliva.

我们的大脑是一台连接机器。这非常实用：如果我们吃了一种不知名的水果，之后感觉不舒服，以后我们就会避免食用，并给这种植物贴上“有毒”或至少“难吃”的标签。知识就是这样产生的。然而，这种方法也会产生虚假的知识。俄罗斯科学家伊万·巴甫洛夫是第一个研究这一现象的人。他最初的目标是测量狗的唾液分泌。他用铃铛叫狗吃东西，但很快铃声就足以让狗分泌唾液。动物的大脑将两件功能上毫不相关的事联系在一起——铃铛的响声和唾液的分泌。

Pavlov’s method works equally well with humans. Advertising creates a link between products and emotions. For this reason, you will never see Coke alongside a frowning face or a wrinkly body. Coke people are young, beautiful, and oh so fun, and they appear in clusters not seen in the real world.

巴甫洛夫的理论对人类同样有效。广告在产品和情感之间建立了联系。正因如此，你永远不会看到可口可乐与愁眉苦脸或满脸皱纹的身影并存。可口可乐的顾客年轻、漂亮，而且非常有趣，他们成群结队地出现，这在现实世界中是看不到的。

These false connections are the work of the association bias , which also influences the quality of our decisions. For example: We often condemn bearers of bad news, since we automatically associate them with the message’s content (otherwise known as “shoot-the-messenger syndrome”). Sometimes, CEOs and investors (unconsciously) steer clear of these harbingers, meaning the only news that reaches the upper echelons is positive, thus creating a distorted view of the real situation. If you lead a group of people, and don’t want to fall prey to false connections, direct your staff to tell you only the bad news—and fast. With this, you overcompensate for the shoot-the-messenger syndrome and, believe me, you will still hear enough positive news.

这些虚假联系源于联想偏差，它也会影响我们决策的质量。例如：我们经常谴责那些带来坏消息的人，因为我们会不自觉地将他们与消息内容联系起来（也称为“枪毙信使综合症”）。有时，CEO和投资者会（无意识地）避开这些“预兆”，这意味着高层收到的只有正面消息，从而扭曲了对真实情况的看法。如果你领导着一群人，又不想落入虚假联系的陷阱，那就指示你的员工只告诉你坏消息——而且要快。这样做，你就过度补偿了“枪毙信使综合症”，相信我，你仍然会听到足够多的正面消息。

In the days before e-mail and telemarketing, traveling salesmen went door-to-door peddling their wares. One day, a particular salesman, George Foster, stood at a front door. The house transpired to be vacant, and unbeknownst to him, a tiny leak had been filling it with gas for weeks. The bell was also damaged, so when he pressed it, it created a spark and the house exploded. Poor George ended up in the hospital, but fortunately he was soon back on his feet. Unfortunately, his fear of ringing doorbells had become so strong that he couldn’t carry out his job for many years. He knew how unlikely a repeat of the incident was, but for all he tried, he just couldn’t manage to reverse the (false) emotional connection.

在电子邮件和电话营销出现之前，旅行推销员会挨家挨户地推销他们的商品。有一天，一位名叫乔治·福斯特的推销员站在一户人家的门口。房子当时空无一人，他浑然不知，一个小小的漏气口已经让房子里充满了煤气好几个星期了。门铃也坏了，所以当他按下门铃时，火花四溅，房子爆炸了。可怜的乔治最终被送进了医院，但幸运的是，他很快就恢复了健康。不幸的是，他对按门铃的恐惧变得如此强烈，以至于他多年来都无法工作。他知道类似的事情不太可能再次发生，但无论他怎么努力，都无法扭转这种（虚假的）情感联系。

The take-home message from all this is phrased most aptly by Mark Twain: “We should be careful to get out of an experience only the wisdom that is in it—and stop there; lest we be like the cat that sits down on a hot stove-lid. She will never sit down on a hot stove-lid again—and that is well; but also she will never sit down on a cold one anymore.”

马克·吐温曾对这一切给出了最贴切的诠释：“我们应该谨慎，只从经验中汲取其中蕴含的智慧——然后就此止步；否则，我们就会像那只坐在热炉盖上的猫一样。它再也不会坐在热炉盖上了——这很好；但它也再也不会坐在冷炉盖上了。”

49

Be Wary When Things Get Off to a Great Start

当事情开始顺利时要保持警惕

Beginner’s Luck

初学者的运气

I n the last chapter, we learned about the association bias —the tendency to see connections where none exist. For example, regardless of how many big presentations he has nailed while wearing them, Kevin’s green polka-dot underpants are no guarantee of success.

在上一章中，我们学习了联想偏差——即倾向于在毫无关联的地方寻找联系。例如，无论凯文穿着他的绿色波点内裤在多少次大型演讲中表现出色，它都无法保证成功。

We now come to a particularly tricky branch of the association bias : creating a (false) link with the past. Casino players know this well; they call it beginner’s luck . People who are new to a game and lose in the first few rounds are usually clever enough to fold. But whoever strikes lucky tends to keep going. Convinced of their above-average skills, these amateurs increase the stakes—but they soon will get a sobering wake-up call when the probabilities “normalize.”

现在我们来谈谈联想偏差中一个特别棘手的分支：与过去建立（错误的）联系。赌场玩家对此深谙其道；他们称之为“新手运气”。新手在前几轮就输掉游戏的人通常足够聪明，会弃牌。但幸运的是，那些运气好的人往往会继续玩下去。这些业余玩家确信自己水平超群，于是加大了赌注——但当概率“正常化”时，他们很快就会得到一个令人警醒的警告。

Beginner’s luck plays an important role in the economy: Say company A buys smaller companies B, C, and D one after the other. The acquisitions prove a success, and the directors believe they have real skill for acquisitions. Buoyed by this confidence, they now buy a much larger company, E. The integration is a disaster. The merger proves too difficult to handle, the estimated synergies impossible to realize. Objectively speaking, this was foreseeable because in the previous acquisitions everything fell perfectly into place as if guided by a magical hand, so beginner’s luck blinded them.

新手的好运在经济中扮演着重要的角色：假设A公司接连收购了规模较小的B、C和D公司。这些收购非常成功，董事们也相信自己拥有真正的收购技巧。在这种信心的鼓舞下，他们又收购了规模大得多的公司E。然而，整合却是一场灾难。合并变得难以处理，预期的协同效应根本无法实现。客观地说，这是可以预见的，因为在之前的收购中，一切都进展顺利，仿佛被一只神奇的手指引着，所以新手的好运蒙蔽了他们的双眼。

The same goes for the stock exchange. Driven by initial success, many investors pumped their life savings into Internet stocks in the late ’90s. Some even took out loans to capitalize on the opportunity. However, these investors overlooked one tiny detail: Their amazing profits at the time had nothing to do with their stock-picking abilities. The market was simply on an upward spiral. Even the most clueless investors won big. When the market finally turned downward, many were left facing mountains of dot-com debt.

股票市场也是如此。受最初成功的驱使，许多投资者在90年代末将毕生积蓄投入互联网股票。有些人甚至借贷来抓住这个机会。然而，这些投资者忽略了一个微小的细节：他们当时惊人的利润与他们的选股能力无关。市场当时正处于螺旋式上升的趋势中。即使是最无知的投资者也能大赚一笔。当市场最终下跌时，许多人面临着巨额的互联网债务。

We witnessed the same delusions during the recent U.S. housing boom. Dentists, lawyers, teachers, and taxi drivers gave up their jobs to “flip” houses—to buy them and resell them right away at higher prices. The first fat profits justified their career changes, but of course these gains had nothing to do with any specific skills. The housing bubble allowed even the most inept amateur brokers to flourish. Many investors became deeply indebted as they flipped even more and even bigger mansions. When the bubble finally burst, many were left with only a string of unsellable properties to their names.

在最近的美国房地产热潮中，我们也见证了同样的妄想。牙医、律师、教师和出租车司机纷纷辞去工作，转而“炒房”——买下房子，然后立即以更高的价格转售。最初的丰厚利润让他们的职业转型变得合理，但这些收益当然与任何特定技能无关。房地产泡沫让即使是最无能的业余经纪人也能蓬勃发展。许多投资者在炒卖更多、更大的豪宅时负债累累。当泡沫最终破裂时，许多人名下只剩下一堆卖不出去的房产。

In fact, history has no shortage of beginner’s luck : I doubt whether Napoleon or Hitler would have dared launch a campaign against the Russians without the previous victories in smaller battles to bolster them.

事实上，历史上从来不乏初学者的好运：我怀疑如果没有先前小规模战役的胜利作为后盾，拿破仑或希特勒是否敢于对俄国人发动战争。

But how do you tell the difference between beginner’s luck and the first signs of real talent? There is no clear rule, but these two tips may help: First, if you are much better than others over a long period of time, you can be fairly sure that talent plays a part. (Unfortunately, you can never be 100 percent, though.) Second, the more people competing, the greater the chances are that one of them will repeatedly strike lucky. Perhaps even you. If, among ten competitors, you establish yourself as a market leader over many years, you can clap yourself on the back. That’s a sure indication of talent. But if you are top dog among ten million players (i.e., in the financial markets), you shouldn’t start visualizing a Buffettesque financial empire just yet; it’s extremely likely that you have simply been very fortunate.

但是，你该如何区分新手的运气和真正天赋的最初迹象呢？并没有明确的规则，但以下两个建议可能会有所帮助：首先，如果你在很长一段时间内都比别人优秀得多，那么你可以相当肯定天赋在其中起了作用。（但不幸的是，你永远不可能做到100%。）其次，竞争对手越多，他们中有人不断走运的可能性就越大。或许你也是如此。如果你在10个竞争对手中，多年来确立了市场领先地位，你可以为自己鼓掌。这肯定是天赋的体现。但如果你是千万玩家中的佼佼者（例如在金融市场中），你也不应该开始想象拥有一个巴菲特式的金融帝国；你极有可能只是运气好而已。

Watch and wait before you draw any conclusions. Beginner’s luck can be devastating, so guard against misconceptions by treating your theories as a scientist would: Try to disprove them. As soon as my first novel, Thirty-five , was ready to go, I sent it to a single publisher, where it was promptly accepted. For a moment I felt like a genius, a literary sensation. (The chance that this publisher will take on a manuscript is one in fifteen thousand.) To test my theory, I then sent the manuscript to ten other big publishers. And I got ten rejection letters. My notion was thus disproved, bringing me swiftly back down to earth.

在下结论之前，务必观察并等待。新手的运气可能非常糟糕，所以要像科学家一样对待你的理论，以防误解：尝试推翻它们。我的第一部小说《三十五》一准备好，我就把它寄给了一家出版商，很快就被接受了。那一刻，我觉得自己像个天才，一个文学巨匠。（这家出版商接受手稿的几率是一万五千分之一。）为了验证我的理论，我又把手稿寄给了另外十家大型出版商。结果我收到了十封拒信。我的想法就这样被推翻了，我很快回到了现实。

50

Sweet Little Lies

甜蜜的小谎言

Cognitive Dissonance

认知失调

A fox crept up to a vine. He gazed longingly at the fat, purple, overripe grapes. He placed his front paws against the trunk of the vine, stretched his neck, and tried to get at the fruit, but it was too high. Irritated, he tried his luck again. He launched himself upward, but his jaw snapped only at fresh air. A third time he leapt with all his might—so powerfully that he landed back down on the ground with a thud. Still not a single leaf had stirred. The fox turned up his nose: “These aren’t even ripe yet. Why would I want sour grapes?” Holding his head high, he strode back into the forest.

一只狐狸蹑手蹑脚地爬到一棵葡萄藤旁。它渴望地凝视着那些饱满、紫色、熟透的葡萄。它用前爪撑住葡萄藤，伸长脖子，想摘下果实，但葡萄太高了。它恼火地又试了一次。它猛地向上一跃，但下巴却被空气咬得啪啪作响。它第三次用尽全力跳起——力道之大，以至于砰的一声落在地上。叶子仍然没有动一下。狐狸嗤之以鼻：“这些葡萄还没熟呢，我为什么要吃酸葡萄呢？”它昂首挺胸，大步走回了森林。

The Greek poet Aesop created this fable to illustrate one of the most common errors in reasoning. An inconsistency arose when the fox set out to do something and failed to accomplish it. He can resolve this conflict in one of three ways: (a) by somehow getting at the grapes, (b) by admitting that his skills are insufficient, or (c) by reinterpreting what happened retrospectively. The last option is an example of cognitive dissonance , or, rather, its resolution.

希腊诗人伊索创作了这则寓言，旨在阐释推理中最常见的错误之一。狐狸着手做某事却未能完成，结果出现了矛盾。他可以用以下三种方式之一解决这一矛盾：(a) 设法得到葡萄；(b) 承认自己能力不足；(c) 回顾过去，重新解读发生的事情。最后一种选择是认知失调的一个例子，或者更确切地说，是认知失调的解决方案。

Suppose you buy a new car. However, you regret your choice soon afterward: The engine sounds like a jet taking off and you just can’t get comfortable in the driver’s seat. What do you do? Giving the car back would be an admission of error (you don’t want that!), and anyway, the dealer probably wouldn’t refund all the money. So you tell yourself that a loud engine and awkward seats are great safety features that will prevent you from falling asleep at the wheel. Not so stupid after all, you think, and you are suddenly proud of your sound, practical purchase.

假设你买了一辆新车。但不久之后，你就后悔了：发动机的声音就像喷气式飞机起飞一样，你坐在驾驶座上感觉不舒服。你会怎么做？退车就等于承认错误（你肯定不想这样！），而且经销商很可能不会全额退款。于是你告诉自己，响亮的发动机和不舒服的座椅是很好的安全配置，可以防止你在驾驶时睡着。你心想，这毕竟不是那么愚蠢，你突然为自己这辆既安全又实用的车感到自豪。

Leon Festinger and James M. Carlsmith of Stanford University once asked their students to carry out an hour of excruciatingly boring tasks. They then divided the subjects into two groups. Each student in group A received a dollar (it was 1959) and instructions to wax lyrical about the work to another student waiting outside—in other words, to lie. The same was asked of the students in group B, with one difference: They were given $20 for the task. Later, the students had to divulge how they really found the monotonous work. Interestingly, those who received only a dollar rated it as significantly more enjoyable and interesting. Why? One measly dollar was not enough for them to lie outright; instead they convinced themselves that the work was not that bad. Just as Aesop’s fox reinterpreted the situation, so did they. The students who received more didn’t have to justify anything. They had lied and netted $20 for it—a fair deal. They experienced no cognitive dissonance .

斯坦福大学的利昂·费斯廷格和詹姆斯·M·卡尔史密斯曾要求他们的学生完成一小时极其枯燥的任务。然后，他们把受试者分成两组。A组的每个学生都拿到一美元（当时是1959年），并被要求向等候在外面的另一个学生滔滔不绝地赞美这项工作——换句话说，就是撒谎。B组的学生也做了同样的要求，但有一点不同：他们得到了20美元来完成这项任务。之后，学生们必须透露他们真正觉得这项单调乏味的工作的原因。有趣的是，那些只得到一美元的学生认为这项工作更加有趣。为什么？区区一美元不足以让他们直接撒谎；相反，他们会说服自己这项工作并没有那么糟糕。就像伊索寓言中的狐狸重新解读了情况一样，他们也重新解读了情况。得到更多钱的学生无需解释任何事情。他们撒了谎，净赚了20美元——一笔划算的交易。他们没有经历认知失调。

Suppose you apply for a job and discover you have lost out to another candidate. Instead of admitting that the other person was better suited, you convince yourself that you didn’t want the job in the first place; you simply wanted to test your “market value” and see if you could get invited for interview.

假设你申请一份工作，却发现自己输给了另一位候选人。你不承认对方更适合你，反而说服自己，你一开始就不想要这份工作；你只是想测试一下自己的“市场价值”，看看能不能被邀请面试。

I reacted very similarly some time ago when I had to choose between investing in two different stocks. My chosen stock lost much of its value shortly after the purchase, whereas shares in the other stock, the one I hadn’t invested in, skyrocketed. I couldn’t bring myself to admit my error. Quite the reverse, in fact: I distinctly remember trying to convince a friend that, though the stock was experiencing teething problems, it still had more potential overall. Only cognitive dissonance can explain this remarkably irrational reaction. The “potential” would indeed have been even greater if I had postponed the decision to purchase the shares until today. It was that friend who told me the Aesop fable. “You can play the clever fox all you want—but you’ll never get the grapes that way.”

不久前，当我必须在两只股票之间做出选择时，我也有过类似的反应。我选择的那只股票在买入后不久就大幅下跌，而另一只我之前没有投资的股票却一路飙升。我无法承认自己的错误。事实上，情况恰恰相反：我清楚地记得自己曾试图说服一位朋友，尽管这只股票当时遇到了一些初期问题，但它总体上仍然拥有更大的潜力。只有认知失调才能解释这种极其不理性的反应。如果我把买入股票的决定推迟到今天，它的“潜力”确实会更大。正是那位朋友告诉我伊索寓言：“你可以随心所欲地扮演聪明的狐狸——但那样你永远也得不到葡萄。”

51

Live Each Day as If It Were Your Last—but Only on Sundays

把每一天都当成生命中的最后一天来过——但仅限于星期天

Hyperbolic Discounting

双曲线贴现

Y ou know the saying: “Live each day as if it were your last.” It features at least three times in every lifestyle magazine and has a slot in every self-help manual’s standard repertoire, too. For such a clever line, it makes you none the wiser. Just imagine what would happen if you followed it to the letter: You would no longer brush your teeth, wash your hair, clean the apartment, turn up for work, pay the bills. . . . In no time, you would be broke, sick, and perhaps even behind bars. And yet its meaning is inherently noble: It expresses a deep longing, a desire for immediacy. We place huge value on immediacy—much more than is justifiable. “Enjoy each day to the fullest and don’t worry about tomorrow” is simply not a smart way to live.

你知道这句话：“把每一天都当成你的最后一天来过。”这句话在每一本生活方式杂志上至少出现三次，也是每一本自助手册的标准内容。虽然这句话很聪明，但它并没有让你变得更聪明。想象一下，如果你完全照做会发生什么：你将不再刷牙、洗头、打扫公寓、去上班、付账单……很快，你就会破产、生病，甚至身陷囹圄。然而，这句话的含义本身是高尚的：它表达了一种深切的渴望，一种对即时性的渴求。我们非常重视即时性——远远超过了它的合理性。“尽情享受每一天，不要担心明天”根本不是一种明智的生活方式。

Would you rather receive $1,000 in a year or $1,100 in a year and a month? Most people will opt for the larger sum in thirteen months—where else will you find a monthly interest rate of 10 percent (or 120 percent per annum!). A wise choice, since the interest will compensate you generously for any risks you face by waiting the extra few weeks.

你愿意一年拿到1000美元，还是一年零一个月拿到1100美元？大多数人会选择13个月拿到更大的金额——不然你还能找到月利率10%（甚至年利率120%）的贷款吗？这真是个明智的选择，因为利息足以弥补你额外等待几周所带来的风险。

Second question: Would you prefer $1,000 today cash on the table or $1,100 in a month? If you think like most people, you’ll take the $1,000 right away. This is amazing. In both cases, if you hold out for just a month longer, you get $100 more. In the first case, it’s simple enough. You figure: “I’ve already waited twelve months; what’s one more?” Not in the second case. The introduction of “now” causes us to make inconsistent decisions. Science calls this phenomenon hyperbolic discounting . Put plainly: The closer a reward is, the higher our “emotional interest rate” rises and the more we are willing to give up in exchange for it. The majority of economists have not yet grasped that we respond so subjectively and inconsistently to interest rates. Their models still depend on constant interest rates and are correspondingly questionable.

第二个问题：你是想今天拿到1000美元现金，还是一个月后拿到1100美元？如果你和大多数人一样想，你会立刻拿走这1000美元。这太神奇了。在这两种情况下，只要你再坚持一个月，就能多得到100美元。在第一种情况下，这很简单。你会想：“我已经等了12个月了，再多一个月又算什么？”在第二种情况下则不然。“现在”的引入导致我们做出不一致的决定。科学上把这种现象称为双曲线贴现。说得直白些：奖励越近，我们的“情感利率”就越高，我们就越愿意为此放弃。大多数经济学家还没有意识到，我们对利率的反应是如此主观和不一致。他们的模型仍然依赖于恒定利率，因此也存在问题。

Hyperbolic discounting , the fact that immediacy magnetizes us, is a remnant of our animal past. Animals will never turn down an instant reward in order to attain more in the future. You can train rats as much as you like; they’re never going to give up a piece of cheese today to get two pieces tomorrow. But wait a minute: Don’t squirrels manage to gather food and save it for much later? Yes, but that’s pure instinct and—verifiably—has nothing to do with impulse control or learning.

双曲线贴现，即我们对即时性的渴望，是我们动物本性的遗留。动物绝不会为了将来获得更多而拒绝即时的奖励。你可以随心所欲地训练老鼠；它们绝不会为了明天得到两块奶酪而放弃今天的一块。但是，等等：松鼠不是会收集食物并储存起来以备后用吗？没错，但那是纯粹的本能，而且——可以证实——与冲动控制或学习无关。

And what about children? In the ’60s, Walter Mischel conducted a famous experiment on delayed gratification. You can find a wonderful video of this on YouTube by typing in “marshmallow experiment.” In it, a group of four-year-olds were each given a marshmallow. They could either eat theirs right away or wait a couple of minutes and receive a second. Amazingly, very few children could wait. Even more amazingly, Mischel found that the capacity for delayed gratification is a reliable indicator of future career success. Patience is indeed a virtue.

那么孩子们呢？上世纪60年代，沃尔特·米歇尔（Walter Mischel）进行了一项关于延迟满足的著名实验。你可以在YouTube上搜索“棉花糖实验”找到一段精彩的视频。实验中，一组四岁的孩子每人拿到一块棉花糖。他们可以选择立即吃掉这块，或者等几分钟再吃第二块。令人惊讶的是，很少有孩子能够等到。更令人惊讶的是，米歇尔发现，延迟满足的能力是未来职业成功的可靠指标。耐心确实是一种美德。

The older we get and the more self-control we build up, the more easily we can delay rewards. Instead of twelve months, we happily wait thirteen to take home an additional $100. However, if we are offered an instant reward, the incentive has to be very high for us to postpone the fulfillment. Case in point: the exorbitant interest rates banks charge on credit-card debt and other short-term personal loans, both of which exploit our must-have-now instincts.

随着年龄增长，自控力增强，我们就越容易推迟获得奖励。我们乐意等待13个月，而不是12个月，就能额外获得100美元。然而，如果我们获得的是即时奖励，那么激励就必须非常高，我们才会推迟兑现。例如：银行对信用卡债务和其他短期个人贷款收取高昂的利率，这两种贷款都利用了我们“必须立即得到”的本能。

In conclusion: Though instantaneous reward is incredibly tempting, hyperbolic discounting is still a flaw. The more power we gain over our impulses, the better we can avoid this trap. The less power we have over our impulses—for example, when we are under the influence of alcohol—the more susceptible we are. Viewed from the other side: If you sell consumer products, give customers the option of getting their hands on the items right away. Some people will be willing to pay extra just so they don’t have to wait. Amazon makes a bundle from this: A healthy chunk of the next-day delivery surcharge goes directly into its coffers. “Live each day as if it were your last” is a good idea—once a week.

总结：虽然即时奖励极具诱惑力，但双曲线折扣仍然是一个缺陷。我们越能控制冲动，就越能避免这个陷阱。我们越无法控制冲动——例如，当我们受到酒精影响时——就越容易受到影响。从另一个角度来看：如果你销售消费品，就应该让顾客选择立即拿到商品。有些人愿意支付额外费用，这样他们就不用等待了。亚马逊从中赚得盆满钵满：次日达附加费的很大一部分直接进入了它的金库。“把每一天都当成最后一天来过”是个好主意——每周一次。

52

Any Lame Excuse

任何站不住脚的借口

“Because” Justification

“因为”的理由

T raffic jam on the highway between Los Angeles and San Francisco: surface repairs. I spent thirty minutes slowly battling my way through until the chaos was a distant scene in my rearview mirror. Or so I thought. Half an hour later, I was again bumper to bumper: more maintenance work. Strangely enough, my level of frustration was much lower this time. Why? Reassuringly cheerful signs along the road announced: “We’re renovating the highway for you!”

洛杉矶和旧金山之间的高速公路上堵车了：路面维修。我花了三十分钟慢慢地奋力前行，直到混乱的景象在我的后视镜里渐渐远去。或者说，我以为是这样的。半小时后，我又一次遇到了拥堵的车流：又是维修工作。奇怪的是，这次我的沮丧程度要低得多。为什么？因为路边令人安心的标牌上写着：“我们正在为您翻新高速公路！”

The jam reminded me of an experiment conducted by the Harvard psychologist Ellen Langer in the 1970s. For this, she went into a library and waited at a photocopier until a line had formed. Then she approached the first in line and said: “Excuse me, I have five pages. May I use the Xerox machine?” Her success rate was 60 percent. She repeated the experiment, this time giving a reason: “Excuse me. I have five pages. May I use the Xerox machine because I’m in a rush?” In almost all cases (94 percent), she was allowed to go ahead. This is understandable: If people are in a hurry, you often let them cut in to the front of the line. She tried yet another approach, this time saying: “Excuse me. I have five pages. May I go before you because I have to make some copies?” The result was amazing: Even though the pretext was (a-hem) paper-thin—after all, everyone was standing in line to make copies—she was allowed to pass to the front of the line in almost all cases (93 percent).

这次堵车让我想起了哈佛大学心理学家艾伦·兰格在20世纪70年代做的一个实验。实验中，她走进图书馆，在复印机前等到排好队。然后她走到排在第一位的人面前说：“不好意思，我还有五页纸，可以用复印机吗？”她的成功率是60%。她重复了这个实验，这次给出了一个理由：“不好意思，我还有五页纸，我赶时间，可以用复印机吗？”几乎所有情况下（94%），她都被允许先走。这很容易理解：如果人们很着急，你通常会让他们插队。她又尝试了另一种方法，这次说：“不好意思，我还有五页纸，我得复印一些，可以先走吗？”结果令人惊奇：尽管借口很薄弱（咳咳）——毕竟大家都在排队复印——但她几乎在所有情况下（93%）都被允许排到队伍的最前面。

When you justify your behavior, you encounter more tolerance and helpfulness. It seems to matter very little if your excuse is good or not. Using the simple validation “because” is sufficient. A sign proclaiming: “We’re renovating the highway for you” is completely redundant. What else would a maintenance crew be up to on a highway? If you hadn’t noticed before, you realize what is going on once you look out the window. And yet this knowledge reassures and calms you. After all, nothing is more frustrating than being kept in the dark.

当你为自己的行为辩解时，你会得到更多的宽容和帮助。你的借口是否合理似乎无关紧要。用简单的“因为”来确认就足够了。一块写着“我们正在为您整修高速公路”的牌子完全是多余的。高速公路上的养护人员还能干什么呢？如果你之前没有注意到，当你向窗外望去时，你就会意识到发生了什么。然而，这种了解会让你感到安心和平静。毕竟，没有什么比被蒙在鼓里更令人沮丧的了。

Gate A57 at JFK airport, waiting to board: An announcement comes over the loudspeaker: “Attention, passengers. Flight 1234 is delayed by three hours.” Wonderful. I walked to the desk to find out why. And came back no more enlightened. I was furious: How dare they leave us waiting in ignorance? Other airlines have the decency to announce: “Flight 5678 is delayed by three hours due to operational reasons.” A throwaway reason if ever there was one, but enough to appease passengers.

在肯尼迪机场A57号登机口等待登机：广播里传来一条广播：“各位乘客请注意。1234航班延误三小时。” 真是妙极了。我走到服务台想了解原因，结果回来后依然一无所获。我怒不可遏：他们怎么敢让我们在无知中苦苦等待？其他航空公司倒是挺体面的，会广播：“5678航班因运营原因延误三小时。” 就算有什么理由，也不过是一句敷衍的借口，但足以安抚乘客。

It seems people are addicted to the word “because”—so much so that we use it even when it’s not necessary. If you are a leader, undoubtedly you have witnessed this. If you provide no rallying call, employee motivation dwindles. It simply doesn’t make the grade to say that the purpose of your shoe company is to manufacture footwear. No, today, higher purposes and the story behind the story are all-important, such as: “We want our shoes to revolutionize the market” (whatever that means). “Better arch support for a better world!” (whatever that means). Zappo’s claims that it is in the happiness business (whatever that means).

人们似乎对“因为”这个词上瘾了——以至于即使没有必要，我们也会用它。如果你是一位领导者，你无疑见证了这一点。如果你没有号召员工，员工的积极性就会下降。说你的鞋业公司的目标是制造鞋类，这根本站不住脚。不，今天，更高的目标和背后的故事才是最重要的，比如：“我们希望我们的鞋子能够彻底改变市场”（不管这意味着什么）。“更好的足弓支撑，创造更美好的世界！”（不管这意味着什么）。Zappo声称自己从事的是幸福事业（不管这意味着什么）。

If the stock market rises or falls by half a percent, you will never hear the true cause from stock market commentators—that it is white noise, the culmination of an infinite number of market movements. No: People want a palpable reason, and the commentator is happy to select one. Whatever explanation he utters will be meaningless—with frequent blame applied to the pronouncements of Federal Reserve Bank presidents.

如果股市上涨或下跌半个百分点，你永远不会从股市评论员那里听到真正的原因——那是白噪音，是无数市场波动的累积结果。不：人们想要一个显而易见的理由，而评论员很乐意选择一个。无论他给出什么解释都毫无意义——美联储主席的言论经常被指责。

If someone asks why you have yet to complete a task, it’s best to say: “Because I haven’t got around to it yet.” It’s a pathetic excuse (had you done so, the conversation wouldn’t be taking place), but it usually does the trick without the need to scramble for more plausible reasons.

如果有人问你为什么还没有完成某项任务，最好这样说：“因为我还没来得及做。”这是一个可悲的借口（如果你这么做了，对话就不会发生了），但它通常能起到作用，而不需要你费力寻找更合理的理由。

One day I watched my wife carefully separating black laundry from blue. As far as I know, this effort isn’t necessary. Both are dark colors, right? Such logic has managed to keep my clothes run-free for many years. “Why do you do that?” I asked. “Because I prefer to wash them separately.” For me, a perfectly fine answer.

有一天，我看着妻子小心翼翼地把黑色衣物和蓝色衣物分开洗。据我所知，这完全没必要。两者都是深色的，对吧？这样的逻辑让我的衣服多年来一直保持干净。“你为什么这么做？”我问。“因为我喜欢分开洗。”对我来说，这完全没问题。

Never leave home without “because.” This unassuming little word greases the wheels of human interaction. Use it unrestrainedly.

出门时一定要说“因为”。这个不起眼的小词能让人际交往更加顺畅。不妨尽情使用它。

53

Decide Better—Decide Less

做出更好的决定——减少决定

Decision Fatigue

决策疲劳

F or weeks, you’ve been working to the point of exhaustion on this presentation. The PowerPoint slides are polished. Each figure in Excel is indisputable. The pitch is a paradigm of crystal-clear logic. Everything depends on your presentation. If you get the green light from the CEO, you’re on your way to a corner office. If the presentation flops, you’re on your way to the unemployment office. The CEO’s assistant proposes the following times for the presentation: 8:00 a.m., 11:30 a.m., or 6:00 p.m. Which slot do you choose?

几周以来，你一直在为这场演讲拼命工作，直到精疲力竭。PowerPoint 幻灯片精雕细琢，Excel 表格中每个数字都清晰无误。演讲稿逻辑清晰，堪称典范。一切都取决于你的演讲。如果 CEO 同意，你就能升职加薪了。如果演讲失败，你就只能去失业救济金办公室了。CEO 的助理建议的演讲时间是：上午 8:00、上午 11:30 或下午 6:00。你会选择哪个时间段？

The psychologist Roy Baumeister and collaborator Jean Twenge once covered a table with hundreds of inexpensive items—from tennis balls and candles to T-shirts, chewing gum, and Coke cans. He divided his students into two groups. The first group he labeled “deciders,” the second, “non-deciders.” He told the first group: “I’m going to show you sets containing two random items and each time you have to decide which you prefer. At the end of the experiment I’ll give you one item you can take home.” They were led to believe that their choices would influence which item they get to keep. To the second group, he said: “Write down what you think about each item, and I’ll pick one and give it to you at the end.” Immediately thereafter, he asked each student to put their hand in ice cold water and hold it there as long as possible. In psychology, this is a classic method to measure willpower or self-discipline; if you have little or none, you yank your hand back out of the water very quickly. The result: The deciders pulled their hands out of the icy water much sooner than the non-deciders did. The intensive decision making had drained their willpower—an effect confirmed in many other experiments.

心理学家罗伊·鲍迈斯特（Roy Baumeister）和同事让·特温格（Jean Twenge）曾经在桌子上摆满了数百种廉价物品——从网球、蜡烛到T恤、口香糖和可乐罐，应有尽有。他将学生分成两组。第一组被称为“决策者”，第二组被称为“非决策者”。他告诉第一组：“我会给你们展示一些包含两件随机物品的套装，每次你们都要决定自己喜欢哪一件。实验结束时，我会给你们一件可以带回家的物品。” 他们被引导相信，他们的选择会影响他们最终能保留哪件物品。他对第二组说：“写下你们对每件物品的看法，最后我会选一件给你们。” 紧接着，他要求每个学生把手伸进冰冷的水中，并尽可能长时间地保持在那里。在心理学中，这是衡量意志力或自律性的经典方法；如果你的意志力或自律性很弱或完全没有，你会很快把手从水里抽出来。结果是：决策者比非决策者更快地把手从冰冷的水中抽出来。密集的决策消耗了他们的意志力——这一效应已在其他许多实验中得到证实。

Making decisions is exhausting. Anyone who has ever configured a laptop online or researched a long trip—flight, hotels, activities, restaurants, weather—knows this well: After all the comparing, considering, and choosing, you are exhausted. Science calls this decision fatigue .

做决定真让人精疲力尽。任何曾经在线配置笔记本电脑或研究过长途旅行（航班、酒店、活动、餐厅、天气）的人都深有体会：经过所有的比较、考虑和选择，你会精疲力竭。科学界称之为决策疲劳。

Decision fatigue is perilous: As a consumer, you become more susceptible to advertising messages and impulse buys. As a decision maker, you are more prone to erotic seduction. Willpower is like a battery. After a while it runs out and needs to be recharged. How do you do this? By taking a break, relaxing, and eating something. Willpower plummets to zero if your blood sugar falls too low. IKEA knows this only too well: On the trek through its mazelike display areas and towering warehouse shelves, decision fatigue sets in. For this reason, its restaurants are located right in the middle of the stores. The company is willing to sacrifice some of its profit margin so that you can top up your blood sugar on Swedish treats before resuming your hunt for the perfect candlesticks.

决策疲劳的危害极大：作为消费者，你更容易受到广告信息和冲动购物的影响。作为决策者，你更容易受到情色诱惑。意志力就像电池，用不了多久就会耗尽，需要充电。该如何充电呢？休息一下，放松一下，吃点东西。如果血糖过低，意志力就会骤降为零。宜家对此深有体会：在迷宫般的展示区和高耸的仓库货架间穿梭，决策疲劳便会油然而生。因此，宜家将餐厅设在商场的正中央。该公司愿意牺牲部分利润率，让你先用瑞典美食补充一下血糖，然后再继续寻找完美的烛台。

Four prisoners in an Israeli jail petitioned the court for early release. Case 1 (scheduled for 8:50 a.m.): an Arab sentenced to thirty months in prison for fraud. Case 2 (scheduled for 1:27 p.m.): a Jew sentenced to sixteen months for assault. Case 3 (scheduled for 3:10 p.m.): a Jew sentenced to sixteen months for assault. Case 4 (scheduled for 4:35 p.m.), an Arab sentenced to thirty months for fraud. How did the judges decide? More significant than the detainees’ allegiance or the severity of their crimes was the judges’ decision fatigue . The judges granted requests 1 and 2 because their blood sugar was still high (from breakfast or lunch). However, they struck out applications 3 and 4 because they could not summon enough energy to risk the consequences of an early release. They took the easy option (the status quo) and the men remained in jail. A study of hundreds of verdicts shows that within a session, the percentage of “courageous” judicial decisions gradually drops from 65 percent to almost zero, and after a recess, returns to 65 percent. So much for the careful deliberations of Lady Justice. But, as long as you have no upcoming trials, all is not lost: You now know when to present your project to the CEO.

以色列监狱的四名囚犯向法庭申请提前释放。案例 1（预定于上午 8:50 开庭）：一名阿拉伯人因诈骗被判处 30 个月监禁。案例 2（预定于下午 1:27 开庭）：一名犹太人因袭击被判处 16 个月监禁。案例 3（预定于下午 3:10 开庭）：一名犹太人因袭击被判处 16 个月监禁。案例 4（预定于下午 4:35 开庭），一名阿拉伯人因诈骗被判处 30 个月监禁。法官如何判决？比囚犯的忠诚度或罪行严重程度更重要的是法官的决策疲劳。法官批准了申请 1 和 2，因为他们的血糖仍然很高（早餐或午餐时）。然而，他们驳回了申请 3 和 4，因为他们没有足够的精力去承担提前释放的风险。他们选择了简单的选项（维持现状），这些人仍然被关在监狱里。一项对数百份判决的研究表明，在一次开庭期间，“勇敢”的司法裁决比例逐渐从65%下降到几乎为零，休庭后又回升到65%。正义女神的审慎审议就到此为止了。不过，只要你没有即将进行的庭审，一切就还好：你现在知道什么时候该向CEO汇报你的项目了。

54

Would You Wear Hitler’s Sweater?

你会穿希特勒的毛衣吗？

Contagion Bias

传染偏差

F ollowing the collapse of the Carolingian Empire in the ninth century, Europe, especially France, descended into anarchy. Counts, commanders, knights, and other local rulers were perpetually embroiled in battles. The ruthless warriors looted farms, raped women, trampled fields, kidnapped pastors, and set convents alight. Both the Church and the unarmed farmers were powerless against the nobles’ savage warmongering.

公元9世纪加洛林帝国覆灭后，欧洲，尤其是法国，陷入了无政府状态。伯爵、统帅、骑士以及其他地方统治者无休止地卷入战火。残暴的战士洗劫农场，强奸妇女，践踏田地，绑架牧师，焚烧修道院。无论是教会还是手无寸铁的农民，都无力抵抗贵族们野蛮的战争。

In the tenth century, a French bishop had an idea. He asked the princes and knights to assemble in a field. Meanwhile, priests, bishops, and abbots gathered all the relics that they could muster from the area and displayed them there. It was a striking sight: bones, blood-soaked rags, bricks, and tiles—anything that had ever come in contact with a saint. The bishop, at that time a person of respect, then called upon the nobles, in the presence of the relics, to renounce unbridled violence and attacks against the unarmed. In order to add weight to his demand, he waved the bloody clothes and holy bones in front of them. The nobles must have had enormous reverence for such symbols: The bishop’s unique appeal to their conscience spread throughout Europe, promoting the “Peace and Truce of God.” “One should never underestimate the fear of saints in the Middle Ages and of saints’ relics,” says American historian Philip Daileader.

公元十世纪，一位法国主教想出了一个主意。他召集诸侯和骑士们聚集在一片田野里。与此同时，神父、主教和修道院院长们把他们能从那里找到的所有圣物都收集起来，摆在那里。场面令人震撼：尸骨、血迹斑斑的破布、砖瓦——任何曾经与圣人接触过的东西，都随处可见。这位当时德高望重的主教，在圣物面前呼吁贵族们放弃肆无忌惮的暴力和对手无寸铁之人的袭击。为了增强他的要求，主教在贵族面前挥舞着沾满鲜血的圣衣和圣骨。贵族们对这些象征物必定怀有崇敬之情：主教对贵族们良知的独特感召力传遍了整个欧洲，宣扬着“上帝的和平与休战”。美国历史学家菲利普·戴利德说：“永远不要低估中世纪人们对圣徒和圣徒遗物的恐惧。”

As an enlightened person, you can only laugh at this silly superstition. But wait: What if I put it to you this way? Would you put on a freshly laundered sweater that Hitler had once worn? Probably not, right? So, it seems that you haven’t lost all respect for intangible forces, either. Essentially, this sweater has nothing to do with Hitler anymore. There isn’t a single molecule of Hitler’s sweat on it. However, the prospect of putting it on still puts you off. It’s more than just a matter of respect. Yes, we want to project a “correct” image to our fellow humans and to ourselves, but the thought puts us off even when we are alone and when we convince ourselves that touching this sweater does not endorse Hitler in any way. This emotional reaction is difficult to override. Even those who consider themselves quite rational have a hard time completely banishing the belief in mysterious forces (me included).

作为一个开明人士，你只能对这种愚蠢的迷信一笑置之。但且慢：如果我这样问你呢？你会穿上希特勒曾经穿过的一件刚洗好的毛衣吗？可能不会，对吧？看来你对那些无形的力量也并没有完全失去敬畏。本质上，这件毛衣已经和希特勒没有任何关系了。上面连希特勒的汗水分子都没有。然而，穿上它的念头仍然让你望而却步。这不仅仅是尊重的问题。没错，我们想要在人类同胞和我们自己面前展现一个“正确”的形象，但即使我们独自一人，即使我们说服自己触摸这件毛衣并不意味着以任何方式认可希特勒，这种想法仍然会让我们望而却步。这种情绪反应很难克服。即使是那些自认为非常理性的人，也很难完全摆脱对神秘力量的信仰（包括我自己）。

Mysterious powers of this kind can’t simply be switched off. Paul Rozin and his research colleagues at the University of Pennsylvania asked test subjects to bring in photos of loved ones. These were pinned to the center of targets and the subjects had to shoot darts at them. Riddling a picture with darts does no harm to the person in it but, nevertheless, the subjects’ hesitation was palpable. They were much less accurate than a control group that had shot at regular targets beforehand. The test subjects behaved as if a mystic force prevented them from hitting the photos.

这种神秘的力量无法轻易关闭。宾夕法尼亚大学的保罗·罗津和他的同事们要求测试对象带上他们所爱之人的照片。这些照片被钉在靶心，测试对象必须用飞镖射向照片。虽然用飞镖射穿照片不会对照片中的人造成伤害，但测试对象的犹豫却显而易见。他们的准确率远低于事先射过常规靶的对照组。测试对象的行为就像有一股神秘力量阻止他们射中照片一样。

The contagion bias describes how we are incapable of ignoring the connection we feel to certain items—be they from long ago or only indirectly related (as with the photos). A friend was a longtime war correspondent for the French public television channel France 2. Just as passengers on a Caribbean cruise take home souvenirs from each island—a straw hat or a painted coconut—my friend also collected mementos from her adventures. One of her last missions was to Baghdad in 2003. A few hours after American troops stormed Saddam Hussein’s government palace, she crept into the private quarters. In the dining room, she spotted six gold-plated wineglasses and promptly commandeered them. When I attended one of her dinner parties in Paris recently, the gilded goblets had pride of place on the dining table. “Are these from Galeries Lafayette?” one person asked. “No, they are from Saddam Hussein,” she said candidly. A horrified guest spat his wine back into the glass and began to splutter uncontrollably. I had to contribute: “You realize how many molecules you’ve already shared with Saddam, simply by breathing?” I asked. “About a billion per breath.” His cough got even worse.

传染性偏见描述了我们如何无法忽视与某些物品之间的联系——无论它们是很久以前的，还是仅仅间接相关的（比如照片）。我的一位朋友是法国公共电视台法国二台的长期战地记者。就像加勒比海游轮上的乘客会从每个岛屿带回纪念品——一顶草帽或一个彩绘椰子——我的朋友也会收集她冒险经历中的纪念品。她最后一次执行的任务之一是2003年的巴格达。美军突袭萨达姆·侯赛因的政府官邸几个小时后，她潜入了私人住所。在餐厅里，她发现了六个镀金酒杯，并立即将它们占为己有。最近我参加她在巴黎的一次晚宴时，这些镀金酒杯在餐桌上占据了显眼的位置。“这些是从老佛爷百货买的吗？”有人问道。“不，它们是萨达姆·侯赛因的，”她坦率地回答。一位客人吓得把酒吐回了杯子里，开始控制不住地喘息。我不得不插嘴道：“你知道吗，仅仅通过呼吸，你已经和萨达姆分享了多少分子？”我问道。“每次呼吸大概有十亿个。”他的咳嗽变得更厉害了。

55

Why There Is No Such Thing as an Average War

为什么不存在所谓的“普通战争”

The Problem with Averages

平均值的问题

S uppose you’re on a bus with forty-nine other people. At the next stop, the heaviest person in America gets on. Question: By how much has the average weight of the passengers increased? Four percent? Five? Something like that? Suppose the bus stops again, and on gets Bill Gates. This time we are not concerned about weight. Question: By how much has the average wealth risen? Four percent? Five? Far from it!

假设你和另外49个人一起坐公交车。下一站，美国最胖的人上车了。问题：乘客的平均体重增加了多少？4%？5%？还是差不多？假设公交车再次停下，比尔·盖茨上车了。这次我们不再关心体重。问题：平均财富增加了多少？4%？5%？远非如此！

Let’s calculate the second example quickly. Suppose each of fifty randomly selected individuals has assets of $54,000. This is the statistical middle value, the median. Then Bill Gates is added to the mix, with his fortune of around $59 billion. The average wealth has just shot up to $1.15 billion, an increase of more than two million percent. A single outlier has radically altered the picture, rendering the term “average” completely meaningless.

让我们快速计算一下第二个例子。假设随机选取50个人，每人资产5.4万美元。这是统计的中间值，即中位数。然后把比尔·盖茨也算进去，他的财富约为590亿美元。平均财富刚刚飙升至11.5亿美元，增幅超过200万个百分点。一个异常值彻底改变了这一格局，使得“平均”一词完全失去了意义。

“Don’t cross a river if it is ( on average ) four feet deep,” warns Nassim Taleb, from whom I have the above examples. The river can be very shallow for long stretches—mere inches—but it might transform into a raging torrent that is twenty feet deep in the middle—in which case you could easily drown. Dealing in averages is a risky undertaking because they often mask the underlying distribution—the way the values stack up.

“如果一条河（平均）只有四英尺深，就不要过河，”纳西姆·塔勒布警告说，我上面的例子就是从他那里得到的。一条河可能在很长一段很浅——只有几英寸——但它也可能变成一条湍急的急流，中间有二十英尺深——在这种情况下，你很容易被淹死。研究平均值是一项冒险的行为，因为它们往往会掩盖潜在的分布——价值的累积方式。

Another example: The average amount of UV rays you are exposed to on a June day is not harmful to your health. But if you were to spend the entire summer in a darkened office, then fly to Barbados and lie in the sun without sunscreen for a week solid, you would have a problem—even though, on average over the summer, you were not getting more UV light than someone who was regularly outside.

再举个例子：你在六月一天中接触到的平均紫外线量对你的健康无害。但如果你整个夏天都待在昏暗的办公室里，然后飞往巴巴多斯，连续一周不涂防晒霜地躺在阳光下，你就会出问题——尽管平均而言，你整个夏天接触到的紫外线量并不比经常在户外的人多。

All this is quite straightforward and maybe you were aware of it already. For example, you drink one glass of red wine for dinner every evening. That’s not a health issue. Many doctors recommend it. But if you drink no alcohol the entire year and on December 31 you gulp 356 glasses, which is equivalent to sixty bottles, you will have a problem, although the average over the year is the same.

这一切都很简单，也许你已经意识到了。比如，你每天晚餐喝一杯红酒。这不会对健康造成影响。很多医生都建议这样做。但如果你全年不喝酒，但在12月31日你喝了356杯，相当于60瓶，你就会有问题，尽管全年的平均值是一样的。

Here’s the update: In a complex world, distribution is becoming more and more irregular. In other words, we will observe the Bill Gates phenomenon in ever more domains. How many visits does an average website get? The answer is: There are no average websites. A handful of sites (such as the New York Times , Facebook, or Google) garner the majority of visits, and countless other pages draw comparatively few. In such cases, mathematicians speak of the so-called power law. Take cities. There is one city on this planet with a population of more than thirty million: Tokyo. There are eleven cities with a population of between twenty and thirty million. There are fifteen cities with a population of between ten and twenty million. There are forty-eight cities between five and ten million inhabitants. And thousands (!) between one and five million. That’s a power law. A few extremes dominate the distribution, and the concept of average is rendered worthless.

最新消息是：在一个复杂的世界中，分布变得越来越不规则。换句话说，我们将在越来越多的领域观察到比尔·盖茨现象。一个普通网站的访问量是多少？答案是：没有普通的网站。少数网站（例如纽约时报、Facebook 或 Google）占据了大部分访问量，而无数其他页面的访问量相对较少。在这种情况下，数学家们谈到了所谓的幂律。以城市为例。这个星球上有一个城市的人口超过三千万：东京。有十一个城市的人口在两千万到三千万之间。有十五个城市的人口在一千万到两千万之间。有四十八个城市的居民在五百万到一千万之间。还有数千个城市（！）的居民在一百万到五百万之间。这就是幂律。一些极端情况主导着分布，平均的概念变得毫无价值。

What is the average size of a company? What is the average population of a city? What is an average war (in terms of deaths or duration)? What is the average daily fluctuation in the Dow Jones? What is the average cost overrun of construction projects? How many copies does an average book sell? What is the average amount of damage a hurricane wreaks? What is a banker’s average bonus? What is the average success of a marketing campaign? How many downloads does an average iPhone app get? How much money does an average actor earn? Of course you can calculate the answers, but it would be a waste of time. These seemingly routine scenarios are subject to the power law.

一家公司的平均规模是多少？一座城市的平均人口是多少？一场战争的平均规模是多少（以死亡人数或持续时间计算）？道琼斯指数的平均每日波动率是多少？建筑项目的平均成本超支是多少？一本书平均售出多少本？一场飓风造成的平均损失是多少？银行家的平均奖金是多少？营销活动的平均成功率是多少？一款iPhone应用的平均下载量是多少？一位演员的平均收入是多少？当然，你可以计算出答案，但这太浪费时间了。这些看似常规的场景都遵循幂律。

To use just the final example: A handful of actors take home more than $10 million per year, while thousands and thousands live on the breadline. Would you advise your son or daughter to get into acting since the average wage is pretty decent? Hopefully not—wrong reason.

再举最后一个例子：少数演员年薪超过1000万美元，而成千上万的人却生活在贫困线以下。既然平均工资相当不错，你会建议自己的儿子或女儿从事演艺事业吗？希望不会——理由错了。

In conclusion: If someone uses the word “average,” think twice. Try to work out the underlying distribution. If a single anomaly has almost no influence on the set, the concept is still worthwhile. However, when extreme cases dominate (such as the Bill Gates phenomenon), we should discount the term “average.” We should all take stock from novelist William Gibson: “The future is already here—it’s just not very evenly distributed.”

总结：如果有人使用“平均”这个词，请三思。试着弄清楚潜在的分布。如果一个异常值对整体几乎没有影响，这个概念仍然有价值。然而，当极端情况占主导地位时（例如比尔·盖茨现象），我们就不应该使用“平均”这个词了。我们都应该借鉴小说家威廉·吉布森的一句话：“未来已来——只是分布不太均匀。”

56

How Bonuses Destroy Motivation

奖金如何摧毁动力

Motivation Crowding

动机拥挤

A few months ago, a friend from Connecticut decided to move to New York City. This man had a fabulous collection of antiques, such as exquisite old books and handblown Murano glasses from generations ago. I knew how attached he was to them, and how anxious he would be handing them over to a moving company, so the last time I visited, I offered to carry the most fragile items with me when I returned to the city. Two weeks later I got a thank-you letter. Enclosed was a $50 bill.

几个月前，一位来自康涅狄格州的朋友决定搬到纽约。他收藏了许多古董，比如精美的古书和几代人以前手工吹制的穆拉诺玻璃杯。我知道他对这些古董珍爱有加，也知道他急于把它们交给搬家公司，所以上次拜访时，我主动提出回纽约时帮我带上那些最易碎的物品。两周后，我收到了一封感谢信，里面附了一张50美元的钞票。

For years, Switzerland has been considering where to store its radioactive waste. The authorities considered a few different locations for the underground repository, including the village of Wolfenschiessen in the center of the country. Economist Bruno Frey and his fellow researchers at the University of Zurich traveled there and recorded people’s opinions at a community meeting. Surprisingly, 50.8 percent were in favor of the proposal. Their positive response can be attributed to several factors: national pride, common decency, social obligation, the prospect of new jobs, and so on. The team carried out the survey a second time, but this time they mentioned a hypothetical reward of $5,000 for each townsperson, paid for by Swiss taxpayers, if they were to accept the proposal. What happened? Results plummeted: Only 24.6 percent were willing to endorse the proposal.

多年来，瑞士一直在考虑将放射性废料储存在何处。当局曾考虑过几个不同的地下处置库地点，其中包括位于瑞士中部的沃尔芬希森村。苏黎世大学的经济学家布鲁诺·弗雷和他的同事们前往当地，并在一次社区会议上记录了民众的意见。令人惊讶的是，50.8% 的受访者支持该提议。他们的积极回应可以归因于几个因素：民族自豪感、基本道德、社会责任感、新的就业前景等等。该团队进行了第二次调查，但这次他们提出，如果居民接受该提议，将由瑞士纳税人支付，为每位居民提供 5,000 美元的奖励。结果如何？结果急剧下降：只有 24.6% 的受访者愿意支持该提议。

Another example is children’s day care centers. Day care workers face the same issue the world over: parents collecting their children after closing time. The staff has no choice but to wait. They can hardly put the last remaining children in taxis or leave them on the curb. To discourage parental tardiness, many nurseries introduced fees for lateness. Ironically, studies show that tardiness actually increased. Of course, they could have instituted a draconian penalty of, say, $500 for each hour—as they could have offered $1 million to each citizen of the small Swiss village. But that’s beside the point. The point is: Small—surprisingly small—monetary incentives crowd out other types of incentives.

另一个例子是儿童日托中心。世界各地的日托中心工作人员都面临着同样的问题：家长在关门后才来接孩子。工作人员别无选择，只能等待。他们很难把最后剩下的孩子送上出租车，或者把他们留在路边。为了防止家长迟到，许多托儿所对迟到者收取费用。讽刺的是，研究表明，迟到的情况实际上有所增加。当然，他们本可以制定严厉的惩罚措施，比如每小时罚款500美元——就像他们本可以向瑞士小村庄的每个公民提供100万美元一样。但这不是重点。重点是：小额——小得惊人的——金钱激励会挤占其他类型的激励。

The three stories illustrate one thing: Money does not always motivate. Indeed, in many cases, it does just the opposite. When my friend slipped me that fifty, he undermined my good deed—and also tainted our friendship. The offer of compensation for the nuclear repository was perceived as a bribe and cheapened the community and patriotic spirit. The nursery’s late fees transformed its relationship with parents from interpersonal to monetary, and essentially legitimized their lateness.

这三个故事说明了一件事：金钱并不总是能激励人心。事实上，在很多情况下，它的作用恰恰相反。当我的朋友偷偷给我那五十块钱时，他破坏了我的善举，也玷污了我们的友谊。核储存库的补偿方案被视为贿赂，贬低了社区和爱国精神。托儿所的逾期费使其与家长的关系从人际关系转变为金钱关系，并从本质上使他们的迟到合法化。

Science has a name for this phenomenon: motivation crowding . When people do something for well-meaning, nonmonetary reasons—out of the goodness of their hearts, so to speak—payments throw a wrench into the works. Financial reward erodes any other motivations.

科学上对这种现象有个名字：动机拥挤。当人们出于善意而非金钱的原因——也就是所谓的好心——做某事时，报酬就会给他们带来阻碍。金钱奖励会侵蚀任何其他动机。

Suppose you run a nonprofit organization. Logically, the wages you pay are quite modest. Nevertheless, your employees are highly motivated because they believe they are making a difference. If you suddenly introduce a bonus system—let’s say a small salary increase for every donation secured— motivation crowding will commence. Your team will begin to snub tasks that bring no extra reward. Creativity, company reputation, knowledge transfer—none of this will matter anymore. Soon, all efforts will zoom in on attracting donations.

假设你经营着一家非营利组织。按理说，你支付的工资很低。然而，你的员工积极性很高，因为他们相信自己正在做出改变。如果你突然引入奖金制度——比如说，每获得一笔捐款，工资就会小幅上涨——就会出现“动力拥挤”现象。你的团队会开始冷落那些没有额外回报的任务。创造力、公司声誉、知识转移——所有这些都将不再重要。很快，所有的努力都将集中在吸引捐款上。

So who is safe from motivation crowding ? This tip should help: Do you know any private bankers, insurance agents, or financial auditors who do their jobs out of passion or who believe in a higher mission? I don’t. Financial incentives and performance bonuses work well in industries with generally uninspiring jobs—industries where employees aren’t proud of the products or the companies and do the work simply because they get a paycheck. On the other hand, if you create a start-up, you would be wise to enlist employee enthusiasm to promote the company’s endeavor rather than try to entice employees with juicy bonuses, which you couldn’t pay anyway.

那么，谁能避免“动机拥挤”呢？以下建议应该有所帮助：你认识哪些私人银行家、保险代理人或财务审计师，他们工作时出于热情或怀揣着更高的使命吗？我认识的没有。财务激励和绩效奖金在工作普遍缺乏激情的行业中效果很好——在这些行业中，员工对产品或公司并不感到自豪，工作仅仅是为了拿到薪水。另一方面，如果你创办一家初创企业，明智的做法是激发员工的热情，推动公司的发展，而不是试图用丰厚的奖金来吸引员工，因为你无论如何都无法支付这些奖金。

One final tip for those of you who have children: Experience shows that young people are not for sale. If you want your kids to do their homework, practice musical instruments, or even mow the lawn once in a while, do not reach for your wallet. Instead, give them a fixed amount of pocket money each week. Otherwise, they will exploit the system and soon refuse to go to bed without recompense.

最后给有孩子的家长们一个建议：经验表明，年轻人是不能买卖的。如果你想让孩子做作业、练习乐器，甚至偶尔修剪一下草坪，都不要掏钱包。相反，每周给他们固定数额的零花钱。否则，他们很快就会利用这个制度，不给零花钱就赖床。

57

If You Have Nothing to Say, Say Nothing

如果你无话可说，那就什么也别说

Twaddle Tendency

废话倾向

W hen asked why a fifth of Americans were unable to locate their country on a world map, Miss Teen South Carolina, a high school graduate, gave this answer in front of rolling cameras: “I personally believe that U.S. Americans are unable to do so because some people out there in our nation don’t have maps, and I believe that our education like such as South Africa and the Iraq everywhere like such as and I believe that they should our education over here in the U.S. should help the U.S., should help South Africa, and should help the Iraq and the Asian countries, so we will be able to build up our future.” The video went viral.

当被问及为什么五分之一的美国人无法在世界地图上找到自己的国家时，南卡罗来纳州的青少年小姐，一位高中毕业生，在滚动的镜头前给出了这样的答案：“我个人认为，美国人无法做到这一点，因为我们国家的一些人没有地图，我相信我们的教育应该像南非和伊拉克这样的国家一样，我相信我们在美国的教育应该帮助美国，应该帮助南非，应该帮助伊拉克和亚洲国家，这样我们才能建设我们的未来。”这段视频在网上疯传。

Catastrophic, you agree, but you don’t waste too much time listening to beauty queens. Okay, how about the following sentence? “There is certainly no necessity that this increasingly reflexive transmission of cultural traditions be associated with subject-centered reason and future-oriented historical consciousness. To the extent that we become aware of the intersubjective constitution of freedom, the possessive-individualist illusion of autonomy as self-ownership disintegrates.” Ring any bells? Top German philosopher and sociologist Jürgen Habermas in Between Facts and Norms .

你同意这是灾难性的，但你不会浪费太多时间听选美皇后的废话。好吧，下面这句话怎么样？“这种日益反思性的文化传统传承，当然没有必要与以主体为中心的理性和面向未来的历史意识联系起来。当我们意识到自由的主体间性构成时，那种将自治视为自我所有制的占有主义个人主义幻觉就会瓦解。” 有没有想起什么？德国顶级哲学家、社会学家尤尔根·哈贝马斯在《事实与规范之间》中写道。

Both of these are manifestations of the same phenomenon, the twaddle tendency. Here, reams of words are used to disguise intellectual laziness, stupidity, or underdeveloped ideas. Sometimes it works, sometimes not. For the beauty queen, the smoke screen strategy failed spectacularly. For Habermas, it has worked so far. The more eloquent the haze of words, the more easily we fall for them. If used in conjunction with the authority bias , such drivel can be especially dangerous.

这两种做法都体现了同一种现象——“胡言乱语倾向”。这种倾向用大量的言辞来掩盖知识上的懒惰、愚蠢或不成熟的思想。有时有效，有时无效。对这位选美皇后来说，烟幕策略彻底失败了。但对哈贝马斯来说，它迄今为止一直有效。言辞越雄辩，我们就越容易上当。如果与权威偏见结合使用，这种胡言乱语就尤其危险。

I myself have fallen for the twaddle tendency on many occasions. When I was younger, French philosopher Jacques Derrida fascinated me. I devoured his books, but even after intense reflection I still couldn’t understand much. Subsequently his writings took on a mysterious aura, and the whole experience drove me to write my dissertation on philosophy. In retrospect, both were tomes of useless chatter—Derrida and my dissertation. In my ignorance, I had turned myself into a walking, talking smoke machine.

我自己也曾多次陷入这种胡言乱语的倾向。年轻时，法国哲学家雅克·德里达深深吸引着我。我如饥似渴地阅读他的著作，但即使经过深思熟虑，我仍然无法理解太多。后来，他的著作披上了一层神秘的色彩，这段经历促使我撰写了哲学论文。现在回想起来，德里达和我的论文都只是些空洞的废话。我一无所知，把自己变成了一台行走的、会说话的烟雾机。

The twaddle tendency is especially rife in sport. Breathless interviewers push equally breathless football players to break down the components of the game, when all they want to say is: “We lost the game—it’s really that simple.” But the presenter has to fill airtime somehow—and seemingly the best method is by jabbering away, and by compelling the athletes and coaches to join in. Jabber disguises ignorance.

这种废话倾向在体育界尤其盛行。气喘吁吁的采访者会逼迫同样气喘吁吁的足球运动员分析比赛的各个环节，而他们真正想说的只是：“我们输了比赛——就这么简单。” 但主持人总得想办法填补播出时间——而最好的办法似乎就是喋喋不休，并迫使运动员和教练也加入进来。喋喋不休掩盖了无知。

This phenomenon has also taken root in the academic spheres. The fewer results a branch of science publishes, the more babble is necessary. Particularly exposed are economists, which we can see in their comments and economic forecasts. The same is true for commerce on a smaller scale: The worse off a company is, the greater the talk of the CEO. The extra chatter extends to not just a lot of talking, but to hyperactivity also designed to mask the hardship. A laudable exception is the former CEO of General Electric Jack Welch. He once said in an interview: “You would not believe how difficult it is to be simple and clear. People are afraid that they may be seen as a simpleton. In reality, just the opposite is true.”

这种现象在学术界也根深蒂固。一个科学分支发表的成果越少，就越需要喋喋不休。经济学家尤其容易受到影响，这一点我们可以从他们的评论和经济预测中看出。同样的情况也发生在规模较小的商业领域：一家公司的状况越差，首席执行官的言论就越多。这种喋喋不休不仅体现在滔滔不绝的讲话中，还体现在为了掩盖困境而过度活跃的行动中。一个值得称赞的例外是通用电气前首席执行官杰克·韦尔奇。他曾在一次采访中说：“你可能无法想象，保持简单明了是多么困难。人们担心自己会被视为傻瓜。但事实恰恰相反。”

In conclusion: Verbal expression is the mirror of the mind. Clear thoughts become clear statements, whereas ambiguous ideas transform into vacant ramblings. The trouble is that, in many cases, we lack very lucid thoughts. The world is complicated, and it takes a great deal of mental effort to understand even one facet of the whole. Until you experience such an epiphany, it’s better to heed Mark Twain: “If you have nothing to say, say nothing.” Simplicity is the zenith of a long, arduous journey, not the starting point.

总而言之：言语表达是心灵的镜子。清晰的思路会变成清晰的陈述，而模糊的想法则会变成空洞的胡言乱语。问题在于，在很多情况下，我们缺乏清晰的思路。世界错综复杂，即使只是理解整体的一个侧面，也需要付出巨大的脑力劳动。在你获得这样的顿悟之前，最好还是听听马克·吐温的名言：“如果你无话可说，那就什么也别说。” 简洁是漫长而艰辛的旅程的顶峰，而非起点。

58

How to Increase the Average IQ of Two States

如何提高两个州的平均智商

Will Rogers Phenomenon

威尔·罗杰斯现象

L et’s say you run a small private bank. The bank manages the money of wealthy and mostly retired individuals. Two money managers—A and B—report to you. Money Manager A manages the money of a few ultra-high-net-worth individuals. Money Manager B has rich, but not extravagantly rich, clients to deal with. The board asks you to increase the average pool of money of both A and B—within six months. If you succeed, you receive a handsome bonus. If not, they’ll find someone else to do it. Where do you start?

假设你经营着一家小型私人银行。这家银行管理着富人的资金，其中大多数是退休人士。你手下有两位基金经理——A 和 B。基金经理 A 管理着几位超高净值人士的资金。基金经理 B 的客户虽然富裕，但并非富可敌国。董事会要求你在六个月内增加 A 和 B 的平均资金池。如果你成功了，你将获得丰厚的奖金。如果失败，他们会另寻他人。你该从何入手？

It’s quite simple, actually: You take a client with a sizable but not a huge pool of money from A and give it to B instead. In one fell swoop, this brings up A’s average managed wealth as well as B’s without you having to find a single new client. The only remaining question is: How will you spend your bonus?

其实很简单：你从A公司接手一个资金池规模可观但不算巨额的客户，然后把钱交给B公司。这样一来，A公司和B公司的平均管理财富就能同时增加，而你无需再寻找任何新客户。剩下的唯一问题是：你打算如何使用你的奖金？

Suppose you switch careers and are now in charge of three hedge funds that invest primarily in privately held companies. Fund A has sensational returns, fund B’s are mediocre, and fund C’s are miserable. You want to prove yourself to the world, so what’s your master plan? You know how it works now: You move a few of A’s shares to B and C—picking exactly those investments that have been pulling down A’s average returns, but which are still profitable enough to fortify B and C.
