In no time, all three funds look much healthier. And, because the transformation happened in-house, you don’t incur a single fee. Of course, the combined value of the trio hasn’t risen by a single cent, but people will still pat you on the back.

假设你转行，现在负责三支主要投资私人控股公司的对冲基金。基金A的回报惊人，基金B表现平平，基金C则惨不忍睹。你想向世界证明自己，那么你的总体规划是什么呢？你现在知道该怎么做了：你将A基金的部分股票转移到B基金和C基金——精准地挑选那些拉低A基金平均回报，但仍然足以支撑B基金和C基金的投资。很快，这三支基金看起来都健康多了。而且，由于转型是在内部进行的，你无需支付任何费用。当然，这三支基金的总价值一分钱都没涨，但人们仍然会拍拍你的肩膀。

This effect is called “stage migration” or the Will Rogers phenomenon , named after an American comedian from Oklahoma. He is said to have joked that Oklahomans who pack up and move to California raise both states’ average IQ. Since we rarely recognize such scenarios, let’s drill the Will Rogers phenomenon to anchor it in your memory.

这种效应被称为“阶段性迁移”或威尔·罗杰斯现象，以一位来自俄克拉荷马州的美国喜剧演员命名。据说他曾开玩笑说，收拾行李搬到加州的俄克拉荷马人会提高两个州的平均智商。鉴于我们很少意识到这种情况，让我们来回顾一下威尔·罗杰斯现象，以便牢牢记住它。

One good example is an auto franchise. Let’s say you take charge of two small branches in the same town with a total of six salesmen: numbers 1, 2, and 3 in branch A, and numbers 4, 5, and 6 in branch B. On average, salesman number 1 sells one car per week, salesman number 2 sells two cars per week, and so on up to top salesman number 6, who shifts six cars each week. With a little calculation, you know that branch A sells two cars per salesman, whereas branch B is far ahead with an average of five cars per salesman per week. You decide to transfer salesman number 4 to branch A. What happens? Its average sales increase to 2.5 units per person. And branch B? It now consists of only two salesmen, numbers 5 and 6. Its average sales increase to 5.5 per person. Such switcheroo strategies don’t change anything overall, but they create an impressive illusion. For this reason, journalists, investors, and board members should be on special alert when they hear of rising averages in countries, companies, departments, cost centers, or product lines.

汽车专营店就是一个很好的例子。假设你负责同一个城镇的两个小分店，总共有六名销售员：分店 A 中的 1、2 和 3 号，分店 B 中的 4、5 和 6 号。平均而言，1 号销售员每周销售一辆汽车，2 号销售员每周销售两辆汽车，依此类推，直到顶级销售员 6 号，他每周销售六辆汽车。稍加计算，你就会知道分店 A 中每位销售员销售两辆汽车，而分店 B 中则遥遥领先，平均每位销售员每周销售五辆汽车。你决定将 4 号销售员调到分店 A。发生了什么？其平均销售额增加到每人 2.5 辆。那么分店 B 呢？现在它只有两名销售员，5 号和 6 号。其平均销售额增加到每人 5.5 辆。这种调换策略并不能改变整体情况，但它们创造了一种令人印象深刻的假象。因此，当记者、投资者和董事会成员听说某个国家、某个公司、某个部门、某个成本中心或某个产品线的平均水平上升时，应该特别警惕。

A particularly deceitful case of the Will Rogers phenomenon is found in medicine. Tumors are usually broken down into four stages: The smallest and most treatable ones are classified as stage one; the worst are rated stage four. Their progression gives us the term “stage migration.” The survival rate is highest for stage one patients and lowest for stage four patients. Now, every year new procedures are released onto the market and allow for more accurate diagnosis. These new screening techniques reveal minuscule tumors that no doctor had ever noticed before. The result: Patients who were erroneously diagnosed as healthy before are now counted as stage one patients. The addition of relatively healthy people into the stage one group increases the group’s average life expectancy. A great medical success? Unfortunately not: mere stage migration .

威尔·罗杰斯现象在医学上有一个特别具有欺骗性的例子。肿瘤通常分为四个阶段：最小且最易治疗的肿瘤归类为第一阶段；最严重的肿瘤归类为第四阶段。它们的进展使我们有了“阶段迁移”一词。第一阶段患者的存活率最高，第四阶段患者的存活率最低。现在，每年都有新的治疗方法推向市场，使诊断更加准确。这些新的筛查技术可以发现以前医生从未注意到的微小肿瘤。结果是：以前被误诊为健康的患者现在被算作第一阶段患者。将相对健康的人纳入第一阶段人群可以提高该人群的平均预期寿命。这是医学上的伟大成就吗？不幸的是，并非如此：仅仅是阶段迁移而已。

59

If You Have an Enemy, Give Him Information

如果你有敌人，就给他提供信息

Information Bias

信息偏差

I n his short story “ Del rigor en la ciencia ,” which consists of just a single paragraph, Jorge Luis Borges describes a special country. In this country, the science of cartography is so sophisticated that only the most detailed of maps will do—that is, a map with a scale of 1:1, as large as the country itself. Their citizens soon realize that such a map does not provide any insight, since it merely duplicates what they already know. Borges’s map is the extreme case of the information bias , the delusion that more information guarantees better decisions.

豪尔赫·路易斯·博尔赫斯在其短篇小说《科学的严谨性》（Del rigor en la ciencia）中，仅用一段文字描述了一个特殊的国家。在这个国家，制图学极其复杂，只有最精细的地图才能满足需求——也就是比例尺为1:1、与国家等大的地图。他们的公民很快意识到，这样的地图并不能提供任何洞见，因为它只是复制了他们已知的信息。博尔赫斯的地图是信息偏见的极端体现，人们误以为更多的信息就能保证更好的决策。

Searching for a hotel in Miami a little while ago, I drew up a short list of five good offers. Right away, one jumped out at me, but I wanted to make sure I had found the best deal and decided to keep researching. I plowed my way through dozens of customer reviews and blog posts and clicked through countless photos and videos. Two hours later, I could say for sure which the best hotel was: the one I had liked at the start. The mountain of additional information did not lead to a better decision. On the contrary, if time is money, then I might as well have taken up residence at the Four Seasons.

不久前，我在迈阿密找酒店时，列了五个不错的酒店清单。其中一家立刻就吸引了我的注意，但为了确保找到最划算的酒店，我决定继续研究。我仔细阅读了几十条顾客评论和博客文章，浏览了无数的照片和视频。两个小时后，我终于确定了哪家酒店是最好的：就是我一开始就喜欢的那家。堆积如山的额外信息并没有让我做出更好的决定。相反，如果时间就是金钱，那我还不如住四季酒店呢。

Jonathan Baron from the University of Pennsylvania asked physicians the following question: A patient presents symptoms that indicate with a probability of 80 percent that he is suffering from disease A. If this is not the case, the patient has either disease X or Y. Each of these diseases is equally bad, and each treatment results in similar side effects. As a doctor, what treatment would you suggest? Logically, you would opt for disease A and recommend the relevant therapy. Now suppose there is a diagnostic test that flashes “positive” when disease X is present and “negative” when disease Y is detected. However, if the patient really does have disease A, the test results will be positive in 50 percent of the cases and negative in the other 50 percent. Would you recommend conducting the test? Most doctors said yes, even though the results would be irrelevant. Assuming that the test result is positive, the probability of disease A is still much greater than that of disease X. The additional information contributes nothing of value to the decision.

宾夕法尼亚大学的乔纳森·巴伦向医生们提出了这样一个问题：一位患者出现的症状表明，有80%的概率他患有疾病A。如果不是，那么患者要么患有疾病X，要么患有疾病Y。这两种疾病的危害程度相同，每种治疗方法的副作用也类似。作为一名医生，您会建议哪种治疗方法？从逻辑上讲，您会选择疾病A并推荐相应的疗法。现在假设有一项诊断测试，当存在疾病X时显示“阳性”，当检测到疾病Y时显示“阴性”。但是，如果患者确实患有疾病A，那么测试结果在50%的病例中为阳性，在另外50%的病例中为阴性。您会建议进行这项测试吗？大多数医生都表示会，即使结果无关紧要。假设测试结果为阳性，那么患有疾病A的概率仍然远大于患有疾病X的概率。额外的信息对决策没有任何价值。

Doctors are not the only professionals with a penchant for surplus information. Managers and investors are almost addicted to it. How often are studies commissioned one after the other, even though the critical facts are readily available? Additional information not only wastes time and money, it can also put you at a disadvantage. Consider this question: Which city has more inhabitants, San Diego or San Antonio? Gerd Gigerenzer of the Max Planck Institute in Germany put this question to students in the University of Chicago and the University of Munich. Sixty-two percent of Chicago students guessed right: San Diego has more. But, astonishingly, every single German student answered correctly. The reason: All of them had heard of San Diego but not necessarily of San Antonio, so they opted for the more familiar city. For the Chicagoans, however, both cities were household names. They had more information, and it misled them.

医生并非唯一热衷于获取过剩信息的专业人士。管理人员和投资者也几乎沉迷于此。即使关键事实唾手可得，研究却常常被一个接一个地委托进行？过多的信息不仅浪费时间和金钱，还会使您处于不利地位。考虑这个问题：圣地亚哥和圣安东尼奥哪个城市的居民更多？德国马克斯普朗克研究所的 Gerd Gigerenzer 向芝加哥大学和慕尼黑大学的学生提出了这个问题。62% 的芝加哥学生猜对了：圣地亚哥人口更多。但令人惊讶的是，每一位德国学生都答对了。原因是：他们都听说过圣地亚哥，但不一定听说过圣安东尼奥，所以他们选择了更熟悉的城市。然而，对于芝加哥人来说，这两个城市都是家喻户晓的。他们掌握着更多信息，而这些信息误导了他们。

Or consider the hundreds of thousands of economists—in service of banks, think tanks, hedge funds, and governments—and all the white papers they have published from 2005 to 2007: The vast library of research reports and mathematical models. The formidable reams of comments. The polished PowerPoint presentations. The terabytes of information on Bloomberg and Reuters news services. The bacchanal dance to worship the god of information. It was all hot air. The financial crisis touched down and upended global markets, rendering the countless forecasts and comments worthless.

或者想想数十万服务于银行、智库、对冲基金和政府的经济学家，以及他们从2005年到2007年发表的所有白皮书：海量的研究报告和数学模型，海量的评论，精美的PowerPoint演示文稿，彭博和路透社新闻服务上数以TB计的信息，以及对信息之神的狂热崇拜。这一切都是空谈。金融危机席卷并颠覆了全球市场，无数的预测和评论变得毫无价值。

Forget trying to amass all the data. Do your best to get by with the bare facts. It will help you make better decisions. Superfluous knowledge is worthless, whether you know it or not. The historian Daniel J. Boorstin put it right: “The greatest obstacle to discovery is not ignorance—it is the illusion of knowledge.” And next time you are confronted by a rival, consider killing him—not with kindness but with reams of data and analysis.

别再试图收集所有数据了。尽力掌握基本事实就好。这会帮助你做出更好的决策。多余的知识毫无价值，无论你是否了解。历史学家丹尼尔·J·布尔斯廷说得对：“探索的最大障碍不是无知，而是对知识的错觉。” 下次你遇到对手时，不妨考虑干掉他——不是用仁慈，而是用大量的数据和分析。

60

Hurts So Good

痛并快乐着

Effort Justification

努力的正当性

J ohn, a soldier in the U.S. Army, has just completed his paratrooper course. He waits patiently in line to receive the coveted parachute pin. At last, his superior officer stands in front of him, lines the pin up against his chest, and pounds it in so hard that it pierces John’s flesh. Ever since, he opens his top shirt button at every opportunity to showcase the small scar. Decades later, he has thrown away all the memorabilia from his time in the army, except for the tiny pin, which hangs in a specially made frame on his living-room wall.

美国陆军士兵约翰刚刚完成伞兵训练。他耐心地排队等候领取梦寐以求的降落伞徽章。最后，他的上级军官站在他面前，将徽章抵在胸前，用力一戳，徽章就扎进了约翰的肉里。从那以后，他抓住一切机会解开衬衫最上面的纽扣，展示这道小小的伤疤。几十年后，他把所有军旅生涯的纪念品都扔掉了，只剩下这枚小小的徽章，它被装在一个特制的相框里，挂在他客厅的墙上。

Mark single-handedly restored a rusty Harley-Davidson. Every weekend and holiday went into getting it up and running; all the while his marriage was approaching breakdown. It was a struggle, but finally Mark’s prized possession was road-ready and gleamed in the sunshine. Two years later, Mark desperately needs money. He sells all his possessions—the TV, the car, even his house—but not the bike. Even when a prospect offers double the actual value, Mark does not sell it.

马克独自一人修复了一辆锈迹斑斑的哈雷戴维森摩托车。他每个周末和假期都用来修理它；与此同时，他的婚姻却濒临破裂。虽然过程艰辛，但马克的宝贝终于可以上路了，在阳光下闪闪发光。两年后，马克急需用钱。他卖掉了所有家当——电视、汽车，甚至房子——唯独没有卖掉那辆摩托车。即使有人出价两倍，马克也不愿卖掉它。

John and Mark are victims of effort justification . When you put a lot of energy into a task, you tend to overvalue the result. Because John had to endure physical pain for the parachute pin, it outshines all his other awards. And since Mark’s Harley cost him so many hours—and also nearly his wife—he prizes the bike so highly that he will never sell it.

约翰和马克都是“努力合理化”的受害者。当你在一项任务上投入大量精力时，你往往会高估结果。因为约翰为了获得降落伞徽章不得不忍受身体上的痛苦，所以它比他其他所有的奖励都更加耀眼。而马克的哈雷摩托车，因为耗费了他太多时间——甚至几乎连妻子都付出了——他对这辆摩托车如此珍视，以至于他永远不会卖掉它。

Effort justification is a special case of “cognitive dissonance.” To have a hole punched in your chest for a simple merit badge borders on the absurd. John’s brain compensates for this imbalance by overvaluing the pin, hyping it up from something mundane to something semisacred. All of this happens unconsciously and is difficult to prevent.

努力辩护是“认知失调”的一个特例。为了一枚简单的功绩徽章而胸前被打个洞，简直荒唐至极。约翰的大脑通过高估徽章的价值来弥补这种不平衡，把它从平凡的事物夸大为某种近乎神圣的东西。所有这些都是在无意识中发生的，难以避免。

Groups use effort justification to bind members to them—for example, through initiation rites. Gangs and fraternities initiate new members by forcing them to withstand nauseating or vicious tests. Research proves that the harder the “entrance exam” is to pass, the greater the subsequent pride and the value they attach to their membership. MBA schools play with effort justification in this way: They work their students day and night without respite, often to the point of exhaustion. Regardless of whether the course work proves useful later on, once the students have the MBAs in the bag, they’ll deem the qualification essential for their careers simply because it demanded so much of them.

团体利用努力正当化来束缚成员——例如，通过入会仪式。帮派和兄弟会则通过强迫新成员接受令人作呕或残酷的考验来入会。研究表明，“入学考试”越难通过，他们随后获得的自豪感和对成员身份的重视程度就越高。MBA 学校就是这样玩弄努力正当化的：他们让学生日夜不停地学习，常常到了精疲力竭的地步。无论这些课程以后是否有用，一旦学生获得 MBA 学位，他们就会认为这个资格对他们的职业生涯至关重要，仅仅因为它对他们要求很高。

A mild form of effort justification is the so-called IKEA effect. Furniture that we assemble ourselves seems more valuable than any expensive designer piece. The same goes for hand-knitted socks. To throw away a handcrafted pair, even if they are tatty and outdated, is hard to do. Managers who put weeks of hard work into a strategy proposal will be incapable of appraising it objectively. Designers, copywriters, product developers, or any other professionals who brood over their creations are similarly guilty of this.

一种温和的努力辩护形式是所谓的宜家效应。我们自己组装的家具似乎比任何昂贵的设计师作品都更有价值。手工编织的袜子也是如此。扔掉一双手工制作的袜子，即使它们破旧不堪，也很难做到。那些花费数周时间辛苦完成战略提案的管理者，无法客观地评估它。设计师、文案、产品开发人员，或任何其他对自己的作品苦思冥想的专业人士，也同样容易犯同样的错误。

In the ’50s, instant cake mixes were introduced to the market. A surefire hit, thought the manufacturers. Far from it: Housewives took an instant disliking to them—because they made things too easy. The firms reacted and made the preparation slightly more difficult (beating in an egg yourself). The added effort raised the ladies’ sense of achievement and, with it, their appreciation for convenience food.

上世纪50年代，速溶蛋糕粉被引入市场。制造商们以为这肯定会大受欢迎。然而，事与愿违：家庭主妇们立刻就不喜欢这种蛋糕粉了——因为它们做得太简单了。于是，公司做出了反应，稍微提高了制作难度（自己打鸡蛋）。额外的努力提升了女士们的成就感，也随之提升了她们对方便食品的喜爱。

Now that you know about effort justification , you can rate your projects more objectively. Try it out: Whenever you have invested a lot of time and effort into something, stand back and examine the result— only the result. The novel you’ve been tinkering with for five years and that no publisher wants: Perhaps it’s not Nobel-worthy after all. The MBA you felt compelled to do: Would you really recommend it? And the woman you’ve been chasing for years: Is she really better than bachelorette number two who would say yes right away?

既然你了解了努力的合理性，你就可以更客观地评价你的项目了。不妨试试：每当你在某件事上投入了大量的时间和精力时，不妨退一步审视一下结果——只关注结果。你苦苦思索了五年却没有出版商想要的小说：或许它根本不配获得诺贝尔奖。你迫不及待想要攻读MBA：你真的会推荐它吗？你追求多年的那个女人：她真的比那个会立刻答应你的第二个单身女郎更好吗？

61

Why Small Things Loom Large

为什么小事能造成大影响

The Law of Small Numbers

小数定律

Y ou sit on the corporate board of a retail company with one thousand stores. Half of the stores are in cities, the other half in rural areas. At the behest of the CEO, a consultant conducted a study on shoplifting and is now presenting his findings. Projected onto the wall in front are the names of the one hundred branches with the highest theft rates compared to sales. In bold letters above them is his eye-opening conclusion: “The branches with the highest theft rate are primarily in rural areas.” After a moment of silence and disbelief, the CEO is first to speak: “Ladies and gentlemen, the next steps are clear. From now on, we will install additional safety systems in all rural branches. Let’s see those hillbillies steal from us then! Do we all agree?”

你是一家零售公司的董事会成员，这家公司拥有一千家门店。一半的门店位于城市，另一半位于农村地区。应首席执行官的要求，一位顾问开展了一项关于商店盗窃行为的研究，现在正在汇报他的研究结果。投影在前面的墙上，是盗窃率与销售额之比最高的一百家门店的名称。上方用粗体字写着他令人大开眼界的结论：“盗窃率最高的门店主要位于农村地区。” 一阵沉默和难以置信之后，首席执行官首先开口说道：“女士们，先生们，接下来的步骤很明确。从现在开始，我们将在所有农村门店安装额外的安全系统。到时候，让我们看看那些乡巴佬会不会偷我们的钱！我们都同意吗？”

Hmmm, not completely. You ask the consultant to call up the hundred branches with the lowest theft rates. After some swift sorting, the list appears. Surprise, surprise: The shops with the least amount of shoplifting in relation to sales are also in rural areas! “The location isn’t the deciding factor,” you begin, smiling somewhat smugly as you gaze around the table at your colleagues. “What counts is the size of the store. In the countryside, the branches tend to be small, meaning a single incident has a much larger influence on the theft rate. Therefore, the rural branches’ rates vary greatly—much more than the larger city branches. Ladies and gentlemen, I introduce you to the law of small numbers . It has just caught you out.”

嗯，不完全是。你让顾问打电话给盗窃率最低的100家分店。快速排序后，名单出现了。出乎意料的是：盗窃率与销售额之比最低的商店竟然也位于农村地区！“地点不是决定因素，”你开口道，一边略带得意地笑着，一边环顾桌子周围的同事。“重要的是商店的规模。在农村，分店通常规模较小，这意味着单次盗窃事件对盗窃率的影响要大得多。因此，农村分店的盗窃率差异很大——比大城市的分店要大得多。女士们，先生们，我向你们介绍小数定律。它刚刚让你们大吃一惊。”

The law of small numbers is not something we understand intuitively. Thus people—especially journalists, managers, and board members—continually fall for it. Let’s examine an extreme example. Instead of the theft rate, consider the average weight of employees in a branch. Instead of a thousand stores, we’ll take just two: a mega-branch and a mini-branch. The big store has one thousand employees; the small store just two. The average weight in the large branch corresponds roughly to the average weight of the population, say 170 pounds. Regardless of who is hired or fired, it will not change much. Unlike the small store: The store manager’s colleague, if rotund or reedy, will affect the average weight tremendously.

我们无法凭直觉理解小数定律。因此人们——尤其是记者、经理和董事会成员——经常会上当受骗。让我们看一个极端的例子。我们不考虑盗窃率，而是考虑一个分店员工的平均体重。我们不取一千家店，而是取两家：一家大型分店和一家小型分店。大型分店有一千名员工，而小型分店只有两名员工。大型分店的平均体重大致相当于当地人口的平均体重，比如说 170 磅。无论谁被雇用或解雇，都不会发生太大变化。与小店不同的是：店长的同事，如果身材肥胖或瘦长，将极大地影响平均体重。

Let’s go back to the shoplifting problem. We now understand why the smaller a branch is, the more its theft rate will vary—from extremely high to extremely low. No matter how the consultant arranges his spreadsheet, if you list all the theft rates in order of size, small stores will appear at the bottom, large stores will take up the middle, and the top slots? Small stores again. So, the CEO’s conclusion was useless, but at least he doesn’t need to go overboard on a security system for the small stores.

让我们回到商店盗窃问题。现在我们明白了为什么分店规模越小，其盗窃率的差异就越大——从极高到极低。无论顾问如何整理他的电子表格，如果按规模大小列出所有盗窃率，小商店都会排在最底层，大商店占据中间位置，而最顶层呢？又是小商店。所以，首席执行官的结论毫无意义，但至少他不需要在小商店的安保系统上投入过多精力。

Suppose you read the following story in the newspaper: “Start-ups employ smarter people. A study commissioned by the National Institute of Unnecessary Research has calculated the average IQ in American companies. The result: Start-ups hire MENSA material.” What is your first reaction? Hopefully a raised eyebrow. This is a perfect example of the law of small numbers . Start-ups tend to employ fewer people. Therefore the average IQs will fluctuate much more than those of large corporations, giving small (and new) businesses the highest and lowest scores. The National Institute’s study has zero significance. It simply confirms the laws of chance.

假设你在报纸上读到这样一则报道：“初创企业雇佣的员工更聪明。美国国家不必要研究所委托进行的一项研究计算了美国公司的平均智商。结果显示：初创企业雇佣的是门萨级别的人才。”你的第一反应是什么？希望你会扬起眉毛。这完美地体现了小数定律。初创企业往往雇佣的员工更少。因此，他们的平均智商波动会比大公司大得多，导致小型企业（以及新兴企业）的得分最高和最低。美国国家不必要研究所的研究毫无意义，它只是证实了偶然性定律。

So, watch out when you hear remarkable statistics about any small entities: businesses, households, cities, data centers, anthills, parishes, schools, and so on. What is being peddled as an astounding finding is, in fact, a humdrum consequence of random distribution. In his latest book, Nobel Prize winner Daniel Kahneman reveals that even experienced scientists succumb to the law of small numbers. How reassuring.

所以，当你听到任何关于小实体的惊人统计数据时，都要小心：企业、家庭、城市、数据中心、蚁丘、教区、学校等等。那些被吹捧为惊人发现的东西，实际上只是随机分布的平凡结果。诺贝尔奖得主丹尼尔·卡尼曼在他的新书中揭示，即使是经验丰富的科学家也会受小数定律的影响。这真是令人欣慰。

62

Handle with Care

小心处理

Expectations

期望

O n January 31, 2006, Google announced its financial results for the final quarter of 2005. Revenue: up 97 percent. Net profit: up 82 percent. A record-breaking quarter. How did the stock market react to these phenomenal figures? In a matter of seconds, shares tumbled 16 percent. Trading had to be interrupted. When it resumed, the stock plunged another 15 percent. Absolute panic. One particularly desperate trader inquired on his blog: “What’s the best skyscraper to throw myself off?” What had gone wrong? Wall Street analysts had anticipated even better results, and when those failed to materialized, $20 billion was slashed from the value of the media giant.

2006年1月31日，谷歌公布了2005年第四季度的财务业绩。营收增长97%，净利润增长82%，创下了历史新高。股市对这些惊人的数据作何反应？几秒钟之内，股价暴跌16%，交易被迫中断。恢复交易后，股价又暴跌15%。市场一片恐慌。一位绝望的交易员在博客上问道：“从哪座摩天大楼跳下去最好？”究竟出了什么问题？华尔街分析师原本预期会有更好的业绩，但这些预期落空后，这家媒体巨头的市值蒸发了200亿美元。

Every investor knows it’s impossible to forecast financial results accurately. The logical response to a poor prediction would be: “A bad guess, my mistake.” But investors don’t react that way. In January 2006, when Juniper Networks announced eagerly anticipated earnings per share that were a tenth of a cent lower than analysts’ forecasts, the share price fell 21 percent and the company’s value plunged $2.5 billion. When expectations are fueled in the run-up to an announcement, any disparity gives rise to draconian punishment, regardless of how paltry the gap is.

每个投资者都知道，准确预测财务结果是不可能的。对糟糕预测的合理回应是：“猜错了，我的失误。” 但投资者不会这样反应。2006年1月，瞻博网络（Juniper Networks）宣布每股收益比分析师预期低了十分之一，股价应声下跌21%，公司市值暴跌25亿美元。当预期在公告发布前被夸大时，任何差异都会招致严厉的惩罚，无论差距多么微不足道。

Many companies bend over backward to meet analysts’ predictions. To escape this terror, some began publishing their own estimates, so-called earnings guidance. Not a smart move. Now, the market heeds only these internal forecasts—and studies them much more closely to boot. CFOs are forced to achieve these targets to the cent, and so must draw on all the accounting artifices available.

许多公司不遗余力地迎合分析师的预测。为了摆脱这种恐惧，一些公司开始发布自己的预估，即所谓的盈利指引。这并非明智之举。如今，市场只关注这些内部预测，并且对其进行更深入的研究。首席财务官被迫精确地实现这些目标，因此必须运用所有可用的会计技巧。

Fortunately, expectations can also lead to commendable incentives. In 1965, the American psychologist Robert Rosenthal conducted a noteworthy experiment in various schools. Teachers were told of a (fake) new test that could identify students who were on the verge of an intellectual spurt—so-called bloomers. Twenty percent of students were randomly selected and classified as such. Teachers remained under the impression that these were indeed high-potential students. After a year, Rosenthal discovered that these students had developed much higher IQs than other children in a control group. This effect became known as the “Rosenthal effect” (or “Pygmalion effect”).

幸运的是，期望也能带来值得称赞的激励。1965年，美国心理学家罗伯特·罗森塔尔在不同的学校进行了一项引人注目的实验。他告诉老师们一项（假的）新测试，该测试可以识别出那些即将迎来智力爆发的学生——所谓的“蓬勃发展者”。20%的学生被随机选中，并被归类为“蓬勃发展者”。老师们仍然认为这些学生确实具有高潜力。一年后，罗森塔尔发现，这些学生的智商远高于对照组的其他孩子。这种效应被称为“罗森塔尔效应”（或“皮格马利翁效应”）。

Unlike the CEOs and CFOs who consciously tailor their performance to meet expectations, the teachers’ actions were subconscious. Unknowingly, they probably devoted more time to the bloomers and, consequently, the group learned more. The prospect of brilliant students influenced the teachers so much that they ascribed not just better grades but also improved personality traits to the “gifted” students.

与那些有意识地调整自身表现以满足期望的CEO和CFO不同，教师们的行为是潜意识的。不知不觉中，他们可能在“高才生”身上投入了更多时间，结果，这群学生学到了更多。优秀学生的前景对教师们影响巨大，以至于他们不仅认为这些“资优生”的成绩更好，还认为他们的性格特征也得到了提升。

But how do we react to personal expectations? This brings us to the “placebo effect”—pills and therapies that are unlikely to improve health, but do so anyway. The “placebo effect” has been registered in one-third of all patients. But how it works is not well understood. All we know is that expectations alter the biochemistry of the brain and thus the whole body. Accordingly Alzheimer’s patients cannot benefit from it: Their condition impairs the area of the brain that deals with expectations.

但我们该如何应对个人期望呢？这引出了“安慰剂效应”——那些不太可能改善健康的药物和疗法，却依然有效。三分之一的患者都出现了“安慰剂效应”。但其作用机制尚不明确。我们只知道，期望会改变大脑的生物化学反应，进而影响整个身体。因此，阿尔茨海默病患者无法从中受益：他们的病情损害了大脑中处理期望的区域。

Expectations are intangible, but their effect is quite real. They have the power to change reality. Can we deprogram them? Is it possible to live a life free from expectations? Unfortunately not. But you can deal with them more cautiously. Raise expectations for yourself and for the people you love. This increases motivation. At the same time, lower expectations for things you cannot control—for example, the stock market. As paradoxical as it sounds: The best way to shield yourself from nasty surprises is to anticipate them.

期望无形，但其影响却实实在在。它们拥有改变现实的力量。我们能摆脱期望的束缚吗？我们有可能过上没有期望的生活吗？很遗憾，我们无法做到。但你可以更谨慎地对待它们。提高对自己和所爱之人的期望。这会提升动力。同时，降低对你无法掌控的事情的期望，例如股市。听起来似乎有些矛盾：保护自己免受意外打击的最好方法就是提前预料。

63

Speed Traps Ahead!

前方有测速陷阱！

Simple Logic

简单逻辑

T hree easy questions. Grab a pen quickly and jot down your answers in the margin. First question: In a department store, a Ping-Pong paddle and a plastic ball cost $1.10. If the paddle costs $1 more, how much is the ball? Second question: In a textile factory, five machines take exactly five minutes to make five shirts. How many minutes will it take one hundred machines to produce one hundred shirts? And, the third question: A pond has water lilies growing in it. The flowers multiply quickly, each day doubling the area they take up. If it takes forty-eight days for the pond to be completely covered with water lilies, how many days will it take for it to be half covered? Don’t read on until you have written down the answers.

三个简单的问题。迅速拿起笔，在空白处记下你的答案。第一个问题：在一家百货商店，一个乒乓球拍和一个塑料球的价格是1.10美元。如果拍子贵1美元，那么球多少钱？第二个问题：在一家纺织厂，五台机器正好需要五分钟才能生产五件衬衫。一百台机器生产一百件衬衫需要多少分钟？第三个问题：一个池塘里生长着睡莲。这些花繁殖迅速，每天的面积都会翻一番。如果池塘完全被睡莲覆盖需要48天，那么池塘被一半覆盖需要多少天？在记下答案之前，不要继续阅读。

For each of these questions, there is an intuitive answer—and a right one. The quick, intuitive answers come to mind first: ten cents, one hundred minutes, and twenty-four days. But these are all wrong. The solutions are: five cents, five minutes, and forty-seven days. How many did you answer correctly?

以上每个问题都有一个直观的答案，而且是一个正确的答案。首先想到的快速、直观的答案是：10美分、100分钟和24天。但这些都是错的。答案是：5美分、5分钟和47天。你答对了多少个？

Thousands of people have taken this Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT), which professor Shane Frederick developed. So far, students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in Boston have fared best. On average, they got 2.18 correct answers. Students at Princeton University came in second with an average of 1.63. Far below were students of the University of Michigan who scored an average of 0.83. However, despite these neat rankings, averages are not interesting in this case. More interesting is how those who scored highly differ from the rest.

数千人参加了由肖恩·弗雷德里克教授开发的认知反射测试 (CRT)。迄今为止，波士顿麻省理工学院 (MIT) 的学生表现最佳。他们平均答对了 2.18 题。普林斯顿大学的学生以 1.63 题的平均分位居第二。密歇根大学的学生则远远落后，平均得分为 0.83。然而，尽管排名如此清晰，但在本例中，平均分并不重要。更有趣的是那些得分高的学生与其他学生之间的差异。

Here’s a hint: Would you prefer a bird in the hand or two in the bush? Frederick discovered that people with low CRT results tend to prefer a bird in the hand. They play it safe. After all, something is better than nothing. Those who score at least 2 or higher usually opt for the riskier option. They prefer the gamble. This is especially true for men.

给你个提示：你是想一鸟在手，还是两鸟在林？弗雷德里克发现，CRT 得分低的人往往更倾向于一鸟在手。他们选择稳妥行事。毕竟，有总比没有好。得分至少为 2 分或更高的人通常会选择风险更高的选项。他们更喜欢冒险一试。男性尤其如此。

One factor that separates the groups is their ability to control their impulses. In chapter 51 on hyperbolic discounting , we covered the seductive power of “now.” Frederick put the following question to the participants: “Would you rather have $3,400 now or $3,800 in a month?” In general, people with low CRT scores favor getting the smaller amount sooner. For them, waiting poses a challenge because they are more impulsive. This also applies to purchasing decisions. In contrast, people with high CRT results usually decide to wait the extra few weeks. They muster the willpower to turn down instant gratification—and are rewarded for it later on.

区分不同群体的一个因素是他们控制冲动的能力。在第51章关于双曲线贴现的章节中，我们讨论了“现在”的诱惑力。弗雷德里克向参与者提出了以下问题：“你愿意现在就得到3400美元，还是一个月后得到3800美元？” 总体而言，CRT分数低的人倾向于尽快获得较小的金额。对他们来说，等待是一个挑战，因为他们更容易冲动。这同样适用于购买决策。相比之下，CRT分数高的人通常会决定多等几周。他们鼓起意志力，拒绝了即时满足——并在之后获得了回报。

Thinking is more exhausting than sensing: Rational consideration requires more willpower than simply giving in to intuition. In other words, intuitive people tend to scrutinize less. This led Harvard psychologist Amitai Shenhav and his research colleagues to investigate whether people’s CRT results correlate with their faith. Americans with a high CRT score (the study was conducted only in the United States) are often atheists, and their convictions have been reinforced over the years. Participants with low CRT results, however, tend to believe in God and “the immortality of the soul,” and often have had divine experiences. This makes sense: The more intuitively people make decisions, the less rationally they query religious beliefs.

思考比感知更耗费精力：理性思考比仅仅屈服于直觉需要更大的意志力。换句话说，直觉型的人往往更少审视。这促使哈佛大学心理学家阿米泰·申哈夫（Amitai Shenhav）和他的同事们研究人们的CRT结果是否与他们的信仰相关。CRT得分高的美国人（这项研究仅在美国进行）通常是无神论者，而且他们的信念多年来得到了强化。然而，CRT得分低的参与者往往相信上帝和“灵魂不朽”，并且经常有过神圣的经历。这很有道理：人们越是依靠直觉做决定，他们就越不会理性地质疑宗教信仰。

If you are less than pleased with your CRT score and want to improve it, start by greeting even the simplest logical questions with incredulity. Not everything that seems plausible is true. Reject the easy answers that pop into your head. So, one more try: You are traveling from A to B. On the way there you drive at 100 mph and on the way back, at 50 mph. What was your average speed? 75 mph? Slow down, slow down!

如果你对自己的CRT分数不太满意，并且想要提高，那就从怀疑开始，即使是最简单的逻辑问题，也要保持怀疑的态度。并非所有看似合理的答案都是真的。拒绝那些突然冒出来的简单答案。所以，再试一次：你从A地前往B地。去程你的速度是100英里/小时，回程是50英里/小时。你的平均速度是多少？75英里/小时？慢下来，慢下来！

64

How to Expose a Charlatan

如何揭穿骗子

Forer Effect

福勒效应

D ear reader, it may surprise you, but I know you personally. This is how I would sum you up: “You have a great need for other people to like and admire you. You have a tendency to be critical of yourself. You have a great deal of unused capacity, which you have not turned to your advantage. While you have some personality weaknesses, you are generally able to compensate for them. Your sexual adjustment has presented problems for you. Disciplined and self-controlled outside, you tend to be worrisome and insecure inside. At times you have serious doubts as to whether you have made the right decision or done the right thing. You prefer a certain amount of change and variety and become dissatisfied when hemmed in by restrictions and limitations. You pride yourself as an independent thinker and do not accept others’ statements without satisfactory proof. You have found it unwise to be too frank in revealing yourself to others. At times you are extroverted, affable, and sociable while at other times you are introverted, wary, and reserved. Some of your aspirations tend to be pretty unrealistic. Security is one of your major goals in life.”

亲爱的读者，这可能会让您感到惊讶，但我认识您。我会这样总结你：“你非常渴望别人喜欢和钦佩你。你倾向于自我批评。你有很多未开发的潜力，但你并没有将其转化为优势。虽然你有一些性格弱点，但通常能够弥补。你的性适应给你带来了一些问题。你外表严谨自律，内心却容易焦虑和缺乏安全感。有时你会严重怀疑自己是否做出了正确的决定或做了正确的事情。你喜欢一定程度的变化和多样性，当受到限制和约束时会感到不满。你以独立思考为荣，除非有充分的证据，否则不会接受他人的言论。你认为过于坦率地向他人展现自己是不明智的。有时你外向、和蔼可亲、善于交际，有时你内向、谨慎、内敛。你的一些愿望往往非常不切实际。安全感是你人生的主要目标之一。”

Do you recognize yourself? On a scale from 1 (poor) to 5 (excellent), how was my assessment?

你认识自己吗？从1（差）到5（优秀），我的评价如何？

In 1948, psychologist Bertram Forer crafted this exact passage using astrology columns from various magazines. He then gave it to his students to read, suggesting that each person was getting a personalized assessment. On average, the students rated their characterizations 4.3 out of 5, that is, they gave Forer an accuracy score of 86 percent. The experiment was repeated hundreds of times in the decades that followed with virtually identical results.

1948年，心理学家伯特伦·福勒（Bertram Forer）根据各杂志上的占星专栏，精心编撰了这段文字。他把这段文字拿给学生们阅读，暗示每个人都会得到一份个性化的评估。学生们平均给自己的性格特征打了4.3分（满分5分），也就是说，福勒的准确率为86%。在接下来的几十年里，这项实验重复了数百次，结果几乎完全相同。

Most likely you gave the text a 4 or 5, too. People tend to identify many of their own traits in such universal descriptions. Science labels this tendency the Forer effect (or the “Barnum effect”). The Forer effect explains why the pseudosciences work so well—astrology, astrotherapy, the study of handwriting, biorhythm analysis, palmistry, tarot card readings, and séances with the dead.

你很可能也给这段文字打了4分或5分。人们倾向于在这种普遍的描述中认同自己的许多特质。科学界将这种倾向称为福勒效应（或“巴纳姆效应”）。福勒效应解释了为什么伪科学——占星术、占星疗法、笔迹研究、生物节律分析、手相术、塔罗牌解读以及与死者进行降神会——如此有效。

What’s behind the Forer effect ? First, the majority of statements in Forer’s passage are so general that they relate to everyone: “Sometimes you seriously doubt your actions.” Who doesn’t? Second, we tend to accept flattering statements that don’t apply to us: “You are proud of your independent thinking.” Obviously! Who sees himself or herself as a mindless follower? Third, the so-called feature-positive effect plays a part: The text contains no negative statements; it states only what we are, even though the absence of characteristics is an equally important part of a person’s makeup. Fourth, the father of all the fallacies, the confirmation bias : We accept whatever corresponds to our self-image and unconsciously filter everything else out. What remains is a coherent portrait.

福勒效应背后是什么？首先，福勒文章中的大部分陈述都非常笼统，几乎适用于所有人：“有时你会认真地怀疑自己的行为。” 谁又不会呢？其次，我们倾向于接受那些并不适用于我们的奉承之词：“你为自己的独立思考感到自豪。” 显然如此！谁会把自己看作盲目的追随者呢？第三，所谓的“特征正效应”也起了作用：文本中没有负面陈述；它只陈述了我们是什么样的人，尽管缺乏特征也是一个人性格中同样重要的一部分。第四，所有谬误之源——确认偏差：我们接受任何符合我们自我形象的事物，并无意识地过滤掉其他一切。剩下的是一个连贯的自我画像。

Whatever tricks astrologers and palm readers can turn, consultants and analysts can, too: “The stock has significant growth potential, even in a very competitive environment. The company lacks the necessary impetus to fully realize and implement ideas from the development team. Management is made up of experienced industry professionals; however, hints of bureaucratization are noticeable. A look at the profit and loss statement clearly shows that savings can be made. We advise the company to focus even more closely on emerging economies to secure future market share.” Sounds about right, no?

占星师和手相师能耍什么花招，咨询顾问和分析师也能。“即使在竞争激烈的环境下，该股仍具有巨大的增长潜力。公司缺乏必要的动力来充分实现和执行开发团队的想法。管理层由经验丰富的行业专业人士组成；然而，官僚主义的迹象显而易见。看看损益表，就能清楚地看到成本可以节省。我们建议公司更加关注新兴经济体，以确保未来的市场份额。” 听起来很对，不是吗？

How do you rate the quality of such a guru—for example, an astrologer? Pick twenty people and secretly assign each a number. Have him characterize the people and write his assessments down on cards. To ensure anonymity, participants never find out their numbers. Afterward, each receives a copy of all the cards. Only when the majority of people identify “their” description is there real talent at hand. I am still waiting.

你如何评价这样一位大师——比如占星师——的品质？挑选二十个人，秘密地给每个人分配一个数字。让他描述这些人的特征，并将他的评估写在卡片上。为了确保匿名，参与者永远不会知道自己的数字。之后，每个人都会收到所有卡片的副本。只有当大多数人都认同“他们”的描述时，才说明他们真的有天赋。我还在等待。

65

Volunteer Work Is for the Birds

志愿工作是为了鸟类

Volunteer’s Folly

志愿者的愚蠢行为

J ack, a photographer, is on the go from Monday to Friday. Commissioned by fashion magazines, he divides his time between Milan, Paris, and New York and is constantly in search of the most beautiful girls, the most original designs, and the perfect light. He is well known on the social circuit, and the money is great: $500 an hour, easy. “That’s as much as a commercial lawyer,” he brags to his buddies, “and what I have in front of my lens looks a lot better than any banker.”

杰克是一位摄影师，周一到周五忙个不停。他受时尚杂志的委托，奔波于米兰、巴黎和纽约之间，不断寻找最美的姑娘、最原创的设计和最完美的光线。他在社交圈里小有名气，收入也很高：每小时500美元，轻轻松松。“这跟商业律师的工资差不多，”他向朋友们吹嘘，“我镜头里的照片比任何银行家的都好看。”

Jack leads an enviable life, but lately he has become more philosophical. It feels as if something has come between him and the fashion world. The selfishness of the industry suddenly repels him. Sometimes he lies in bed, staring at the ceiling, and yearns for more meaningful work. He would like to be selfless once again, to contribute something to the world, no matter how small.

杰克过着令人羡慕的生活，但最近他变得更加理性了。他感觉自己和时尚界之间似乎出现了某种隔阂。这个行业的自私让他突然感到厌恶。有时，他会躺在床上，盯着天花板，渴望从事更有意义的工作。他渴望再次变得无私，为世界贡献一份力量，无论多么微不足道。

One day his phone rings. It’s Patrick, his former classmate and current president of the local bird club: “Next Saturday we’re having our annual birdhouse drive. We’re looking for volunteers to help us build birdhouses for endangered species. Afterward we’ll put them up in the woods. Do you have time? We’re meeting at eight o’clock in the morning. We should be done shortly after noon.”

有一天，他的电话响了。是帕特里克打来的，他是他以前的同学，也是当地鸟类俱乐部的现任主席。他说：“下周六我们要举行一年一度的鸟舍活动。我们正在寻找志愿者来帮助我们为濒危物种建造鸟舍。之后我们会把它们安置在树林里。你有时间吗？我们早上八点开会。中午过后应该就能完成了。”

What should Jack say if he really is serious about creating a better world? That’s right, he should turn down the request. Why? Jack earns $500 an hour. A carpenter, $50. It would be much more sensible to work an extra hour as a photographer and then hire a professional carpenter for six hours to make good-quality birdhouses (which Jack could never hope to accomplish). Taxes aside, he could donate the difference ($200) to the bird club. Doing so, his contribution would go much further than if he grabbed a saw and rolled up his sleeves.

如果杰克真的想创造一个更美好的世界，他该怎么说呢？没错，他应该拒绝这个请求。为什么？杰克每小时挣500美元，木匠挣50美元。更明智的做法是，做个摄影师，多工作一小时，然后雇个专业木匠花六个小时做高质量的鸟舍（杰克永远也做不出来）。撇开税费不谈，他可以把差额（200美元）捐给鸟类俱乐部。这样做，他的贡献比他拿起锯子撸起袖子干活要大得多。

Nevertheless, it is highly likely that Jack will turn up bright and early next Saturday to build birdhouses. Economists call this volunteer’s folly . It is a popular phenomenon: More than one-fourth of Americans volunteer their time. But what makes it folly? Among other things, if Jack chooses to cobble together a few birdhouses himself, it takes away work from a tradesman. Working a little longer and donating a portion of the earnings is the most effective contribution Jack can make. Hands-on volunteer work would be helpful only if he could make use of his expertise. If the bird club were planning a fund-raising mail campaign and needed a professional photo, Jack could either shoot it himself or work an hour longer to hire another top photographer and donate the remainder.

尽管如此，杰克很有可能会在下周六一大早就出现，开始建造鸟舍。经济学家称这种志愿者行为是“愚蠢的”。这是一个普遍现象：超过四分之一的美国人愿意奉献自己的时间。但是什么让它变得“愚蠢”呢？首先，如果杰克选择自己拼凑几个鸟舍，就会减少工匠的工作量。多工作一会儿，并捐出一部分收入，是杰克能做出的最有效的贡献。亲自动手的志愿者工作只有在他能利用自己的专业知识时才会有帮助。如果鸟类俱乐部计划进行邮件筹款活动，需要一张专业照片，杰克可以自己拍摄，也可以多工作一个小时，聘请另一位顶级摄影师，并将剩余的照片捐出。

So now we come to the thorny topic of altruism. Does selflessness exist at all or is it merely a balm to our egos? Although a desire to help the community motivates many volunteers, personal benefits play a big part, such as gaining skills, experience, and contacts. Suddenly we’re not acting quite so selflessly. Indeed, many volunteers engage in what might be deemed “personal happiness management,” the benefits of which are sometimes far removed from the real cause. Strictly speaking, anyone who profits or feels even the slightest satisfaction from volunteering is not a pure altruist.

现在我们来谈谈利他主义这个棘手的话题。无私究竟存在吗？还是它只是我们自尊心的一种慰藉？虽然帮助社区的愿望激励着许多志愿者，但个人利益也起着重要作用，例如获得技能、经验和人脉。突然之间，我们变得不那么无私了。事实上，许多志愿者参与了所谓的“个人幸福管理”，其好处有时与真正的目的相去甚远。严格来说，任何从志愿服务中获利或感受到哪怕一丝满足的人都不是纯粹的利他主义者。

So does it mean Jack is a fool if he turns up, hammer in hand, on Saturday morning? Not necessarily. There is one group exempt from volunteer’s folly : celebrities. If Bono, Kate Winslet, and Mark Zuckerberg pose for photos while making birdhouses, cleaning oil-stained beaches, or digging for earthquake victims, they lend something priceless to the situation: publicity. Therefore, Jack must critically assess whether he is famous enough to make his participation worthwhile. The same applies to you and me: If people don’t double-take when they pass you on the street, the best way to contribute is with greenbacks rather than greenhorn labor.

那么，如果杰克周六早上拿着锤子出现，是不是就意味着他是个傻瓜？未必。有一群人可以免于志愿者的愚蠢行为：名人。如果波诺、凯特·温斯莱特和马克·扎克伯格在制作鸟舍、清理被油污污染的海滩或为地震灾民挖掘房屋时摆姿势拍照，他们就为这些活动增添了无价的一笔：宣传。因此，杰克必须认真评估自己的名气是否足以让他的参与变得有价值。同样的道理也适用于你我：如果人们在街上与你擦肩而过时不会多看一眼，那么贡献的最佳方式就是用钞票而不是新手劳动力。

66

Why You Are a Slave to Your Emotions

为什么你会成为情绪的奴隶

Affect Heuristic

情感启发法

W hat do you think of genetically modified wheat? It’s a complex issue. You don’t want to answer too hastily. A rational approach would be to consider the controversial technology’s pros and cons separately. Write down the possible benefits, weight them in terms of importance, and then multiply them by the probability that they will occur. Doing so, you get a list of expected values. Next, do the same with the cons. List all the disadvantages, estimate their potential damage, and multiply them by the likelihood of them happening. The positive sum minus the negative sum equals the net expected value. If it is above zero, you are in favor of genetically modified wheat. If the sum is below zero, you are against it. More than likely you have already heard of this approach. It is called “expected value,” and it features in most literature on decision theory. But just as probable is that you’ve never bothered to carry out such an evaluation. And without a doubt, none of the professors who wrote the textbooks turned to this method to select their spouses.

你对转基因小麦有何看法？这是一个复杂的问题，你肯定不想草率地回答。理性的方法是分别考虑这项备受争议的技术的利弊。写下可能的好处，按重要性进行加权，然后乘以它们发生的概率。这样，你就能得到一个预期值列表。接下来，对弊端也进行同样的操作。列出所有缺点，估计它们的潜在损害，然后乘以它们发生的可能性。正和减负和等于净预期值。如果净预期值大于零，则表示你支持转基因小麦。如果净预期值小于零，则表示你反对。你很可能已经听说过这种方法。它被称为“预期值”，在大多数决策理论文献中都有提及。但同样可能的是，你从未进行过这样的评估。毫无疑问，编写教科书的教授们都没有用这种方法来选择配偶。

Truth be told, no one uses this method to make decisions. First of all, we lack enough imagination to list all the possible pros and cons. We are limited by what springs to mind; we can only conjure up what we have seen in our modest experience. It is hard to imagine a storm of the century if you’re only thirty years old. Second, calculating small probabilities is impossible because we do not have enough data on rare events. The smaller the probability, the fewer data points we have and the higher the error rate on the exact probability—a vicious effect. Third, our brain is not built for such calculations. They require time and effort—not our preferred state. In our evolutionary past, whoever thought too long and hard vanished inside a predator’s jaws. We are the descendants of quick decision makers, and we rely on mental shortcuts called heuristics.

说实话，没人用这种方法做决定。首先，我们缺乏足够的想象力来列出所有可能的利弊。我们受限于脑海中浮现的想法；我们只能凭空想象我们所见过的事物。如果你只有三十岁，很难想象一场世纪风暴。其次，计算小概率是不可能的，因为我们没有足够的罕见事件数据。概率越小，我们拥有的数据点就越少，对确切概率的错误率就越高——这是一个恶性循环。第三，我们的大脑天生不适合进行这样的计算。这需要时间和精力——这不是我们喜欢的状态。在我们进化的过去，任何思考太久太过深入的人都会消失在捕食者的口中。我们是快速决策者的后代，我们依赖于被称为启发式的思维捷径。

One of the most popular is the affect heuristic . An affect is a momentary judgment: something you like or dislike. The word “gunfire” triggers a negative effect. The word “luxury” produces a positive one. This automatic, one-dimensional impulse prevents you from considering risks and benefits to be independent variables, which indeed they are. Instead, the affect heuristic puts risks and benefits on the same sensory thread.

最受欢迎的方法之一是情感启发法。情感是一种瞬间的判断：你喜欢或不喜欢的事物。“枪声”这个词会引发负面效应。“奢侈品”这个词则会产生正面效应。这种自动的、一维的冲动会阻止你将风险和收益视为独立变量，而事实上它们确实是独立的。相反，情感启发法将风险和收益放在同一条感官线索上。

Your emotional reactions to issues such as nuclear power, organic vegetables, private schools, or motorbikes determine how you assess their risks and benefits. If you like something, you believe that the risks are smaller and the benefits greater than they actually are. If you don’t like something, the opposite is true. Risks and benefits appear to be dependent. Of course, in reality, they are not.

你对核电、有机蔬菜、私立学校或摩托车等问题的情绪反应决定了你如何评估它们的风险和收益。如果你喜欢某件事，你会认为它的风险比实际要小，而收益则比实际要大。如果你不喜欢某件事，情况则相反。风险和收益看似相互关联，但实际上并非如此。

Even more impressive: Suppose you own a Harley-Davidson. If you come across a study that states that driving one is riskier than previously thought, you will subconsciously tweak how you rate the benefits, deeming the experience “an even greater sense of freedom.”

更令人印象深刻的是：假设你拥有一辆哈雷戴维森摩托车。如果你看到一项研究表明驾驶哈雷戴维森摩托车的风险比之前认为的要大，你会下意识地调整你对哈雷戴维森摩托车益处的评价，认为这种体验“是一种更强烈的自由感”。

But how does an affect—the initial, spontaneous emotion—come to be? Researchers at the University of Michigan flashed one of three images for less than one hundredth of a second in front of participants: a smiling face, an angry face, or a neutral figure. The subjects then had to indicate whether they liked a randomly selected Chinese character or not (the participants didn’t speak Chinese). Most preferred symbols that immediately followed the smiling face. Seemingly insignificant factors influence our emotions. Here is another example where an insignificant factor plays a role. Researchers David Hirschleifer and Tyler Shumway tested the relationship between the amount of morning sun and daily market performance in twenty-six major stock exchanges between 1982 and 1997. They found a correlation that reads much like a farmer’s adage: If the sun is shining in the morning, the stock market will rise during the day. Not always, but often. Who would have thought that sunshine can move billions. The morning sun obviously has the same effect as a smiley face.

但是情感——最初的、自发的情绪——是如何产生的呢？密歇根大学的研究人员在参与者面前闪现了三幅图像中的一幅，时间不到百分之一秒：一张笑脸、一张愤怒的脸或一个中性人物。然后，受试者必须表明他们是否喜欢随机选择的汉字（参与者不会说中文）。大多数人喜欢紧跟在笑脸后面的符号。看似微不足道的因素会影响我们的情绪。这是另一个微不足道的因素发挥作用的例子。研究人员大卫·赫希莱弗和泰勒·沙姆韦测试了1982年至1997年间26个主要证券交易所的早晨阳光量与每日市场表现之间的关系。他们发现了一种很像农谚的相关性：如果早晨阳光明媚，股市就会在白天上涨。并非总是如此，但经常如此。谁会想到阳光可以感动数十亿人呢？早晨的阳光显然具有与笑脸相同的效果。

Whether we like it or not, we are puppets of our emotions. We make complex decisions by consulting our feelings, not our thoughts. Against our best intentions, we substitute the question, “What do I think about this?” with “How do I feel about this?” So, smile! Your future depends on it.

无论我们乐意与否，我们都是情绪的傀儡。我们做复杂的决定时，总是依靠感觉，而不是思考。我们违背自己的初衷，用“我对此有何感想？”来代替“我对此有何看法？”。所以，微笑吧！你的未来就靠它了。

67

Be Your Own Heretic

做你自己的异教徒

Introspection Illusion

内省错觉

B ruce is in the vitamin business. His father founded the company when supplements were not yet a lifestyle product; a doctor had to prescribe them. When Bruce took over the operation in the early ’90s, demand skyrocketed. Bruce seized the opportunity with both hands and took out huge loans to expand production. Today, he is one of the most successful people in the business and president of a national association of vitamin manufactures. Since childhood, hardly a day has passed without him swallowing at least three multivitamins. A journalist once asked him if they do anything. He replied: “I’m sure of it.” Do you believe him?

布鲁斯从事维生素生意。他父亲创立这家公司时，补充剂还未成为一种生活方式产品，需要医生开处方才能购买。90年代初，布鲁斯接手公司后，需求量猛增。布鲁斯抓住机遇，举债巨资扩大生产。如今，他是业内最成功的人士之一，同时也是一家全国维生素制造商协会的主席。从孩提时代起，他几乎每天都会服用至少三片复合维生素。一位记者曾问他，这些复合维生素有什么作用。他回答说：“我确信它有效。”你相信他吗？

I have another question for you: Take any idea you are 100 percent sure of: Perhaps that gold will rise over the next five years. Perhaps that God exists. Perhaps that your dentist is overcharging you. Whatever the belief, write it down in one sentence. Do you believe yourself?

我还有一个问题想问你：随便举一个你百分之百确定的想法：也许未来五年金价会上涨。也许上帝存在。也许你的牙医收费过高。无论你相信什么，用一句话写下来。你相信自己吗？

I bet you consider your conviction more valid than Bruce’s, right? Here’s why: Yours is an internal observation, whereas Bruce’s is external. Crudely put, you can peek into your own soul, but not into his.

我敢打赌，你肯定觉得你的信念比布鲁斯的更有道理，对吧？原因如下：你的信念是内在的观察，而布鲁斯的信念是外在的。简而言之，你可以窥视自己的灵魂，却窥视不到他的灵魂。

In Bruce’s case, you might think: “Come on, it’s obviously in his interest to believe that vitamins are beneficial. After all, his wealth and social status depend on the success of the company. He has to maintain a family tradition. All his life he has gulped down pills, so he’ll never admit that it was a waste of time.” For you, however, it’s a different story: You have searched deep inside. You are completely impartial.

就布鲁斯的情况而言，你可能会想：“拜托，相信维生素有益显然符合他的利益。毕竟，他的财富和社会地位取决于公司的成功。他必须维护家族传统。他一生都在吞食药丸，所以他永远不会承认那是浪费时间。” 然而，对你来说，情况就不同了：你已经深入内心了。你完全不偏不倚。

But how pure and honest is internal reflection? The Swedish psychologist Petter Johannson allowed test subjects to glimpse two portrait photos of random people and choose which face was more attractive. Then he showed them the preferred photo up close and asked them to describe the most attractive features. However, with a sleight of hand, he switched the pictures. Most participants failed to notice and proceeded to justify, in detail, why they favored the image. The results of the study: Introspection is not reliable. When we soul-search, we contrive the findings.

但内心反思究竟有多纯粹和真诚呢？瑞典心理学家佩特·约翰逊让受试者随意浏览两张人物肖像照，并挑选出哪张更具吸引力。然后，他向受试者近距离展示了他们最喜欢的那张照片，并要求他们描述其中最具吸引力的特征。然而，他巧妙地将照片换了。大多数受试者并未注意到这一点，并开始详细解释他们为什么更喜欢这张照片。研究结果：内省并不可靠。当我们进行自我反省时，我们往往会捏造出结论。

The belief that reflection leads to truth or accuracy is called the introspection illusion . This is more than sophistry. Because we are so confident of our beliefs, we experience three reactions when someone fails to share our views. Response 1: Assumption of ignorance. The other party clearly lacks the necessary information. If he knew what you know, he would be of the same opinion. Political activists think this way: They believe they can win others over through enlightenment. Reaction 2: Assumption of idiocy. The other person has the necessary information, but his mind is underdeveloped. He cannot draw the obvious conclusions. In other words, he’s a moron. This reaction is particularly popular with bureaucrats who want to protect “stupid” consumers from themselves. Response 3: Assumption of malice. Your counterpart has the necessary information—he even understands the debate—but he is deliberately confrontational. He has evil intentions. This is how many religious leaders and followers treat disbelievers: If they don’t agree, they must be servants of the devil!

认为反思可以得出真理或准确性的信念被称为内省错觉。这不仅仅是诡辩。因为我们对自己的信念如此自信，所以当有人不认同我们的观点时，我们会有三种反应。反应 1：假设对方无知。对方显然缺乏必要的信息。如果他知道你所知道的，他也会持同样的观点。政治活动家是这样想的：他们相信通过启蒙可以赢得他人的支持。反应 2：假设对方是白痴。对方具备必要的信息，但他的头脑不发达。他无法得出显而易见的结论。换句话说，他是个白痴。这种反应尤其受到那些想要保护“愚蠢”消费者免受自己伤害的官僚的欢迎。反应 3：假设对方有恶意。你的对手具备必要的信息 — — 他甚至理解这场辩论 — — 但他故意对抗。他心怀恶意。许多宗教领袖和信徒就是这样对待不信教者的：如果他们不同意，他们就是魔鬼的仆人！

In conclusion: Nothing is more convincing than your own beliefs. We believe that introspection unearths genuine self-knowledge. Unfortunately, introspection is, in large part, fabrication posing two dangers: First, the introspection illusion creates inaccurate predictions of future mental states. Trust your internal observations too much and too long, and you might be in for a very rude awakening. Second, we believe that our introspections are more reliable than those of others, which creates an illusion of superiority. Remedy: Be all the more critical with yourself. Regard your internal observations with the same skepticism as claims from some random person. Become your own toughest critic.

总结：没有什么比你自己的信念更有说服力。我们相信，内省能发掘真正的自我认知。然而，内省很大程度上是一种虚构，它会带来两个风险：首先，内省错觉会导致对未来精神状态的预测不准确。过度相信自己内心的观察，时间过长，你可能会大吃一惊。其次，我们认为自己比别人的内省更可靠，这会产生一种优越感。解决办法：对自己更加批判。用怀疑的态度对待你内心的观察，就像怀疑某个陌生人的言论一样。成为自己最严厉的批评者。

68

Why You Should Set Fire to Your Ships

为什么要放火烧你的船

Inability to Close Doors

无法关门

N ext to my bed, two dozen books are stacked high. I have dipped in and out of all of them but am unable to part with even one. I know that sporadic reading won’t help me achieve any real insights, despite the many hours I put in, and that I should really devote myself to one book at a time. So why am I still juggling all twenty-four?

我的床边堆满了二十四本书。我翻来覆去地翻阅，却一本也舍不得放下。我知道，即使我投入了大量时间，断断续续地阅读也无法让我获得真正的洞见，我应该一次只专注于一本书。那么，为什么我还要同时阅读二十四本书呢？

I know a man who is dating three women. He is in love with all three and can imagine starting a family with any of them. However, he simply doesn’t have the heart to choose just one because then he would be passing up on the other two for good. If he refrains from deciding, all options remain open. The downside is that no real relationship will develop.

我认识一个男人，他同时在和三个女人约会。他爱着这三个女人，甚至能想象和她们中的任何一个组建家庭。然而，他实在不忍心只选择一个，因为那样就等于永远放弃了另外两个。如果他不做决定，其他选择都还有机会。但缺点是，他不会发展出真正的感情。

In the third century BC, General Xiang Yu sent his army across the Yangtze River to take on the Qin dynasty. While his troops slept, he ordered all the ships to be set alight. The next day he told them: “You now have a choice: Either you fight to win or you die.” By removing the option of retreat, he switched their focus to the only thing that mattered: the battle. Spanish conquistador Cortés used the same motivational trick in the sixteenth century. After landing on the east coast of Mexico, he sank his own ship.

公元前三世纪，项羽将军率军渡过长江攻打秦朝。他趁士兵们熟睡时下令将所有船只付之一炬。第二天，他告诉士兵们：“现在你们面临一个选择：要么奋战求胜，要么战死沙场。” 通过剥夺撤退的选择，他让士兵们的注意力转移到唯一重要的事情上：战斗。16世纪，西班牙征服者科尔特斯也使用了同样的激励手段。在登陆墨西哥东海岸后，他击沉了自己的船只。

Xiang Yu and Cortés are exceptions. We mere mortals do everything we can to keep open the maximum number of options. Psychology professors Dan Ariely and Jiwoong Shin demonstrated the strength of this instinct using a computer game. Players started with one hundred points, and on the screen in front of them, three doors appeared—a red one, a blue one, and a green one. Opening a door cost a point, but for every room they entered, they could accrue more points. The players reacted logically: They found the most fruitful room and holed up there for the whole session. Ariely and Shin then changed the rules. If doors were not opened within twelve moves, they started shrinking on the screen and eventually vanished. Players now rushed from door to door to secure access to all potential treasure troves. All this unproductive scrambling meant they scored 15 percent fewer points than in the previous game. The organizers then added another twist: Opening doors now cost three points. The same anxiety kicked in: Players frittered away their points trying to keep all doors open. Even when the subjects learned how many points were hidden in each room, nothing changed. Sacrificing options was a price they were not willing to pay.

项羽和科尔特斯是例外。我们凡人会竭尽所能，保留尽可能多的选择。心理学教授丹·艾瑞里和申智雄用一款电脑游戏展示了这种本能的力量。玩家初始得分为100分，他们面前的屏幕上出现了三扇门——一扇红门、一扇蓝门和一扇绿门。打开一扇门需要1分，但每进入一个房间，就能获得更多分数。玩家们做出了合乎逻辑的反应：他们找到了最有收获的房间，并在那里躲了整整一局。艾瑞里和申智雄随后改变了规则。如果十二步之内没有打开门，门就会在屏幕上缩小，最终消失。玩家们现在需要从一扇门冲到另一扇门，以确保获得所有潜在的宝藏。所有这些徒劳无功的争抢导致他们的得分比上一局少了15%。随后，组织者又增加了一个新规则：现在打开门需要3分。同样的焦虑感再次袭来：玩家们为了保持所有门都打开而浪费了积分。即使受试者知道每个房间隐藏着多少积分，情况也没有任何改变。牺牲选择权是他们不愿承受的代价。

Why do we act so irrationally? Because the downside to such behavior is not always apparent. In the financial markets, things are clear: A financial option on a security always costs something. There is no such thing as a free option. In most other realms, however, options seem to be free. But this is an illusion. They also come at a price, but the price tag is often hidden and intangible: Each decision costs mental energy and eats up precious time for thinking and living. CEOs who examine every possible expansion option often choose none in the end. Companies that aim to address all customer segments end up addressing no one. Salespeople who chase every single lead close no deals.

我们为什么会如此不理性？因为这种行为的弊端并不总是显而易见的。在金融市场，情况一目了然：证券的金融期权总是需要付出代价的。没有免费的期权。然而，在大多数其他领域，期权似乎是免费的。但这只是一种假象。期权也有代价，但代价往往是隐蔽的、无形的：每个决策都会耗费脑力，吞噬宝贵的思考和生活时间。那些研究所有可能的扩张方案的CEO，最终往往什么都做不了。那些力求满足所有客户群体的公司，最终却一个也满足不了。那些追逐每一条销售线索的销售人员最终也做不成任何交易。

We are obsessed with having as many irons as possible in the fire, ruling nothing out, and being open to everything. However, this can easily destroy success. We must learn to close doors. A business strategy is primarily a statement on what not to engage in. Adopt a life strategy similar to a corporate strategy: Write down what not to pursue in your life. In other words, make calculated decisions to disregard certain possibilities and when an option shows up, test it against your not-to-pursue list. It will not only keep you from trouble but also save you lots of thinking time. Think hard once and then just consult your list instead of having to make up your mind whenever a new door cracks open. Most doors are not worth entering, even when the handle seems to turn so effortlessly.

我们执着于同时做尽可能多的事情，不排除任何可能性，对一切都持开放态度。然而，这很容易毁掉成功。我们必须学会关上大门。商业战略本质上就是告诉人们哪些事情不该做。不妨采取类似于企业战略的人生战略：写下你一生中不该追求的事情。换句话说，经过深思熟虑后，放弃某些可能性，当一个选项出现时，对照你的“不该追求”清单进行测试。这不仅能让你避免麻烦，还能节省你大量的思考时间。认真思考一次，然后直接参考你的清单，而不是每次看到新的门就不得不下定决心。大多数门都不值得一试，即使把手看起来转动起来毫不费力。

69

Disregard the Brand New

忽视全新

Neomania

新狂热

H ow will the world look in fifty years? What will your everyday life be like? With which items will you surround yourself?

五十年后的世界会是什么样子？你的日常生活会是什么样子？你的身边会摆放哪些物品？

People who pondered this question fifty years ago had fanciful notions of how “the future” would look: Highways in the skies. Cities that resemble glass worlds. Bullet trains winding between gleaming skyscrapers. We would live in plastic capsules, work in underwater cities, vacation on the moon, and consume everything in pill form. We wouldn’t conceive offspring anymore; instead we would choose children from a catalog. Our best friends would be robots, death would be cured, and we would have exchanged our bikes for jet packs long ago.

五十年前思考这个问题的人们对“未来”有着异想天开的设想：空中高速公路。玻璃世界般的城市。子弹头列车在闪闪发光的摩天大楼间穿梭。我们将生活在塑料胶囊里，在水下城市工作，在月球上度假，所有食物都以药丸的形式摄入。我们不再生育后代，而是从目录中选择孩子。我们最好的朋友是机器人，死亡将被治愈，我们早就用喷气背包取代自行车了。

But hang on a second. Take a look around. You’re sitting in a chair, an invention from ancient Egypt. You wear pants, developed about five thousand years ago and adapted by Germanic tribes around 750 BC. The idea behind your leather shoes comes from the last ice age. Your bookshelves are made of wood, one of the oldest building materials in the world. At dinnertime, you use a fork, a well-known “killer app” from Roman times, to shovel chunks of dead animals and plants into your mouths. Nothing has changed.

等等。看看周围。你正坐在椅子上，这是古埃及的发明。你穿着裤子，大约在五千年前发明，并在公元前750年左右被日耳曼部落改良。你的皮鞋的灵感来自上一个冰河时代。你的书架是用木头做的，这是世界上最古老的建筑材料之一。晚餐时，你会用叉子，这是罗马时代著名的“杀手锏”，把死去的动植物残骸铲进嘴里。一切都没有改变。

How will the world look in fifty years? In his latest book, Antifragile , Nassim Taleb gives us a clue: Assume that most of the technology that has existed for the past fifty years will serve us for another half century. And assume that recent technology will be passé in a few years’ time. Why? Think of these inventions as if they were species: Whatever has held its own throughout centuries of innovation will probably continue to do so in the future, too. Old technology has proven itself; it possesses an inherent logic even if we do not always understand it. If something has endured for epochs, it must be worth its salt. You can take this to heart the next time you are in a strategy meeting. Fifty years into the future will look a lot like today. Of course, you will witness the birth of many flashy gadgets and magic contraptions. But most will be short-lived.

五十年后的世界会是什么样子？纳西姆·塔勒布在其新书《反脆弱》中给出了一条线索：假设过去五十年中存在的大多数技术将为我们服务半个世纪。同时假设最近的技术几年后就会过时。为什么？不妨把这些发明想象成一个物种：任何在几个世纪的创新中屹立不倒的东西，在未来很可能也会继续屹立不倒。旧技术已经证明了自己；它拥有内在的逻辑，即使我们并不总是理解它。如果某种东西能够历经几个时代，它一定是有价值的。下次参加战略会议时，你可以把这句话牢记在心。五十年后的未来将与今天非常相似。当然，你会见证许多炫酷的小玩意和神奇装置的诞生。但大多数都将昙花一现。

When contemplating the future, we place far too much emphasis on flavor-of-the-month inventions and the latest “killer apps” while underestimating the role of traditional technology. In the 1960s, space travel was all the rage, so we imagined ourselves on school trips to Mars. In the ’70s, plastic was in, so we mulled over how we would furnish our see-through houses. Taleb traces this tendency back to the neomania pitfall: the mania for all things shiny and new.

当我们展望未来时，我们过于注重那些时下流行的发明和最新的“杀手级应用”，而低估了传统科技的作用。20世纪60年代，太空旅行风靡一时，我们想象着自己去火星旅行。70年代，塑料大行其道，我们琢磨着该如何装饰我们透明的房子。塔勒布将这种倾向追溯到“新潮狂热”的陷阱：对所有闪亮新奇事物的狂热。

In the past, I sympathized with so-called early adopters, the breed of people who cannot survive without the latest iPhone. I thought they were ahead of their time. Now I regard them as irrational and suffering from a kind of sickness: neomania . To them, it is of minor importance if an invention provides tangible benefits; novelty matters more.

过去，我同情所谓的“早期采用者”，也就是那些没有最新款iPhone就活不下去的人。我当时觉得他们领先于时代。现在，我却认为他们缺乏理性，患上了一种病：新奇癖。对他们来说，一项发明是否能带来实际好处并不重要；“新奇”才是最重要的。

So don’t go out on a limb when forecasting the future. Stanley Kubrick’s cult movie 2001: A Space Odyssey illustrates why you shouldn’t. Made in 1968, the movie predicted that, at the turn of the millennium, the United States would have a thousand-strong colony on the moon and that Pan Am would operate the commuter flights there and back. With this fanciful forecast in mind, I suggest this rule of thumb: Whatever has survived for X years will last another X years. Taleb wagers that the “bullshit filter of history” will sort the gimmicks from the game changers. And that’s one bet I’m willing to back.

所以，预测未来时不要冒险。斯坦利·库布里克的邪典电影《2001：太空漫游》就说明了为什么你不应该冒险。这部拍摄于1968年的电影预测，在千禧年之际，美国将在月球上建立一座拥有1000人的殖民地，泛美航空将运营往返月球的通勤航班。考虑到这个不切实际的预测，我建议遵循一条经验法则：任何存活了X年的东西，都将再存活X年。塔勒布打赌，“历史的胡扯过滤器”会区分出噱头和真正改变游戏规则的因素。我愿意支持这个赌注。

70

Why Propaganda Works

宣传为何有效

Sleeper Effect

睡眠者效应

D uring World War II, every nation produced propaganda movies. These were devised to fill the population, especially soldiers, with enthusiasm for their country and, if necessary, to bolster them to lay down their lives. The United States spent so much money on propaganda that the War Department decided to find out whether the expense was really worth it. A number of studies were carried out to investigate how the movies affected regular soldiers. The result was disappointing: They did not intensify the privates’ enthusiasm for war in the slightest.

第二次世界大战期间，各国纷纷制作宣传电影。这些电影旨在激发民众，尤其是士兵对祖国的热爱，并在必要时激励他们献出生命。美国在宣传上投入了巨额资金，以至于陆军部决定调查这些投入是否真的值得。他们开展了一系列研究，以调查这些电影对普通士兵的影响。结果令人失望：它们丝毫没有增强士兵的战争热情。

Was it because they were poorly made? Hardly. Rather, the soldiers were aware that the movies were propaganda, which discredited their message even before they were rolling. Even if the movie argued a point reasonably or managed to stir the audience, it didn’t matter; its content was deemed hollow from the outset and dismissed.

是因为影片制作粗糙吗？并非如此。更确切地说，士兵们意识到这些影片是宣传品，这在影片上映之前就已经使其所传达的信息失去可信度。即使影片论证了某个观点，或者成功地激起了观众的共鸣，也无济于事；其内容从一开始就被认为空洞无物，因此被忽略了。

Nine weeks later, something unexpected happened. The psychologists measured the soldiers’ attitudes a second time. The result: Whoever had seen the movie expressed much more support for the war than those who had not viewed it. Apparently, propaganda did work after all!

九周后，意想不到的事情发生了。心理学家们再次测量了士兵们的态度。结果：看过这部电影的人比没看过的人对战争的支持程度要高得多。看来，宣传终究还是奏效了！

The scientists were baffled, especially since they knew that an argument’s persuasiveness decreased over time. It has a half-life like a radioactive substance. Surely you have experienced this yourself: Let’s say you read an article on the benefits of gene therapy. Immediately after reading it you are a zealous convert, but after a few weeks, you don’t really remember why. More time passes until finally only a tiny fraction of enthusiasm remains.

科学家们对此感到困惑，尤其因为他们知道一个论点的说服力会随着时间的推移而减弱。它就像放射性物质一样，有半衰期。你肯定也经历过这种情况：假设你读了一篇关于基因疗法益处的文章。读完之后，你立刻热情地皈依了该疗法，但几周后，你却记不清为什么了。时间一长，热情只剩下微乎其微的余波。

Amazingly, just the opposite is true for propaganda. If it strikes a chord with someone, this influence will only increase over time. Why? Psychologist Carl Hovland, who led the study for the War Department, named this phenomenon the sleeper effect . To date, the best explanation is that, in our memories, the source of the argument fades faster than the argument. In other words, your brain quickly forgets where the information came from (e.g., from the Department of Propaganda). Meanwhile, the message itself (i.e., war is necessary and noble) fades only slowly or even endures. Therefore, any knowledge that stems from an untrustworthy source gains credibility over time. The discrediting force melts away faster than the message does.

令人惊讶的是，宣传恰恰相反。如果它引起了某人的共鸣，这种影响力只会随着时间的推移而增强。为什么呢？领导美国陆军部这项研究的心理学家卡尔·霍夫兰将这种现象命名为“睡眠者效应”。迄今为止，最好的解释是，在我们的记忆中，论点的来源比论点本身消逝得更快。换句话说，你的大脑很快就会忘记信息的来源（例如，来自宣传部）。与此同时，信息本身（即战争是必要的和高尚的）只会缓慢地消逝，甚至会持续存在。因此，任何来自不可靠来源的信息都会随着时间的推移而获得可信度。抹黑的力量消散的速度比信息本身更快。

In the United States, elections increasingly revolve around nasty advertisements, in which candidates seek to tarnish one another’s record or reputation. However, by law, each political ad must disclose its sponsor at the end so that it is clearly distinguishable as an electioneering message. However, countless studies show that the sleeper effect does its job here, too, especially among undecided voters. The messenger fades from memory; the ugly accusations persevere.

在美国，选举日益被恶意广告所笼罩，候选人试图抹黑彼此的记录或声誉。然而，根据法律规定，每则政治广告都必须在结尾处披露其赞助商，以便清晰地辨认其为竞选宣传。然而，无数研究表明，“潜伏效应”在这里也发挥了作用，尤其是在摇摆选民中。宣传者被遗忘，而那些丑陋的指控却挥之不去。

I’ve often wondered why advertising works at all. Any logical person must recognize ads for what they are, and suitably categorize and disqualify them. But even you as a discerning and intelligent reader won’t always succeed at this. It’s quite possible that, after a few weeks, you won’t remember if you picked up certain information from a well-researched article or from a tacky advertorial.

我常常思考广告究竟为何有效。任何理性的人都应该能辨别广告的真面目，并对其进行适当的分类和筛选。但即使你是一位眼光敏锐、睿智的读者，也未必总能做到这一点。很有可能，几周后，你就记不清自己是从一篇研究透彻的文章中，还是从一篇俗气的软文广告中获取了某些信息。

How can you thwart the sleeper effect ? First, don’t accept any unsolicited advice, even if it seems well meant. Doing so, you protect yourself to a certain degree from manipulation. Second, avoid ad-contaminated sources like the plague. How fortunate we are that books are (still) ad-free! Third, try to remember the source of every argument you encounter. Whose opinions are these? And why do they think that way? Probe the issue like an investigator would: Cui bono ? Who benefits? Admittedly, this is a lot of work and will slow down your decision making. But it will also refine it.

如何才能避免“沉睡者效应”？首先，不要接受任何未经请求的建议，即使它看起来是善意的。这样做可以在一定程度上保护自己免受操纵。其次，要像躲避瘟疫一样避开那些充斥着广告的信息来源。我们多么幸运，书籍（仍然）没有广告！第三，试着记住你遇到的每一个论点的来源。这些观点是谁的？他们为什么这么认为？像调查员一样探究这个问题：谁受益？谁受益？诚然，这需要大量工作，会减慢你的决策速度。但它也会使你的决策更加精准。

71

Why It’s Never Just a Two-Horse Race

为什么这绝不仅仅是一场双雄之争

Alternative Blindness

另类失明

Y ou leaf through a brochure that gushes about the benefits of the university’s MBA degree. Your gaze sweeps over photos of the ivy-covered campus and the ultramodern sports facilities. Sprinkled throughout are images of smiling students from various ethnic backgrounds with an emphasis on young women, young Chinese, and young Indian go-getters. On the last page you come to an overview that illustrates the financial value of an MBA. The $100,000 fee is easily offset by the statistical extra income that graduates earn before they retire: $400,000— after taxes. Who wouldn’t want to be up $300,000? It’s a no-brainer.

你翻阅着一本宣传册，上面滔滔不绝地介绍了这所大学MBA学位的种种优势。你的目光扫过常春藤覆盖的校园和超现代化体育设施的照片。照片中散布着来自不同种族背景、笑容满面的学生照片，重点是年轻女性、华裔青年和积极进取的印度青年。在最后一页，你会看到一份概述，阐述了MBA学位的经济价值。10万美元的学费很容易被毕业生退休前获得的额外收入抵消：40万美元——税后。谁不想多赚30万美元呢？这显而易见。

Wrong. Such an argument hides not one but four fallacies. First, we have the swimmer’s body illusion : MBA programs attract career-oriented people who will probably earn above-average salaries at some stage of their careers, even without the extra qualification of an MBA. The second fallacy: An MBA takes two years. During this time you can expect a loss of earnings—say, $100,000. So in fact the MBA costs $200,000, not $100,000. That amount, if invested well, could easily exceed the additional income that the brochure promises. Third, to estimate earnings that are more than thirty years away is idiotic. Who knows what will happen over the next three decades? Finally, other alternatives exist. You are not stuck between “do an MBA” and “don’t do an MBA.” Perhaps you can find a different program that costs significantly less and also represents a shot in the arm for your career. This fourth misconception interests me the most. Let’s call it alternative blindness : We systematically forget to compare an existing offer with the next-best alternative.

错了。这种说法背后隐藏着不止一个，而是四个谬误。首先，我们犯了游泳运动员身体错觉：MBA 课程吸引的是职业导向型人才，即使没有 MBA 的额外资格，他们也可能在职业生涯的某个阶段获得高于平均水平的薪水。第二个谬误：MBA 课程需要两年时间。在此期间，你可能会损失收入，比如说 10 万美元。所以实际上 MBA 课程的费用是 20 万美元，而不是 10 万美元。如果投资得当，这笔钱很容易超过宣传册承诺的额外收入。第三，估算三十年后的收入是愚蠢的。谁知道未来三十年会发生什么？最后，还有其他选择。你不必在“读 MBA”和“不读 MBA”之间左右为难。也许你可以找到一个费用低得多，还能为你的职业生涯注入活力的其他课程。第四个误解最让我感兴趣。我们称之为“选择盲区”：我们总是忘记将现有报价与次优替代方案进行比较。

Here’s an example from the world of finance: Suppose you have a little money in your savings account, and you ask your investment broker for advice. He proposes a bond that will earn you 5 percent interest. “That’s much better than the 1 percent you get with your savings account,” he points out. Does it make sense to buy the bond? We don’t know. It’s wrong to consider just these two options. To assess your options properly, you would have to compare the bond with all other investment options and then select the best. This is how top investor Warren Buffett does things: “Each deal we measure against the second-best deal that is available at any given time—even if it means doing more of what we are already doing.”

举个金融界的例子：假设你的储蓄账户里有一点钱，你向你的投资经纪人寻求建议。他推荐你购买一张能获得5%利息的债券。“这比你储蓄账户1%的利息好多了，”他指出。购买这张债券划算吗？我们不知道。只考虑这两种选择是错误的。要正确评估你的选择，你必须将这张债券与所有其他投资选择进行比较，然后选择最佳方案。顶级投资者沃伦·巴菲特就是这样做的：“我们会把每一笔交易与当时市面上第二好的价格进行比较——即使这意味着我们要比现在做得更多。”

Unlike Warren Buffett, politicians often fall victim to alternative blindness . Let’s say your city is planning to build a sports arena on a vacant plot of land. Supporters argue that such an arena would benefit the population much more that an empty lot—both emotionally and financially. But this comparison is wrong. They should compare the construction of the sports arena with all other ideas that become impossible due to its construction—for example, building a school, a performing arts center, a hospital, or an incinerator. They could also sell the land and invest the proceeds or reduce the city’s debt.

与沃伦·巴菲特不同，政客们常常会陷入对其他方案的盲目性。假设你的城市计划在一块空地上建造一个体育场馆。支持者认为，这样的体育场馆比空地更能造福民众——无论是在情感上还是在经济上。但这种比较是错误的。他们应该将体育场馆的建设与所有其他因其建设而无法实现的方案进行比较——例如，建造学校、表演艺术中心、医院或焚化炉。他们也可以出售土地，将所得收益用于投资，或者减少城市债务。

And you? Do you often overlook the alternatives? Let’s say your doctor discovers a tumor that will kill you in five years. He proposes a complicated operation that, if successful, removes the tumor completely. However, this procedure is highly risky, with a survival rate of just 50 percent. How do you decide? You weigh up your choices: Certain death in five years or a 50 percent chance of dying next week. Alternative blindness ! Perhaps there is a variant of the invasive surgery that your hospital doesn’t offer but a hospital across town does. This invasive surgery might not remove the tumor altogether, just slow its growth, but is much safer and gives you an extra ten years. And who knows, maybe during these ten years a more sophisticated therapy for eradicating tumors will be made available.

你呢？你是否经常忽略其他选择？假设你的医生发现一个肿瘤，五年后你就会死。他建议你做一个复杂的手术，如果手术成功，就能彻底切除肿瘤。然而，这种手术风险极高，存活率只有50%。你会如何抉择？你需要权衡各种选择：五年内必死无疑，还是下周死亡的概率高达50%。另一种选择是失明！或许有一种侵入性手术，你所在的医院没有，但城里另一边的医院却有。这种侵入性手术或许不能彻底切除肿瘤，只是减缓其生长，但它更安全，还能让你多活十年。谁知道呢，也许在这十年里，一种更为先进的肿瘤根除疗法将会问世。

The bottom line: If you have trouble making a decision, remember that the choices are broader than “no surgery” or “highly risky surgery.” Forget about the rock and the hard place, and open your eyes to the other, superior alternatives.

底线是：如果你难以做出决定，请记住，选择范围远不止“不做手术”或“高风险手术”。别再纠结于眼前的困境，放眼其他更优的选择吧。

72

Why We Take Aim at Young Guns

为什么我们瞄准年轻人

Social Comparison Bias

社会比较偏差

A s one of my books reached number one on the bestseller list, my publisher asked me for a favor. An acquaintance’s title was on the verge of entering the top 10 list, and the publisher was convinced that a testimonial from me would give it the necessary push.

我的一本书登上畅销书排行榜第一名后，出版商请我帮忙。他认识的一位朋友的书即将进入前十，出版商确信我的推荐能给这本书带来必要的推动力。

It always amazes me that these little testimonials work at all. Everyone knows that only favorable comments end up on a book’s jacket. (The book you hold in your hands is no exception.) A rational reader should ignore the praise or at least consider it alongside the criticism, which is always available, albeit in different places. Nevertheless, I’ve written plenty of testimonials for other books, but they were never for rival titles. I hesitated: Wouldn’t writing a blurb be cutting off my nose to spite my face? Why should I help someone who might soon vie for the top slot? As I pondered the question, I realized social comparison bias had kicked in—that is, the tendency to withhold assistance to people who might outdo you, even if you look like a fool in the long run.

这些小小的推荐信竟然能起到作用，这总是让我感到惊讶。众所周知，只有好评才会出现在书封上。（你手里拿着的这本书也不例外。）一个理性的读者应该忽略这些赞美，或者至少将其与批评放在一起考虑，批评总是存在的，尽管它们出现在不同的地方。尽管如此，我也为其他书籍写过很多推荐信，但从未为竞争对手的书籍写过。我犹豫了：写个简介难道不是自作自受吗？我为什么要帮助一个可能很快就能跻身榜首的人？当我思考这个问题时，我意识到社会比较偏见已经出现了——也就是说，即使从长远来看你看起来像个傻瓜，你也倾向于拒绝帮助那些可能胜过你的人。

Book testimonials are a harmless example of the social comparison bias . However, the phenomenon has reached toxic levels in academia. Every scientist’s goal is to publish as many articles as possible in the most prestigious scientific journals. Over time, you make a name for yourself, and soon editors ask you to assess other scientists’ submissions. In the end, often just two or three experts decide what gets published in a particular field. Taking this into account, what happens if a young researcher sends in an earth-shattering paper that turns the entire department on its head and threatens to knock them off their thrones? They will be especially rigorous when evaluating the article. That’s social comparison bias hard at work.

书籍推荐是社会比较偏见的一个无害例子。然而，这种现象在学术界已达到有害的程度。每位科学家的目标都是在最负盛名的科学期刊上发表尽可能多的文章。久而久之，你声名鹊起，很快编辑们就会请你评估其他科学家的投稿。最终，通常只有两三位专家决定在特定领域发表哪些文章。考虑到这一点，如果一位年轻的研究人员提交了一篇惊天动地的论文，让整个部门都为之震惊，甚至威胁到他们的科研水平，会发生什么？他们在评估文章时会格外严格。这就是社会比较偏见在作祟。

The psychologist Stephen Garcia and his fellow researchers describe the case of a Nobel laureate who prevented a promising young colleague from applying for a job at “his” university. This may seem judicious in the short term, but in the long run it is counterproductive. What happens when that young prodigy joins another research group and applies his acumen there—most likely depriving the old institution of maintaining its world-class status? Garcia suggests that social comparison bias may well be the reason why hardly any research groups remain at the top for many years in succession.

心理学家斯蒂芬·加西亚和他的同事们描述了一位诺贝尔奖得主阻止一位前途无量的年轻同事申请“他”所在大学的职位的案例。从短期来看，这或许明智，但从长远来看，却适得其反。如果这位年轻的天才加入另一个研究小组，并在那里运用他的智慧——这很可能使原有的机构失去世界一流地位——会发生什么？加西亚认为，社会比较偏差很可能是导致几乎没有研究小组能够连续多年保持领先地位的原因。

The social comparison bias is also a cause for concern with start-up companies. Guy Kawasaki was “chief evangelist” at Apple for four years. Today he is a venture capitalist and advises entrepreneurs. Kawasaki says: “A-players hire people even better than themselves. It’s clear, though, that B-players hire C-players so they can feel superior to them, and C-players hire D-players. If you start hiring B-players, expect what Steve [Jobs] called ‘the bozo explosion’ to happen in your organization.” In other words, start hiring B-players and you end up with Z-players. Recommendation: Hire people who are better than you, otherwise you soon preside over a pack of underdogs. The so-called Duning-Kruger effect applies to such Z-players: The inept are gifted at overlooking the extent of their incompetence. They suffer from illusory superiority, which leads them to make even more thinking errors, thus creating a vicious cycle that erodes the talent pool over time.

社会比较偏差也是初创公司值得担忧的一个原因。盖伊·川崎曾在苹果公司担任了四年的“首席布道师”。如今，他是一位风险投资家，为企业家提供咨询服务。川崎说道：“A级人才会雇佣比自己更优秀的人。但很明显，B级人才会雇佣C级人才，这样他们就会觉得自己比别人优越，而C级人才则会雇佣D级人才。如果你开始雇佣B级人才，那么史蒂夫·乔布斯所说的‘笨蛋爆炸’就会在你的公司发生。”换句话说，如果你开始雇佣B级人才，最终你只会雇佣Z级人才。建议：雇佣比你优秀的人，否则你很快就会被一群弱者所包围。所谓的达宁-克鲁格效应就适用于这类Z级人才：无能的人往往容易忽视自己能力的不足。他们被虚幻的优越感所困扰，这导致他们犯下更多的思维错误，从而形成恶性循环，随着时间的推移，人才库逐渐流失。

While his school was closed due to an outbreak of plague in 1666–67, twenty-five-year-old Isaac Newton showed his professor, Isaac Barrow, what research he was conducting in his spare time. Barrow immediately gave up his job as a professor and became a student of Newton. What a noble gesture. What ethical behavior. When was the last time you heard of a professor vacating his post in favor of a better candidate? And when was the last time you read about a CEO clearing out his desk when he realized that one of his twenty thousand employees could do a better job?

1666-67年，学校因瘟疫爆发而关闭，25岁的艾萨克·牛顿向他的教授艾萨克·巴罗展示了他在业余时间进行的研究。巴罗立即辞去了教授职务，成为牛顿的学生。这是多么高尚的举动，多么合乎道德的行为。你上次听说教授辞去职位，让位给更合适的人选是什么时候？你上次读到一位首席执行官意识到两万名员工中有人能做得更好，于是清理办公桌，又是什么时候？

In conclusion: Do you foster individuals more talented than you? Admittedly, in the short term, the preponderance of stars can endanger your status, but in the long run, you can only profit from their contributions. Others will overtake you at some stage anyway. Until then, you should get in the up-and-comers’ good books—and learn from them. This is why I wrote the testimonial in the end.

总结：你培养的人才比你更有才华吗？诚然，短期内明星辈出可能会危及你的地位，但从长远来看，你只会从他们的贡献中获益。反正总有一天会有人超越你。在那之前，你应该好好学习这些后起之秀，并向他们学习。这就是我最后写下那篇感言的原因。

73

Why First Impressions Are Deceiving

为什么第一印象具有欺骗性

Primacy and Recency Effects

首因效应和近因效应

A llow me to introduce you to two men, Alan and Ben. Without thinking about it too long, decide whom you prefer. Alan is smart, hardworking, impulsive, critical, stubborn, and jealous. Ben, however, is jealous, stubborn, critical, impulsive, hardworking, and smart. Who would you prefer to get stuck with in an elevator? Most people choose Alan, even though the descriptions are exactly the same. Your brain pays more attention to the first adjectives in the lists, causing you to identify two different personalities. Alan is smart and hardworking. Ben is jealous and stubborn. The first traits outshine the rest. This is called the primacy effect .

请允许我向你介绍两位男士，艾伦和本。不用想太多，决定一下你更喜欢谁。艾伦聪明、勤奋、冲动、挑剔、固执、嫉妒心强。而本则嫉妒心强、固执、挑剔、冲动、勤奋、聪明。你更愿意和谁一起被困在电梯里？尽管他们的描述一模一样，但大多数人还是会选择艾伦。你的大脑会更关注列表中的第一个形容词，导致你识别出两种不同的性格。艾伦聪明又勤奋。本嫉妒心强又固执。第一个特质比其他特质更突出。这被称为首因效应。

If it were not for the primacy effect , people would refrain from decking out their headquarters with luxuriously appointed entrance halls. Your lawyer would feel happy turning up to meet you in worn-out sneakers rather than beautifully polished designer oxfords.

如果不是首因效应，人们就不会在公司总部布置奢华的门厅。你的律师会很乐意穿着破旧的运动鞋来见你，而不是穿着擦得锃亮的名牌牛津鞋。

The primacy effect triggers practical errors, too. Nobel laureate Daniel Kahneman describes how he used to grade examination papers at the beginning of his professorship. He did it as most teachers do—in order: student 1 followed by student 2 and so on. This meant that students who answered the first questions flawlessly endeared themselves to him, thus affecting how he graded the remaining parts of their exams. So, Kahneman switched methods and began to grade the individual questions in batches—all the answers to question one, then the answers to question two, and so forth. Thus, he canceled out the primacy effect .

首因效应也会引发实际错误。诺贝尔奖得主丹尼尔·卡尼曼描述了他刚开始教授生涯时是如何批改试卷的。他和大多数老师一样，按顺序批改：学生1，然后是学生2，依此类推。这意味着，那些完美回答第一个问题的学生会赢得他的好感，从而影响他对其余部分试卷的评分。于是，卡尼曼改变了方法，开始分批批改单个试卷——先批改第一个问题的所有答案，然后是第二个问题的答案，以此类推。这样，他就抵消了首因效应。

Unfortunately, this trick is not always replicable. When recruiting a new employee, for example, you run the risk of hiring the person who makes the best first impression. Ideally, you would set up all the candidates in order and let them answer the same question one after the other.

不幸的是，这个技巧并不总是可复制的。例如，在招聘新员工时，你可能会雇佣给人留下第一印象最好的人。理想情况下，你应该把所有候选人按顺序排列，让他们一个接一个地回答同一个问题。

Suppose you sit on the board of a company. A point of discussion is raised—a topic on which you have not yet passed judgment. The first opinion you hear will be crucial to your overall assessment. The same applies to the other participants, a fact that you can exploit: If you have an opinion, don’t hesitate airing it first. This way, you will influence your colleagues more and draw them over to your side. If, however, you are chairing the committee, always ask members’ opinions in random order so that no one has an unfair advantage.

假设你是一家公司的董事会成员。有人提出了一个讨论点——一个你尚未做出判断的话题。你听到的第一个意见将对你的整体评估至关重要。其他参与者也一样，你可以利用这一点：如果你有意见，不要犹豫，先说出来。这样，你就能更好地影响你的同事，并把他们拉拢到你这边。但是，如果你是委员会主席，请务必以随机顺序征求成员的意见，以免任何人获得不公平的优势。

The primacy effect is not always the culprit; the contrasting “recency effect” matters as well. The more recent the information, the better we remember it.
