This occurs because our short-term memory file drawer, as it were, contains very little extra space. When a new piece of information gets filed, an older piece of information is discarded to make room.

首因效应并非总是罪魁祸首；与之形成对比的“近因效应”也同样重要。信息越新，我们记得越牢。这是因为我们的短期记忆文件柜几乎没有多余的空间。当一条新信息被归档时，一条旧的信息就会被丢弃，腾出空间。

When does the primacy effect supersede the recency effect , or vice versa? If you have to make an immediate decision based on a series of “impressions” (such as characteristics, exam answers, etc.), the primacy effect weighs heavier. But if the series of impressions was formed some time ago, the recency effect dominates. For instance, if you listened to a speech a few weeks ago, you will remember the final point or punch line more clearly than your first impressions.

首因效应何时会取代近因效应，反之亦然？如果你必须根据一系列“印象”（例如性格、考试答案等）立即做出决定，首因效应会更加显著。但如果这一系列印象是在一段时间前形成的，近因效应就会占主导地位。例如，如果你几周前听过一场演讲，你会比第一印象更清楚地记得演讲的最后要点或妙语。

In conclusion: First and last impressions dominate, meaning the content sandwiched between has only a weak influence. Try to avoid evaluations based on first impressions. They will deceive you, guaranteed, in one way or another. Try to assess all aspects impartially. It’s not easy, but there are ways around it. For example, in interviews, I jot down a score every five minutes and calculate the average afterward. This way, I make sure that the “middle” counts just as much as hello and good-bye.

总结：第一印象和最后印象占主导地位，这意味着夹在中间的内容影响力很小。尽量避免基于第一印象的评价。它们肯定会以某种方式欺骗你。尽量客观地评估所有方面。这并非易事，但总有办法。例如，在面试中，我每五分钟记下一次分数，然后计算平均值。这样，我就能确保“中间”部分和你好、再见一样重要。

74

Why You Can’t Beat Homemade

为什么你不能打败自制

Not-Invented-Here Syndrome

非我发明综合症

M y cooking skills are quite modest, and my wife knows it. However, every now and then I concoct a dish that could pass for edible. A few weeks ago, I bought some sole. Determined to escape the monotony of familiar sauces, I devised a new one—a daring combination of white wine, pureed pistachio nuts, honey, grated orange peel, and a dash of balsamic vinegar. Upon tasting it, my wife slid her baked sole to the edge of the plate and began to scrape off the sauce, smiling ruefully as she did so. I, on the other hand, didn’t think it was bad at all. I explained to her in detail what a bold creation she was missing, but her expression stayed the same.

我的厨艺很一般，妻子也心知肚明。不过，我偶尔也能做出一盘勉强能吃的菜。几周前，我买了一条鳎鱼。为了摆脱那些千篇一律的酱汁，我发明了一种新的酱汁——大胆地用白葡萄酒、开心果泥、蜂蜜、橙皮碎和少许香醋混合。妻子尝了一口，把烤好的鳎鱼滑到盘子边缘，开始刮掉酱汁，脸上带着一丝苦笑。而我，却一点也不觉得这道菜糟糕。我详细地向她解释了她缺少什么大胆的创意，但她的表情却毫无变化。

Two weeks later, we were having sole again. This time my wife did the cooking. She prepared two sauces: The first was her tried-and-true beurre blanc, and the other, a new recipe from a French top chef. The second tasted horrible. Afterward, she confessed that it was not a French recipe at all, but a Swiss one: my masterpiece from two weeks before! She had caught me out. I was guilty of the not-invented-here syndrome ( NIH syndrome ), which fools us into thinking anything we create ourselves is unbeatable.

两周后，我们又吃了鲽鱼。这次我妻子做饭。她准备了两种酱汁：第一种是她屡试不爽的白黄油酱，另一种是法国顶级厨师的新配方。第二种味道糟透了。事后，她坦白说，这根本不是法国菜谱，而是瑞士菜谱：我两周前的杰作！她把我看穿了。我得了“非我发明”综合症（NIH综合症），这种综合症让我们误以为我们自己创造的任何东西都是无可匹敌的。

NIH syndrome causes you to fall in love with your own ideas. This is valid not only for fish sauces, but for all kinds of solutions, business ideas, and inventions. Companies tend to rate homegrown ideas as far more important than those from outsiders, even if, objectively, this is not the case. I recently had lunch with the CEO of a company that specializes in software for health insurance firms. He told me how difficult it is to sell his software to potential customers, even though his firm is the market leader in terms of service, security, and functionality. Most insurers are convinced that the best solution is what they have crafted themselves in-house over the past thirty years. Another CEO told me how hard it is to get his staff in the company’s headquarters to accept solutions proposed from far-flung subsidiaries.

NIH综合症会让你爱上自己的想法。这不仅适用于鱼露，也适用于各种解决方案、商业理念和发明。公司往往认为自主研发的创意远比外部创意重要，即使客观来看并非如此。我最近与一家专门为健康保险公司开发软件的公司的首席执行官共进午餐。他告诉我，尽管他的公司在服务、安全和功能方面处于市场领先地位，但向潜在客户推销他的软件却非常困难。大多数保险公司都坚信，最好的解决方案是他们过去三十年来在内部精心打造的。另一位首席执行官告诉我，要让公司总部的员工接受来自遥远子公司提出的解决方案是多么困难。

When people collaborate to solve problems and then evaluate these ideas themselves, NIH syndrome will inevitably exert an influence. Thus, it makes sense to split teams into two groups. The first group generates ideas, the second rates them, and vice versa. We tend to rate our own business ideas as more successful than other people’s concepts. This self-confidence forms the basis of thriving entrepreneurship but also explains start-ups’ frequently miserable returns.

当人们合作解决问题，然后自行评估这些想法时，NIH综合症不可避免地会产生影响。因此，将团队分成两组是合理的。第一组提出想法，第二组对其进行评估，反之亦然。我们倾向于认为自己的商业想法比别人的理念更成功。这种自信构成了蓬勃发展的创业精神的基础，但也解释了初创企业回报往往惨淡的原因。

This is how psychologist Dan Ariely measured the NIH syndrome . Writing in his blog at the New York Times , Ariely asked readers to provide solutions to six issues, such as “How can cities reduce water consumption without limiting it by law?” The readers had to make suggestions and to assess the feasibility of all the ideas proposed. They also had to specify how much of their time and money they would invest in each idea. Finally, they were limited to using a set list of fifty words, ensuring that everyone gave more or less the same answers. Despite this, the majority rated their own responses as more important and applicable than the others, even though the submissions were virtually identical.

心理学家丹·艾瑞里（Dan Ariely）就是这样测量NIH综合症的。艾瑞里在《纽约时报》的博客中写道，他要求读者针对六个问题提出解决方案，例如“城市如何在不立法限制用水的情况下减少用水量？”读者需要提出建议，并评估所有方案的可行性。他们还必须明确说明愿意为每个方案投入多少时间和金钱。最后，他们只能使用一份50字的固定答案，以确保每个人的答案大致相同。尽管如此，大多数人仍然认为自己的答案比其他人的答案更重要、更实用，尽管提交的答案几乎完全相同。

On a societal level, NIH syndrome has serious consequences. We overlook shrewd ideas simply because they come from other cultures. In Switzerland, where each state or “canton” has certain powers, one tiny canton never approved women’s suffrage; it took a federal court ruling in 1990 to change the law—a startling case of NIH . Or consider the modern traffic roundabout, with its clear yield requirements, that was designed by British transport engineers in the 1960s and implemented throughout the UK. It took another thirty years full of oblivion and resistance until this obvious traffic decongestant found its way in the United States and continental Europe. Today France alone has more than thirty thousand roundabouts, which the French now probably falsely attribute to the designer of the Place de l’Étoile.

在社会层面上，“非遗传性健康综合征”（NIH）会带来严重后果。我们会因为一些精明的想法来自其他文化而忽视它们。在瑞士，每个州或“州”（canton）都拥有一定的权力，但有一个小州从未批准过妇女参政权；直到1990年，联邦法院才最终裁决修改了法律——这是一个令人震惊的“非遗传性健康综合征”案例。或者想想现代交通环岛，它有明确的让行要求，是由英国交通工程师在20世纪60年代设计的，并在英国各地实施。又过了三十年，在被遗忘和抵制之后，这种显而易见的交通拥堵解决方案才在美国和欧洲大陆普及。如今，仅在法国就有三万多个环岛，而法国人现在可能错误地将它们归功于星形广场（Place de l’Étoile）的设计者。

In conclusion: We are drunk on our own ideas. To sober up, take a step back every now and then and examine their quality in hindsight. Which of your ideas from the past ten years were truly outstanding? Exactly.

总结：我们沉醉于自己的想法。为了清醒，不妨时不时地退一步，回顾一下它们的质量。过去十年里，你有哪些真正杰出的想法？没错。

75

How to Profit from the Implausible

如何从难以置信的事情中获利

The Black Swan

《黑天鹅》

A ll swans are white.” For centuries, this statement was watertight. Every snowy specimen corroborated this. A swan in a different color? Unthinkable. That was until the year 1697, when Willem de Vlamingh saw a black swan for the first time during an expedition to Australia. Since then, black swans have become symbols of the improbable.

“所有的天鹅都是白色的。”几个世纪以来，这句话无懈可击。每一只雪白的天鹅都印证了这一点。天鹅的颜色不一样？简直不可思议。直到1697年，威廉·德·弗拉明在澳大利亚探险期间第一次见到了黑天鹅。从那时起，黑天鹅就成了不可思议之事的象征。

You invest money in the stock market. Year in, year out, the Dow Jones rises and falls a little. Gradually, you grow accustomed to this gentle up and down. Then, suddenly, a day like October 19, 1987, comes around and the stock market tumbles 22 percent. With no warning. This event is a Black Swan , as described by Nassim Taleb in his book with the same title.

你把钱投入股市。年复一年，道琼斯指数时涨时跌。渐渐地，你习惯了这种平缓的波动。然后，突然间，像1987年10月19日这样的一天，股市暴跌了22%。毫无预兆。正如纳西姆·塔勒布在其同名著作中所描述的那样，这起事件就是一只“黑天鹅”。

A Black Swan is an unthinkable event that massively affects your life, your career, your company, your country. There are positive and negative Black Swans . The meteorite that flattens you, Sutter’s discovery of gold in California, the collapse of the Soviet Union, the invention of the transistor, the Internet browser, the overthrow of Egyptian dictator Mubarak, or another encounter that upturns your life completely—all are Black Swans .

黑天鹅是指那些对你的生活、事业、公司和国家产生巨大影响的不可想象的事件。黑天鹅有积极的一面，也有消极的一面。陨石砸扁你，萨特在加州发现黄金，苏联解体，晶体管和互联网浏览器的发明，埃及独裁者穆巴拉克的下台，或者其他彻底颠覆你生活的事件——所有这些都是黑天鹅。

Think what you like of former U.S. secretary of defense Donald Rumsfeld, but at a press conference in 2002, he expressed a philosophical thought with exceptional clarity when he offered this observation: There are things we know (“known facts”), there are things we do not know (“known unknowns”), and there are things we do not know that we do not know (“unknown unknowns”).

不管你怎么看待前美国国防部长唐纳德·拉姆斯菲尔德，他在 2002 年的一次新闻发布会上提出了这样的观点，他异常清晰地表达了一种哲学思想：有些事情我们知道（“已知事实”），有些事情我们不知道（“已知的未知数”），有些事情我们不知道我们不知道（“未知的未知数”）。

How big is the universe? Does Iran have nuclear weapons? Does the Internet make us smarter or dumber? These are “known unknowns.” With enough effort, we can hope to answer these one day. Unlike the “unknown unknowns.” No one foresaw Facebook mania ten years ago. It is a Black Swan .

宇宙有多大？伊朗有核武器吗？互联网让我们变得更聪明还是更愚蠢？这些都是“已知的未知数”。只要我们付出足够的努力，总有一天能够找到答案。这与“未知的未知数”不同。十年前没有人预见到Facebook的狂热。它是一只黑天鹅。

Why are Black Swans important? Because, as absurd as it may sound, they are cropping up more and more frequently and they tend to become more consequential. Though we can continue to plan for the future, Black Swans often destroy our best-laid plans. Feedback loops and nonlinear influences interact and cause unexpected results. The reason: Our brains are designed to help us hunt and gather. Back in the Stone Age, we hardly ever encountered anything truly extraordinary. The deer we chased was sometimes a bit faster or slower, sometimes a little bit fatter or thinner. Everything revolved around a stable mean.

为什么“黑天鹅”如此重要？因为，尽管听起来可能有些荒谬，但它们出现的频率越来越高，而且往往影响深远。虽然我们可以继续规划未来，但“黑天鹅”往往会破坏我们精心策划的计划。反馈回路和非线性影响相互作用，导致意想不到的结果。原因在于：我们的大脑是为了帮助我们狩猎和采集而设计的。在石器时代，我们几乎从未遇到过真正非同寻常的事情。我们追逐的鹿有时快一点，有时慢一点，有时胖一点，有时瘦一点。一切都围绕着一个稳定的平均值运转。

Today is different. With one breakthrough, you can increase your income by a factor of ten thousand. Just ask Larry Page, Usain Bolt, George Soros, J. K. Rowling, or Bono. Such fortunes did not exist previously; peaks of this size were unknown. Only in the most recent of human history has this been possible—hence our problem with extreme scenarios. Since probabilities cannot fall below zero, and our thought processes are prone to error, you should assume that everything has an above-zero probability.

如今情况不同了。只需一次突破，你的收入就能增加一万倍。问问拉里·佩奇、尤塞恩·博尔特、乔治·索罗斯、J·K·罗琳或波诺就知道了。这样的财富在以前是不存在的；如此规模的巅峰也从未出现过。只有在人类历史上最近的时期才有可能实现——因此我们才会面临极端情况的问题。由于概率不可能低于零，而我们的思维过程又容易出错，你应该假设所有事物的概率都高于零。

So, what can be done? Put yourself in situations where you can catch a ride on a positive Black Swan (as unlikely as that is). Become an artist, inventor, or entrepreneur with a scalable product. If you sell your time (e.g., as an employee, dentist, or journalist), you are waiting in vain for such a break. But even if you feel compelled to continue as such, avoid surroundings where negative Black Swans thrive. This means: Stay out of debt, invest your savings as conservatively as possible, and get used to a modest standard of living—no matter whether your big breakthrough comes or not.

那么，该怎么办呢？让自己置身于可以搭上“积极黑天鹅”的顺风车（尽管可能性不大）。成为一名艺术家、发明家或拥有可扩展产品的企业家。如果你出卖自己的时间（例如，作为一名雇员、牙医或记者），那么你等待这样的机会就是徒劳的。但即使你觉得不得不继续这样做，也要避开负面“黑天鹅”滋生的环境。这意味着：无论你的重大突破是否到来，都要避免负债，尽可能保守地投资你的积蓄，并习惯于适度的生活水平。

76

Knowledge Is Nontransferable

知识不可转让

Domain Dependence

领域依赖

W riting books about clear thinking brings with it many pluses. Business leaders and investors invite me to give talks for good money. (Incidentally, this is in itself poor judgment on their part: books are much cheaper.) At a medical conference, the following happened to me. I was speaking about base-rate neglect and illustrated it with a medical example: In a forty-year-old patient, stabbing chest pain (among other things) may indicate heart problems as well as stress. Stress is much more frequent (with a higher base rate), so it is advisable to test the patient for this first. All this is very reasonable, and the doctors understood it intuitively. But when I used an example from economics, most faltered.

写关于清晰思维的书籍有很多好处。商界领袖和投资者邀请我做演讲，报酬丰厚。（顺便说一句，这本身就是他们判断失误：书籍要便宜得多。）在一次医学会议上，我遇到了以下情况。当时我正在谈论基准忽视率，并用一个医学案例来说明：对于一位40岁的患者来说，胸口刺痛（以及其他症状）可能表明心脏问题以及压力。压力的发生率更高（基准忽视率也更高），因此建议先对患者进行这方面的检查。所有这些都很有道理，医生们也直观地理解了。但当我举一个经济学的例子时，大多数人都愣住了。

The same thing happens when I speak in front of investors. If I illustrate fallacies using financial examples, most catch on immediately. However, if I take instances from biology, many are lost. The conclusion: Insights do not pass well from one field to another. This effect is called domain dependence .

当我在投资者面前演讲时，也会发生同样的事情。如果我用金融例子来解释谬误，大多数人都能立刻理解。然而，如果我举生物学的例子，很多人就会听不懂。结论是：洞察力很难从一个领域很好地传递到另一个领域。这种效应被称为领域依赖性。

In 1990, Harry Markowitz received the Nobel Prize in Economics for his theory of “portfolio selection.” It describes the optimum composition of a portfolio, taking into account both risk and return prospects. When it came to Markowitz’s own portfolio—how he should allot his savings into stocks and bonds—he simply opted for fifty-fifty distribution: half in shares, the other half in bonds. The Nobel Prize winner was incapable of applying his ingenious process to his own affairs. A blatant case of domain dependence : He failed to transfer knowledge from the academic world to the private sphere.

1990年，哈里·马科维茨因其“投资组合选择”理论荣获诺贝尔经济学奖。该理论描述了投资组合的最佳构成，兼顾风险和回报前景。至于马科维茨自己的投资组合——他应该如何将储蓄配置到股票和债券中——他只是简单地选择了五五开的分配方式：一半投资股票，另一半投资债券。这位诺贝尔奖得主未能将他独创的策略应用于自身业务。这是一个明显的领域依赖案例：他未能将知识从学术界转移到私人领域。

A friend of mine is a hopeless adrenaline junkie, scaling overhanging cliffs with his bare hands, and launching himself off mountains in a wing suit. He explained to me last week why starting a business is dangerous: Bankruptcy can never be ruled out. “Personally, I’d rather be bankrupt than dead,” I replied. He didn’t appreciate my logic.

我有个朋友是个彻头彻尾的肾上腺素瘾君子，赤手空拳攀爬悬崖，还穿着翼装从山上跳下。上周他跟我解释了创业为何危险：破产的可能性不可避免。“就我个人而言，我宁愿破产也不愿死，”我回答道。他不太理解我的逻辑。

As an author, I realize just how difficult it is to transfer skills to a new area. For me, devising plots for my novels and creating characters are a cinch. A blank, empty page doesn’t daunt me. It’s quite a different story with, say, an empty apartment. When it comes to interior decor, I can stand in the room for hours, hands in my pockets, devoid of one single idea.

作为一名作家，我深知将技能迁移到新领域是多么困难。对我来说，构思小说情节和塑造人物轻而易举。一张白纸并不会让我感到畏惧。但对于空荡荡的公寓来说，情况就完全不同了。说到室内装饰，我可以双手插在口袋里，在房间里站上几个小时，却没有任何灵感。

Business is teeming with domain dependence . A software company recruits a successful consumer-goods salesman. The new position blunts his talents; transferring his sales skills from products to services is exceedingly difficult. Similarly, a presenter who is outstanding in front of small groups may well tank when his audience reaches one hundred people. Or a talented marketing mind may be promoted to CEO and suddenly find that he lacks any strategic creativity.

商业领域充斥着对不同领域的依赖。一家软件公司招聘了一位成功的消费品销售员。新的职位削弱了他的才能；将他的销售技能从产品转移到服务极其困难。同样，一位在小群体面前表现出色的演讲者，当他的听众达到一百人时，可能会变得一蹶不振。又或者，一位才华横溢的营销人才被提拔为首席执行官，却突然发现自己缺乏战略创造力。

With the Markowitz example, we saw that the transfer from the professional realm to the private realm is particularly difficult to navigate. I know CEOs who are charismatic leaders in the office and hopeless duds at home. Similarly, it would be a hard task to find a more cigarette-toting profession than the prophets of health themselves, the doctors. Police officers are twice as violent at home as civilians. Literary critics’ novels get the poorest reviews. And, almost proverbially, the marriages of couples’ therapists are frequently more fragile than those of their clients. Mathematics professor Barry Mazur tells this story: “Some years ago I was trying to decide whether or not I should move from Stanford to Harvard. I had bored my friends silly with endless discussion. Finally, one of them said, ‘You’re one of our leading decision theorists. Maybe you should make a list of the costs and benefits and try to roughly calculate your expected utility.’ Without thinking, I blurted out, ‘Come on, Sandy, this is serious.’ ”

从马科维茨的例子可以看出，从职业领域到私人领域的转变尤其艰难。我认识一些CEO，他们在办公室里是魅力十足的领导者，在家里却一无是处。同样，很难找到一个比健康预言家——医生——更爱抽烟的职业。警察在家的暴力程度是普通人的两倍。文学评论家的小说评价最差。而且，几乎可以肯定的是，夫妻治疗师的婚姻往往比客户的婚姻更脆弱。数学教授巴里·马祖尔讲述了这样一个故事：“几年前，我一直在犹豫是否应该从斯坦福转到哈佛。我没完没了地和朋友们讨论，把他们烦得够呛。最后，其中一位说，‘你是我们顶尖的决策理论家之一。也许你应该列个清单，看看成本和收益，粗略地计算一下你的预期效用。’我不假思索地脱口而出，‘拜托，桑迪，这可不是闹着玩的。’”

What you master in one area is difficult to transfer to another. Especially daunting is the transfer from academia to real life—from the theoretically sound to the practically possible. Of course, this also counts for this book. It will be difficult to transfer the knowledge from these pages to your daily life. Even for me as the writer, that transition proves to be a tough one. Book smarts don’t transfer to street smarts easily.

你在一个领域掌握的知识很难转移到另一个领域。尤其令人畏惧的是将学术知识转移到现实生活中——从理论上可行的理论到切实可行的实践。当然，这本书也面临同样的挑战。将书中的知识运用到日常生活中并非易事。即使对我这个作家来说，这种转变也同样艰难。书本知识并非易事，难以转化为实际操作。

77

The Myth of Like-Mindedness

志同道合的神话

False-Consensus Effect

错误共识效应

W hich do you prefer: music from the ’60s or music from the ’80s? How do you think the general public would answer this question? Most people tend to extrapolate their preferences onto others. If they love the ’60s, they will automatically assume that the majority of their peers do, too. The same goes for ’80s aficionados. We frequently overestimate unanimity with others, believing that everyone else thinks and feels exactly like we do. This fallacy is called the false-consensus effect .

你更喜欢哪一种：60年代的音乐还是80年代的音乐？你认为公众会如何回答这个问题？大多数人倾向于将自己的喜好外推到他人身上。如果他们喜欢60年代的音乐，他们就会自然而然地认为大多数同龄人也喜欢。80年代的爱好者也是如此。我们常常高估与他人的一致性，认为其他人的想法和感受都和我们一模一样。这种谬误被称为“错误共识效应”。

Stanford psychologist Lee Ross hit upon this in 1977. He fashioned a sandwich board emblazoned with the slogan “Eat at Joe’s” and asked randomly selected students to wear it around campus for thirty minutes. They also had to estimate how many other students would put themselves forward for the task. Those who declared themselves willing to wear the sign assumed that the majority (62 percent) would also agree to it. On the other hand, those who politely refused believed that most people (67 percent) would find it too stupid to undertake. In both cases, the students imagined themselves to be in the popular majority.

1977年，斯坦福大学心理学家李·罗斯（Lee Ross）灵机一动，发明了这项实验。他制作了一块印有“在乔家餐厅吃饭”标语的广告牌，并要求随机挑选的学生佩戴它在校园里走三十分钟。他们还必须估计有多少其他学生会主动承担这项任务。那些表示愿意佩戴标语的学生认为，大多数人（62%）也会同意。另一方面，那些礼貌地拒绝的学生则认为，大多数人（67%）会觉得这项任务太愚蠢，不值得去做。在这两种情况下，学生们都把自己想象成大多数人中的一员。

The false-consensus effect thrives in interest groups and political factions that consistently overrate the popularity of their causes. An obvious example is global warming. However critical you consider the issue to be, you probably believe that the majority of people share your opinion. Similarly, if politicians are confident of election, it’s not just blind optimism: They cannot help overestimating their popularity.

虚假共识效应在那些持续高估其事业受欢迎程度的利益集团和政治派系中盛行。一个明显的例子就是全球变暖。无论你认为这个问题多么关键，你很可能都认为大多数人会认同你的观点。同样，如果政客们对当选充满信心，那也不仅仅是盲目乐观：他们无法避免地高估了自己的受欢迎程度。

Artists are even worse off. In 99 percent of new projects, they expect to achieve more success than ever before. A personal example: I was completely convinced that my novel Massimo Marini would be a resounding success. It was at least as good as my previous books, I thought, and those had done very well. But the public was of a different opinion and I was proven wrong: false-consensus effect .

艺术家的情况更糟。99% 的新项目，他们都期望取得比以往更大的成功。举个个人例子：我完全相信我的小说《马西莫·马里尼》会取得巨大成功。我以为它至少和我之前的作品一样好，而且那些作品也卖得很好。但公众却持不同意见，事实证明我错了：虚假共识效应。

Of course, the business world is equally prone to such false conclusions. Just because an R & D department is convinced of its product’s appeal doesn’t mean consumers will think the same way. Companies with tech people in charge are especially affected. Inventors fall in love with their products’ sophisticated features and mistakenly believe that these will bowl customers over, too.

当然，商业世界也同样容易出现这种错误结论。研发部门确信其产品具有吸引力，并不意味着消费者也会这么想。由技术人员负责的公司尤其容易受到影响。发明家们会迷恋其产品的尖端功能，并错误地认为这些功能也会让消费者赞叹不已。

The false-consensus effect is fascinating for yet another reason. If people do not share our opinions, we categorize them as “abnormal.” Ross’s experiment also corroborated this: The students who wore the sandwich board considered those who refused to be stuck up and humorless, whereas the other camp saw the sign-wearers as idiots and attention seekers.

错误共识效应之所以引人入胜，还有另一个原因。如果人们不认同我们的观点，我们就会把他们归类为“异常”。罗斯的实验也证实了这一点：佩戴广告牌的学生认为那些拒绝认同的人既傲慢又缺乏幽默感，而另一组学生则认为佩戴广告牌的人是白痴，是爱出风头的人。

Perhaps you remember the fallacy of social proof , the notion that an idea is better the more people believe in it. Is the false-consensus effect identical? No. Social proof is an evolutionary survival strategy. Following the crowd has saved our butts more often in the past hundred thousand years than striking out on our own. With the false-consensus effect , no outside influences are involved. Despite this, it still has a social function, which is why evolution didn’t eliminate it. Our brain is not built to recognize the truth; instead, its goal is to leave behind as many offspring as possible. Whoever seemed courageous and convincing (thanks to the false-consensus effect ) created a positive impression, attracted a disproportionate amount of resources, and thus increased their chances of passing on their genes to future generations. Doubters were less sexy.

你或许还记得社会认同的谬误，即一个想法被越多人相信就越好。这和虚假共识效应是一样的吗？不一样。社会认同是一种进化的生存策略。在过去的十万年里，从众比单打独斗更能拯救我们。虚假共识效应不涉及任何外界影响。尽管如此，它仍然具有社会功能，这也是进化没有消除它的原因。我们的大脑并非为识别真相而生；相反，它的目标是尽可能多地繁衍后代。那些看起来勇敢而有说服力的人（这要归功于虚假共识效应）会给人留下积极的印象，吸引不成比例的资源，从而增加他们将基因遗传给后代的机会。怀疑论者则不那么有吸引力。

In conclusion: Assume that your worldview is not borne by the public. More than that: Do not assume that those who think differently are idiots. Before you distrust them, question your own assumptions.

总而言之：假设你的世界观不被公众接受。更重要的是：不要把那些想法不同的人当成傻瓜。在你怀疑他们之前，先质疑一下你自己的假设。

78

You Were Right All Along

你一直都是对的

Falsification of History

伪造历史

W inston Smith, a frail, brooding, thirty-nine-year-old office employee, works in the Ministry of Truth. His job is to update old newspaper articles and documents so that they agree with new developments. His work is important. Revising the past creates the illusion of infallibility and helps the government secure absolute power.

温斯顿·史密斯，一位体弱多病、忧郁的三十九岁办公室职员，在真理部工作。他的工作是更新旧报纸文章和文件，使其与最新发展相符。他的工作意义重大。修改过去会制造出一种绝对正确的假象，并帮助政府巩固绝对权力。

Such historical misrepresentation, as witnessed in George Orwell’s classic 1984 , is alive and well today. It may shock you but a little Winston is scribbling away in your brain, too. Worse still: Whereas in Orwell’s novel, he toiled unwillingly and eventually rebelled against the system, in your brain he is working with the utmost efficiency and according to your wishes and goals. He will never rise up against you. He revises your memories so effortlessly—elegantly, even—that you never notice his work. Discreet and reliable, Winston disposes of your old, mistaken views. As they vanish one by one, you start to believe you were right all along.

正如乔治·奥威尔的经典著作《1984》所见证的那样，这种对历史的歪曲在今天依然存在。或许你会感到震惊，但你的大脑里也正有一个小小的温斯顿在挥洒汗水。更糟糕的是：在奥威尔的小说中，他不情愿地辛勤劳作，最终反抗体制；而在你的大脑里，他正以极高的效率，按照你的意愿和目标运作。他永远不会反抗你。他如此轻而易举地——甚至可以说是优雅地——修改你的记忆，以至于你从未察觉到他的存在。温斯顿谨慎可靠，会破除你过去那些错误的观点。随着它们一个接一个地消失，你开始相信自己一直以来都是对的。

In 1973, U.S. political scientist Gregory Markus asked three thousand people to share their opinions on controversial political issues, such as the legalization of drugs. Their responses ranged from “fully agree” to “completely disagree.” Ten years later, he interviewed them again on the same topics, and also asked what they had replied ten years previously. The result: What they recalled disclosing in 1973 was almost identical to their present-day views—and a far cry from their original responses.

1973年，美国政治学家格雷戈里·马库斯（Gregory Markus）邀请三千人就诸如毒品合法化等颇具争议的政治议题发表看法。他们的回答从“完全同意”到“完全不同意”不等。十年后，他再次就同样的话题采访了他们，并询问他们十年前的回答。结果：他们回忆起1973年披露的内容与他们现在的观点几乎完全相同，与他们最初的回答大相径庭。

By subconsciously adjusting past views to fit present ones, we avoid any embarrassing proof of our fallibility. It’s a clever coping strategy because no matter how tough we are, admitting mistakes is an emotionally difficult task. But this is preposterous. Shouldn’t we let out a whoop of joy every time we realize we are wrong? After all, such admissions would ensure we will never make the same mistake twice and have essentially taken a step forward. But we do not see it that way.

通过潜意识地调整过去的观点以适应现在的观点，我们避免了任何令人尴尬的证据表明我们容易犯错。这是一种聪明的应对策略，因为无论我们多么坚强，承认错误在情感上都是一项艰巨的任务。但这很荒谬。每次意识到自己错了，我们难道不应该发出一声欢呼吗？毕竟，这样的承认可以确保我们不会重蹈覆辙，并且实际上向前迈进了一步。但我们并不这么认为。

So does this mean our brains contain no accurately etched memories? Surely not! After all, you can recall the exact moment when you met your partner as if it were captured in a photo. And you can remember exactly where you were on September 11, 2001, when you learned of the terrorist attack in New York, right? You recall to whom you were speaking and how you felt. Your memories of 9/11 are extraordinarily vivid and detailed. Psychologists call these “flashbulb memories”: They feel as incontestable as photographs.

那么，这是否意味着我们的大脑中没有精确刻画的记忆？当然不是！毕竟，你能清晰地回忆起与伴侣相遇的那一刻，就像照片一样。你也能清楚地记得2001年9月11日得知纽约恐怖袭击事件时你在哪里，对吧？你还记得当时和谁说话，以及当时的感受。你对9/11事件的记忆异常清晰细致。心理学家称之为“闪光灯记忆”：它们就像照片一样清晰无误。

They are not. Flashbulb memories are as flawed as regular recollections. They are the product of reconstruction. Ulric Neisser, one of the pioneers in the field of cognitive science, investigated them: In 1986, the day after the explosion of the Challenger space shuttle, he asked students to write essays detailing their reactions. Three years later, he interviewed them again. Less than 7 percent of the new data correlated with the initial submissions. In fact, 50 percent of the recollections were incorrect in two-thirds of the points, and 25 percent failed to match even a single detail. Neisser took one of these conflicting papers and presented it to its owner. Her answer: “I know it’s my handwriting, but I couldn’t have written this.” The question remains: Why do flashbulb memories feel so real? We don’t know yet.

并非如此。闪光灯记忆和普通回忆一样有缺陷。它们是重建的产物。认知科学领域的先驱之一乌尔里克·奈瑟（Ulric Neisser）对此进行了研究：1986年，挑战者号航天飞机爆炸的第二天，他要求学生们写一篇文章，详细描述他们的反应。三年后，他再次采访了他们。新数据中只有不到7%与最初提交的数据相关。事实上，50%的回忆在三分之二的点上是不正确的，25%的回忆甚至连一个细节都对不上。奈瑟拿起其中一份相互矛盾的论文，递给它的主人。她回答说：“我知道这是我的笔迹，但我不可能写这个。” 问题依然存在：为什么闪光灯记忆感觉如此真实？我们还不知道。

It is safe to assume that half of what you remember is wrong. Our memories are riddled with inaccuracies, including the seemingly flawless flashbulb memories. Our faith in them can be harmless—or lethal. Consider the widespread use of eyewitness testimony and police lineups to identify criminals. To trust such accounts without additional investigation is reckless, even if the witnesses are adamant that they would easily recognize the perpetrator again.

可以肯定地说，你记忆中有一半是错误的。我们的记忆充满了不准确的信息，包括看似完美的闪光灯记忆。我们对这些记忆的信任可能是无害的，也可能是致命的。想想目击证人证词和警方列队辨认罪犯的广泛应用。不经进一步调查就相信这些证词是鲁莽的，即使目击者坚称他们很容易再次认出罪犯。

79

Why You Identify with Your Football Team

为什么你会认同你的足球队

In-Group Out-Group Bias

内群体外群体偏见

W hen I was a child, a typical wintery Sunday looked like this: My family sat in front of the TV watching a ski race. My parents cheered for the Swiss skiers and wanted me to do the same. I didn’t understand the fuss. First, why zoom down a mountain on two planks? It makes as little sense as hopping up the mountain on one leg, while juggling three balls and stopping every hundred feet to hurl a log as far possible. Second, how can one-hundredth of a second count as a difference? Common sense would say that if people are that close together, they are equally good skiers. Third, why should I identify with the Swiss skiers? Was I related to any of them? I didn’t think so. I didn’t even know what they thought or read, and if I lived a few feet over the Swiss border, I would probably (have to) cheer for another team altogether.

小时候，一个典型的冬日星期天是这样的：全家坐在电视机前看滑雪比赛。父母为瑞士滑雪运动员加油，也希望我能这么做。我当时不明白为什么这么热闹。首先，为什么要用两块木板从山上飞驰而下？这就像单腿跳上山，一边玩三个球，一边每隔一百英尺停下来把木头尽可能地扔得更远一样不合理。其次，百分之一秒怎么能算差别呢？常识告诉我们，如果人们靠得那么近，他们的滑雪技术一定一样好。第三，我为什么要认同瑞士滑雪运动员？我和他们中的任何一个人有亲戚关系吗？我不这么认为。我甚至不知道他们在想什么，读什么，如果我住在瑞士边境几英尺外的地方，我可能（不得不）为另一支队伍加油。

This brings us to the question: Does identifying with a group—a sports team, an ethnicity, a company, a state—represent flawed thinking?

这就引出了一个问题：认同一个群体——一支运动队、一个种族、一家公司、一个国家——是否代表着思维缺陷？

Over thousands of years, evolution has shaped every behavioral pattern, including attraction to certain groups. In times past, group membership was vital. Fending for yourself was close to impossible. As people began to form alliances, all had to follow suit. Individuals stood no chance against collectives. Whoever rejected membership or got expelled forfeited their place not only in the group, but also in the gene pool. No wonder we are such social animals—our ancestors were, too.

数千年来，进化塑造了每一种行为模式，包括对特定群体的吸引力。在过去，群体成员身份至关重要。自力更生几乎是不可能的。随着人们开始结成联盟，所有人都不得不效仿。个人在集体面前毫无胜算。任何拒绝成员身份或被驱逐的人，不仅会丧失在群体中的地位，还会在基因库中失去一席之地。难怪我们是这样的群居动物——我们的祖先也是如此。

Psychologists have investigated different group effects. These can be neatly categorized under the term in-group out-group bias . First, groups often form based on minor, even trivial, criteria. With sports affiliations a random birthplace suffices, and in business it is where you work. To test this, the British psychologist Henri Tajfel split strangers into groups, tossing a coin to choose who went to which group. He told the members of one group it was because they all liked a particular type of art. The results were impressive: Although (a) they were strangers, (b) they were allocated a group at random, and (c) they were far from art connoisseurs, the group members found each other more agreeable than members of other groups. Second, you perceive people outside your own group to be more similar than they actually are. This is called the “out-group homogeneity bias.” Stereotypes and prejudices stem from it. Have you ever noticed that, in science-fiction movies, only the humans have different cultures and the aliens do not? Third, since groups often form on the basis of common values, group members receive a disproportionate amount of support for their own views. This distortion is dangerous, especially in business: It leads to the infamous organizational blindness.

心理学家研究过不同的群体效应。这些效应可以简单地归类为“内群体-外群体偏见”。首先，群体的形成往往基于一些次要的、甚至是无关紧要的标准。在体育界，随机的出生地就足够了；在商界，出生地就是你的工作地点。为了测试这一点，英国心理学家亨利·泰菲尔将陌生人分成几组，通过抛硬币来决定谁被分到哪一组。他告诉其中一个组的成员，这是因为他们都喜欢某种特定的艺术类型。结果令人印象深刻：尽管 (a) 他们是陌生人，(b) 他们被随机分配到一个小组，(c) 他们远非艺术鉴赏家，但小组成员发现彼此比其他组的成员更融洽。其次，你会认为自己小组之外的人比实际上更相似。这被称为“外群体同质性偏见”。刻板印象和偏见源于此。你有没有注意到，在科幻电影里，只有人类拥有不同的文化，而外星人却没有？第三，由于群体通常建立在共同价值观的基础上，群体成员会因为自身观点而获得不成比例的支持。这种扭曲非常危险，尤其是在商业领域：它会导致臭名昭著的组织盲区。

Family members helping one another out is understandable. If you share half your genes with your siblings, you are naturally interested in their well-being. But there is such a thing as “pseudo-kinship.” It evokes the same emotions without blood relationship. Such feelings can lead to the most idiotic cognitive error of all: laying down your life for a random group—also known as going to war. It is no coincidence that “motherland” suggests kinship. And it’s not by chance that the goal of any military training is to forge soldiers together as “brothers.”

家庭成员之间互相帮助是可以理解的。如果你和兄弟姐妹有一半的基因相同，你自然会关心他们的幸福。但有一种“伪亲属”的存在。它能唤起没有血缘关系的相同情感。这种情感会导致最愚蠢的认知错误：为一个随机群体献出生命——也就是所谓的参战。“祖国”一词暗示着亲情，这绝非偶然。任何军事训练的目标都是将士兵们培养成“兄弟”，这绝非偶然。

In conclusion: Prejudice and aversion are biological responses to anything foreign. Identifying with a group has been a survival strategy for hundreds of thousands of years. Not any longer. Identifying with a group distorts your view of the facts. Should you ever be sent to war, and you don’t agree with its goals, desert.

总结：偏见和厌恶是对任何外来事物的生物反应。认同某个群体一直是数十万年来的生存策略。如今已不再如此。认同某个群体会扭曲你对事实的看法。如果你被派去参战，而你不认同其目标，那就开小差吧。

80

The Difference between Risk and Uncertainty

风险与不确定性的区别

Ambiguity Aversion

模糊厌恶

T wo boxes. Box A contains one hundred balls: fifty red and fifty black. Box B also holds one hundred balls, but you don’t know how many are red and how many are black. If you reach into one of the boxes without looking and draw out a red ball, you win $100. Which box will you choose: A or B? The majority will opt for A.

两个盒子。A盒子里有一百个球：五十个红球，五十个黑球。B盒子里也装了一百个球，但你不知道其中有多少个红球，有多少个黑球。如果你不看盒子，直接伸手到其中一个盒子里，取出一个红球，你就赢了100美元。你会选择哪个盒子：A还是B？大多数人会选择A。

Let’s play again, using exactly the same boxes. This time, you win $100 if you draw out a black ball. Which box will you go for now? Most likely you’ll choose A again. But that’s illogical! In the first round, you assumed that B contained fewer red balls (and more black balls), so, rationally, you would have to opt for B this time around.

我们再玩一次，用同样的盒子。这次，如果你抽出一个黑球，你就赢了100美元。你现在会选择哪个盒子？你很可能会再次选择A。但这不合逻辑！在第一轮中，你假设B盒子里的红球较少（黑球较多），所以理性地说，这次你必须选择B。

Don’t worry; you’re not alone in this error—quite the opposite. This result is known as the “Ellsberg Paradox”—named after Daniel Ellsberg, a former Harvard psychologist. (As a side note, he later leaked the top-secret Pentagon Papers to the press, leading to the downfall of President Nixon.) The Ellsberg Paradox offers empirical proof that we favor known probabilities (box A) over unknown ones (box B).

别担心；犯这个错误的不止你一个人——恰恰相反。这个结果被称为“埃尔斯伯格悖论”，以哈佛大学前心理学家丹尼尔·埃尔斯伯格的名字命名。（顺便提一句，他后来向媒体泄露了绝密的五角大楼文件，导致尼克松总统下台。）埃尔斯伯格悖论提供了经验证据，证明我们更倾向于已知概率（方框A），而不是未知概率（方框B）。

Thus we come to the topics of risk and uncertainty (or ambiguity), and the difference between them. Risk means that the probabilities are known. Uncertainty means that the probabilities are unknown. On the basis of risk, you can decide whether or not to take a gamble. In the realm of uncertainty, though, it’s much harder to make decisions. The terms “risk” and “uncertainty” are as frequently mixed up as “cappuccino” and “latte macchiato”—with much graver consequences. You can make calculations with risk, but not with uncertainty. The three-hundred-year-old science of risk is called statistics. A host of professors deal with it, but not a single textbook exists on the subject of uncertainty. Because of this, we try to squeeze ambiguity into risk categories, but it doesn’t really fit. Let’s look at two examples: one from medicine (where it works) and one from the economy (where it does not).

因此，我们来谈谈风险和不确定性（或模糊性）这两个话题，以及它们之间的区别。风险意味着概率已知。不确定性意味着概率未知。基于风险，你可以决定是否冒险。然而，在不确定性领域，决策要困难得多。“风险”和“不确定性”这两个词经常被混淆，就像“卡布奇诺”和“拿铁玛奇朵”一样——后果要严重得多。你可以用风险来计算，但不能用不确定性来计算。统计学是一门有着三百年历史的风险科学。许多教授都研究这门学科，但没有一本关于不确定性的教科书。正因为如此，我们试图将模糊性塞进风险类别中，但这并不合适。让我们看两个例子：一个来自医学领域（它有效），另一个来自经济学领域（它无效）。

There are billions of humans on earth. Our bodies do not differ dramatically. We all reach a similar height (no one will ever be one hundred feet tall) and a similar age (no one will live for ten thousand years—or for only a millisecond). Most of us have two eyes, four heart valves, thirty-two teeth. Another species would consider us to be homogeneous—as similar to one another as we consider mice to be. For this reason, there are many similar diseases and it makes sense to say, for example: “There is a 30 percent risk you will die of cancer.” On the other hand, the following assertion is meaningless: “There is a 30 percent chance that the euro will collapse in the next five years.” Why? The economy resides in the realm of uncertainty. There are not billions of comparable currencies from whose history we can derive probabilities. The difference between risk and uncertainty also illustrates the difference between life insurance and credit default swaps. A credit default swap is an insurance policy against specific defaults, a particular company’s inability to pay. In the first case (life insurance), we are in the calculable domain of risk; in the second (credit default swap), we are dealing with uncertainty. This confusion contributed to the chaos of the financial crisis in 2008. If you hear phrases such as “the risk of hyperinflation is x percent” or “the risk to our equity position is y,” start worrying.

地球上有数十亿人。我们的体型差异不大。我们都长得差不多（没有人能长到一百英尺），寿命也差不多（没有人能活一万年——或者仅仅一毫秒）。我们大多数人都有两只眼睛、四个心脏瓣膜和三十二颗牙齿。其他物种会认为我们是同质的——彼此之间就像我们认为老鼠一样相似。因此，有很多相似的疾病，例如说“你死于癌症的风险是30%”是有道理的。另一方面，以下断言毫无意义：“欧元在未来五年内崩溃的可能性是30%。”为什么？经济处于不确定性的境地。我们无法从数十亿种可比货币的历史中推导出它们的概率。风险和不确定性之间的差异也体现了人寿保险和信用违约掉期之间的区别。信用违约掉期是一种针对特定违约（即特定公司无力偿还）的保险单。在第一种情况下（人寿保险），我们处于可计算的风险范围；在第二种情况下（信用违约掉期），我们面对的是不确定性。这种混乱加剧了2008年金融危机的混乱局面。如果你听到诸如“恶性通货膨胀的风险为x%”或“我们的股票头寸的风险为y%”这样的话，那就开始担心吧。

To avoid hasty judgment, you must learn to tolerate ambiguity. This is a difficult task and one that you cannot influence actively. Your amygdala plays a crucial role. This is a nut-sized area in the middle of the brain responsible for processing memory and emotions. Depending on how it is built, you will tolerate uncertainty with greater ease or difficulty. This is evident not least in your political orientation: The more averse you are to uncertainty, the more conservatively you will vote. Your political views have a partial biological underpinning.

为了避免草率判断，你必须学会容忍模糊性。这是一项艰巨的任务，你无法主动影响。你的杏仁核起着至关重要的作用。它是大脑中部一个坚果大小的区域，负责处理记忆和情绪。根据杏仁核的构造，你对不确定性的承受能力会有所不同。这在你的政治倾向中尤为明显：你越厌恶不确定性，你的投票倾向就越保守。你的政治观点部分受到生物学因素的影响。

Either way, whoever hopes to think clearly must understand the difference between risk and uncertainty. Only in very few areas can we count on clear probabilities: casinos, coin tosses, and probability textbooks. Often we are left with troublesome ambiguity. Learn to take it in stride.

无论如何，任何想要清晰思考的人都必须理解风险和不确定性之间的区别。只有在极少数领域，我们才能依靠明确的概率：赌场、抛硬币和概率教科书。我们常常会陷入令人困扰的模糊性。学会从容应对。

81

Why You Go with the Status Quo

为什么你要维持现状

Default Effect

默认效果

I n a restaurant the other day I scanned the wine list in desperation. Irouléguy? Harslevelü? Susumaniello? I’m far from an expert, but I could tell that a sommelier was trying to prove his worldliness with these selections. On the last page, I found redemption: “Our French house wine: Réserve du Patron, Bourgogne,” $52. I ordered it right away; it couldn’t be that bad, I reasoned.

前几天在一家餐厅，我绝望地浏览着酒单。Irouléguy？Harslevelü？Susumaniello？我远非专家，但我看得出来，侍酒师正试图用这些酒来证明他的世故。在最后一页，我终于找到了救赎：“我们的法国招牌酒：Réserve du Patron，勃艮第，”52美元。我立刻点了它；我心想，它应该不会那么糟糕。

I’ve owned an iPhone for several years now. The gadget allows me to customize everything—data usage, app synchronization, phone encryption, even how loud I want the camera shutter to sound. How many of these have I set up so far? You guessed it: not one.

我已经用 iPhone 好几年了。这款小工具可以让我自定义一切——流量使用、应用同步、手机加密，甚至相机快门声音的音量。到目前为止，我设置了多少个这样的设置？你猜对了：一个也没有。

In my defense, I’m not technically challenged. Rather, I’m just another victim of the so-called default effect . The default setting is as warm and welcoming as a soft pillow, into which we happily collapse. Just as I tend to stick with the house wine and factory cell-phone settings, most people cling to the standard options. For example, new cars are often advertised in a certain color; in every catalog, video, and ad, you see the new car in the same color, although the car is available in a myriad of colors. The percentage of buyers who select this default color far exceeds the percentage of car buyers who bought this particular color in the past. Many opt for the default.

我得为自己辩解一下，我技术上确实没问题。更确切地说，我只是所谓默认效应的又一个受害者。默认设置就像柔软的枕头一样温暖舒适，我们舒服地窝进去。就像我倾向于坚持使用店内葡萄酒和原厂手机设置一样，大多数人也固守着标准选项。例如，新车广告中通常会采用某种颜色；在所有的目录、视频和广告中，你都会看到同一种颜色的新车，尽管这款车有各种各样的颜色可供选择。选择这种默认颜色的买家比例远远超过过去购买这种颜色的买家比例。许多人最终还是选择了默认颜色。

In their book Nudge , economist Richard Thaler and law professor Cass Sunstein illustrate how a government can direct its citizens without unconstitutionally restricting their freedom. The authorities simply need to provide a few options—always including a default choice for indecisive individuals. This is how New Jersey and Pennsylvania presented two car-insurance policies to their inhabitants. The first policy was cheaper but waived certain rights to compensation should an accident take place. New Jersey advertised this as the standard option, and most people were happy to take it. In Pennsylvania, however, the second, more expensive option was touted as the standard and promptly became the bestseller. This outcome is quite remarkable, especially when you consider that both states’ drivers cannot differ all that much in what they want covered or in what they want to pay.

经济学家理查德·塞勒和法学教授卡斯·桑斯坦在他们的著作《助推》中阐述了政府如何在不违宪限制公民自由的情况下引导公民。当局只需提供一些选择——其中始终包括为犹豫不决的人提供的默认选择。新泽西州和宾夕法尼亚州就是这样向居民提供两种汽车保险政策的。第一种政策更便宜，但放弃了发生事故时获得赔偿的某些权利。新泽西州将其作为标准选项进行宣传，大多数人都乐意选择。然而，在宾夕法尼亚州，第二种更昂贵的选项被吹捧为标准，并迅速成为畅销品。这个结果相当了不起，尤其是当你考虑到两个州的司机在他们想要的保险范围或他们愿意支付的费用上差别并不大的时候。

Or consider this experiment: There is a shortage of organ donors. Only about 40 percent of people opt for it. Scientists Eric Johnson and Dan Goldstein asked people whether, in the event of death, they wanted to actively opt out of organ donation. Making donation the default option increased take-up from 40 percent to more than 80 percent of participants, a huge difference between an opt-in and an opt-out default.

或者考虑一下这个实验：器官捐献者短缺。只有大约40%的人选择捐献。科学家埃里克·约翰逊和丹·戈德斯坦询问人们，如果不幸身故，他们是否愿意主动选择不捐献器官。将捐献设为默认选项后，参与者的接受率从40%上升到80%以上，可见默认选择和默认选择之间存在巨大差异。

The default effect is at work even when no standard option is mentioned. In such cases, we make our past the default setting, thereby prolonging and sanctifying the status quo. People crave what they know. Given the choice of trying something new or sticking to the tried-and-tested option, we tend to be highly conservative, even if a change would be beneficial. My bank, for example, charges an annual fee of $60 for mailing out account statements. I could save myself this amount if I downloaded the statements online. However, though the pricey (and paper-guzzling) service has bothered me for years, I still can’t bring myself to get rid of it once and for all.

即使没有提及任何标准选项，默认效应也会发挥作用。在这种情况下，我们将过去的经历作为默认设定，从而延长并神圣化现状。人们渴望他们所熟知的事物。如果在尝试新事物和坚持久经考验的选项之间做出选择，我们往往会非常保守，即使改变会带来好处。例如，我的银行每年收取60美元的邮寄账户对账单费用。如果我在线下载对账单，就可以省下这笔钱。然而，尽管这项昂贵（且耗纸量大）的服务困扰了我多年，我仍然无法彻底摆脱它。

So where does the “status-quo bias” come from? In addition to sheer convenience, loss aversion plays a role. Recall that losses upset us twice as much as similar gains please us. For this reason, tasks such as renegotiating existing contracts prove very difficult. Regardless of whether these are private or professional, each concession you make weighs twice as heavy as any you receive, so such exchanges end up feeling like net losses.

那么，“现状偏见”从何而来？除了纯粹的便利性之外，损失厌恶也起着作用。回想一下，损失给我们带来的痛苦是收益给我们带来的快乐两倍。因此，重新谈判现有合同之类的任务变得非常困难。无论这些合同是私人的还是专业的，你做出的每一次让步都比你得到的每一项让步重两倍，所以这样的交易最终会让你感觉像是净亏损。

Both the default effect and the status-quo bias reveal that we have a strong tendency to cling to the way things are, even if this puts us at a disadvantage. By changing the default setting, you can change human behavior.

默认效应和现状偏见都表明，我们强烈地倾向于维持现状，即使这会让我们处于不利地位。通过改变默认设置，你可以改变人类的行为。

“Maybe we live our lives according to some grand hidden default idea,” I suggested to a dinner companion, hoping to draw him into a deep philosophical discussion. “Maybe it just needs a little time to develop,” he said after trying the Réserve du Patron.

“也许我们的生活遵循着某种宏大的、隐藏的、默认的理念，”我向一位晚餐同伴建议道，希望能把他拉进一场深入的哲学讨论。“也许只是需要一点时间来发展，”他尝了一杯“主人特饮”（Réserve du Patron）后说道。

82

Why “Last Chances” Make Us Panic

为什么“最后机会”让我们恐慌

Fear of Regret

害怕后悔

T wo stories: Paul owns shares in company A. During the year, he considered selling them and buying shares in company B. In the end, he didn’t. Today he knows that if he had done so, he would have been up $1,200. Second story: George had shares in company B. During the year, he sold them and bought shares in company A. Today he also knows that if he had stuck with B, he would have netted an extra $1,200. Who feels more regret?

两个故事：保罗持有A公司的股票。这一年里，他考虑过卖掉这些股票，然后买入B公司的股票。最终，他没有这么做。现在他知道，如果当时这么做，他可以赚1200美元。第二个故事：乔治持有B公司的股票。这一年里，他卖掉了这些股票，然后买入A公司的股票。现在他也知道，如果当时继续持有B公司的股票，他可以多赚1200美元。谁会更后悔呢？

Regret is the feeling of having made the wrong decision. You wish someone would give you a second chance. When asked who would feel worse, 8 percent of respondents said Paul, whereas 92 percent chose George. Why? Considered objectively, the situations are identical. Both Paul and George were unlucky, picked the wrong stock, and were out of pocket for the exact same amount. The only difference: Paul already possessed the shares in A, whereas George went out and bought them. Paul was passive, George active. Paul embodies the majority—most people leave their money lying where it is for years—and George represents the exception. It seems that whoever does not follow the crowd experiences more regret.

后悔是一种做了错误决定的感觉。你希望有人能再给你一次机会。当被问及谁会感觉更糟时，8% 的受访者说是保罗，而 92% 的受访者说是乔治。为什么？客观来看，他们的情况是一样的。保罗和乔治都运气不好，选错了股票，而且损失的金额完全相同。唯一的区别是：保罗已经拥有 A 公司的股票，而乔治是自己买的。保罗是被动的，乔治是主动的。保罗代表了大多数人——大多数人会把钱放在那里好几年——而乔治代表了例外。似乎不随波逐流的人会经历更多的后悔。

It is not always the one who acts who feels more regret. Sometimes, choosing not to act can constitute an exception. An example: A venerable publishing house stands alone in its refusal to publish trendy e-books. Books are made of paper, asserts the owner, and he will stick by this tradition. Shortly afterward, ten publishers go bankrupt. Nine of them attempted to launch e-book strategies and faltered. The final victim is the conventional paper-only publisher. Who will regret the series of decisions most, and who will gain the most sympathy? Right, the stoic e-grumbler.

行动者并不总是后悔得更多。有时，选择不行动也算是一种例外。例如：一家历史悠久的出版社孤军奋战，拒绝出版时下流行的电子书。这家出版社的老板坚称，书是纸做的，他会坚持这一传统。不久之后，十家出版社破产了。其中九家尝试推出电子书战略，但最终失败了。最终的受害者是那些只出版纸质书的传统出版社。谁会最后悔这一系列决定，谁又会获得最多的同情？没错，就是那个坚忍不拔、抱怨电子书的出版社。

Here is an example from Daniel Kahneman’s book Thinking, Fast and Slow : After every plane crash, we hear the story of one unlucky person who actually wanted to fly a day earlier or later, but for some reason he changed his booking at the last minute. Since he is the exception, we feel more sympathy for him than for the other “normal” passengers who were booked on the ill-fated flight from the outset.

丹尼尔·卡尼曼在他的著作《思考，快与慢》中举了一个例子：每次飞机失事后，我们都会听到一个不幸的人的故事，他本来想提前或推迟一天飞行，但不知何故在最后一刻更改了预订。由于他是个例外，我们对他的同情，远胜于那些从一开始就预订了这趟不幸航班的其他“正常”乘客。

The fear of regret can make us behave irrationally. To dodge the terrible feeling in the pits of our stomachs, we tend to act conservatively, so as not to deviate from the crowd too much. No one is immune to this, not even supremely self-confident traders. Statistics show that each year on December 31 (D-day for performance reviews and bonus calculations), they tend to off-load their more exotic stocks and conform to the masses. Similarly, fear of regret (and the endowment effect ) prevents you from throwing away things you no longer require. You are afraid of the remorse you will feel in the unlikely event that you needed those worn-out tennis shoes after all.

害怕后悔会让我们做出非理性的行为。为了逃避那种令人心碎的糟糕感觉，我们倾向于采取保守的行动，以免与大众市场格格不入。没有人能幸免于此，即使是极其自信的交易员也难免如此。统计数据显示，每年12月31日（绩效评估和奖金计算的截止日期），交易员往往会抛售手中较为稀缺的股票，随波逐流。同样，害怕后悔（以及禀赋效应）会阻止你扔掉不再需要的东西。你害怕的是，万一你最终需要那双破旧的网球鞋，你会后悔莫及。

The fear of regret becomes really irksome when combined with a “last chance” offer. A safari brochure promises “the last chance to see a rhino before the species is extinct.” If you never cared about seeing one before today, why would you fly all the way to Tanzania to do so now? It is irrational.

害怕后悔，再加上“最后一次机会”的诱惑，真的让人烦透了。一份狩猎旅行手册承诺“这是犀牛灭绝前最后一次观犀牛的机会”。如果你今天之前根本没想过要去看犀牛，那现在又何必千里迢迢飞到坦桑尼亚去看呢？这太不合理了。

Let’s say you have long dreamed of owning a house. Land is becoming scarce. Only a handful of plots with sea views are left. Three remain, then two, and now just one. It’s your last chance! This thought racing through your head, you give in and buy the last plot at an exorbitant price. The fear of regret tricked you into thinking this was a onetime offer, when in reality, real estate with a lake view will always come on the market. The sale of stunning property isn’t going to stop anytime soon. “Last chances” make us panic-stricken, and the fear of regret can overwhelm even the most hardheaded deal makers.

假设你一直梦想着拥有一栋房子。土地越来越稀缺，海景地块寥寥无几。先是剩下三块，然后是两块，现在只剩下一块。这是你最后的机会！这个想法在你脑海中闪过，你最终妥协，以高昂的价格买下了最后一块地。对后悔的恐惧让你误以为这只是一次性的报价，而实际上，湖景房源永远都会有。豪宅的销售热潮不会很快停止。“最后的机会”让我们惊慌失措，对后悔的恐惧甚至会压垮最精明的交易者。

83

How Eye-Catching Details Render Us Blind

引人注目的细节如何让我们失明

Salience Effect

显着效应

I magine the issue of marijuana has been dominating the media for the past few months. Television programs portray potheads, clandestine growers, and dealers. The tabloid press prints photos of twelve-year-old girls smoking joints. Broadsheets roll out the medical arguments and illuminate the societal, even philosophical aspects of the substance. Marijuana is on everyone’s lips. Let’s assume for a moment that smoking does not affect driving in any way. Just as anyone can wind up in an accident, a driver with a joint is also involved in a crash every now and then—purely coincidentally.

想象一下，过去几个月大麻问题占据了媒体的头条。电视节目描绘了瘾君子、秘密种植者和毒贩的形象。小报刊登了十二岁女孩吸食大麻的照片。大报刊登了相关的医学论证，并阐释了这种物质的社会层面，甚至哲学层面。大麻成了人们热议的话题。我们姑且假设吸食大麻不会对驾驶造成任何影响。正如任何人都可能遭遇事故一样，偶尔也会有司机因叼着大麻而发生车祸——这纯属巧合。

Kurt is a local journalist. One evening, he happens to drive past the scene of an accident. A car is wrapped around a tree trunk. Since Kurt has a very good relationship with the local police, he learns that they found marijuana in the backseat of the car. He hurries back to the newsroom and writes this headline: “Marijuana Kills Yet Another Motorist.”

科特是一名当地记者。一天晚上，他开车路过一处事故现场。一辆汽车撞上了一根树干。由于科特与当地警方关系很好，他得知警方在汽车后座发现了大麻。他赶紧赶回编辑部，写下了这样的标题：“大麻又夺走了一位驾车者的性命。”

As stated above, we are assuming that the statistical relationship between marijuana and car accidents is zero. Thus, Kurt’s headline is unfounded. He has fallen victim to the salience effect . Salience refers to a prominent feature, a stand-out attribute, a particularity, something that catches your eye. The salience effect ensures that outstanding features receive much more attention than they deserve. Since marijuana is the salient feature of this accident, Kurt believes that it is responsible for the crash.

如上所述，我们假设大麻和车祸之间的统计关系为零。因此，库尔特的标题毫无根据。他成了“显著性效应”的受害者。“显著性”指的是一个突出的特征、一个突出的属性、一个特殊性，或者某种吸引你眼球的东西。“显著性效应”确保突出的特征得到比其应得的更多的关注。由于大麻是这起事故的显著特征，库尔特认为它是造成事故的罪魁祸首。

A few years later, Kurt moves into business journalism. One of the largest companies in the world has just announced it is promoting a woman to CEO. This is big news! Kurt snaps open his laptop and begins to write his commentary: The woman in question, he types, got the post simply because she is female. In truth, the promotion probably had nothing to do with gender, especially since men fill most top positions. If it were so important to have women as leaders, other companies would have acted by now. But in this news story, gender is the salient feature, and thus it earns undue weight.

几年后，库尔特转行做商业新闻。全球最大的公司之一刚刚宣布提拔一位女性担任首席执行官。这可是条大新闻！库尔特猛地打开笔记本电脑，开始撰写评论：他写道，这位女性之所以能获得这个职位，仅仅是因为她是女性。事实上，这次晋升可能与性别无关，尤其是在大多数高管职位都由男性担任的情况下。如果女性领导者真的如此重要，其他公司早就采取行动了。但在这则新闻中，性别是突出的特征，因此它被赋予了不应有的分量。

Not only journalists fall prey to the salience effect. We all do. Two men rob a bank and are arrested shortly after. It transpires that they are Nigerian. Although no ethnic group is responsible for a disproportionate number of bank robberies, this salient fact distorts our thinking. Lawless immigrants at it again, we think. If an Armenian commits rape, it is attributed to the “Armenians” rather than other factors that also exist among Americans. Thus, prejudices form. That the vast majority of immigrants live lawful lives is easily forgotten. We always recall the undesirable exceptions—they are particularly salient . Therefore, whenever immigrants are involved, it is the striking, negative incidents that come to mind first.

不仅记者容易受到显著效应的影响，我们所有人都会。两名男子抢劫银行，不久后被捕。后来发现他们是尼日利亚人。虽然没有哪个族群对如此多的银行抢劫案负有责任，但这个显著的事实扭曲了我们的思维。我们认为，这又是无法无天的移民干的。如果一个亚美尼亚人犯了强奸罪，就会被归咎于“亚美尼亚人”，而不是美国人身上也存在的其他因素。于是，偏见就形成了。绝大多数移民都过着守法的生活，这一点很容易被遗忘。我们总是会想起那些不受欢迎的例外——它们尤其引人注目。因此，每当涉及到移民时，首先想到的就是那些令人震惊的负面事件。

The salience effect influences not only how we interpret the past but also how we imagine the future. Daniel Kahneman and his fellow researcher Amos Tversky found that we place unwarranted emphasis on salient information when we are forecasting. This explains why investors are more sensitive to sensational news (i.e., the dismissal of a CEO) than they are to less striking information (such as the long-term growth of a company’s profits). Even professional analysts cannot always evade the salience effect .

显著性效应不仅影响我们对过去的解读，也影响我们对未来的想象。丹尼尔·卡尼曼和他的同事阿莫斯·特沃斯基发现，我们在预测时会过分强调显著信息。这解释了为什么投资者对耸人听闻的新闻（例如首席执行官被解雇）比对不那么引人注目的信息（例如公司利润的长期增长）更敏感。即使是专业分析师也难以完全避免显著性效应的影响。

In conclusion: Salient information has an undue influence on how you think and act. We tend to neglect hidden, slow-to-develop, discreet factors. Do not be blinded by irregularities. A book with an unusual, fire-engine red jacket makes it onto the bestseller list. Your first instinct is to attribute the success of the book to the memorable cover. Don’t. Gather enough mental energy to fight against seemingly obvious explanations.

总结：突出的信息会对你的思维和行为产生过度的影响。我们往往会忽略那些隐藏的、缓慢发展的、谨慎的因素。不要被不寻常的现象蒙蔽双眼。一本封面奇特、火红的书登上了畅销书排行榜。你的第一反应是把这本书的成功归功于它令人难忘的封面。千万别这么做。要集中精力，去反驳那些看似显而易见的解释。

84

Why Money Is Not Naked

为什么金钱不是赤裸裸的

House-Money Effect

房屋-金钱效应

A windy fall day in the early 1980s. The wet leaves swirled about the sidewalk. Pushing my bike up the hill to school, I noticed a strange leaf at my feet. It was big and rust-brown, and only when I bent down did I realize it was a 500–Swiss franc bill! That was the equivalent of about $250 back then, an absolute fortune for a high school student. The money spent little time in my pocket: I soon bought myself a top-of-the-range bike with disc brakes and Shimano gears, one of the best models around. The funny thing was my old bike worked fine.

20世纪80年代初一个刮风的秋日。湿漉漉的落叶在人行道上飞舞。我推着自行车上山去上学，突然注意到脚下有一片奇怪的叶子。它很大，呈锈褐色，弯下腰才发现那是一张500瑞士法郎的钞票！当时这笔钱相当于250美元，对一个高中生来说，绝对是一笔巨款。但这笔钱没怎么花：我很快就给自己买了一辆带碟刹和禧玛诺变速系统的高档自行车，那是当时市面上最好的自行车之一。有趣的是，我的旧自行车竟然还能骑。

Admittedly, I wasn’t completely broke back then: I had managed to save up a few hundred francs through mowing grass in the neighborhood. However, it never crossed my mind to spend this hard-earned money on something so unnecessary. The most I treated myself to was a trip to the movies every now and then. It was only upon reflection that I realized how irrational my behavior had been. Money is money, after all. But we don’t see it that way. Depending on how we get it, we treat it differently. Money is not naked; it is wrapped in an emotional shroud.

诚然，那时我并不穷得一文不名：我靠在附近修剪草坪攒了几百法郎。然而，我从未想过要把这些辛苦赚来的钱花在如此不必要的事情上。我最多也就是偶尔去看场电影。直到反思之后，我才意识到自己的行为有多么不理智。毕竟，钱就是钱。但我们并不这么认为。我们获得钱的方式不同，对待钱的态度也不同。金钱并非赤裸裸的，它裹着一层情感的裹尸布。

Two questions. You’ve worked hard for a year. At the end of the twelve months, you have $20,000 more in your account than you had at the beginning. What do you do? (a) Leave it sitting in the bank. (b) Invest it. (c) Use it to make necessary improvements, such as renovating your moldy kitchen or replacing old tires. (d) Treat yourself to a luxury cruise. If you think like most people, you’ll opt for A, B, or C.

两个问题。你辛苦工作了一年。12个月后，你的账户比年初多了2万美元。你会怎么做？（a）把它存入银行。（b）投资。（c）用它来做一些必要的改进，比如翻新发霉的厨房或更换旧轮胎。（d）犒劳自己一次豪华游轮之旅。如果你和大多数人的想法一样，你会选择A、B或C。

Second question: You win $20,000 in the lottery. What do you do with it? Choose from A, B, C, or D above. Most people now take C or D. And of course, by doing so, they exhibit flawed thinking. You can count it any way you like; $20,000 is still $20,000.

第二个问题：你中了2万美元的彩票。你会怎么处理这笔钱？从上面的A、B、C或D中选择。现在大多数人都会选择C或D。当然，这样做会暴露出他们的思维缺陷。你可以随便怎么算，2万美元仍然是2万美元。

We witness similar delusions in casinos. A friend places $1,000 on the roulette table—and loses everything. When asked about this, he says: “I didn’t really gamble away a thousand dollars. I won all that earlier.” “But it’s the same amount!” “Not for me,” he says, laughing.

我们在赌场里也见过类似的错觉。一位朋友在轮盘赌桌上押了1000美元，结果输得精光。有人问起这件事，他说：“我其实没输掉一千美元。我之前都赢了。” “但金额一样啊！” “对我来说不一样，”他笑着说。

We treat money that we win, discover, or inherit much more frivolously than hard-earned cash. The economist Richard Thaler calls this the house-money effect . It leads us to take bigger risks and, for this reason, many lottery winners end up worse off after they’ve cashed in their winnings. That old platitude—win some, lose some—is a feeble attempt to downplay real losses.

我们对待赢得、发现或继承的钱比对待辛苦赚来的钱要轻率得多。经济学家理查德·塞勒称之为“庄家效应”。它促使我们承担更大的风险，因此，许多彩票中奖者在兑现奖金后，最终境况反而更糟。那句老话——有得必有失——不过是试图淡化真实损失的苍白无力。

Thaler divided his students into two groups. The first group learned they had won $30 and could choose to take part in the following coin toss: If it was tails, they would win $9. If heads, they would lose $9. Seventy percent of students opted to risk it. The second group learned they had won nothing but that they could choose between receiving $30 or taking part in a coin toss in which heads won them $21 and tails secured $39. The second group behaved more conservatively. Only 43 percent were prepared to gamble—even though the expected value for both options was the same: $30.

泰勒将他的学生分成两组。第一组学生得知他们赢了30美元，并可以选择参加以下抛硬币游戏：如果掷出反面，他们将赢得9美元；如果掷出正面，他们将损失9美元。70%的学生选择冒险一试。第二组学生得知他们什么也没赢，但他们可以选择赢得30美元，或者参加抛硬币游戏，如果掷出正面，他们将赢得21美元，反面则赢得39美元。第二组学生表现得更为保守。只有43%的学生准备冒险一试——尽管两种选择的预期价值相同：30美元。

Marketing strategists recognize the usefulness of the house-money effect . Online gambling sites “reward” you with $100 credit when you sign up. Credit card companies offer the same when you fill in the application form. Airlines present you with a few thousand miles when you join their frequent-flier clubs. Phone companies give you free call credit to get you accustomed to making lots of calls. A large part of the coupon craze stems from the house-money effect .

营销策略师们认识到了“庄家钱效应”的实用性。在线赌博网站会在你注册时“奖励”你100美元的信用额度。信用卡公司也会在你填写申请表时提供同样的奖励。航空公司会在你加入常旅客俱乐部时赠送你几千英里的里程。电话公司会提供免费通话信用额度，让你习惯拨打大量电话。优惠券热潮很大程度上源于“庄家钱效应”。

In conclusion: Be careful if you win money or if a business gives you something for free. Chances are you will pay it back with interest out of sheer exuberance. It’s better to tear the provocative clothes from this seemingly free money. Put it in workmen’s gear. Put it in your bank account or back into your own company.

总而言之：如果你赢了钱，或者有商家免费送你东西，一定要小心。你很可能会因为兴奋而连本带利地还回去。最好把这些看似免费的钱撕掉那些诱人的外衣。把它做成工人的装备。存入你的银行账户，或者投入你自己的公司。

85

Why New Year’s Resolutions Don’t Work

为什么新年决心不起作用

Procrastination

拖延

A friend, a writer, someone who knows how to capture emotion in sentences—let’s call him an artist—writes modest books of about a hundred pages every seven years. His output is the equivalent of two lines of print per day. When asked about his miserable productivity, he says: “Researching is just so much more enjoyable than writing.” So he sits at his desk, surfing the Web for hours on end or immersed in the most abstruse books—all in the hope of hitting upon a magnificent, forgotten story. Once he has found suitable inspiration, he convinces himself that there is no point starting until he is in the “right mood.” Unfortunately, the right mood is a rare occurrence.

一位朋友，一位作家，一位善于用文字捕捉情感的人——我们姑且称他为艺术家吧——每七年写一本大约一百页的小书。他的产出相当于每天两行印刷品。当被问及他那可怜的生产力时，他说：“做研究比写作有趣多了。”于是，他坐在书桌前，一连几个小时上网，或者沉浸在最深奥的书籍中——只为期盼偶然发现一个宏伟却被遗忘的故事。一旦找到合适的灵感，他就会说服自己，除非“心情好”，否则没有必要开始写作。可惜的是，好心情难得。

Another friend has tried to quit smoking every day for the past ten years. Each cigarette is his last. And me? My tax returns have been lying on my desk for six months, waiting to be completed. I haven’t yet given up hope that they will fill themselves in.

另一个朋友过去十年来每天都尝试戒烟。每一支烟都是他最后一支。那我呢？我的纳税申报单已经放在办公桌上六个月了，等着我去填写。我还没放弃希望，希望它们会自己填好。

Procrastination is the tendency to delay unpleasant but important acts: the arduous trek to the gym, switching to a cheaper insurance policy, writing thank-you letters. Even New Year’s resolutions won’t help you here.

拖延症是指倾向于推迟那些令人不快却又重要的事情：比如长途跋涉去健身房、换一份更便宜的保险、写感谢信等等。即使是新年决心，也帮不了你。

Procrastination is idiotic because no project completes itself. We know that these tasks are beneficial, so why do we keep pushing them onto the back burner? Because of the time lapse between sowing and reaping. To bridge it requires a high degree of mental energy, as psychologist Roy Baumeister demonstrated in a clever experiment. He put students in front of an oven in which chocolate cookies were baking. Their delicious scent wafted around the room. He then placed a bowl filled with radishes by the oven and told the students that they could eat as many of these as they wanted, but the cookies were strictly out of bounds. He then left the students alone in the room for thirty minutes. Students in a second group were allowed to eat as many cookies as they wanted. Afterward, both groups had to solve a tough math problem. The students who were forbidden to eat any cookies gave up on the math problem twice as fast as those who were allowed to gorge freely on cookies. The period of self-control had drained their mental energy—or willpower—which they now needed to solve the problem. Willpower is like a battery, at least in the short term. If it is depleted, future challenges will falter.

拖延症很愚蠢，因为没有哪个项目能自动完成。我们知道这些任务有益，那为什么还要一直把它们搁置呢？因为播种和收获之间有时间间隔。要弥合这段时间的差距，需要极大的精神能量，心理学家罗伊·鲍迈斯特在一个巧妙的实验中证明了这一点。他让学生们站在一个烤箱前，烤箱里正在烘烤巧克力饼干。饼干的香味飘散在房间里。然后，他在烤箱旁放了一碗萝卜，告诉学生们想吃多少萝卜就吃多少，但饼干是绝对不能吃的。之后，他把学生们单独留在房间里三十分钟。第二组学生可以想吃多少饼干就吃多少。之后，两组学生都要解一道难题。被禁止吃饼干的学生放弃解题的速度是那些可以肆意狂吃饼干的学生的两倍。这段自我控制的时间耗尽了他们的精神能量——或者说意志力——而现在他们需要这些能量来解题。意志力就像电池，至少在短期内如此。如果耗尽，未来的挑战就会变得无力。

This is a fundamental insight. Self-control is not available around the clock. It needs time to refuel. The good news: To achieve this, all you need to do is refill your blood sugar and kick back and relax.

这是一个基本的道理。自控力并非全天候可用。它需要时间来补充能量。好消息是：要做到这一点，你只需要补充血糖，然后放松身心。

Though eating enough and giving yourself breaks is important, the next necessary condition is employing an array of tricks to keep you on the straight and narrow. This includes eliminating distractions. When I write a novel, I turn off my Internet access. It’s just too enticing to go online when I reach a knotty part. The most effective trick, however, is to set deadlines. Psychologist Dan Ariely found that dates stipulated by external authorities—for example, a teacher or the IRS—work best. Self-imposed deadlines will work only if the task is broken down step-by-step, with each part assigned its own due date. For this reason, nebulous New Year’s resolutions are doomed to fail.

虽然吃饱喝足、给自己充足的休息时间很重要，但下一个必要条件是运用一系列技巧，让自己保持正轨。这包括消除干扰。我写小说的时候会关掉网络。因为每当遇到棘手的部分，上网的诱惑实在太大了。然而，最有效的技巧是设定截止日期。心理学家丹·艾瑞里发现，由外部权威机构（例如老师或美国国税局）规定的截止日期效果最好。只有将任务分解成各个部分，并为每个部分设定截止日期，自我设定的截止日期才会有效。因此，模糊不清的新年决心注定会失败。

So get over yourself. Procrastination is irrational but human. To fight it, use a combined approach. This is how my neighbor managed to write her doctoral thesis in three months: She rented a tiny room with neither telephone nor Internet connection. She set three dates, one for each part of the paper. She told anyone who would listen about these deadlines and even printed them on the back of her business cards. This way, she transformed personal deadlines into public commitments. At lunchtime and in the evenings, she refueled her batteries by reading fashion magazines and sleeping a lot.

所以，克服自己吧。拖延症虽然不合理，但却是人之常情。要克服它，就要采取综合方法。我的邻居就是这样在三个月内完成博士论文的：她租了一间既没有电话也没有网络的小房间。她为论文的每个部分设定了三个日期。她把这些截止日期告诉所有愿意听的人，甚至把它们印在名片背面。就这样，她把个人截止日期变成了公开承诺。午餐和晚上，她通过阅读时尚杂志和大量睡眠来补充能量。

86

Build Your Own Castle

建造你自己的城堡

Envy

嫉妒

T hree scenarios—which would irk you the most? (a) Your friends’ salaries increase. Yours stays the same. (b) Their salaries stay the same. Yours does, too. (c) Their average salaries are cut. Yours is, too. If you answered A, don’t worry, that’s perfectly normal: You’re just another victim of the green-eyed monster.

三种情况——哪种最让你恼火？（a）你朋友的工资涨了，你的工资保持不变。（b）他们的工资保持不变，你的工资也保持不变。（c）他们的平均工资被削减，你的工资也削减。如果你的答案是A，别担心，这很正常：你只是又一个嫉妒的受害者而已。

Here is a Russian tale: A farmer finds a magic lamp. He rubs it, and out of thin air a genie appears who promises to grant him one wish. The farmer thinks about this for a little while. Finally, he says: “My neighbor has a cow and I have none. I hope that his drops dead.”

有个俄罗斯故事：一位农夫发现了一盏神灯。他擦了擦，突然一个精灵凭空出现，答应满足他一个愿望。农夫想了一会儿，最后说：“邻居家有一头牛，我没有。我希望邻居家的牛死了。”

As absurd as it sounds, you can probably identify with the farmer. Admit it: A similar thought must have occurred to you at some point in your life. Imagine your colleague scores a big bonus and you get a gift certificate. You feel envy . This creates a chain of irrational behavior: You refuse to help him any longer, sabotage his plans, perhaps even puncture the tires of his Porsche. And you secretly rejoice when he breaks his leg skiing.

虽然听起来很荒唐，但你或许能体会到这位农夫的感受。承认吧：你人生中肯定也曾有过类似的想法。想象一下，你的同事获得了一大笔奖金，而你却收到了一张礼券。你心生嫉妒。这引发了一系列非理性行为：你不再帮助他，破坏他的计划，甚至可能刺破他保时捷的轮胎。而当他滑雪摔断腿时，你却暗自庆幸。

Of all the emotions, envy is the most idiotic. Why? Because it is relatively easy to switch off. This is in contrast to anger, sadness, or fear. “Envy is the most stupid of vices, for there is no single advantage to be gained from it,” writes Balzac. In short, envy is the most sincere type of flattery; other than that, it’s a waste of time.

在所有情绪中，嫉妒是最愚蠢的。为什么？因为它相对容易被关闭。这与愤怒、悲伤或恐惧形成对比。巴尔扎克写道：“嫉妒是最愚蠢的恶习，因为它没有任何好处。”简而言之，嫉妒是最真诚的奉承；除此之外，它只是浪费时间。

Many things spark envy : ownership, status, health, youth, talent, popularity, beauty. It is often confused with jealousy because the physical reactions are identical. The difference: The subject of envy is a thing (status, money, health, etc.). The subject of jealousy is the behavior of a third person. Envy needs two people. Jealousy, on the other hand, requires three: Peter is jealous of Sam because the beautiful girl next door phones him instead.

很多事情都会引发嫉妒：所有权、地位、健康、青春、才华、人气、美貌。嫉妒常常与嫉妒混淆，因为它们的生理反应相同。区别在于：嫉妒的对象是事物（地位、金钱、健康等等）。嫉妒的对象是第三者的行为。嫉妒需要两个人的共同作用。而嫉妒则需要三个人：彼得嫉妒萨姆，因为隔壁那个漂亮的女孩反而给他打电话。

Paradoxically, with envy, we direct resentments toward those who are most similar to us in age, career, and residence. We don’t envy businesspeople from the century before last. We don’t begrudge plants or animals. We don’t envy millionaires on the other side of the globe—just those on the other side of the city. As a writer, I don’t envy musicians, managers, or dentists, but other writers. As a CEO you envy other, bigger CEOs. As a supermodel you envy more successful supermodels. Aristotle knew this: “Potters envy potters.”

矛盾的是，嫉妒往往指向那些在年龄、职业和居住地上与我们最相似的人。我们不会嫉妒上个世纪的商人。我们不会嫉妒植物或动物。我们不会嫉妒地球另一端的百万富翁——我们只嫉妒城市另一端的百万富翁。作为一名作家，我嫉妒的不是音乐家、经理或牙医，而是其他作家。作为一名CEO，你会嫉妒其他更成功的CEO。作为一名超级名模，你会嫉妒更成功的超级名模。亚里士多德深谙此道：“陶工嫉妒陶工。”

This brings us to a classic practical error: Let’s say your financial success allows you to move from one of New York’s grittier neighborhoods to Manhattan’s Upper East Side. In the first few weeks, you enjoy being in the center of everything and how impressed your friends are with your new apartment and address. But soon you realize that apartments of completely different proportions surround you. You have traded in your old peer group for one that is much richer. Things start to bother you that haven’t bothered you before. Envy and status anxiety are the consequences.

这引出了一个典型的实际错误：假设你的经济成功让你得以从纽约一个较为繁华的街区搬到曼哈顿上东区。最初几周，你享受着身处一切中心的感觉，朋友们也对你的新公寓和新住所赞不绝口。但很快你就发现，周围都是面积完全不同的公寓。你已经告别了原来的同龄人圈子，换成了一个富裕得多的圈子。一些以前从未困扰过你的事情开始困扰你。嫉妒和地位焦虑就是由此产生的后果。

How do you curb envy ? First, stop comparing yourself to others. Second, find your “circle of competence” and fill it on your own. Create a niche where you are the best. It doesn’t matter how small your area of mastery is. The main thing is that you are king of the castle.

如何抑制嫉妒？首先，不要拿自己和别人比较。其次，找到你的“能力圈”，并努力填补它。创造一个你最擅长的领域。你的专长领域有多小并不重要。重要的是，你是城堡之王。

Like all emotions, envy has its origins in our evolutionary past. If the hominid from the cave next door took a bigger share of the mammoth, it meant less for the loser. Envy motivated us to do something about it. Laissez-faire hunter-gatherers disappeared from the gene pool; in extreme cases, they died of starvation, while others feasted. We are the offspring of the envious. But, in today’s world, envy is no longer vital. If my neighbor buys himself a Porsche, it doesn’t mean that he has taken anything from me.

像所有情感一样，嫉妒源于我们进化的过去。如果隔壁洞穴的原始人夺取了猛犸象的更多份额，那么对失败者来说就意味着更少。嫉妒促使我们采取行动。自由放任的狩猎采集者从基因库中消失了；在极端情况下，他们饿死，而其他人则大快朵颐。我们是嫉妒者的后代。但在当今世界，嫉妒已不再重要。如果我的邻居买了一辆保时捷，这并不意味着他从我这里拿走了什么。

When I find myself suffering pangs of envy , my wife reminds me: “It’s okay to be envious—but only of the person you aspire to become.”

当我发现自己嫉妒别人时，我的妻子提醒我：“嫉妒是可以的——但只能嫉妒你渴望成为的人。”

87

Why You Prefer Novels to Statistics

为什么你更喜欢小说而不是统计数据

Personification

拟人化

F or eighteen years, the American media was prohibited from showing photographs of fallen soldiers’ coffins. In February 2009, Defense Secretary Robert Gates lifted this ban and images flooded onto the Internet. Officially, family members have to give their approval before anything is published, but such a rule is unenforceable. Why was the ban created in the first place? To conceal the true costs of war. We can easily find out the number of casualties, but statistics leave us cold. People, on the other hand, especially dead people, spark an emotional reaction.

十八年来，美国媒体被禁止展示阵亡士兵棺材的照片。2009年2月，国防部长罗伯特·盖茨解除了这项禁令，照片随后涌入互联网。官方规定，任何内容发布前都必须征得家属同意，但这项规定无法执行。这项禁令最初为何出台？是为了掩盖战争的真实代价。伤亡人数显而易见，但统计数据却令人麻木。而人，尤其是死者，却能引发情感反应。

Why is this? For eons, groups have been essential to our survival. Thus, over the past hundred thousand years, we have developed an impressive sense of how others think and feel. Science calls this the “theory of mind.” Here’s an experiment to illustrate it: You are given $100 and must share it with a stranger. You can decide how it is divided up. If the other person is happy with your suggestion, the money will be divided that way. If he or she turns down your offer, you must return the $100 and no one gets anything. How do you split the sum?

这是为什么呢？千百年来，群体对于我们的生存至关重要。因此，在过去的几十万年里，我们发展出了一种令人印象深刻的感知能力，能够感知他人的想法和感受。科学称之为“心智理论”。这里有一个实验可以说明这一点：你拿到100美元，必须和一个陌生人分享。你可以决定如何分配。如果对方同意你的建议，钱就按你的建议分配。如果对方拒绝了你的提议，你必须退还这100美元，双方一无所获。那么，这笔钱该如何分配呢？

It would make sense to offer the stranger very little—maybe just a dollar. After all, it’s better than nothing. However, in the 1980s, when economists began experimenting with such “ultimatum games” (the technical term), the subjects behaved very differently: They offered the other party between 30 percent and 50 percent. Anything below 30 percent was considered “unfair.” The ultimatum game is one of the clearest manifestations of the “theory of mind”: In short, we empathize with the other person.

给陌生人很少的钱——也许只有一美元——或许合情合理。毕竟，总比没有强。然而，在20世纪80年代，当经济学家开始尝试这种“最后通牒博弈”（专业术语）时，受试者的表现却大相径庭：他们给对方的钱在30%到50%之间。低于30%的钱被认为“不公平”。最后通牒博弈是“心智理论”最清晰的体现之一：简而言之，我们会同情他人。

However, with one tiny change, it is possible to almost eliminate this compassion: Put the players in separate rooms. When people can’t see their counterparts—or, indeed, when they have never seen them—it is more difficult to simulate their feelings. The other person becomes an abstraction, and the share they are offered drops, on average, to below 20 percent.

然而，只需稍加改变，就能几乎消除这种同情心：将玩家分别安置在不同的房间。当人们看不到对方——或者实际上从未见过对方——时，就更难模拟他们的感受。对方变得抽象，他们获得的份额平均下降到20%以下。

In another experiment, psychologist Paul Slovic asked people for donations. One group was shown a photo of Rokia from Malawi, an emaciated child with pleading eyes. Afterward, people donated an average of $2.83 to the charity (out of $5 they were given to fill out a short survey). The second group was shown statistics about the famine in Malawi, including the fact that more than three million malnourished children were affected. The average donation dropped by 50 percent. This is illogical: You would think that people’s generosity would grow if they knew the extent of the disaster. But we do not function like that. Statistics don’t stir us; people do.

在另一项实验中，心理学家保罗·斯洛维奇向人们征集捐款。一组人看到了一张来自马拉维的罗基亚的照片，照片中她是一个瘦骨嶙峋、眼神恳求的孩子。实验结束后，人们平均向慈善机构捐款2.83美元（他们收到一份简短的调查问卷，其中5美元用于填写）。第二组人看到了关于马拉维饥荒的统计数据，其中包括超过300万营养不良儿童受灾的事实。结果平均捐款额下降了50%。这很不合逻辑：你可能会认为，如果人们了解灾难的严重程度，他们的慷慨程度会更高。但我们并非如此。统计数据无法打动我们，只有人才能。

The media has long known that factual reports and bar charts do not entice readers. Hence the guideline: Give the story a face. If a company features in the news, a picture of the CEO appears alongside (either grinning or grimacing, depending on the market). If a state makes the headlines, the president represents it. If an earthquake takes place, a victim becomes the face of the crisis.

媒体早已深知，事实报道和条形图无法吸引读者。因此，媒体的准则是：给报道配上一张面孔。如果一家公司出现在新闻中，旁边就会出现该公司首席执行官的照片（根据市场情况，可能是咧嘴大笑，也可能是愁眉苦脸）。如果某个州成为头条新闻，总统就会代表该州。如果发生地震，灾民就会成为危机的代表。

This obsession explains the success of a major cultural invention: the novel. This literary “killer app” projects personal and interpersonal conflicts onto a few individual destinies. A scholar could have written a meaty dissertation about the methods of psychological torture in Puritan New England, but instead, we still read Hawthorne’s The Scarlet Letter . And the Great Depression? In statistical form, this is just a long series of numbers. As a family drama, in Steinbeck’s The Grapes of Wrath , it is unforgettable.

这种痴迷解释了一项重大文化发明的成功：小说。这部文学“杀手级应用”将个人和人际冲突投射到少数人的命运之上。一位学者本可以写一篇关于清教徒新英格兰心理折磨方法的详尽论文，但我们读的仍然是霍桑的《红字》。至于大萧条？从统计数据来看，这只是一长串数字。而斯坦贝克的《愤怒的葡萄》作为一部家庭剧，却令人难忘。

In conclusion: Be careful when you encounter human stories. Ask for the facts and the statistical distribution behind them. You can still be moved by the story, but this way, you can put it into the right context. If, however, you seek to move and motivate people for your own ends, make sure your tale is seasoned with names and faces.

总结：遇到人性故事时要谨慎。要询问背后的事实和统计分布。你仍然会被故事感动，但这样才能把它放在正确的语境中去理解。然而，如果你想感动和激励他人，确保你的故事充满人名和人物。

88

You Have No Idea What You Are Overlooking

你不知道自己忽略了什么

Illusion of Attention

注意力错觉

A fter heavy rains in the south of England, a river in a small village overflowed its banks. The police closed the ford, the shallow part of the river where vehicles cross, and diverted traffic. The crossing stayed closed for two weeks, but each day at least one car drove past the warning sign and into the rushing water. The drivers were so focused on their car’s navigation systems that they didn’t notice what was right in front of them.

英国南部暴雨过后，一个小村庄的一条河流泛滥成灾。警方封锁了车辆通行的浅滩，并疏导了车辆。这条河道关闭了两周，但每天至少有一辆汽车冲过警示牌，冲入湍急的河水中。司机们全神贯注于汽车导航系统，以至于没有注意到眼前的情况。

In the 1990s, Harvard psychologists Daniel Simons and Christopher Chabris filmed two teams of students passing basketballs back and forth. One team wore black T-shirts, the other, white. The short clip, “The Monkey Business Illusion,” is available on YouTube. (Take a look before reading on.) In the video, viewers are asked to count how many times the players in white T-shirts pass the ball. Both teams move in circles, weaving in and out, passing back and forth. Suddenly, in the middle of the video, something bizarre happens: A student dressed as a gorilla walks into the center of the room, pounds his chest, and promptly disappears again. At the end, you are asked if you noticed anything unusual. Half the viewers shake their heads in astonishment. Gorilla? What gorilla?

20世纪90年代，哈佛大学心理学家丹尼尔·西蒙斯（Daniel Simons）和克里斯托弗·查布里斯（Christopher Chabris）拍摄了两队学生来回传篮球的画面。其中一队身穿黑色T恤，另一队身穿白色T恤。这段名为“猴子生意幻觉”（The Monkey Business Illusion）的短片可以在YouTube上观看。（继续阅读前请先观看视频。）在视频中，观众被要求数出身穿白色T恤的球员传球的次数。两队球员都绕圈移动，来回穿梭，来回传球。突然，在视频中间，发生了一件怪事：一个扮成大猩猩的学生走到房间中央，捶胸顿足，然后又迅速消失了。最后，视频询问你是否注意到什么异常。一半的观众惊讶地摇头。大猩猩？什么大猩猩？

The monkey business test is considered one of the most famous experiments in psychology and demonstrates the so-called illusion of attention : We are confident that we notice everything that takes place in front of us. But in reality, we often see only what we are focusing on—in this case, the passes made by the team in white. Unexpected, unnoticed interruptions can be as large and conspicuous as a gorilla.

“猴子生意测试”被认为是心理学中最著名的实验之一，它揭示了所谓的注意力错觉：我们自信地认为自己注意到了眼前发生的一切。但实际上，我们往往只看到自己关注的事情——在这个例子中，就是白衣队员的传球。意料之外、未被注意到的干扰，有时规模巨大，甚至像大猩猩一样引人注目。

The illusion of attention can be precarious, for example, when making a phone call while driving. Most of the time doing so poses no problems. The call does not negatively influence the straightforward task of keeping the car in the middle of the lane and braking when a car in front does. But as soon as an unanticipated event takes place, such as a child running across the street, your attention is too stretched to react in time. Studies show that drivers’ reactions are equally slow when using a cell phone as when under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Furthermore, it does not matter whether you hold the phone with one hand, jam it between your shoulder and jaw, or use a hands-free kit: Your responsiveness to unexpected events is still compromised.

注意力的错觉可能会带来危险，比如开车时打电话。大多数情况下，打电话不会造成任何问题。打电话不会对保持车辆在车道中间行驶以及前车刹车等简单操作产生负面影响。但一旦发生意外事件，例如小孩跑过马路，你的注意力就会过于集中，无法及时做出反应。研究表明，驾驶员在使用手机时的反应速度与酒精或药物影响下的反应速度一样慢。此外，无论你用一只手拿着手机，还是把它夹在肩膀和下巴之间，或者使用免提设备，你对意外事件的反应能力仍然会受到影响。

Perhaps you know the expression “the elephant in the room.” It refers to an obvious subject that nobody wants to discuss, a kind of taboo. In contrast, let us define what “the gorilla in the room” is: a topic that is of the utmost importance and urgency, and that we absolutely need to address, but nobody knows about it.

你或许听说过“房间里的大象”这个说法。它指的是一个显而易见却无人愿意讨论的话题，一种禁忌。相比之下，让我们来定义一下什么是“房间里的大猩猩”：一个极其重要和紧迫、我们绝对需要解决，但却无人知晓的话题。

Take the case of Swissair, a company that was so fixated on expansion that it overlooked its evaporating liquidity and went bankrupt in 2001. Or the mismanagement in the Eastern bloc that led to the fall of the Berlin Wall. Or the risks on banks’ books that up until 2007 nobody paid any attention to. Such gorillas stomp around right in front of us—and we barely spot them.

以瑞士航空为例，这家公司过于执着于扩张，以至于忽视了自身不断蒸发的流动性，最终于2001年破产。东欧集团的管理不善也导致了柏林墙的倒塌。银行账簿上的风险，直到2007年才被人重视。这些“大猩猩”就在我们面前肆意践踏——我们却几乎察觉不到它们的存在。

It’s not the case that we miss every extraordinary event. The crux of the matter is that whatever we fail to notice remains unheeded. Therefore, we have no idea what we are overlooking. This is exactly why we still cling to the dangerous illusion that we perceive everything of importance.

我们并非错过了所有非凡的事件。问题的关键在于，我们未能注意到的事物最终都会被忽视。因此，我们根本不知道自己忽略了什么。正因如此，我们仍然抱有危险的幻想，认为自己感知到了所有重要的事情。

Purge yourself of the illusion of attention every now and then. Confront all possible and seemingly impossible scenarios. What unexpected events might happen? What lurks beside and behind the burning issues? What is no one addressing? Pay attention to silences as much as you respond to noises. Check the periphery, not just the center. Think the unthinkable. Something unusual can be huge; we still may not see it. Being big and distinctive is not enough to be seen. The unusual and huge thing must be expected.

时不时地清除自己对注意力的幻想。直面所有可能和看似不可能的情景。哪些意想不到的事件可能发生？在紧迫问题的背后隐藏着什么？哪些问题无人关注？关注沉默，就像关注声音一样。审视外围，而不仅仅是中心。思考那些不可想象的事情。一些不寻常的事情可能很巨大；我们可能仍然看不到它。规模宏大、独具特色并不足以被看到。不同寻常的巨大事物必须被期待。

89

Hot Air

热风

Strategic Misrepresentation

战略性失实陈述
