S uppose you apply for your dream job. You buff your résumé to a shine. In the job interview, you highlight your achievements and abilities and gloss over weak points and setbacks. When they ask if you could boost sales by 30 percent while cutting costs by 30 percent, you reply in a calm voice: “Consider it done.” Even though you are trembling inside and racking your brain about how the hell you are going to pull that off, you do and say whatever is necessary to get the job. You concentrate on wowing the interviewers; the details will follow. You know that if you give even semi-realistic answers, you’ll put yourself out of the race.

假设你申请了梦寐以求的工作。你把简历润色得光彩夺目。在面试中，你突出自己的成就和能力，淡化弱点和挫折。当他们问你是否能将销售额提高30%，同时将成本降低30%时，你平静地回答：“就算了。” 尽管你内心忐忑不安，绞尽脑汁思考究竟该如何实现这一目标，但为了得到这份工作，你还是竭尽所能。你专注于让面试官赞叹不已；细节问题自然会随之而来。你知道，哪怕你的答案只是半现实的，你也会让自己出局。

Imagine you are a journalist and have a great idea for a book. The issue is on everyone’s lips. You find a publisher who is willing to pay a nice advance. However, he needs to know your timeline. He removes his glasses and looks at you: “When can I expect the manuscript? Can you have it ready in six months?” You gulp. You’ve never written a book in under three years. Your answer: “Consider it done.” Of course you don’t want to lie, but you know that you won’t get the advance if you tell the truth. Once the contract is signed and the money is nestling in your bank account, you can always keep the publisher at bay for a while. You’re a writer; you’re great at making up stories!

想象一下，你是一名记者，突然想到一个很棒的书稿创意。这个问题大家都在讨论。你找到一家愿意支付一大笔预付款的出版商。但是，他需要知道你的时间安排。他摘下眼镜，看着你问道：“我什么时候能拿到稿子？六个月内能完成吗？”你倒吸了一口凉气。你从来没有在三年内写完过一本书。你的回答是：“就算完成了。”你当然不想撒谎，但你知道说实话就拿不到预付款。一旦合同签了，钱到账了，你就可以暂时不理会出版商了。你是个作家，编故事编得真棒！

The official term for such behavior is strategic misrepresentation : the more at stake, the more exaggerated your assertions become. Strategic misrepresentation does not work everywhere. If your ophthalmologist promises five times in a row to give you perfect vision, but after each procedure you see worse than before, you will stop taking him seriously at some point. However, when unique attempts are involved, strategic misrepresentation is worth a try—in interviews, for example, as we saw above. A single company isn’t going to hire you several times. It’s either a yes or no.

这种行为的官方术语是“策略性虚假陈述”：风险越大，你的断言就越夸张。策略性虚假陈述并非在所有情况下都有效。如果你的眼科医生连续五次承诺让你恢复完美视力，但每次手术后你的视力都比以前更差，你最终会不再相信他。然而，当涉及到独特的尝试时，策略性虚假陈述值得一试——例如，正如我们上面提到的，在面试中。一家公司不会多次雇用你。答案要么是肯定的，要么是否定的。

Most vulnerable to strategic misrepresentation are mega-projects, where (a) accountability is diffuse (for example, if the administration that commissioned the project is no longer in power), (b) many businesses are involved, leading to mutual finger-pointing, or (c) the end date is a few years down the road.

最容易受到战略性失实陈述影响的是大型项目，因为（a）问责制很分散（例如，如果委托该项目的政府不再掌权），（b）涉及许多企业，导致相互指责，或（c）结束日期还要几年。

No one knows more about large-scale projects than Oxford professor Bent Flyvbjerg. Why are cost and schedule overruns so frequent? Because it is not the best offer overall that wins; it is whichever one looks best on paper. Flyvbjerg calls this “reverse Darwinism”: Whoever produces the most hot air will be rewarded with the project. However, is strategic misrepresentation simply brazen deceit? Yes and no. Are women who wear makeup frauds? Are men who lease Porsches to signal financial prowess liars? Yes and no. Objectively they are, but the deceit is socially acceptable, so we don’t get worked up about it. The same counts for strategic misrepresentation.

没有人比牛津大学教授本特·弗莱夫比约格更了解大型项目。为什么成本和工期超支如此频繁？因为最终胜出的并非整体最优的方案，而是纸面上看起来最好的方案。弗莱夫比约格称之为“逆达尔文主义”：谁能制造最多的空谈，谁就能赢得项目。然而，战略性虚假陈述仅仅是赤裸裸的欺骗吗？是也不是。化妆的女人是骗子吗？租保时捷来炫耀财力的男人是骗子吗？是也不是。客观上，他们的确是骗子，但这种欺骗在社会上是可以接受的，所以我们不会为此感到不安。战略性虚假陈述也同样如此。

In many cases, strategic misrepresentation is harmless. However, for the things that matter, such as your health or future employees, you must be on your guard. So, if you are dealing with a person (a first-rate candidate, an author, or an ophthalmologist), don’t go by what they claim; look at their past performance. When it comes to projects, consider the timeline, benefits, and costs of similar projects, and grill anyone whose proposals are much more optimistic. Ask an accountant to pick apart the plans mercilessly. Add a clause into the contract that stipulates harsh financial penalties for cost and schedule overruns. And, as an added safety measure, have this money transferred to a secure escrow account.

很多情况下，策略性虚假陈述无害。然而，对于重要的事情，例如你的健康或未来的员工，你必须保持警惕。所以，如果你正在与一个人（一流候选人、作家或眼科医生）打交道，不要轻信他们的说法；看看他们过去的表现。谈到项目，要考虑类似项目的时间表、收益和成本，并对那些提案比他们乐观得多的人进行质询。请一位会计师毫不留情地批判这些计划。在合同中加入一项条款，规定对成本和进度超支的严厉经济处罚。此外，为了增加安全措施，将这笔钱转入一个安全的托管账户。

90

Where’s the Off Switch?

关闭开关在哪里？

Overthinking

想太多

T here was once an intelligent centipede. Sitting on the edge of a table, he looked over and saw a tasty grain of sugar across the room. Clever as he was, he started to weigh up the best route: Which table leg should he crawl down—left or right—and which table leg should he crawl up? The next tasks were to decide which foot should take the first step, in which order the others should follow, and so on. He was adept at mathematics, so he analyzed all the variants and selected the best path. Finally, he took the first step. However, still engrossed in calculation and contemplation, he got tangled up and stopped dead in his tracks to review his plan. In the end, he came no further and starved.

从前有一只聪明的蜈蚣。它蹲在桌边，抬头望去，看到房间另一边有一粒美味的糖。它聪明伶俐，开始琢磨最佳路线：应该从哪条桌腿爬下去——左边还是右边——又该从哪条桌腿爬上去？接下来的任务是决定哪只脚迈出第一步，其他脚应该按照什么顺序迈出，等等。它擅长数学，分析了所有可能的情况，找到了最佳路径。终于，它迈出了第一步。然而，它还在沉迷于计算和思考，却被缠住了，不得不停下来重新审视自己的计划。最终，它没能继续前进，饿死了。

The British Open golf tournament in 1999: French golfer Jean van de Velde played flawlessly until the final hole. With a three-shot lead, he could easily afford a double bogey (two over par) and still win. Child’s play! Entry into the big leagues was now only a matter of minutes away. All he needed to do was to play it safe. But as Van de Velde stepped up, beads of sweat began to form on his forehead. He teed off like a beginner. The ball sailed into the bushes, landing almost twenty feet from the hole. He became increasingly nervous. The next shots were no better. He hit the ball into knee-high grass, then into the water. He took off his shoes, waded into the water, and for a minute contemplated shooting from the pond. But he decided to take the penalty. He then shot into the sand. His body movements suddenly resembled those of a novice. Finally, he made it onto the green and—after a seventh attempt—into the hole. Van de Velde lost the British Open and secured a place in sporting history with his now-notorious triple bogey. It was the beginning of the end of his career. (He celebrated an impressive comeback in 2005.)

1999年英国高尔夫公开赛：法国高尔夫球手让·范德维尔德直到最后一洞都表现得完美无瑕。他领先三杆，即使吞下双柏忌（高于标准杆两杆），也能轻松夺冠。简直易如反掌！进入大联盟仅剩几分钟，他只需稳扎稳打。但范德维尔德越发自信，额头上开始渗汗。他像个新手一样开球。球飞进了灌木丛，距离球洞将近二十英尺。他越来越紧张。接下来的几杆也好不到哪里去。他把球打进了齐膝深的草丛，然后又落入水中。他脱掉鞋子，蹚进水里，想了一会儿要不要从池塘里打。但他决定接受罚杆。然后，他把球打进了沙坑。他的动作突然变得像个新手。最终，他终于上了果岭，在第七次尝试之后，终于把球打进了洞。范德维尔德输掉了英国公开赛，并以如今臭名昭著的三柏忌载入了体育史册。这标志着他职业生涯的终结。（2005年，他迎来了一场令人印象深刻的复出。）

In the 1980s, Consumer Reports asked experienced tasters to sample forty-five different varieties of strawberry jelly. A few years later, psychology professors Timothy Wilson and Jonathan Schooler repeated the experiment with students from the University of Washington. The results were almost identical. Both students and experts preferred the same type. But that was only the first part of Wilson’s experiment. He repeated it with a second group of students who, unlike the first group, had to fill in a questionnaire justifying their ratings in detail. The rankings turned out to be completely warped. Some of the best varieties ended up at the bottom of the rankings.

20世纪80年代，《消费者报告》邀请经验丰富的品尝师品尝了45种不同的草莓果冻。几年后，心理学教授蒂莫西·威尔逊和乔纳森·斯库勒在华盛顿大学的学生中重复了这项实验。结果几乎完全相同。学生和专家都偏爱同一种类型。但这只是威尔逊实验的第一部分。他又邀请了第二组学生，与第一组不同的是，第二组学生需要填写一份问卷，详细阐述他们的评分理由。结果发现，排名完全扭曲了。一些最好的品种最终排名垫底。

Essentially, if you think too much, you cut off your mind from the wisdom of your feelings. This may sound a little esoteric—and a bit surprising coming from someone like me who strives to rid my thinking of irrationality—but it is not. Emotions form in the brain, just as crystal-clear, rational thoughts do. They are merely a different form of information processing—more primordial, but not necessarily an inferior variant. In fact, sometimes they provide the wiser counsel.

本质上，如果你思考太多，你的大脑就会与你感受的智慧隔绝。这听起来可能有点深奥——而且对于像我这样努力摆脱非理性思维的人来说，这有点令人惊讶——但事实并非如此。情绪是在大脑中形成的，就像清晰、理性的思维一样。它们只是信息处理的一种不同形式——更原始，但不一定是劣等的变体。事实上，有时它们能提供更明智的建议。

This raises the question: When do you listen to your head and when do you heed your gut? A rule of thumb might be: If it is something to do with practiced activities, such as motor skills (think of the centipede, Van de Velde, or mastering a musical instrument) or questions you’ve answered a thousand times (think of Warren Buffett’s “circle of competence”), it’s better not to reflect to the last detail. It undermines your intuitive ability to solve problems. The same applies to decisions that our Stone Age ancestors faced—evaluating what was edible, who would make good friends, whom to trust. For such purposes, we have heuristics, mental shortcuts that are clearly superior to rational thought. With complex matters, though, such as investment decisions, sober reflection is indispensable. Evolution has not equipped us for such considerations, so logic trumps intuition.

这就引出了一个问题：什么时候听从理智，什么时候听从直觉？一个经验法则或许是：如果事情与练习有关，比如运动技能（想想蜈蚣、范德维尔德，或者掌握一种乐器），或者你已经回答过一千遍的问题（想想沃伦·巴菲特的“能力圈”），最好不要深思熟虑。这会削弱你解决问题的直觉能力。这同样适用于我们石器时代的祖先面临的决策——评估什么可以吃，谁会成为好朋友，谁值得信任。为了达到这些目的，我们有启发式方法，即明显优于理性思考的思维捷径。然而，对于投资决策等复杂问题，冷静的思考是必不可少的。进化并没有让我们具备这样的思考能力，所以逻辑胜过直觉。

91

Why You Take On Too Much

为什么你承担了太多

Planning Fallacy

计划谬误

E very morning, you compile a to-do list. How often does it happen that everything is checked off by the end of the day? Always? Every other day? Maybe once a week? If you are like most people, you will achieve this rare state once a month. In other words, you systematically take on too much. More than that: Your plans are absurdly ambitious. Such a thing would be forgivable if you were a planning novice. But you’ve been compiling to-do lists for years, if not decades. Thus, you know your capabilities inside out and it’s unlikely that you overestimate them afresh every day. This is not facetiousness: In other areas, you learn from experience. So why is there no learning curve when it comes to making plans? Even though you realize that most of your previous endeavors were overly optimistic, you believe in all seriousness that, today, the same workload—or more—is eminently doable. Daniel Kahneman calls this the planning fallacy .

每天早上，你都会列一份待办事项清单。一天结束前，所有事项都完成了的概率有多大？总是如此？每隔一天？还是一周一次？如果你和大多数人一样，那么你每个月都会遇到一次这种罕见的情况。换句话说，你系统性地承担了太多任务。不仅如此，你的计划雄心勃勃，简直荒谬。如果你是计划新手，这种事情或许情有可原。但你列待办事项清单已经好几年了，甚至几十年。因此，你对自己的能力了如指掌，不太可能每天都重新高估自己。这并非玩笑：在其他领域，你都是从经验中学习的。那么，为什么制定计划时没有学习曲线呢？即使你意识到自己之前的大多数努力都过于乐观，你仍然一本正经地认为，今天完成同样甚至更多的工作量是完全可行的。丹尼尔·卡尼曼称之为计划谬误。

In their last semesters, students generally have to write theses. The Canadian psychologist Roger Buehler and his research team asked the following of their final-year class: The students had to specify two submission dates: The first was a “realistic” deadline and the second was a “worst-case scenario” date. The result? Only 30 percent of students made the realistic deadlines. On average, the students needed 50 percent more time than planned—and a full seven days more than their worst-case scenario date.

在最后一学期，学生们通常需要撰写论文。加拿大心理学家罗杰·比勒和他的研究团队向他们的毕业班学生提出了以下问题：学生们必须指定两个提交日期：第一个是“现实”的截止日期，第二个是“最坏情况”的截止日期。结果如何？只有30%的学生在现实的截止日期前完成论文。平均而言，学生们需要的时间比计划多50%，比他们最坏情况的截止日期多了整整七天。

The planning fallacy is particularly evident when people work together—in business, science, and politics. Groups overestimate duration and benefits and systematically underestimate costs and risks. The conch-shaped Sydney Opera House was planned in 1957: Completion was due in 1963 at a cost of $7 million. It finally opened its doors in 1973 after $102 million had been pumped in—fourteen times the original estimate!

规划谬误在人们合作时尤为明显——无论是在商业、科学还是政治领域。群体会高估持续时间和收益，而系统性地低估成本和风险。海螺形状的悉尼歌剧院于1957年规划，预计于1963年竣工，耗资700万美元。最终，在投入1.02亿美元——是最初预算的14倍——之后，它于1973年正式开放！

So why are we not natural-born planners? The first reason: wishful thinking. We want to be successful and achieve everything we take on. Second, we focus too much on the project and overlook outside influences. Unexpected events too often defeat our plans. This is true for daily schedules, too: Your daughter swallows a fish bone. Your car battery gives up the ghost. An offer for a house lands on your desk and must be discussed urgently. There goes the plan. If you planned things even more minutely, would that be a solution? No, step-by-step preparation amplifies the planning fallacy . It narrows your focus even more and thus distracts you even more from anticipating the unexpected.

那么，为什么我们不是天生的计划者呢？第一个原因：一厢情愿。我们渴望成功，完成所有承担的任务。其次，我们过于专注于项目本身，而忽略了外界的影响。意外事件常常会打乱我们的计划。日常安排也是如此：你的女儿吞下了一根鱼刺。你的汽车电池坏了。一份房屋报价摆在你面前，必须紧急处理。计划泡汤了。如果你计划得更周全一些，就能解决问题吗？不，一步一步的准备只会加剧计划谬误。它会进一步缩小你的注意力，从而让你更加难以预料意外情况。

So what can you do? Shift your focus from internal things, such as your own project, to external factors, like similar projects. Look at the base rate and consult the past. If other ventures of the same type lasted three years and devoured $5 million, this will probably apply to your project, too—no matter how carefully you plan. And, most important, shortly before decisions are made, perform a so-called premortem session (literally, “before death”). American psychologist Gary Klein recommends delivering this short speech to the assembled team: “Imagine it is a year from today. We have followed the plan to the letter. The result is a disaster. Take five or ten minutes to write about this disaster.” The stories will show you how things might turn out.

那么你能做什么呢？将你的注意力从内部因素（例如你自己的项目）转移到外部因素（例如类似的项目）。看看基准利率，并参考过去的经验。如果其他同类型的项目持续了三年，耗资500万美元，那么这可能也适用于你的项目——无论你计划得多么周密。最重要的是，在做出决策之前，进行一次所谓的事前剖析（字面意思是“死亡之前”）。美国心理学家加里·克莱因建议向团队发表以下简短演讲：“想象一下，一年后的今天。我们严格按照计划行事。结果却是一场灾难。花五到十分钟来描述一下这场灾难。” 这些故事会告诉你事情可能如何发展。

92

Those Wielding Hammers See Only Nails

那些挥舞着锤子的人只看到钉子

Déformation Professionnelle

专业变形

A man takes out a loan, starts a company, and goes bankrupt shortly afterward. He falls into a depression and commits suicide.

一名男子贷款创办了一家公司，但不久后就破产了。他陷入抑郁，最终自杀身亡。

None of them. “If your only tool is a hammer, all your problems will be nails,” said Mark Twain—a quote that sums up the déformation professionnelle perfectly. Charlie Munger, Warren Buffett’s business partner, named the effect the “man with the hammer tendency” after Twain: “But that’s a perfectly disastrous way to think and a perfectly disastrous way to operate in the world. So you’ve got to have multiple models. And the models have to come from multiple disciplines—because all the wisdom of the world is not to be found in one little academic department.”

都不是。“如果你唯一的工具是一把锤子，那么你所有的问题都会变成钉子，”马克·吐温曾说——这句话完美地概括了“职业变形”。沃伦·巴菲特的商业伙伴查理·芒格以吐温的名言将这种现象命名为“锤子倾向的人”：“但这是一种极其糟糕的思维方式，也是一种极其糟糕的处世之道。所以你必须拥有多种模型。而这些模型必须来自多个学科——因为世界上所有的智慧并非都集中在一个小的学术部门。”

Here are a few examples of déformation professionnelle : Surgeons want to solve almost every medical problem with a scalpel, even if their patients could be treated with less invasive methods. Armies think of military solutions first. Engineers, structural. Trend gurus see trends in everything (incidentally, this is one of the most idiotic ways to view the world). In short: If you ask people the crux of a particular problem, they usually link it to their own areas of expertise.

以下是一些职业畸形的例子：外科医生几乎想用手术刀解决所有医疗问题，即使他们的病人可以用创伤更小的方法来治疗。军队首先考虑的是军事解决方案。工程师首先考虑的是结构问题。潮流大师能洞察一切趋势（顺便说一句，这是看待世界最愚蠢的方式之一）。简而言之：如果你问人们某个问题的症结所在，他们通常会将其与自己的专业领域联系起来。

So what’s wrong with that? It’s good if, say, a tailor sticks to what he knows. The déformation professionnelle becomes hazardous when people apply their specialized processes in areas where they don’t belong. Surely you’ve come across some of these: Teachers who scold their friends like students. New mothers who begin to treat their husbands like children. Or consider the omnipresent Excel spreadsheet that is featured on every computer: We use them even when it makes no sense—for example, when generating ten-year financial projections for start-ups or when comparing potential lovers that we have “sourced” from dating sites. Excel spreadsheets might as well be one of the most dangerous recent inventions.

那么这有什么错呢？比如说，裁缝坚持自己擅长的领域，这当然很好。当人们将自己的专业技能运用到不属于自己的领域时，职业转型就变得危险了。你肯定遇到过这样的人：老师像学生一样责骂朋友。新晋妈妈开始把丈夫当孩子一样对待。或者想想每台电脑上都自带的Excel电子表格：即使它毫无意义，我们也会用它——比如，为初创公司制作十年财务预测，或者比较从约会网站上“找到”的潜在对象。Excel电子表格可以说是近年来最危险的发明之一。

Even in his own jurisdiction, the man with the hammer tends to overuse it. Literary reviewers are trained to detect authors’ references, symbols, and hidden messages. As a novelist, I realize that literary reviewers conjure up such devices where there are none. T his is not a million miles away from what business journalists do, too. They scour the most trivial utterings of central bank governors and somehow discover hints of fiscal policy change by parsing their words.

即使在自己的管辖范围内，这位“铁锤男”也倾向于滥用它。文学评论家受过训练，能够发现作者的参考文献、符号和隐藏的信息。作为一名小说家，我意识到文学评论家会在没有这些技巧的地方变出这些技巧。这与商业记者的做法也相差无几。他们仔细研究央行行长最琐碎的言论，并通过分析他们的措辞，以某种方式发现财政政策变化的蛛丝马迹。

In conclusion: If you take your problem to an expert, don’t expect the overall best solution. Expect an approach that can be solved with the expert’s tool kit. The brain is not a central computer. Rather, it is a Swiss Army knife with many specialized tools. Unfortunately, our “pocketknives” are incomplete. Given our life experiences and our professional expertise, we already possess a few blades. But to better equip ourselves, we must try to add two or three additional tools to our repertoire—mental models that are far afield from our areas of expertise. For example, over the past few years, I have begun to take a biological view of the world and have won a new understanding of complex systems. Locate your shortcomings and find suitable knowledge and methodologies to balance them. It takes about a year to internalize the most important ideas of a new field, and it’s worth it: Your pocketknife will be bigger and more versatile, and your thoughts sharper.

总结：如果你把问题交给专家，不要指望他能提供最佳的整体解决方案。你只需要期待一个专家工具包就能解决的方法。大脑并非中央计算机，而是一把配备多种专用工具的瑞士军刀。遗憾的是，我们的“小刀”并不完整。鉴于我们的生活经历和专业知识，我们已经拥有了几个刀片。但为了更好地装备自己，我们必须尝试在自己的工具库中增加两到三种额外的工具——那些远离我们专业领域的心智模型。例如，在过去的几年里，我开始从生物学的角度看待世界，并对复杂系统有了新的理解。找到自己的不足之处，并找到合适的知识和方法来弥补不足。内化一个新领域最重要的思想大约需要一年时间，这是值得的：你的小刀会更大、更灵活，你的思维也会更敏锐。

93

Mission Accomplished

任务完成

Zeigarnik Effect

蔡加尼克效应

B erlin, 1927: A group of university students and professors visit a restaurant. The waiter takes order upon order, including special requests, but does not bother to write anything down. This is going to end badly, they think. But, after a short wait, all diners receive exactly what they ordered. After dinner, outside on the street, Russian psychology student Bluma Zeigarnik notices that she has left her scarf behind in the restaurant. She goes back in, finds the waiter with the incredible memory, and asks him if he has seen it. He stares at her blankly. He has no idea who she is or where she sat. “How can you have forgotten?” she asks indignantly. “Especially with your super memory!” The waiter replies curtly: “I keep every order in my head—until it is served.”

1927年，柏林：一群大学生和教授来到一家餐馆。服务员接连点菜，包括特殊要求，却懒得记录。他们心想，这样下去恐怕不好。然而，等了一会儿之后，所有食客都收到了他们点的菜。晚餐后，在街上，俄罗斯心理学学生布鲁玛·蔡加尼克（Bluma Zeigarnik）发现自己把围巾落在了餐馆里。她回到餐厅，找到记忆力超群的服务员，问他是否看到了围巾。他茫然地盯着她，不知道她是谁，也不知道她坐在哪里。“你怎么会忘了？”她愤愤不平地问道，“你记忆力这么好！”服务员简短地回答：“我把每道菜都记在脑子里——直到上桌。”

Zeigarnik and her mentor, Kurt Lewin, studied this strange behavior and found that all people function more or less like the waiter. We seldom forget uncompleted tasks; they persist in our consciousness and do not let up, tugging at us like little children, until we give them our attention. On the other hand, once we’ve completed a task and checked it off our mental list, it is erased from memory.

蔡加尼克和她的导师库尔特·勒温研究了这种奇怪的行为，发现所有人的行为方式或多或少都像那位服务员。我们很少会忘记未完成的任务；它们会一直萦绕在我们的意识中，不肯罢休，像小孩子一样牵着我们，直到我们把注意力集中到它们身上。另一方面，一旦我们完成了一项任务，并从脑海清单上划掉，它就会从记忆中消失。

The researcher has lent her name to this: Scientists now speak of the Zeigarnik effect . However, in her investigation, she uncovered a few untidy outliers: Some people kept a completely clear head even if they had dozens of projects on the go. Only in recent years could Roy Baumeister and his research team at Florida State University shed light on this. He took students who were a few months away from their final examinations and split them into three groups. Group 1 had to focus on a party during the current semester. Group 2 had to concentrate on the exam. Group 3 had to focus on the exam and also create a detailed study plan. Then Baumeister asked students to complete words under time pressure. Some students saw “pa . . .” and filled in “panic,” while others thought of “party” or “Paris.” This was a clever method of finding out what was on each of their minds. As expected, group 1 had relaxed about the upcoming exam, while students in group 2 could think of nothing else. Most astonishing was the result from group 3. Although these students also had to focus on the upcoming exam, their minds were clear and free from anxiety. Further experiments confirmed this. Outstanding tasks gnaw at us only until we have a clear idea of how we will deal with them. Zeigarnik mistakenly believed that it was necessary to complete tasks to erase them from memory. But it’s not; a good plan of action suffices.

研究人员以自己的名字命名了这一现象：科学家们现在称之为蔡加尼克效应。然而，在她的调查中，她发现了一些不寻常的异常现象：有些人即使同时进行几十个项目，也能保持头脑完全清醒。直到近年来，佛罗里达州立大学的罗伊·鲍迈斯特和他的研究团队才揭示了这一点。他把距离期末考试还有几个月的学生分成三组。第一组必须专注于本学期的一次聚会。第二组必须专注于考试。第三组必须专注于考试，并制定详细的学习计划。然后，鲍迈斯特要求学生在时间压力下完成单词。一些学生看到“pa……”就填写“panic”，而另一些学生则想到“party”或“Paris”。这是一种巧妙的方法，可以了解每个人心中的想法。不出所料，第一组对即将到来的考试很放松，而第二组的学生则什么都不想。最令人惊讶的是第三组的结果。尽管这些学生也必须专注于即将到来的考试，但他们的头脑却非常清晰，没有焦虑。进一步的实验证实了这一点。未完成的任务只会让我们感到困扰，直到我们清楚地知道该如何处理它们。蔡加尼克错误地认为，只有完成任务才能将它们从记忆中抹去。但事实并非如此；一个好的行动计划就足够了。

David Allen, the author of a best-selling book aptly entitled Getting Things Done , argues that he has one goal: to have a head as clear as water. For this, you don’t need to have your whole life sorted into tidy compartments. But it does mean that you need a detailed plan for dealing with the messier areas. This plan must be divided into step-by-step tasks and preferably written down. Only when this is done can your mind rest. The adjective “detailed” is important. “Organize my wife’s birthday party” or “find a new job” are worthless. Allen forces his clients to split such projects into twenty to fifty individual tasks.

畅销书《搞定一切》（Getting Things Done）的作者戴维·艾伦（David Allen）声称，他有一个目标：头脑清澈如水。为此，你无需将整个生活整理成一个个整齐的分区。但这确实意味着你需要一个详细的计划来处理那些比较杂乱的部分。这个计划必须分解成逐步完成的任务，最好能写下来。只有这样做，你的头脑才能安心。“详细”这个形容词很重要。“组织我妻子的生日派对”或“找份新工作”之类的想法毫无意义。艾伦会要求他的客户将这类项目分解成20到50个独立的任务。

It’s worth noting that Allen’s recommendation seems to fly in the face of the planning fallacy ( chapter 91 ): the more detailed our planning, the more we tend to overlook factors from the periphery that will derail our projects. But here is the rub: If you want peace of mind, go for Allen’s approach. If you want the most accurate estimate on cost, benefit, and duration of a project, forgot your detailed plan and look up similar projects. If you want both, do both.

值得注意的是，艾伦的建议似乎与“计划谬误”（第91章）截然相反：我们的计划越详细，我们就越容易忽略那些可能阻碍项目进展的外围因素。但问题就在这里：如果你想安心，那就采用艾伦的方法。如果你想对项目的成本、收益和工期进行最准确的估算，那就忘掉你的详细计划，去查找类似的项目。如果你想两者兼顾，那就两者兼顾。

Fortunately, you can do all this yourself with the aid of a decidedly low-tech device. Place a notepad by your bed. The next time you cannot get to sleep, jot down outstanding tasks and how you will tackle them. This will silence the cacophony of inner voices. “You want to find God, but you’re out of cat food, so create a plan to deal with it,” says Allen. His advice is sound, even if you have already found God or have no cat.

幸运的是，借助一个绝对低科技的设备，你完全可以自己完成这一切。在床边放一本记事本。下次你睡不着的时候，就记下一些未完成的任务以及你将如何解决它们。这能让你内心的喧嚣安静下来。“你想找到上帝，但你没有猫粮了，所以制定一个计划来应对吧，”艾伦说。他的建议很有意义，即使你已经找到了上帝，或者没有猫。

94

The Boat Matters More Than the Rowing

船比划船更重要

Illusion of Skill

技能幻觉

W hy are there so few serial entrepreneurs—businesspeople who start successful companies one after the other? Of course, there’s Steve Jobs and Richard Branson, but they represent a tiny minority. Serial entrepreneurs account for less than 1 percent of everyone who starts a company. Do they all retire to their private yachts after the first success just like Microsoft cofounder Paul Allen did? Surely not. True businesspeople possess too much get-up-and-go to lie on a beach chair for hours on end. Is it because they can’t let go and want to cosset their firms until they turn sixty-five? No. Most founders sell their shares within ten years. Actually, you would assume that such self-starters who are blessed with talent, a good personal network, and a solid reputation would be well equipped to found numerous other start-ups. So why do they stop? They didn’t stop. They just failed at succeeding. Only one answer makes sense: Luck plays a bigger role than skill does. No businessperson likes to hear this. When I first heard about the illusion of skill , my reaction was: “What, my success was a fluke?” At first, it sounds a little offensive, especially if you worked hard to get there.

为什么连续创业者（即那些创办了一家又一家成功企业的企业家）这么少？当然，也有史蒂夫·乔布斯和理查德·布兰森，但他们只是极少数。连续创业者占所有创业者的比例不到1%。他们是不是都像微软联合创始人保罗·艾伦那样，在第一次成功后就退休，去私人游艇上享受退休生活？当然不是。真正的企业家精力充沛，不会在沙滩椅上躺上几个小时。是因为他们舍不得放手，想一直宠着自己的公司到65岁吗？不是的。大多数创始人会在10年内卖掉手中的股份。实际上，你会认为，这些拥有天赋、良好人脉和良好声誉的创业者，完全有能力创办许多其他初创企业。那么，他们为什么会停下来呢？他们没有停下来。他们只是没能成功。只有一个答案说得通：运气比技能更重要。没有哪个商人喜欢听到这种说法。当我第一次听说技能幻觉时，我的反应是：“什么，我的成功只是侥幸？”起初，这听起来有点冒犯，尤其是如果你努力奋斗才达到这个目标的话。

Let’s take a sober look at business success: How much of it comes down to luck, and how much is the fruit of hard work and distinct talent? The question is easily misunderstood. Of course, little is achieved without talent, and nothing is achieved without hard work. Unfortunately, neither skills nor toil and trouble are the key criteria for success. They are necessary —but not sufficient. How do we know this? There is a very simple test: When a person is successful for a long time—more than that, when they enjoy more success in the long run compared to less qualified people—then and only then is talent the essential element. This is not the case with company founders; otherwise, the majority of successful entrepreneurs would, after the first achievement, continue to found and grow second, third, and fourth start-ups.

让我们冷静地看待商业成功：它有多少是运气的功劳，又有多少是勤奋和独特天赋的成果？这个问题很容易被误解。当然，没有天赋就一事无成，没有努力就一事无成。不幸的是，技能、辛劳和艰辛都不是成功的关键标准。它们是必要条件，但还不够。我们如何知道这一点？有一个非常简单的测试：当一个人长期取得成功——不仅如此，从长远来看，他们比资历较浅的人获得更多成功——那时，也只有那时，天赋才是关键因素。公司创始人并非如此；否则，大多数成功的企业家在取得第一次成功后，会继续创办和发展第二家、第三家、第四家初创企业。

What about corporate leaders? How important are they to the success of a company? Researchers have determined a set of traits deemed to be associated with “a strong CEO”—management procedures, strategic brilliance in the past, and so on. Then they measured the relationship between these behaviors, on the one hand, and the increase of the companies’ values during the reign of these CEOs, on the other hand. The result: If you compare two companies at random, in 60 percent of cases, the stronger CEO leads the stronger company. In 40 percent of the cases, the weaker CEO leads the stronger company. This is only 10 percentage points more than no relationship at all. Kahneman said: “It’s hard to imagine that people enthusiastically buy books written by business leaders who are, on average, only slightly better than the norm.” Even Warren Buffett thinks nothing of CEO deification: “A good managerial record . . . is far more a function of what business boat you get into than it is of how effectively you row.”

那么企业领导者呢？他们对公司的成功有多重要？研究人员确定了一系列被认为与“强势CEO”相关的特质——管理流程、过往的战略才华等等。然后，他们衡量了这些行为与CEO任期内公司价值增长之间的关系。结果显示：如果随机比较两家公司，在60%的情况下，强势CEO领导的公司会更强。在40%的情况下，弱势CEO领导的公司会更强。这仅比完全没有关系高出10个百分点。卡尼曼说：“很难想象人们会热情地购买那些平均水平仅略高于平均水平的商业领袖所写的书籍。” 即使是沃伦·巴菲特也对CEO的神化不以为然：“良好的管理记录……与其说取决于你划船的效率，不如说取决于你乘坐的是哪艘商业巨轮。”

In certain areas, skill plays no role whatsoever. In his book Thinking, Fast and Slow , Kahneman describes his visit to an asset management company. To brief him, they sent him a spreadsheet showing the performance of each investment adviser over the past eight years. From this, a ranking was assigned to each: number 1, 2, 3, and so on in descending order. This was compiled every year. Kahneman quickly calculated the relationship between the years’ rankings. Specifically, he calculated the correlation of the rankings between year 1 and year 2, between year 1 and year 3, year 1 and year 4, up until year 7 and year 8. The result: pure coincidence. Sometimes the adviser was at the very top and sometimes the very bottom. If an adviser had a great year, this was neither bolstered by previous years nor carried into subsequent years. The correlation was zero. And yet the consultants pocketed bonuses for their performance. In other words, the company was rewarding luck rather than skill.

在某些领域，技能根本不起作用。卡尼曼在其著作《思考，快与慢》中描述了他对一家资产管理公司的访问。为了向他介绍情况，公司给他发了一份电子表格，上面列出了过去八年每位投资顾问的业绩。然后，每位顾问都被分配了一个排名：按降序排列，分别是 1、2、3 等等。这份排名每年都会汇总。卡尼曼很快就计算出了各年排名之间的关系。具体来说，他计算了第 1 年与第 2 年、第 1 年与第 3 年、第 1 年与第 4 年，直到第 7 年与第 8 年的排名相关性。结果：纯属巧合。有时顾问名列前茅，有时却垫底。如果一位顾问某一年表现出色，这既不会在前几年得到巩固，也不会延续到后几年。相关性为零。然而，这些顾问却凭借其出色的业绩获得了奖金。换句话说，公司奖励的是运气而不是技能。

In conclusion: Certain people make a living from their abilities, such as pilots, plumbers, and lawyers. In other areas, skill is necessary but not critical, as with entrepreneurs and leaders. Finally, chance is the deciding factor in a number of fields, such as in financial markets. Here, the illusion of skill pervades. So, give plumbers due respect and chuckle at successful financial jesters.

总而言之：有些人靠自己的能力谋生，比如飞行员、水管工和律师。在其他领域，技能是必需的，但并非关键，比如企业家和领导者。最后，在许多领域，运气才是决定性因素，比如金融市场。在这里，技能的幻觉弥漫开来。所以，请尊重水管工，嘲笑那些成功的金融小丑。

95

Why Checklists Deceive You

为什么清单会欺骗你

Feature-Positive Effect

特征正效应

T wo series of numbers: The first, series A, consists of: 724, 947, 421, 843, 394, 411, 054, 646. What do these numbers have in common? Don’t read on until you have an answer. It’s simpler than you think: The number 4 features in each of them. Now examine series B: 349, 851, 274, 905, 772, 032, 854, 113. What links these numbers? Do not read further until you’ve figured it out. Series B is more difficult, right? Answer: None use the number 6. What can you learn from this? Absence is much harder to detect than presence. In other words, we place greater emphasis on what is present than on what is absent.

两组数字：第一组，即 A 系列，由以下数字组成：724、947、421、843、394、411、054、646。这些数字有什么共同点？在找到答案之前，请不要继续阅读。它比你想象的要简单：每个数字都包含数字 4。现在检查 B 系列：349、851、274、905、772、032、854、113。是什么将这些数字联系在一起？在弄清楚之前，请不要继续阅读。B 系列更难，对吗？答案：没有一个使用数字 6。你能从中学到什么？缺失比存在更难检测。换句话说，我们更重视存在的东西，而不是不存在的东西。

Last week, while on a walk, it occurred to me that nothing hurt. It was an unexpected thought. I rarely experience pain anyway, but when I do, it is very present. But the absence of pain I rarely recognize. It was such a simple, obvious fact, it amazed me. For a moment, I was elated—until this little revelation slipped from my mind again.

上周散步时，我突然想到，其实什么都不疼。这想法出乎意料。我本来很少感到疼痛，但一旦感到疼痛，疼痛就无比真实。只是我很少意识到疼痛的消失。这实在是一个显而易见的事实，让我感到不可思议。有那么一瞬间，我欣喜若狂——直到这小小的启示再次从我的脑海中消失。

At a classical recital, an orchestra performed Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony. A storm of enthusiasm gripped the concert hall. During the ode in the fourth movement, tears of joy could be seen here and there. How fortunate we are that this symphony exists, I thought. But is that really true? Would we be less happy without the work? Probably not. Had the symphony never been composed, no one would miss it. The director would receive no angry calls saying: “Please have this symphony written and performed immediately.” In short, what exists means a lot more than what is missing. Science calls this the feature-positive effect .

在一场古典独奏音乐会上，管弦乐队演奏了贝多芬的《第九交响曲》。音乐厅里洋溢着热情的风暴。在第四乐章的颂歌中，不时可以看到喜悦的泪水。我心想，我们多么幸运能有这部交响曲。但事实真的如此吗？如果没有这部作品，我们会不会不那么快乐？可能不会。如果这部交响曲从未创作过，也不会有人怀念它。指挥也不会接到愤怒的电话：“请立即创作并演奏这部交响曲。”简而言之，现有的意义远大于缺失的意义。科学界称之为“特征正效应”。

Prevention campaigns utilize this well. “Smoking causes lung cancer” is much more powerful than “Not smoking leads to a life free of lung cancer.” Auditors and other professionals who employ checklists are prone to the feature-positive effect : Outstanding tax declarations are immediately obvious because they feature on their lists. What does not appear, however, is more artistic fraud, such as the goings-on at Enron and with Bernie Madoff’s Ponzi scheme. Also absent are the undertakings of “rogue traders,” such as Nick Leeson and Jerome Kerviel, to whom Barings and Société Générale fell victim. Financial vagaries of this kind are not on any checklist. And they do not have to be illegal: A mortgage bank will be on the lookout for credit risk due to a drop in the debtor’s income because this appears on its list; however, it will overlook the devaluation of property, say, through the construction of an incineration plant in the vicinity.

预防运动很好地利用了这一点。“吸烟导致肺癌”比“不吸烟可以远离肺癌”更有力。审计师和其他使用清单的专业人士容易受到特征正效应的影响：未缴税款一目了然，因为它们列在清单上。然而，那些更具艺术性的欺诈行为并没有出现，例如安然公司和伯纳德·麦道夫的庞氏骗局。同样缺席的还有尼克·利森和杰罗姆·科维尔等“流氓交易员”的行径，巴林银行和法国兴业银行就是他们的受害者。这类金融变幻莫测的行为不在任何清单上。而且它们不一定是非法的：一家抵押贷款银行会密切关注债务人收入下降带来的信用风险，因为这列在它的清单上；然而，它会忽略房产贬值，比如在附近建造焚烧厂。

Suppose you manufacture a dubious product, such as a salad dressing with a high level of cholesterol. What do you do? On the label, you promote the twenty different vitamins in the dressing and omit the cholesterol level. Consumers won’t notice its absence. And the positive, present features will make sure that they feel safe and informed.

假设你生产了一种可疑产品，比如一种胆固醇含量高的沙拉酱。你会怎么做？在标签上，你会宣传沙拉酱中含有的二十种维生素，却忽略胆固醇含量。消费者不会注意到胆固醇含量的缺失。而这些积极的、现成的标签信息会确保他们感到安全，并了解相关信息。

In academia, we constantly encounter the feature-positive effect . The confirmation of hypotheses leads to publications, and in exceptional cases these are rewarded with Nobel Prizes. On the other hand, the falsification of a hypothesis is a lot harder to get published, and as far as I know, there has never been a Nobel Prize awarded for this. However, such falsification is as scientifically valuable as confirmation. Another consequence of the effect is that we are also much more open to positive advice (do X) than to negative suggestions (forget about Y)—no matter how useful the latter may be.

在学术界，我们经常遇到特征正效应。假设的证实会带来成果发表，在特殊情况下，这些成果甚至会获得诺贝尔奖。另一方面，假设的证伪则更难发表，据我所知，从未有过诺贝尔奖因此而颁发。然而，这种证伪的科学价值与证实一样高。这种效应的另一个后果是，我们更容易接受积极的建议（做 X），而不是消极的建议（忘掉 Y），无论后者多么有用。

In conclusion: We have problems perceiving nonevents. We are blind to what does not exist. We realize if there is a war, but we do not appreciate the absence of war during peacetime. If we are healthy, we rarely think about being sick. Or, if we get off the plane in Cancún, we do not stop to notice that we did not crash. If we thought more frequently about absence, we might well be happier. But it is tough mental work. The greatest philosophical question is: Why does something and not nothing exist? Don’t expect a quick answer; rather, the question itself represents a useful instrument for combating the feature-positive effect .

总结：我们难以感知非事件。我们对不存在的事物视而不见。我们意识到战争的存在，却无法珍惜和平时期没有战争的美好。如果我们身体健康，很少会想到生病。或者，如果我们在坎昆下飞机，也不会停下来思考飞机没有坠毁。如果我们更频繁地思考“不存在”，我们或许会更快乐。但这是一项艰巨的脑力劳动。最伟大的哲学问题是：为什么存在某种东西而不是什么都没有？不要期待一个快速的答案；相反，这个问题本身就是对抗特征正效应的有力工具。

96

Drawing the Bull’s-Eye around the Arrow

画出箭周围的靶心

Cherry Picking

挑选樱桃

O n their websites, hotels present themselves in the very best light. They carefully select each photo, and only beautiful, majestic images make the cut. Unflattering angles, dripping pipes, and drab breakfast rooms are swept under the tattered carpet. Of course, you know this is true. When you are confronted by the shabby lobby for the first time, you simply shrug your shoulders and head to the registration desk.

酒店在网站上以最佳状态展现自己。他们精心挑选每一张照片，只留下美丽、气派的照片。丑陋的角度、滴水的管道和单调的早餐室都被掩盖在破旧的地毯下。当然，你知道这是真的。当你第一次面对破旧的大堂时，你只会耸耸肩，然后走向登记处。

What the hotel did is called cherry picking : selecting and showcasing the most attractive features and hiding the rest. As with the hotel experience, you approach other things with the same muted expectations: brochures for cars, real estate, or law firms. You know how they work, and you don’t fall for them.

这家酒店的做法被称为“精挑细选”：挑选并展示最吸引人的功能，隐藏其余部分。就像酒店体验一样，你对待其他事物也抱有同样的低调期望：汽车、房地产或律师事务所的宣传册。你知道它们的运作方式，所以不会上当受骗。

However, you respond differently to the annual reports of companies, foundations, and government organizations. Here, you tend to expect objective depictions. You are mistaken. These bodies also cherry-pick : If goals are achieved, they are talked up; if they falter, they are not even mentioned.

然而，你对公司、基金会和政府机构的年度报告的反应却截然不同。你往往期望这些报告有客观的描述。但你错了。这些机构还会精挑细选：如果目标实现了，就会大肆宣传；如果目标未能实现，甚至连提都不提。

Suppose you are the head of a department. The board invites you to present your team’s state of play. How do you tackle this? You devote most of your PowerPoint slides to elaborate on the team’s triumphs and throw in a token few to identify “challenges.” Any other unmet achievements you conveniently forget.

假设你是一个部门的主管。董事会邀请你汇报团队的现状。你会怎么做？你会用大部分的PowerPoint幻灯片来阐述团队取得的成就，只偶尔插入几句来说明“挑战”。至于其他尚未实现的成就，你则视而不见。

Anecdotes are a particularly tricky sort of cherry picking . Imagine you are the managing director of a company that manufactures some kind of technical device. A survey has revealed that the vast majority of customers cannot operate your gadget. It’s too complicated. Now the HR manager gives his two cents, proclaiming: “My father-in-law picked it up yesterday and figured out how to work it right away.” How much weight would you attach to this particular cherry? Right: close to zero. To rebuff an anecdote is difficult because it is a mini-story, and we know how vulnerable our brains are to those. To prevent this, cunning leaders train themselves throughout their careers to be hypersensitive to such anecdotes and to shoot them down as soon as they are uttered.

轶事是特别棘手的“采摘樱桃”技巧。想象一下，你是一家生产某种技术设备的公司的总经理。一项调查显示，绝大多数客户不会操作你的设备。它太复杂了。现在，人力资源经理发表了自己的看法，宣称：“我岳父昨天拿到了它，马上就搞清楚了怎么用。” 你会给这个“樱桃”多大的重视？对的：几乎为零。驳斥轶事很难，因为它只是一个小故事，而我们知道我们的大脑对这类故事有多么敏感。为了避免这种情况，精明的领导者会在整个职业生涯中训练自己对这类轶事高度敏感，并在它们被说出后立即予以驳斥。

The more elevated or elite a field is, the more we fall for cherry picking . In Antifragile , Taleb describes how all areas of research—from philosophy to medicine to economics—brag about their results: “Like politicians, academia is well equipped to tell us what it did for us, not what it did not—hence it shows how indispensable her methods are.” Pure cherry picking . But our respect for academics is far too great for us to notice this.

一个领域越是高高在上或精英化，我们就越容易陷入“择优录取”的陷阱。塔勒布在《反脆弱》一书中描述了所有研究领域——从哲学到医学再到经济学——如何吹嘘自己的成果：“就像政客一样，学术界很擅长告诉我们它为我们做了什么，而不是它没有做什么——因此，它表明了它的方法是多么不可或缺。” 纯粹的“择优录取”。但我们对学术界的敬意太强烈，以至于我们察觉不到这一点。

Or consider the medical profession: To tell people that they should not smoke is the greatest medical contribution of the past sixty years—superior to all the research and medical advances since the end of the Second World War. Physician Druin Burch confirms this in his book Taking the Medicine . A few cherries—antibiotics, for instance—distract us, and so drug researchers are celebrated while antismoking activists are not.

或者想想医学界：告诉人们不应该吸烟是过去六十年来最伟大的医学贡献——超越了二战结束以来的所有研究和医学进步。医生德鲁因·伯奇在他的著作《服药》中证实了这一点。一些无关紧要的事物——例如抗生素——会分散我们的注意力，因此药物研究人员受到赞扬，而反吸烟活动家则不然。

Administrative departments in large companies glorify themselves like hoteliers do. They are masters at showcasing all they have done, but they never communicate what they haven’t achieved for the company. What should you do? If you sit on the supervisory board of such an organization, ask about the “leftover cherries,” the failed projects and missed goals. You learn a lot more from this than from the successes. It is amazing how seldom such questions are asked. Second: Instead of employing a horde of financial controllers to calculate costs to the nearest cent, double-check targets. You will be amazed to find that, over time, the original goals have faded. These have been replaced, quietly and secretly, with self-set goals that are always attainable. If you hear of such targets, alarm bells should sound. It is the equivalent of shooting an arrow and drawing a bull’s-eye around where it lands.

大公司的行政部门像酒店老板一样吹嘘自己。他们擅长展示自己所做的一切，却从不告诉别人他们没有为公司取得什么成就。你该怎么办？如果你是这类组织的监事会成员，不妨问问那些“剩余的樱桃”、失败的项目和未实现的目标。你从中学到的东西比从成功案例中学到的多得多。令人惊讶的是，人们很少问这样的问题。第二：与其雇佣一大群财务总监来精确计算成本，不如仔细检查目标。你会惊奇地发现，随着时间的推移，最初的目标已经消失。这些目标悄无声息地被那些总是可以实现的自我设定的目标所取代。如果你听到这样的目标，就应该敲响警钟。这相当于射出一支箭，然后在它落下的地方画一个靶心。

97

The Stone Age Hunt for Scapegoats

石器时代寻找替罪羊

Fallacy of the Single Cause

单一原因谬误

C hris Matthews is one of MSNBC’s top journalists. In his news show, so-called political experts are wheeled in one after the other and interviewed. I’ve never understood what a political expert is or why such a career is worthwhile. In 2003, the U.S. invasion of Iraq was the issue on everybody’s lips. More important than the experts’ answers were Chris Matthews’s questions: “What is the motive behind the war?” “I wanted to know whether 9/11 is the reason , because a lot of people think it’s payback.” “Do you think that the weapons of mass destruction was the reason for this war?” “Why do you think we invaded Iraq? The real reason , not the sales pitch.” And so on.

克里斯·马修斯是MSNBC的顶级记者之一。在他的新闻节目中，所谓的政治专家被一个接一个地拉进来接受采访。我一直不明白政治专家是什么，也不明白为什么这样的职业值得从事。2003年，美国入侵伊拉克成了人们热议的话题。比专家的回答更重要的是克里斯·马修斯提出的问题：“战争背后的动机是什么？”“我想知道9/11事件是不是原因，因为很多人认为这是报复。”“你认为大规模杀伤性武器是这场战争的起因吗？”“你认为我们为什么入侵伊拉克？真正的原因，而不是政治宣传。”等等。

I can’t abide questions like that anymore. They are symptomatic of the most common of all mental errors, a mistake for which, strangely enough, there is no everyday term. For now, the awkward phrase, the fallacy of the single cause , will have to do.

我再也无法忍受这样的问题了。它们代表着所有思维错误中最常见的一种，奇怪的是，这种错误并没有一个日常用语来形容。现在，只能用那个尴尬的词——“单一原因谬误”来形容了。

Five years later, in 2008, panic reigned in the financial markets. Banks caved in and had to be nursed back to health with tax dollars. Investors, politicians, and journalists probed furiously for the root of the crisis: Greenspan’s loose monetary policy? The stupidity of investors? The dubious rating agencies? Corrupt auditors? Bad risk models? Pure greed? Not a single one, and yet every one of these, is the cause.

五年后的2008年，恐慌席卷了金融市场。银行纷纷倒闭，不得不用纳税人的钱来维持。投资者、政客和记者们疯狂地探究危机的根源：是格林斯潘的宽松货币政策？是投资者的愚蠢？是可疑的评级机构？是腐败的审计师？是糟糕的风险模型？还是纯粹的贪婪？以上任何一个都不是，但所有这些，却都是危机的根源。

A balmy Indian summer, a friend’s divorce, the First World War, cancer, a school shooting, the worldwide success of a company, the invention of writing—any clear-thinking person knows that no single factor leads to such events. Rather, there are hundreds, thousands, an infinite number of factors that add up. Still, we keep trying to pin the blame on just one.

温暖宜人的秋分、朋友的离婚、第一次世界大战、癌症、校园枪击案、一家公司在世界范围内的成功、文字的发明——任何头脑清晰的人都知道，这些事件的发生并非单一因素造成的。相反，这些事件是由成百上千、数不清的因素共同作用的结果。然而，我们却总是试图把责任归咎于单一因素。

“When an apple ripens and falls—what makes it fall? Is it that it is attracted to the ground, is it that the stem withers, is it that the sun has dried it up, that is has grown heavier, that the wind shakes it, that the boy standing underneath it wants to eat it? No one thing is the cause.” In this passage from War and Peace , Tolstoy hit the nail on the head.

“当一个苹果成熟并掉落时，是什么促使它掉落？是因为它被地吸住了，是因为它茎干枯萎了，是因为它被太阳晒干了，是因为它变重了，是因为它被风吹动了，还是因为站在它下面的男孩想吃它？没有任何一件事是原因。”托尔斯泰在《战争与和平》中的这段话一针见血。

Suppose you are the product manager for a well-known breakfast cereal brand. You have just launched an organic, low-sugar variety. After a month, it’s painfully clear that the new product is a flop. How do you go about investigating the cause? First, you know that there will never be one sole factor. Take a sheet of paper and sketch out all the potential reasons. Do the same for the reasons behind these reasons. After a while, you will have a network of possible influencing factors. Second, highlight those you can change and delete those you cannot (such as “human nature”). Third, conduct empirical tests by varying the highlighted factors in different markets. This costs time and money, but it’s the only way to escape the swamp of superficial assumptions.

假设你是一家知名早餐麦片品牌的产品经理。你刚刚推出了一款有机低糖早餐麦片。一个月后，你痛苦地发现这款新产品惨败了。你会如何调查原因呢？首先，你知道失败的原因绝非单一因素。拿出一张纸，列出所有可能的原因。然后，对这些原因背后的原因也进行同样的分析。一段时间后，你就会形成一个可能的影响因素网络。其次，突出那些你可以改变的因素，删除那些你无法改变的因素（例如“人性”）。第三，通过在不同的市场中改变这些突出的因素来进行实证检验。这需要时间和金钱，但这是摆脱肤浅假设泥潭的唯一方法。

The fallacy of the single cause is as ancient as it is dangerous. We have learned to see people as the “masters of their own destinies.” Aristotle proclaimed this 2,500 years ago. Today we know that it is wrong. The notion of free will is up for debate. Our actions are brought about by the interaction of thousands of factors—from genetic predisposition to upbringing, from education to the concentration of hormones between individual brain cells. Still we hold firmly to the old image of self-governance. This is not only wrong but also morally questionable. As long as we believe in singular reasons, we will always be able to trace triumphs or disasters back to individuals and stamp them “responsible.” The idiotic hunt for a scapegoat goes hand in hand with the exercise of power—a game that people have been playing for thousands of years.

单一原因谬误由来已久，危险至极。我们习以为常地将人视为“自己命运的主人”。亚里士多德早在2500年前就宣称了这一点。如今，我们知道这是错误的。自由意志的概念仍有待商榷。我们的行为是由成千上万种因素相互作用所致——从遗传倾向到成长环境，从教育到个体脑细胞间激素浓度。然而，我们仍然固守着旧有的自治观念。这不仅是错误的，而且在道德上也值得商榷。只要我们相信单一原因，我们就总能将成功或失败归咎于个人，并给他们贴上“责任”的标签。愚蠢地寻找替罪羊与权力的行使密不可分——这是人类几千年来一直在玩的游戏。

And yet the fallacy of the single cause is so popular that Tracy Chapman was able to build her worldwide success on it. “Give Me One Reason” is the song that secured her success. But hold on—weren’t there a few others, too?

然而，单一原因谬论如此流行，以至于特蕾西·查普曼得以以此为基础，在世界范围内取得成功。《给我一个理由》正是她成功的基石。但等等——难道还有其他几首歌吗？

98

Why Speed Demons Appear to Be Safer Drivers

为什么超速驾驶者看起来是更安全的驾驶员

Intention-to-Treat Error

意向治疗错误

Y ou’ll find it hard to believe, but speed demons drive more safely than so-called careful drivers. Why? Well, consider this: The distance from Miami to West Palm Beach is around seventy-five miles. Drivers who cover the distance in an hour or less we’ll categorize as “reckless drivers” because they’re traveling at an average of 75 mph or more. All others we put into the group of careful drivers. Which group experiences fewer accidents? Without a doubt, it is the “reckless drivers.” They all completed the journey in less than an hour, so they could not have been involved in any accidents. This automatically puts all drivers who end up in accidents in the slower drivers’ category. This example illustrates a treacherous fallacy, the so-called intention-to-treat error . Unfortunately, there is no catchier term for it.

你可能难以置信，但速度狂魔比所谓的谨慎驾驶员更安全。为什么？想想看：从迈阿密到西棕榈滩的距离约为 75 英里。我们将在一小时或更短时间内完成此距离的驾驶员归类为“鲁莽驾驶员”，因为他们的平均行驶速度为 75 英里/小时或更高。我们将所有其他人归入谨慎驾驶员组。哪一类人发生的事故更少？毫无疑问，是“鲁莽驾驶员”。他们都在不到一小时内完成了旅程，因此他们不可能卷入任何事故。这自动将所有最终发生事故的驾驶员归入慢速驾驶员类别。这个例子说明了一个危险的谬误，即所谓的意向治疗错误。不幸的是，没有更吸引人的术语来形容它。

This might sound to you like the survivorship bias ( chapter 1 ), but it’s different. In the survivorship bias you see only the survivors, not the failed projects or cars involved in accidents. In the intention-to-treat error , the failed projects or cars with accidents prominently show up, just in the wrong category.

这听起来可能很像第一章提到的幸存者偏差，但两者截然不同。在幸存者偏差中，你只会看到幸存者，而不会看到失败的项目或发生事故的汽车。而在意向治疗错误中，失败的项目或发生事故的汽车会显著地出现，只是被归类到了错误的类别中。

A banker showed me an interesting study recently. Its conclusion: Companies with debt on their balance sheets are significantly more profitable than firms with no debt (equity only). The banker vehemently insisted that every company should borrow at will, and, of course, his bank is the best place to do it. I examined the study more closely. How could that be? Indeed, from one thousand randomly selected firms, those with large loans displayed higher returns not only on their equity but also on their total capital. They were in every respect more successful than the independently financed firms. Then the penny dropped: Unprofitable companies don’t get corporate loans. Thus, they form part of the “equity-only” group. The other firms that make up this set have bigger cash cushions, stay afloat longer, and, no matter how sickly they are, remain part of the study. On the other side, firms that have borrowed a lot go bankrupt more quickly. Once they cannot pay back the interest, the bank takes over, and the companies are sold off—thus disappearing from the sample. The ones that remain in the “debt group” are relatively healthy, regardless of how much debt they have amassed on their balance sheets.

最近，一位银行家给我看了一项有趣的研究。研究结论是：资产负债表上有债务的公司比没有债务（只有股权）的公司盈利能力强得多。这位银行家坚决主张每家公司都应该随意借款，而他的银行当然是借款的最佳选择。我更仔细地研究了这项研究。这怎么可能呢？事实上，从随机选取的一千家公司中，那些拥有大额贷款的公司不仅在股权方面，而且在总资本方面都表现出更高的回报率。它们在各个方面都比独立融资的公司更成功。然后我恍然大悟：不盈利的公司无法获得公司贷款。因此，它们被归类为“只有股权”的公司。构成这一组的其他公司拥有更大的现金缓冲，能够维持更长时间的运营，而且无论它们状况多么糟糕，都仍然是研究对象。另一方面，那些借款额度很大的公司破产得更快。一旦它们无力偿还利息，银行就会接管，这些公司就会被出售——从而从样本中消失。那些仍属于“债务集团”的公司相对健康，无论其资产负债表上积累了多少债务。

If you’re thinking, “Okay, got it,” watch out. The intention-to-treat error is not easy to recognize. A fictional example from medicine: A pharmaceutical company has developed a new drug to fight heart disease. A study “proves” that it significantly reduces patients’ mortality rates. The data speaks for itself: Among patients who have taken the drug regularly, the five-year mortality rate is 15 percent. For those who have swallowed placebo pills, it is about the same, indicating that the pill doesn’t work. However—and this is crucial—the mortality rate of patients who have taken the drug at irregular intervals is 30 percent—twice as high! A big difference between regular and irregular intake. So, the pill is a complete success. Or is it?

如果你心想：“好吧，明白了”，那就要当心了。意向治疗错误并不容易识别。举一个医学上的虚构例子：一家制药公司研发了一种对抗心脏病的新药。一项研究“证明”它显著降低了患者的死亡率。数据说明了一切：定期服用该药的患者，五年死亡率为 15%。服用安慰剂的患者，五年死亡率也差不多，这表明这种药不起作用。然而——这一点至关重要——不定期服用该药的患者的死亡率高达 30%——高出两倍！定期服用和不定期服用之间存在巨大差异。那么，这种药丸是完全成功的。真的是这样吗？

Here’s the snag: The pill is probably not the decisive factor; rather, it is the patients’ behavior. Perhaps patients discontinued the pill following severe side effects and thus landed in the “irregular intake” category. Maybe they were so ill that there was no way to continue it on a regular basis. Either way, only relatively healthy patients remain in the “regular” group, which makes the drug look a lot more effective than it really is. The really sick patients who, for this very reason, couldn’t take the drug on a regular basis ended up populating the “irregular intake” group.

问题在于：药片本身可能并非决定性因素，而是患者的行为。或许患者在出现严重副作用后停药，因此被归入“不规律服药”类别。又或许他们的病情过于严重，无法继续规律服药。无论如何，只有相对健康的患者才会留在“规律服药”组，这使得药物看起来比实际效果好得多。而那些病情严重、由于这个原因无法规律服药的患者最终被归入“不规律服药”组。

In reputable studies, medical researchers evaluate the data of all patients whom they originally intend to treat (hence the title); it doesn’t matter if they take part in the trial or they drop out. Unfortunately, many studies flout this rule. Whether this is intentional or accidental remains to be seen. Therefore, be on your guard: Always check whether test subjects—drivers who end up in accidents, bankrupt companies, critically ill patients—have, for whatever reason, vanished from the sample. If so, you should file the study where it belongs: in the trash can.

在权威的研究中，医学研究人员会评估所有他们原本计划治疗的患者（因此得名）的数据；无论患者是否参与试验或退出，都无关紧要。不幸的是，许多研究违反了这条规则。这究竟是故意还是无意，还有待观察。因此，务必保持警惕：务必检查测试对象——无论是出事故的司机、破产的公司还是危重病人——是否因任何原因从样本中消失了。如果是这样，你应该将研究归档到它应该去的地方：垃圾桶。

99

Why You Shouldn’t Read the News

为什么你不应该读新闻

News Illusion

新闻幻觉

E arthquake in Sumatra. Plane crash in Russia. Man holds daughter captive in cellar for thirty years. Heidi Klum separates from Seal. Record salaries at Bank of America. Attack in Pakistan. Resignation of Mali’s president. New world record in shot put.

苏门答腊地震。俄罗斯飞机失事。男子将女儿囚禁在地窖三十年。海蒂·克鲁姆与席尔分居。美国银行薪资创历史新高。巴基斯坦发生袭击事件。马里总统辞职。铅球创下新世界纪录。

Do you really need to know all these things?

你真的需要知道所有这些事情吗？

We are incredibly well informed, yet we know incredibly little. Why? Because two centuries ago, we invented a toxic form of knowledge called “news.” News is to the mind what sugar is to the body: appetizing, easy to digest—and highly destructive in the long run.

我们消息灵通，却又知之甚少。为什么？因为两个世纪前，我们发明了一种名为“新闻”的有害知识。新闻之于思维，犹如糖之于身体：令人垂涎，易于消化——但从长远来看，却极具破坏性。

Three years ago, I began an experiment. I stopped reading and listening to the news. I canceled all newspaper and magazine subscriptions. Television and radio were disposed of. I deleted the news apps from my iPhone. I didn’t touch a single free newspaper and deliberately looked the other way when someone on a plane tried to offer me any such reading material. The first weeks were hard. Very hard. I was constantly afraid of missing something. But after a while, I had a new outlook. The result after three years: clearer thoughts, more valuable insights, better decisions, and much more time. And the best thing? I haven’t missed anything important. My social network—not Facebook, the one that exists in the real world consisting of flesh-and-blood friends and acquaintances—works as a news filter and keeps me in the loop.

三年前，我开始了一个实验。我停止阅读和收听新闻。我取消了所有报纸和杂志的订阅，电视和广播也弃之不用。我从iPhone上删除了新闻应用。我一份免费报纸都没碰，而且当飞机上有人试图给我提供这类阅读材料时，我故意视而不见。最初的几周很艰难，非常艰难。我总是担心错过什么。但过了一段时间，我有了新的视角。三年后的成果是：思路更清晰，见解更深刻，决策更明智，时间也更充裕。最棒的是？我没有错过任何重要的事情。我的社交网络——不是Facebook，而是存在于现实世界中、由有血有肉的朋友和熟人组成的社交网络——就像一个新闻过滤器，让我随时掌握最新动态。

A dozen reasons exist to give news a wide berth. Here are the top three: First, our brains react disproportionately to different types of information. Scandalous, shocking, people-based, loud, fast-changing details all stimulate us, whereas abstract, complex, and unprocessed information sedates us. News producers capitalize on this. Gripping stories, garish images, and sensational “facts” capture our attention. Recall for a moment their business models: Advertisers buy space and thus finance the news circus on the condition that their ads will be seen. The result: Everything subtle, complex, abstract, and profound must be systematically filtered out, even though such stories are much more relevant to our lives and to our understanding of the world. As a result of news consumption, we walk around with a distorted mental map of the risks and threats we actually face.

有十几个理由让我们对新闻敬而远之。以下是最重要的三个：首先，我们的大脑对不同类型的信息反应不均衡。丑闻、令人震惊、以人为本、喧闹、快速变化的细节都会刺激我们，而抽象、复杂和未经处理的信息则会让我们麻木。新闻制作人利用了这一点。扣人心弦的故事、艳丽的图片和耸人听闻的“事实”吸引了我们的注意力。回想一下他们的商业模式：广告商购买版面，从而为新闻大亨提供资金，条件是他们的广告会被看到。结果是：所有微妙、复杂、抽象和深刻的东西都必须被系统地过滤掉，即使这些故事与我们的生活和我们对世界的理解更为相关。由于新闻消费，我们带着一张扭曲的心理地图四处走动，对我们实际面临的风险和威胁心存疑虑。

Second, news is irrelevant. In the past twelve months, you have probably consumed about ten thousand news snippets—perhaps as many as thirty per day. Be very honest: Name one of them, just one that helped you make a better decision—for your life, your career, or your business—compared with not having this piece of news. No one I have asked has been able to name more than two useful news stories—out of ten thousand. A miserable result. News organizations assert that their information gives you a competitive advantage. Too many fall for this. In reality, news consumption represents a competitive disadvantage. If news really helped people advance, journalists would be at the top of the income pyramid. They aren’t—quite the opposite.

其次，新闻无关紧要。在过去的十二个月里，你可能已经阅读了大约一万条新闻片段，每天可能多达三十条。请诚实地说出其中一条，哪怕只是一条帮助你做出更好决定的新闻——无论对你的生活、事业还是生意——而不是没有这条新闻。我问过的人中，没有一个人能在一万条新闻中说出两条以上有用的新闻。结果可怜。新闻机构声称，他们的信息能给你带来竞争优势。太多人上当了。事实上，新闻消费代表着一种竞争劣势。如果新闻真的能帮助人们进步，记者就会站在收入金字塔的顶端。但事实并非如此——恰恰相反。

Third, news is a waste of time. An average human being squanders half a day each week on reading about current affairs. In global terms, this is an immense loss of productivity. Take the 2008 terror attacks in Mumbai. Out of sheer thirst for recognition, terrorists murdered two hundred people. Let’s say a billion people devoted an hour of their time to following the aftermath: They viewed the minute-by-minute updates and listened to the inane chatter of a few “experts” and “commentators.” This is a very realistic “guesstimate” since India has more than a billion inhabitants. Thus our conservative calculation: One billion people multiplied by an hour’s distraction equals one billion hours of work stoppage. If we convert this, we learn that news consumption wasted around two thousand lives—ten times more than the attack. A sarcastic but accurate observation.

第三，新闻浪费时间。普通人每周平均要浪费半天时间阅读时事新闻。从全球范围来看，这是巨大的生产力损失。以2008年孟买恐怖袭击为例。恐怖分子纯粹出于对认可的渴望，杀害了两百人。假设十亿人花费一小时追踪事件后续发展：他们关注着每分钟的新闻更新，听着少数“专家”和“评论员”的无聊闲聊。这是一个非常现实的“估计”，因为印度人口超过十亿。因此，我们保守计算：十亿人乘以一小时的分心时间，等于十亿小时的停工时间。如果我们换算一下，就会发现，新闻消费浪费了大约两千人的生命——比袭击事件本身多十倍。这是一个讽刺却准确的观察。

I would predict that turning your back on news will benefit you as much as purging any of the other ninety-eight flaws we have covered in the pages of this book. Kick the habit—completely. Instead, read long background articles and books. Yes, nothing beats books for understanding the world.

我估计，放弃新闻的益处，和我们本书提到的其他九十八个缺点一样多。彻底戒掉这个习惯吧。不如读读长篇背景文章和书籍。没错，没有什么比书籍更能理解世界了。

Epilogue

结语

T he pope asked Michelangelo: “Tell me the secret of your genius. How have you created the statue of David, the masterpiece of all masterpieces?” Michelangelo’s answer: “It’s simple. I removed everything that is not David.”

教皇问米开朗基罗：“告诉我你天才的秘密。你是如何创作出大卫雕像——所有杰作中的杰作的？”米开朗基罗回答说：“很简单。我去掉了所有不属于大卫的部分。”

Let’s be honest. We don’t know for sure what makes us successful. We can’t pinpoint exactly what makes us happy. But we know with certainty what destroys success or happiness. This realization, as simple as it is, is fundamental: Negative knowledge (what not to do) is much more potent than positive knowledge (what to do).

说实话，我们并不确定是什么让我们成功。我们也无法确切指出是什么让我们快乐。但我们确信是什么会毁掉成功或快乐。这个认识虽然简单，但却至关重要：负面知识（不该做什么）比正面知识（该做什么）更有力量。

Thinking more clearly and acting more shrewdly means adopting Michelangelo’s method: Don’t focus on David. Instead, focus on everything that is not David and chisel it away. In our case: Eliminate all errors and better thinking will follow.

更清晰的思考和更精明的行动意味着要采用米开朗基罗的方法：不要专注于大卫。相反，要专注于所有非大卫的部分，并将其剔除。对我们来说：消除所有错误，更好的思维就会随之而来。

The Greeks, Romans, and medieval thinkers had a term for this approach: via negativa . Literally, the negative path, the path of renunciation, of exclusion, of reduction. Theologians were the first to tread the via negativa : We cannot say what God is; we can only say what God is not. Applied to the present day: We cannot say what brings us success. We can pin down only what blocks or obliterates success. Eliminate the downside, the thinking errors, and the upside will take care of itself. This is all we need to know.

希腊人、罗马人和中世纪的思想家们为这种方法起了一个术语：否定之路（via negativa）。字面意思是否定之路，一条放弃、排斥、简化的道路。神学家是第一批踏上否定之路的人：我们无法说出上帝是什么；我们只能说上帝不是什么。应用到今天：我们无法说出是什么带给我们成功。我们只能指出是什么阻碍或摧毁了成功。消除负面因素，消除思维错误，正面因素自然会水到渠成。这就是我们需要知道的全部。

As a novelist and company founder, I have fallen into a variety of traps. Fortunately I was always able to free myself from them. Nowadays when I hold presentations in front of doctors, CEOs, board members, investors, politicians, or government officials, I sense a kinship. I feel that we are sitting in the same boat—after all, we are all trying to row through life without getting swallowed up by the maelstroms. Still, many people are uneasy with the via negativa . It is counterintuitive. It is even countercultural, flying in the face of contemporary wisdom. But look around and you’ll find plenty of examples of the via negativa at work. This is what the legendary investor Warren Buffett writes about himself and his partner Charlie Munger: “Charlie and I have not learned how to solve difficult business problems. What we have learned is to avoid them.” Welcome to the via negativa .

作为一名小说家和公司创始人，我曾陷入各种各样的陷阱。幸运的是，我总能摆脱它们。如今，当我在医生、首席执行官、董事会成员、投资者、政客或政府官员面前做演讲时，我感到一种亲切感。我觉得我们同舟共济——毕竟，我们都在努力划桨前行，不被人生的漩涡吞噬。然而，许多人仍然对“负向路径”（via negativa）感到不安。它违反直觉，甚至反文化，与当代智慧背道而驰。但环顾四周，你会发现很多“负向路径”的例子。传奇投资者沃伦·巴菲特这样描述自己和他的合伙人查理·芒格：“查理和我并没有学会如何解决棘手的商业问题。我们学会的是避免它们。”欢迎来到“负向路径”。

I have listed almost one hundred thinking errors in this book without answering the question: What are thinking errors anyway? What is irrationality? Why do we fall into these traps? Two theories of irrationality exist: a hot and a cold . The hot theory is as old as the hills. Here is Plato’s analogy: A rider steers wildly galloping horses; the rider signifies reason and the galloping horses embody emotions. Reason tames feelings. If this fails, irrationality runs free. Another example: Feelings are like bubbling lava. Usually, reason can keep a lid on them, but every now and then the lava of irrationality erupts. Hence hot irrationality. There is no reason to fret about logic: It is error-free; it’s just that, sometimes, emotions overpower it.

我在本书中列出了近百种思维错误，却没有回答这个问题：思维错误到底是什么？非理性是什么？我们为什么会陷入这些陷阱？关于非理性，有两种理论：热非理性理论和冷非理性理论。热非理性理论历史悠久。柏拉图曾打过一个比喻：骑手驾驭着狂奔的骏马，骑手象征着理性，而奔腾的骏马则体现着情感。理性可以驯服情感。如果理性失效，非理性就会肆意妄为。另一个例子：情感就像沸腾的熔岩。通常情况下，理性可以将其控制住，但非理性的熔岩时不时就会喷薄而出。因此，就有了热非理性。没有理由担心逻辑：它是没有错误的，只是有时候情感会压倒它。

This hot theory of irrationality boiled and bubbled for centuries. For John Calvin, the founder of a strict form of Protestantism in the 1500s, such feelings represented evil, and only by focusing on God could you repel them. People who underwent volcanic eruptions of emotion were of the devil. They were tortured and killed. According to Austrian psychoanalyst Sigmund Freud’s theory, the rationalist “ego” and the moralistic “superego” control the impulsive “id.” But that theory holds less water in the real world. Forget about obligation and discipline. To believe that we can completely control our emotions through thinking is illusory—as illusory as trying to make your hair grow by willing it to.

这种关于非理性的狂热理论沸腾了几个世纪。对于16世纪严格新教的创始人约翰·加尔文来说，这种感觉代表着邪恶，只有专注于上帝才能驱散它们。那些情绪火山爆发的人是魔鬼。他们会遭受折磨和杀害。根据奥地利精神分析学家西格蒙德·弗洛伊德的理论，理性主义的“自我”和道德主义的“超我”控制着冲动的“本我”。但这个理论在现实世界中站不住脚。忘掉义务和纪律吧。相信我们可以通过思考完全控制情绪是虚幻的——就像试图通过意志力让头发长出来一样虚幻。

On the other hand, the cold theory of irrationality is still young. After the Second World War, many searched for explanations about the irrationality of the Nazis. Emotional outbursts were rare in Hitler’s leadership ranks. Even his fiery speeches were nothing more than masterful performances. It was not molten eruptions but stone-cold calculation that resulted in the Nazi madness. The same can be said of Stalin or of the Khmer Rouge.

另一方面，冷酷的非理性理论尚不成熟。二战后，许多人都在探寻纳粹非理性的根源。希特勒领导层中鲜有情绪爆发。就连他那些激情四射的演讲也不过是大师级的表演。纳粹的疯狂并非源于炽热的爆发，而是源于冷酷的算计。斯大林和红色高棉也同样如此。

In the 1960s, psychologists began to do away with Freud’s claims and to examine our thinking, decisions, and actions scientifically. The result was a cold theory of irrationality that states: Thinking is in itself not pure, but prone to error. This affects everyone. Even highly intelligent people fall into the same cognitive traps. Likewise, errors are not randomly distributed. We systematically err in the same direction. That makes our mistakes predictable, and thus fixable to a degree—but only to a degree, never completely. For a few decades, the origins of these errors remained in the dark. Everything else in our body is relatively reliable—heart, muscles, lungs, immune system. Why should our brains of all things experience lapse after lapse?

20世纪60年代，心理学家开始推翻弗洛伊德的主张，转而用科学的方法审视我们的思维、决策和行为。其结果诞生了一个冷酷的非理性理论：思维本身并非纯粹，而是容易出错。这会影响到每个人，即使是高智商的人也会落入同样的认知陷阱。同样，错误并非随机分布，我们总是会朝着同一个方向犯错。这使得我们的错误可以预测，因此在一定程度上可以纠正——但这只是在一定程度上，永远无法完全纠正。几十年来，这些错误的根源一直不为人知。我们身体的其他部分——心脏、肌肉、肺、免疫系统——都相对可靠。为什么我们的大脑会一次又一次地犯错呢？

Thinking is a biological phenomenon. Evolution has shaped it just as it has the forms of animals or the colors of flowers. Suppose we could go back fifty thousand years, grab hold of an ancestor, and bring him back with us into the present. We send him to the hairdresser and put him in a Hugo Boss suit. Would he stand out on the street? No. Of course, he would have to learn English, how to drive, and how to operate a cell phone, but we had to learn those things, too. Biology has dispelled all doubt: Physically, and that includes cognitively, we are hunter-gatherers in Hugo Boss (or H&M, as the case may be).

思考是一种生物现象。进化塑造了它，就像进化塑造了动物的形态或花朵的颜色一样。假设我们能够回到五万年前，找到一位祖先，并将他带回现代。我们让他去理发店，给他穿上Hugo Boss的西装。他会在街上引人注目吗？不会。当然，他必须学习英语、开车和使用手机，但这些我们也必须学习。生物学已经消除了所有疑虑：从生理上，也包括认知上，我们是穿着Hugo Boss（或H&M，视情况而定）的狩猎采集者。

What has changed markedly since ancient times is the environment in which we live. Back then, things were simple and stable. We lived in small groups of about fifty people. There was no significant technological or social progress. Only in the last ten thousand years did the world begin to transform dramatically, with the development of crops, livestock, villages, cities, global trade, and financial markets. Since industrialization, little is left of the environment for which our brain is optimized. If you spend fifteen minutes in a shopping mall, you will pass more people than our ancestors saw during their entire lifetimes. Whoever claims to know how the world will look in ten years is made into a laughingstock less than a year after such a pronouncement. In the past ten thousand years, we have created a world that we no longer understand. Everything is more sophisticated, but also more complex and interdependent. The result is overwhelming material prosperity, but also lifestyle diseases (such as type 2 diabetes, lung cancer, and depression) and errors in thinking. If the complexity continues to rise—and it will, that much is certain—these errors will only increase and intensify.

自古以来，显著变化的是我们生活的环境。那时，一切都简单而稳定。我们生活在大约五十人的小群体中。没有重大的技术或社会进步。直到最近一万年，随着农作物、牲畜、村庄、城市、全球贸易和金融市场的发展，世界才开始发生翻天覆地的变化。自工业化以来，我们大脑所适应的环境所剩无几。如果你在购物中心待上十五分钟，你遇到的人比我们祖先一生见过的还要多。任何声称知道十年后世界会是什么样子的人，在说出这句话不到一年后就会成为笑柄。在过去的一万年里，我们创造了一个我们不再理解的世界。一切都更加精妙，也更加复杂和相互依存。其结果是物质的繁荣，但也带来了生活方式疾病（例如二型糖尿病、肺癌和抑郁症）以及思维错误。如果复杂性继续上升——这是肯定的——这些错误只会增加和加剧。

In our hunter-gatherer past, activity paid off more often than reflection did. Lightning-fast reactions were vital, and long ruminations were ruinous. If your hunter-gatherer buddies suddenly bolted, it made sense to follow suit—regardless of whether a saber-toothed tiger or a boar had startled them. If you failed to run away, and it turned out to be a tiger, the price of a first-degree error was death. On the other hand, if you had just fled from a board, this lesser mistake would have cost you only a few calories. It paid to be wrong about the same things. Whoever was wired differently exited the gene pool after the first or second incidence. We are the descendants of those homines sapientes who tend to flee when the crowd does. But in the modern world, this intuitive behavior is disadvantageous. Today’s world rewards single-minded contemplation and independent action. Anyone who has fallen victim to stock market hype has witnessed that.

在我们狩猎采集的时代，行动比反思更有回报。闪电般的快速反应至关重要，而长时间的沉思则会带来毁灭性的后果。如果你的狩猎采集伙伴突然逃跑，你也应该效仿——无论惊吓到他们的是剑齿虎还是野猪。如果你没能逃脱，而对方是老虎，那么一级错误的代价就是死亡。另一方面，如果你只是从一块木板旁逃开，这个较小的错误只会让你损失几卡路里。在同样的事情上犯错是有回报的。任何与你基因不同的人，在第一次或第二次事件之后就会退出基因库。我们是那些倾向于随波逐流的智人的后代。但在现代世界，这种直觉行为是不利的。当今世界奖励一心一意的思考和独立行动。任何成为股市炒作受害者的人都见证了这一点。

Evolutionary psychology is still mostly a theory, but a very convincing one at that. It explains the majority of flaws, though not all of them. Consider the following statement: “Every Hershey bar comes in a brown wrapper. Thus, every candy bar in a brown wrapper must be a Hershey bar.” Even intelligent people are susceptible to this flawed conclusion—so are native tribes that, for the most part, remain untouched by civilization. Our hunter-gatherer ancestors were certainly not impervious to faulty logic. Some bugs in our thinking are hardwired and have nothing to do with the “mutation” of our environment.

进化心理学在很大程度上仍然是一种理论，但却是一种非常令人信服的理论。它解释了大多数缺陷，尽管并非全部。请考虑以下陈述：“每块好时巧克力都用棕色包装纸包装。因此，每块用棕色包装纸包装的巧克力都一定是好时巧克力。”即使是聪明人也容易得出这种错误的结论——那些大部分未受文明影响的土著部落也是如此。我们的狩猎采集祖先当然也并非完全不受逻辑错误的影响。我们思维中的一些缺陷是与生俱来的，与环境的“变异”无关。

Why is that? Evolution does not “optimize” us completely. As long as we advance beyond our competitors (i.e., beat the Neanderthals), we can get away with error-laced behavior. Consider the cuckoo: For hundreds of thousands of years, they have laid their eggs in the nests of songbirds, which then incubate and even feed the cuckoo chicks. This represents a behavioral error that evolution has not erased from the smaller birds; it is not deemed to be serious enough.

为什么会这样？进化并没有完全“优化”我们。只要我们超越竞争对手（比如打败尼安德特人），我们就可以避免犯错。想想杜鹃：几十万年来，它们一直把蛋产在鸣禽的巢里，然后鸣禽孵化，甚至喂养杜鹃雏鸟。这代表着进化尚未从小型鸟类身上消除的行为错误；人们认为这种错误还不够严重。

A second, parallel explanation of why our mistakes are so persistent took shape in the late 1990s: Our brains are designed to reproduce rather than search for the truth. In other words, we use our thoughts primarily to persuade. Whoever convinces others secures power and thus access to resources. Such assets represent a major advantage for mating and for rearing offspring. That truth is, at best, a secondary focus and is reflected in the book market: Novels sell much better than nonfiction titles, in spite of the latter’s superior candor.

20世纪90年代末，关于为什么我们的错误如此顽固，出现了第二个类似的解释：我们的大脑天生就是为了复制，而不是为了探寻真相。换句话说，我们主要用思想来说服别人。谁能说服别人，谁就能获得权力，从而获得资源。这些资源在交配和养育后代方面具有巨大的优势。但这个事实充其量只是次要的，这反映在图书市场上：小说的销量远高于非虚构类书籍，尽管后者更坦诚。

Finally, a third explanation exists: Intuitive decisions, even if they lack logic, are better under certain circumstances. So-called heuristic research deals with this topic. For many decisions, we lack the necessary information, so we are forced to use mental shortcuts and rules of thumb (heuristics). If you are drawn to different potential romantic partners, you must evaluate whom to marry. This is not a rational decision; if you rely solely on logic, you will remain single forever. In short, we often decide intuitively and justify our choices later. Many decisions (career, life partner, investments) take place subconsciously. A fraction of a second later, we construct a reason so that we feel we made a conscious choice. Alas, we do not behave like scientists who are purely interested in objective facts. Instead, we think like lawyers, crafting the best possible justification for a predetermined conclusion.

最后，还有第三种解释：直觉决策，即使缺乏逻辑，在某些情况下也更有效。所谓的启发式研究就是研究这个主题的。对于许多决策，我们缺乏必要的信息，因此被迫使用思维捷径和经验法则（启发式）。如果你被不同的潜在伴侣吸引，你必须评估自己应该与谁结婚。这不是一个理性的决定；如果你仅仅依赖逻辑，你将永远单身。简而言之，我们经常凭直觉做决定，之后再证明自己的选择是正确的。许多决定（职业、人生伴侣、投资）都是在潜意识中做出的。转瞬之间，我们就会构建一个理由，让自己觉得自己做出了有意识的选择。可惜的是，我们的行为方式不像纯粹关注客观事实的科学家。相反，我们的思维方式像律师，为预先确定的结论精心设计最佳的论证。

So, forget about the “left and right brain” that semi-intelligent self-help books describe. Much more important is the difference between intuitive and rational thinking. Both have legitimate applications. The intuitive mind is swift, spontaneous, and energy-saving. Rational thinking is slow, demanding, and energy-guzzling (in the form of blood sugar). Nobody has described this better than the great Daniel Kahneman in Thinking, Fast and Slow .

所以，别再想那些半智能自助书籍里说的“左右脑”了。更重要的是直觉思维和理性思维之间的区别。两者都有合理的应用。直觉思维敏捷、自发、省力。理性思维缓慢、费力、耗能（以血糖的形式）。没有人比伟大的丹尼尔·卡尼曼在《思考，快与慢》一书中对此有更清晰的描述。

Since I started to collect cognitive errors, people often ask me how I manage to live an error-free life. The answer is: I don’t. In fact, I don’t even try. Just like everybody else, I make snap decisions by consulting not my thoughts but my feelings. For the most part I substitute the question “What do I think about this?” with “How do I feel about this?” Quite frankly, anticipating and avoiding fallacies is a costly undertaking.

自从我开始收集认知错误以来，人们经常问我如何做到不犯错。答案是：我做不到。事实上，我甚至都没尝试过。和其他人一样，我做快速决定时，不是参考我的想法，而是参考我的感觉。大多数情况下，我会用“我对此有何感受？”来代替“我对此有何看法？”坦白说，预测并避免谬误是一项代价高昂的任务。

To make things simple, I have set myself the following rules: In situations where the possible consequences are large (i.e., important personal or business decisions), I try to be as reasonable and rational as possible when choosing. I take out my list of errors and check them off one by one, just like a pilot does. I’ve created a handy checklist decision tree, and I use it to examine important decisions with a fine-tooth comb. In situations where the consequences are small (i.e., regular or Diet Pepsi, sparkling or flat water?), I forget about rational optimization and let my intuition take over. Thinking is tiring. Therefore, if the potential harm is small, don’t rack your brains; such errors won’t do lasting damage. You’ll live better like this. Nature doesn’t seem to mind if our decisions are perfect or not, as long as we can maneuver ourselves through life—and as long as we are ready to be rational when it comes to the crunch. And there’s one other area where I let my intuition take the lead: when I am in my “circle of competence.” If you practice an instrument, you learn the notes and tell your fingers how to play them. Over time, you know the keys or the strings inside out. You see a musical score and your hands play the notes almost automatically. Warren Buffett reads balance sheets like professional musicians read scores. This is his circle of competence, the field he intuitively understands and masters. So, find out where your circle of competence is. Get a clear grasp of it. Hint: It’s smaller than you think. If you face a consequential decision outside that circle, apply the hard, slow, rational thinking. For everything else, give your intuition free rein.

为了简单起见，我给自己定了以下规则：在可能造成重大后果的情况下（例如，重要的个人或商业决策），我会尽量理性地做出选择。我会拿出我的错误清单，像飞行员一样，逐一核对。我创建了一个方便的清单决策树，并用它来仔细检查重要的决策。在后果较小的情况下（例如，普通百事可乐还是健怡百事可乐，苏打水还是纯净水？），我会忘记理性的优化，让直觉占据上风。思考很累。因此，如果潜在危害很小，就不要绞尽脑汁；这样的错误不会造成持久的损害。这样你会活得更好。大自然似乎并不介意我们的决定是否完美，只要我们能够掌控自己的人生——并且我们准备好在关键时刻保持理性。还有一个领域，我会让直觉占据主导地位：当我处于自己的“能力圈”时。如果你练习一种乐器，你会学习音符，并告诉你的手指如何演奏它们。久而久之，你就会彻底了解琴键或琴弦。你看到乐谱，你的双手几乎会自动弹奏出音符。沃伦·巴菲特阅读资产负债表就像专业音乐家阅读乐谱一样。这就是他的能力圈，是他凭直觉理解和掌握的领域。所以，找出你的能力圈在哪里。清楚地掌握它。提示：它比你想象的要小。如果你面临一个超出这个范围的重要决策，那就运用艰难、缓慢、理性的思考。对于其他所有事情，让你的直觉自由发挥。

Alas, he encouraged me to write novels, arguing that nonfiction isn’t “sexy.” The time we have passed together discussing how to live in a world we don’t understand have been my favorite hours of the week. Thanks to Koni Gebistorf, who masterfully edited the original German texts, and to Nicky Griffin, who translated the book into English (when she was away from her office at Google). I couldn’t have picked better publishers and editors than Hollis Heimbouch from HarperCollins and Drummond Moir from Sceptre who have given these chapters their final finesse. Thanks to the scientists of the ZURICH.MINDS community for the countless debates about the state of research. Without the weekly pressure to forge one’s thoughts into a readable format, my notes would never have been published in book form.

感谢我的朋友纳西姆·尼古拉斯·塔勒布，即使他建议我无论如何都不要出版这本书，也激励我写下这本书。唉，他却鼓励我写小说，认为非虚构作品并不“性感”。我们一起讨论如何在一个我们并不理解的世界中生活的时光，是我一周中最美好的时光。感谢科尼·格比斯托夫，他精湛地编辑了德文原版；感谢妮基·格里芬，她将本书翻译成了英文（当时她不在谷歌办公室）。哈珀柯林斯的霍利斯·海姆博赫和Sceptre的德拉蒙德·莫尔是我能找到的最佳出版商和编辑，他们为这些章节的最终润色提供了绝佳的润色。感谢苏黎世思想社区的科学家们，感谢他们就研究现状展开的无数次辩论。特别感谢Gerd Gigerenzer、Roy Baumeister、Leda Cosmides、John Tooby、Robert Cialdini、Jonathan Haidt、Ernst Fehr、Bruno Frey、Iris Bohnet、Dan Golstein、Tomáš Sedláček以及哲学家John Gray的精彩对话。我还要感谢我的文学经纪人John Brockman和他的优秀团队，他们帮助我完成了本书的美国版和英国版。感谢Frank Schirrmacher为我的专栏在《法兰克福汇报》找到版面，感谢Giovanni di Lorenzo和Moritz Mueller-Wirth在德国《时代周报》发表我的专栏，以及感谢Martin Spieler在瑞士《周日报》为我的专栏找到一个温暖的归宿。如果没有每周将自己的想法转化为可读格式的压力，我的笔记永远不会以书籍的形式出版。

For everything that appears here after the countless stages of editing, I alone bear the responsibility. My greatest thanks goes to my wife, Sabine Ried, who proves to me every day that the “good life”—as defined by Aristotle—consists of far more than clear thoughts and clever actions.

经过无数道编辑工序，最终呈现于此的所有内容，均由我独自承担。我最诚挚的感谢，莫过于我的妻子萨宾·里德 (Sabine Ried)，她每天都在向我证明，亚里士多德所定义的“美好生活”远不止清晰的思维和机智的行动。

A Note on Sources

关于来源的说明

Hundreds of studies have been conducted on the vast majority of cognitive and behavioral errors. In a scholarly work, the complete reference section would easily double the pages of this book. I have focused on the most important quotes, technical references, recommendations for further reading, and comments. The knowledge encompassed in this book is based on the research carried out in the fields of cognitive and social psychology over the past three decades.

针对绝大多数认知和行为错误，已有数百项研究。在学术著作中，完整的参考文献部分足以让本书的篇幅翻倍。我重点介绍了最重要的引文、技术参考、进一步阅读的建议和评论。本书涵盖的知识基于过去三十年来认知和社会心理学领域的研究成果。

SURVIVORSHIP BIAS

幸存者偏差

Survivorship bias in funds and stock market indices, see: Edwin J. Elton, Martin J. Gruber, and Christopher R. Blake, “Survivorship Bias and Mutual Fund Performance,” The Review of Financial Studies 9, no. 4 (1996): 1097–1120.

基金和股票市场指数中的幸存者偏差，请参阅：Edwin J. Elton、Martin J. Gruber 和 Christopher R. Blake，《幸存者偏差和共同基金表现》，《金融研究评论》9，第 4 期（1996 年）：1097-1120。

Statistically relevant results by coincidence (self-selection), see: John P. A. Ioannidis, “Why Most Published Research Findings Are False,” PLoS Med 2, no. 8 (2005): e124.

通过巧合（自我选择）获得的统计相关结果，请参阅：John P. A. Ioannidis，“为什么大多数已发表的研究结果都是错误的”，PLoS Med 2，no. 8（2005）：e124。

SWIMMER’S BODY ILLUSION

游泳者的身体错觉

Nassim Nicholas Taleb, The Black Swan: The Impact of the Highly Improbable (New York: Random House, 2007), 109–10.

纳西姆·尼古拉斯·塔勒布，《黑天鹅：极不可能事件的影响》（纽约：兰登书屋，2007 年），109–10。

“Ideally, the comparison should be made between people who went to Harvard and people who were admitted to Harvard but chose instead to go to Podunk State. Unfortunately, this is likely to produce samples too small for statistical analysis.” Thomas Sowell, Economic Facts and Fallacies (New York: Basic Books, 2008), 106.

理想情况下，应该比较那些就读哈佛大学的人和那些被哈佛大学录取但最终选择就读波顿克州立大学的人。遗憾的是，这种做法可能会导致样本量过小，无法进行统计分析。托马斯·索维尔，《经济事实与谬误》（纽约：基础图书出版社，2008年），第106页。

David Lykken and Auke Tellegen, “Happiness Is a Stochastic Phenomenon,” Psychological Science 7, no. 3 (May 1996): 189.

David Lykken 和 Auke Tellegen，《幸福是一种随机现象》，《心理科学》7，第 3 期（1996 年 5 月）：189。

In his book Good to Great , Jim Collins cites the CEO of Pitney Bowes, Dave Nassef: “I used to be in the Marines, and the Marines get a lot of credit for building people’s values. But that’s not the way it really works. The Marine Corps recruits people who share the corps’ values, then provides them with training required to accomplish the organization’s mission.”

吉姆·柯林斯在其著作《从优秀到卓越》中引用了必能宝公司首席执行官戴夫·纳塞夫的话：“我曾在海军陆战队服役，海军陆战队在塑造员工价值观方面功不可没。但实际情况并非如此。海军陆战队招募认同其价值观的人员，然后为他们提供完成组织使命所需的培训。”

CLUSTERING ILLUSION

聚类错觉

The random sequence OXXXOXXXOXXOOOXOOXXOO: Thomas Gilovich, How We Know What Isn’t So: The Fallibility of Human Reason in Everyday Life (New York: Free Press, 1993), 16.

随机序列 OXXXOXXXXOXXOOOXOOXXOO：Thomas Gilovich，《我们如何知道并非如此：人类理性在日常生活中的易错性》（纽约：自由出版社，1993 年），16。

Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky, “Subjective Probability: A Judgment of Representativeness,” in Daniel Kahneman, Paul Slovic, and Amos Tversky, Judgment under Uncertainty: Heuristics and Biases (New York: Cambridge University Press, 1982), 32–47.

Daniel Kahneman 和 Amos Tversky，“主观概率：代表性判断”，载于 Daniel Kahneman、Paul Slovic 和 Amos Tversky 合著的《不确定性下的判断：启发式和偏见》（纽约：剑桥大学出版社，1982 年），第 32-47 页。

This paper caused controversy because it destroyed many athletes and sports commentators’ belief in the “hot hand”—in lucky streaks: Thomas Gilovich, Robert Vallone, and Amos Tversky, “The Hot Hand in Basketball: On the Misperception of Random Sequences,” Cognitive Psychology 17 (1985): 295–314.

这篇论文引起了争议，因为它摧毁了许多运动员和体育评论员对“热手”——幸运连胜——的信念：Thomas Gilovich、Robert Vallone 和 Amos Tversky，“篮球中的热手：论对随机序列的误解”，认知心理学 17（1985 年）：295-314。

The Virgin Mary on toast on BBC: accessed November 1, 2012, http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/4034787.stm.
